Article_Name: 颱風波密拉 (1961年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Pamela (English: Typhoon Pamela, International Number: 6120, Mainland China Number: 6122, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 20W) was a well-known intense typhoon in the 1960s and one of the typhoons that caused significant wind damage in Taiwan, with the disaster area concentrated in northern Taiwan.

On September 6, 1961, a tropical depression formed over the waters near Guam, moving northwest at a speed of 25 kilometers per hour. However, the guiding airflow became unclear, and from the 7th to the 9th, its speed was only 5 kilometers per hour. During this time, its development was very slow, and it was not until the afternoon of September 9 that it intensified into a mild typhoon (by today's standards, it would not yet be considered a mild typhoon). At this point, it was located about 850 kilometers southwest of Iwo Jima. The typhoon then began to intensify rapidly, with its maximum wind speed increasing from 15 meters per second to 35 meters per second by the following morning. Its speed also began to accelerate, moving northwest-west at 15 kilometers per hour. At this time, Pamila had already become a moderate typhoon.

On the morning of September 11, Pamila had moved to the waters south of Naha. A strong high-pressure ridge to the north guided it to move west-northwest, with a pressure of 950 millibars and a maximum wind speed of 50 meters per second at its center. It had developed into a strong typhoon by the standards of the time. It suddenly accelerated, increasing from a slow pace to 33 kilometers per hour, and its westward path posed a serious threat to Taiwan. By 8 p.m., Pamila had reached a pressure of 930 millibars, with a peak maximum wind speed of 60 meters per second, and was located about 270 kilometers east of Hualien. At 2 a.m. on the 12th, it made landfall in the area between Yilan and Hualien. Later, it made a second landfall in mainland China. After making landfall in mainland China, Pamila gradually weakened and dissipated.

What is truly astonishing is not just that Typhoon Pamela passed directly through the Central Mountain Range, but that despite being a relatively fast-moving typhoon, which generally causes more wind damage than rain, it brought only 100 millimeters of rainfall yet caused severe flooding in the Taipei area. Areas such as Sanchong, Luzhou, Xinzhuang, Yonghe, Shilin, and Dazhi experienced serious flooding. Many of the flooded areas were within the Dahan River basin. In addition to the natural factor of heavy rain, it is said that human factors also played a role. The newly completed Shimen Reservoir upstream of the Dahan River misjudged the situation and suddenly released water. At a time when information was not well-developed, the public was unprepared, leading to catastrophic flooding and casualties in the Dahan River basin. According to data from the police department at the time, Typhoon Pamela caused 153 deaths, 140 missing persons, and 1,874 injuries across Taiwan. A total of 12,349 houses were completely destroyed, and 26,442 houses were partially destroyed, resulting in severe casualties. Many fishing boats also capsized and were damaged. Yilan County bore the brunt of the disaster and suffered unprecedented losses. After the disaster, the Executive Yuan established the "Taipei Area River Flood Control Plan Review Committee" to actively implement the Taipei flood control plan.

In general, many typhoons passing through Taiwan's Central Mountain Range encounter varying levels of difficulty due to the circulation at different altitudes, which can easily induce a secondary low-pressure center to guide the typhoon across the mountains. However, Typhoon Pamela moved at a very fast speed, crossing the Snow Mountain Range before a secondary low-pressure system could form. By 8 a.m., it had already exited to the northwest of Taichung, spending only a little over five hours on land, which was quite astonishing. During this time, the typhoon's structure was also damaged, downgrading it to a moderate typhoon. While crossing the Snow Mountain Range, due to the influence of wind and terrain, the Foehn effect occurred in the Taitung area, causing temperatures to rise from 27°C at 1 a.m. to 32.3°C at 2 a.m., which lasted until 6 a.m. By 2 p.m., Pamela had entered the mainland and rapidly weakened, transforming into an extratropical cyclone by the next morning.

The highest average wind speed of Typhoon Pamela was recorded in Keelung City at 35 meters per second, followed by the landfall point in Yilan County at 34.8 meters per second, with the maximum instantaneous gust reaching 44.8 meters per second. In terms of rainfall, Wulai in Taipei County received the most, with 347.2 millimeters during the typhoon's passage over Taiwan. Su'ao Township recorded 319.8 millimeters, Yilan City had 203 millimeters, Taipei City only received 100 millimeters, and the plains in the southwest and eastern regions barely exceeded 50 millimeters. Hengchun Township experienced almost no rainfall (0.9 millimeters).

Additionally, when Pamela formed, its development was slow during the first three days, and its structure was not very strong. However, it rapidly intensified into a severe typhoon within just two to three days (one of the fastest-developing typhoons in recent years was Typhoon Zeb). It also accelerated from its initial slow movement. The meteorological bureau originally predicted that Pamela would continue moving northwest, but unexpectedly, the high pressure to the north prevented it from moving northward, causing it to shift westward and threaten Taiwan. At the time, meteorological technology was lacking, and there was insufficient maritime data to make accurate predictions. The bureau had to rely on meteorological data from the U.S. military to issue typhoon warnings for Pamela. The bureau initially predicted landfall at 9 a.m. on the 12th, but as the typhoon approached eastern Taiwan, it slowed down to search for a landfall point. However, it unexpectedly made landfall in the Yilan-Hualien border area at 2 a.m., catching meteorologists off guard. It then rapidly crossed the Snow Mountain Range, leaving meteorologists astonished and drawing criticism from the public for the large prediction error. Furthermore, the severe flooding in the Dahan River basin in Taipei was attributed to human factors, highlighting that the issues surrounding Typhoon Pamela were not only about its path but also about human negligence.

Article_Name: 熱帶低氣壓618 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Depression 618 (English: Tropical Depression 618) is a tropical depression that formed in Hong Kong waters in 2000. This tropical depression formed in nearshore waters and was only upgraded by the Hong Kong Observatory.

On June 18, 2000, a trough of low pressure affected the northern South China Sea and the coastal areas of Guangdong. At 9 PM that evening, one of the atmospheric vortices within the trough intensified into a small tropical depression over the waters south of Lantau Island, approximately 35 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters. The Hong Kong Observatory assessed its central wind speed at 60 kilometers per hour. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also rated this tropical disturbance as "low," indicating a certain probability of developing into a tropical cyclone, but it was ultimately not upgraded to a tropical depression. The tropical depression moved northward, passing between Lantau Island and Hong Kong Island, then crossing Tsing Yi Island, and made landfall near Tsuen Wan before 10:15 PM that evening. It passed through Pat Heung and Kai Kung Leng. The tropical depression left Hong Kong around midnight, entering Shenzhen near Lok Ma Chau. Subsequently, Tropical Depression 618 continued into inland Guangdong and quickly dissipated.

Tropical Depression 618 caused the Hong Kong Observatory to issue the first tropical cyclone warning signal of 2000, and it was also the first tropical cyclone to directly affect Hong Kong (passing within 100 kilometers) after the millennium. Due to the formation of a tropical depression within Hong Kong's territory, wind speeds increased rapidly, prompting the Observatory to directly issue the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 9:15 PM. This was the first time since 1993 that the No. 3 Signal was directly issued. At that time, the tropical depression was located about 35 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters. The tropical depression had a diameter of approximately 200 kilometers, with a strong wind radius of about 25 kilometers and a central wind speed of 60 kilometers per hour. The tropical depression came closest to the Observatory headquarters at around 10 PM that night, passing about 10 kilometers west of the headquarters, and then made landfall near Tsuen Wan before 10:15 PM (initial reports suggested landfall around 10:30 PM). It crossed the western New Territories, with winds shifting to the southwest and gradually weakening by early morning. Sustained winds in the eastern regions briefly reached gale force, with a 10-minute average wind speed of 70 kilometers per hour recorded in Sai Kung. 

As the tropical depression moved inland and began to dissipate, the Observatory announced at midnight that the No. 3 Signal would be lowered shortly, and all tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 1:45 AM the following day. During the impact of Tropical Depression 618 on Hong Kong, incidents such as scaffolding collapse in Siu Sai Wan and wooden boards falling from a construction site in Chai Wan occurred, but no injuries were reported. 

It is relatively rare for a tropical depression to form so close to land. The last tropical cyclone to form in close proximity was Tropical Storm Lisa in 1996, which formed about 160 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong, requiring only the issuance of the No. 1 Standby Signal. This tropical depression was later referred to as "Tropical Depression 618."

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau considered the low-pressure area's gale radius to be small and did not upgrade it, thus no signal was issued, resulting in a discrepancy in the level 2 cyclone warning between Hong Kong and Macau. On the afternoon of June 18, under the influence of a low-pressure trough, the Macau Meteorological Bureau issued a red rainstorm warning signal at 3:00 PM, which was subsequently canceled at 5:15 PM. The accumulated rainfall across various districts in Macau that day reached 84.8 to 126.6 millimeters. The lowest recorded pressure in Macau that day was 1005.2 hPa.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴菲特 (2001年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Fitow (English: Tropical Storm Fitow, International Number: 0114, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 18W) was the 14th named storm of the 2001 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Fitow" was provided by Micronesia and refers to a beautiful and fragrant flower.

On the morning of August 28, a tropical depression formed over the South China Sea. The tropical depression moved westward, then turned northwest, and passed near Changsa Town, Wenchang City, Hainan Province, at 5 p.m. on August 29. The tropical depression then turned northwest. At 2 a.m. on August 31, the tropical depression intensified into a tropical storm in the Beibu Gulf and was named Fitow. At noon on August 31, Fitow made landfall near Qisha Town, Port District, Fangchenggang City, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region. After landfall, Fitow quickly weakened. By 2 p.m., Fitow had weakened into a tropical depression. By 5 p.m. on September 1, it had completely dissipated. [1] However, the China Meteorological Administration believed that Fitow had not completely dissipated, later re-entered the sea off the eastern Leizhou Peninsula, and made landfall again in Sanya City, Hainan Province, at 5 a.m. on September 10, before dissipating after making landfall in Vietnam at 2 a.m. on September 12. It affected Hainan Province for 16 days, making it the longest-lasting tropical cyclone to affect Hainan Province since 1949. It made landfall on Hainan Island twice and stayed on land for over 72 hours, also making it the longest-lasting tropical cyclone to make landfall on Hainan Island since 1949. [2][3]

The No. 1 Standby Signal was hoisted at 10:15 PM on August 28. Under the combined influence of Fitow and a continental anticyclone, strong winds were experienced offshore and in high areas of Hong Kong. On August 29, the outer rainbands of Fitow brought heavy rain to Hong Kong, with over 100 millimeters of rainfall recorded in the Sha Tin and Shek Kong areas on that day. Fitow was closest to Hong Kong on the evening of August 29, located about 320 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. Under the influence of Fitow, the Hong Kong Observatory recorded the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure of 998.8 hPa at 5:18 AM on August 29. As Fitow gradually moved away from Hong Kong, local winds weakened, and the No. 1 Standby Signal was canceled at 4:45 AM on August 30. However, the outer rainbands of Fitow continued to bring occasional heavy rain to Hong Kong, and the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal was issued at 12:55 PM that afternoon, remaining in effect until 5:20 PM. In Hong Kong, on August 28, Fire Services Officer Chiu Shun-on tragically lost his life while rescuing a 15-year-old boy from drowning at Tai Long Wan in Sai Kung.

Whole_Text.header: After the storm, there was even a heavy rainstorm.
Whole_Text.content: After Typhoon Fitow dissipated, its remnants formed an active trough of low pressure along the southern coast of China, bringing heavy rain and severe thunderstorms from the night of September 1 to the early morning of September 2. The Hong Kong Observatory issued a Black Rainstorm Warning Signal at 10:45 PM on September 1, which was not canceled until 4:30 AM. Rainfall across Hong Kong reached 100 millimeters, with areas such as Tsuen Wan, Kwai Chung, and Sha Tin recording up to 200 millimeters. During the rainstorm, there were over 19 cases of flooding and 11 landslides. One landslide occurred in Tai Wai, where 11 villagers had to be urgently evacuated. In Sai Kung, a slope collapsed during the rainstorm, severely damaging a stone house. A section of the overhead power cable on the Kwun Tong Line of the MTR was struck by lightning, causing a temporary power outage. One train service between Quarry Bay Station and Lam Tin Station was disrupted, and approximately 400 passengers had to walk 500 meters along the tracks to the station. The trough of low pressure lingered along the southern coast of China, causing unstable weather for several days. Red Rainstorm Warning Signals were issued on September 3 and September 7. The weather in Hong Kong only improved on September 8 as the trough moved away.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Signal No. 1 at 10:30 PM on August 28. As Typhoon Fitow gradually approached Macao, the bureau upgraded to Signal No. 3 at 1:30 PM the following afternoon. Fitow was closest to Macao between 10 PM on August 28 and 1 PM on August 29, located approximately 300 kilometers southwest of Macao. As Fitow gradually moved away from Macao, the winds weakened, and Signal No. 3 was lowered at 6 AM on August 30.

Article_Name: 颱風嘉曼 (1974年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Carmen (Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Tering) was one of the named tropical cyclones in the 1974 Pacific typhoon season and one of the few typhoons to affect the northern South China Sea in October. Due to Carmen's impact, Hong Kong and Macau had to hoist the second-highest No. 9 tropical cyclone warning signal for two consecutive years. The storm formed on October 14 over the Philippine Sea, further developing into a typhoon and moving toward central Philippines, where it made landfall. While affecting the Philippines, Carmen weakened temporarily due to terrain effects but reorganized after entering the South China Sea. However, as it approached the coast near the Pearl River Estuary, it was suddenly deflected westward by cold air from Guangdong Province, avoiding landfall, and dissipated south of Shangchuan Island on October 20, with a lifespan of about six days. Carmen caused at least 13 deaths, 9 injuries, and economic losses of 64 million pesos in the Philippines. It brought significant damage to South China but also alleviated drought conditions with its rainfall, prompting the Hong Kong government to fully lift the water rationing measures for that year. [Note 1]

A tropical depression formed on October 14 over the Philippine Sea, 805 kilometers east-southeast of Manila, Philippines. After forming, it moved westward at a speed of approximately 13 kilometers per hour, heading toward central and northern Philippines. [1] The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration began monitoring it and assigned it the Philippine name "Tering" as it formed within the Philippine Area of Responsibility. [2] The next day, the system shifted to a northwestward movement, and both the Royal Hong Kong Observatory and the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm, with the latter naming it "Koinu." [3] On the same day, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a mild typhoon. [4][Note 2] The Hong Kong Observatory further upgraded Koinu to a severe tropical storm on the same day. [1] By October 16, Koinu had intensified further. The Hong Kong Observatory analyzed satellite imagery and noted that its circulation was well-organized. Subsequently, reconnaissance aircraft reported a continuous drop in central pressure, prompting the Observatory to follow the U.S. in upgrading it to a typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon on the same day. [3][4][1] Koinu maintained a northwestward direction on the same day and made landfall in central Luzon. It later exited to the sea, entering the northern South China Sea. [1] Koinu's structure was damaged due to the terrain of the Philippines, leading the U.S. to downgrade it to a tropical storm. However, as it moved over the South China Sea, it reorganized, and the U.S. re-upgraded Koinu to a typhoon. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau maintained its classification as a typhoon and a moderate typhoon, respectively. [4][1] Later on October 17, Koinu steadily moved to the waters south of the Pearl River Estuary, accelerating to a speed of nearly 17 kilometers per hour. The Hong Kong Observatory observed that its spiral rainbands continued to develop and intensify. [1] On October 18, the Hong Kong Observatory's weather radar captured Koinu's cyclone center, with an eye diameter of nearly 100 kilometers, and indicated that Koinu was turning northwestward, moving closer to the Pearl River Estuary. [1] However, the U.S. and the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it again to a tropical storm and a mild typhoon, respectively, on the same day. [4] At that time, Guangdong Province was under the influence of cold air, which affected Koinu. As it approached the coastal area near the Pearl River Estuary, it suddenly turned westward without making landfall and began to weaken rapidly during the day on October 19. The U.S. and the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it to a tropical depression within the same day, while the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. [3][4][1] The next day, the Hong Kong Observatory reported that Koinu had weakened into a low-pressure area south of Shangchuan Island. [1]

After Kammuri made landfall in central Luzon, it affected parts of the Philippines. Flooding occurred in low-lying areas of Manila due to continuous heavy rain, and a bus skidded while traveling in the rain, injuring 35 people. In Mindoro Island to the south, including San Jose City, water levels reached four to five feet, causing severe damage to roads and bridges. In Baguio City, landslides occurred in some residential areas. According to Agence France-Presse, a six-year-old girl and her 16-year-old brother lost their lives due to landslides caused by the typhoon, and some members of two families were injured. The Philippine authorities later reported that the storm caused 13 deaths, 9 injuries, and affected 7,766 households or 28,486 people nationwide, with economic losses amounting to 64 million pesos.

The Observatory hoisted the No. 1 Standby Signal at 10:55 am on October 17. [9] As Kaman moved directly towards the coast of South China, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 4:30 pm the same day, when Kaman was steadily moving northwest in the evening. [10] Due to Kaman's increased northward movement, advancing towards the Pearl River Estuary, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 10:10 am on October 18. [11] Kaman began to turn northwest by north in the evening, moving closer to Hong Kong. At 4:30 am on October 19, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 9 Gale or Storm Increasing Signal. [12] Kaman was closest to Hong Kong at around 9 am, located approximately 130 kilometers southwest by south of Hong Kong, marking the farthest distance of a storm center from Hong Kong for a No. 9 Signal in history. [1] Affected by a cool and dry northerly airstream, Kaman began to turn west and slowly moved away from Hong Kong. As it was expected that the wind in Hong Kong would not further intensify, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 8 Southeast Signal at 11 am and then with the No. 3 Signal at 3 pm the same day. [13] Kaman continued to weaken under the influence of the airstream and became a low-pressure area south of Shangchuan Island on the morning of October 20. All signals were removed at 10 am that day, with all times in daylight saving time. [14][1] In response to the typhoon, the Education Department announced the suspension of classes in all schools across Hong Kong on October 18 and 19. The Foreign Exchange Bankers' Association announced the temporary closure of all banks in Hong Kong. The four major stock exchanges and the Gold and Silver Exchange suspended trading from the afternoon, some maritime routes ceased services, and some flights were canceled. Land transportation and the Kowloon-Canton Railway provided limited services until gradually stopping in the evening. [15] Some government departments deployed personnel to maintain emergency services and remain on alert, while typhoon shelters in various districts were opened for those in need. [16] Kaman brought continuous heavy rain to Hong Kong. A young man who swam from mainland China to Hong Kong was found lying on the beach at Sharp Nose Point during the No. 9 Signal and was confirmed dead after being sent to the hospital. [17] Another girl was swept away by floodwaters in Kam Tin. [18] The storm caused severe flooding in low-lying areas of urban Kowloon and the New Territories. Authorities also received numerous reports of landslides or road damage, as well as incidents of ships breaking anchor and collisions between two vessels, but no injuries were reported. [19] A severe landslide occurred on the slope behind Lai Sing House in Tai Hang Road due to the storm, submerging the underground parking lot in mud. Hundreds of residents of Lai Sing House had to evacuate overnight. [20] The Third Resettlement Area near Chai Wan Estate was affected by the storm, with seawater flooding the area and causing waterlogging. 800 residents had to evacuate to nearby police stations and Chai Wan Estate for temporary shelter, with the number of evacuees later increasing to over a thousand. After the incident, the resettlement area was left muddy, and many homes were in disarray. [21] More than ten days later, Typhoon Ellen struck Hong Kong, prompting the Observatory to hoist the No. 8 Signal again. As both Kaman and Ellen brought abundant rainfall, a record for the highest October rainfall since the Observatory's establishment was set, along with a significant 220 billion gallons of potable water. The Public Works Department's Water Supplies Department announced the complete cancellation of water rationing measures for that year. [22]

The Macau Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 9 at 7:15 a.m. on October 19, which was downgraded to Signal No. 8 at 2:15 p.m. the same day, and further downgraded to Signal No. 3 at 4:30 p.m. that afternoon. During the tropical cyclone's impact, the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge was temporarily closed and only reopened for traffic at 6:30 p.m. on the 19th after the Signal No. 3 was issued. Most shops suspended operations, Macau's streets were paralyzed for a time, and the Emperor Entertainment Group temporarily ceased operations until the evening of the 19th, while the Grand Lisboa remained unaffected. Additionally, Jai Alai and greyhound racing events were also suspended due to the impact of the storm. Signal No. 3 was finally lowered at 8:30 a.m. on October 20, and the city gradually returned to normal. Apart from some damage to farmland and fish ponds, the overall damage across Macau was minimal.

According to the records of the Guangdong Meteorological Observatory in mainland China, the "22nd Typhoon of the Year" (Typhoon 7422, referred to as Carmen) did not make landfall in Guangdong, but its circulation affected the coastal areas of Guangdong, especially around Taishan County. During the typhoon, 44 counties and cities in the province experienced gale-force winds of level 8, and 10 counties and cities experienced winds of level 10. At the same time, 73 counties and cities experienced heavy rain, and 35 counties and cities experienced torrential rain. Among them, Huidong County recorded an extraordinary rainfall of 323.8 millimeters on October 19. In the following days, under the combined influence of the typhoon and cold air, temperatures in Guangzhou and Shaoguan areas dropped to 20 degrees Celsius or below. This affected the late rice harvest, reducing its yield, and the flooded area of rice fields reached 215,000 hectares.

Article_Name: 颱風姬羅莉亞 (1957年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gloria (English: Typhoon Gloria, International Number: 5715, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 14W) was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 1957 Pacific typhoon season. Gloria formed on September 17, 1957. It later crossed the Philippines as a Category 2 typhoon and entered the South China Sea. When Gloria reached the Pearl River Estuary, Hong Kong recorded hurricane-force winds for one hour during the hoisting of the No. 8 signal, prompting the Royal Hong Kong Observatory to directly raise the No. 10 signal. Meanwhile, the Macau Meteorological Bureau did not record sustained hurricane-force winds and thus only raised the No. 9 signal. The observatory recorded 12 hours of strong winds, 14 hours of gale-force winds, and one hour of hurricane-force winds. On September 22, Macau recorded a pressure of 970.8 hPa, an east wind at 110 km/h, gusts reaching 144 km/h, and a maximum daily rainfall of 79.3 mm, causing flooding in low-lying areas of Macau. Typhoon Gloria made landfall in Macau at 9 p.m. on September 22, with maximum wind speeds at the center reaching 162 km/h. It then passed through Zhongshan, Panyu, and Guangzhou before dissipating inland.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 10:20 a.m. Hong Kong Summer Time on September 21, 1957. Less than three hours later, at 1:10 p.m., it was replaced with the No. 3 signal. At 4:00 a.m. on the 22nd, the No. 7 signal was hoisted. At 12:30 p.m., the No. 8 signal was hoisted. Twenty minutes later, at 12:50 p.m., the Observatory directly hoisted the No. 10 signal, making it the only typhoon to directly hit Hong Kong since 1946 without the No. 9 signal being hoisted. It was also the only No. 10 signal in Hong Kong during the entire 1950s, lasting nearly 8 hours. The Observatory replaced the No. 10 signal with the No. 8 signal at 8:45 p.m. and then replaced it with the No. 3 signal at 6:00 a.m. on the 23rd. As Gloria moved away from Hong Kong, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 11:15 p.m.

During the impact of Gloria, the storm surge caused by the storm reached a tidal difference of 2.30 meters, combined with the occurrence of astronomical tides, resulting in a stronger storm surge phenomenon. Macau recorded the highest tide level at 4.35 meters, causing road flooding with a depth of 1.15 meters. [2]

In the northeastern part of Macau, over 200 acres of vegetable fields were flooded, affecting 200 farming households and over 1,000 people. Approximately 5,000 pigs of various sizes drowned, and dozens of wooden houses in the city were destroyed or collapsed. During the storm, a police officer on duty drowned in Hac Sa Wan, a man in Ilha Verde was electrocuted to death, and a man was killed when a shanty house collapsed on Rua da Pedra. When Typhoon Gloria swept through Macau, a seawall near Hac Sa Wan on the eastern side of the Border Gate was breached in three places, flooding the vegetable fields, with water levels reaching six to seven feet at their deepest. Two hundred farming households fled in panic, with cries of distress echoing continuously. Authorities dispatched military police and four small boats for rescue operations, saving 132 people, but a Portuguese police officer, Rodolfo, accidentally fell into the water and drowned in the line of duty. Farmers in Hac Sa Wan suffered losses of approximately one million Macau patacas in property and livestock. In areas such as Mong Ha Hill and the New Reclamation Zone, many crops were also destroyed by the wind, resulting in significant losses. Dozens of wooden houses in Lin Ma Hang and the area near White Pigeon Nest Hill were destroyed, leaving over a hundred disaster victims. In the Ilha Verde wooden house area, a man was electrocuted and died outside his home at 8 p.m. on September 22. Numerous signs in the city were destroyed, and all the trees on Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro were broken or toppled. A century-old tree in Camoes Garden was uprooted, and a large tree on Rua do Campo collapsed. A six-foot-long boulder from the Ruins of St. Paul was blown down by the strong winds, embedding itself more than a foot deep into the ground. Many power lines in the city were destroyed, leaving one-third of the city's telephones out of service.

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Cimaron (English: Severe Tropical Storm Cimaron, International Number: 0101, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 03W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Crising) was the first named storm of the 2001 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Cimaron" was provided by the Philippines and refers to a type of wild buffalo in the region.

At 12:00 UTC on May 9, a tropical depression formed over the sea between Mindoro Island and Palawan Island in the Philippines. The tropical depression moved northward. At 00:00 UTC on May 11, the tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm west of Luzon Island and was named Cimaron. Cimaron turned northeastward. At 00:00 UTC on May 13, Cimaron further intensified into a severe tropical storm south of Taiwan. At 06:00 UTC on May 13, Cimaron weakened into a tropical storm. Cimaron maintained its northeastward path until 09:00 UTC on May 14 in southern Japan. Cimaron then moved eastward and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the sea northeast of Okinawa at 12:00 UTC on May 14. It completely dissipated at 18:00 UTC on May 15. [1]

At 11:15 AM on May 11, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning. At 8:35 PM, the Central Weather Bureau issued a land typhoon warning. At 5:50 PM on May 13, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the land typhoon warning. At 8:05 PM, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the sea typhoon warning.

Whole_Text.content: The Gengzi Typhoon Disaster occurred on November 10, 1900, when a powerful typhoon directly struck Hong Kong, resulting in over 200 fatalities. It was the fifth deadliest typhoon in Hong Kong's history, the only one to directly hit Hong Kong in November, and the latest in the year to do so. It was also one of the strongest typhoons to hit Hong Kong before World War II.

The Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the red downward cone at 11:45 am on November 8, indicating that a tropical cyclone was located more than 300 miles (480 kilometers) south of Hong Kong, with fresh to strong north to northeast winds expected in Hong Kong. At 11:50 am on November 9, the Observatory hoisted the black downward cone, signaling strong east to northeast winds with the possibility of reaching gale force. That afternoon, the typhoon posed a direct threat to Hong Kong, prompting the Observatory to sound the typhoon gun at 6:15 pm, forecasting wind strength to increase to gale force. By 7:30 pm, the Observatory vertically hoisted two lanterns. Between 5:00 am and 6:00 am on November 10, the Observatory recorded the highest average wind speed of 61 knots, equivalent to 113 kilometers per hour, reaching storm force. The typhoon passed over the eastern part of Hong Kong around 6:00 to 7:00 am. Subsequently, the wind in Hong Kong weakened to gale force and shifted to westerly winds, leading the Observatory to replace the black drum at 6:40 am. Later, as the typhoon moved north of Hong Kong, the Observatory hoisted the black upward cone at 8:45 am. In the afternoon, the wind in Hong Kong further subsided, and the Observatory finally removed all typhoon signals at 4:00 pm.

Whole_Text.content: The hailstorm of Reutlingen was a severe weather event on July 28, 2013, in Baden-Württemberg, primarily in Reutlingen, and in Bavaria. The storm caused a total damage of 3.6 billion euros, making it the largest hail damage in Germany up to that point, and with insured damages of 2.8 billion euros, it was the largest single-event damage for the insurance industry in Germany to date. It moved from the Black Forest along the densely populated Albtrauf over the Ostalb into the Nördlinger Ries and gradually weakened over Bavaria.

In the third decade of July 2013, a heatwave occurred in large parts of Central Europe. In many places, weather stations in Germany recorded temperatures of up to 38 °C. Even along the coasts of the North and Baltic Seas, daily maximum temperatures of up to 32 °C were recorded. Responsible for these temperatures was an upper trough over the eastern Atlantic, which brought hot and humid air directly from the Mediterranean to Germany. Due to this massive warm air advection into Central Europe, temperatures in Germany could reach such heights. On the front side of the trough, so-called shortwave troughs moved from France into Germany during the third and fourth weeks of July. These disturbances repeatedly induced the formation of towering cumulus clouds in Central Europe, which could develop into large thunderstorm complexes in the hot and humid air. For example, on July 25, 2013, severe thunderstorms occurred in France. On July 26 and 27, 2013, further severe storms formed over Baden-Württemberg, North Rhine-Westphalia, and Lower Saxony. In Pforzheim, for instance, hailstones up to 4 cm in size were reported, while in Lower Saxony, particularly in the Hanover metropolitan region, hailstones with diameters of up to 10 cm were recorded. The peak of the heatwave was expected to be reached on July 28, 2013, as the corresponding low-pressure system Andreas advanced further into Germany. On the front side of the associated cold front, a convergence formed over Baden-Württemberg, marking the culmination of the weather event, which would cause the highest insured damages of any hailstorm in German history as well as of any natural disaster worldwide in 2013.

In the course of July 28, 2013, the previously inactive convergence until around 3 p.m. lay across Baden-Württemberg. Due to the daytime heating of the air mass, thunderstorms were triggered over the southern Black Forest around 3:30 p.m. Due to favorable atmospheric conditions, the thunderstorms quickly developed into large and well-organized hailstorms, which moved northeastward due to the prevailing southwesterly upper-level flow. During the further development process, two of the thunderstorms formed into so-called supercells. Cities along the Swabian Jura and further towards Bavaria lay in their path. The two cells moved parallel to each other at a distance of about 50 kilometers across Baden-Württemberg. While the northern of the two thunderstorm cells caused only local hail damage in the Schwäbisch Hall district, the southern and stronger cell moved along the Swabian Jura and caused hailstorms of previously undocumented dimensions. The districts of Zollernalb, Tübingen, Reutlingen, Esslingen, and Göppingen, as well as the Ostalbkreis, were particularly hard hit. Here, a swath up to 15 km wide experienced severe hailstorms with hailstones up to 8 cm in size. Reutlingen was hit particularly hard. The fire department control center in Reutlingen registered 10,900 emergency calls in the first two days after the storm. To manage the many emergency sites, fire departments, THW, and other aid organization associations from all over Baden-Württemberg were brought together. At times, up to 120 emergency vehicles and over 800 emergency personnel were deployed in Reutlingen and the surrounding area. After reaching the Bavarian state border, the thunderstorms weakened but still caused flooding and hail damage, especially in the northern district of Bavarian Swabia. Thirteen hours after the first thunderstorms formed, the structures disappeared from radar images.

The hailstones, up to the size of tennis balls, damaged or destroyed vehicles, facades, photovoltaic and solar systems, roof windows, and roof tiles. Traffic lights and power lines were also affected. Fallen trees and flooded underpasses prevented the progress of rescue teams and clearing vehicles. Hail and fallen leaves clogged drainage systems on roads and in water management systems, often leading to flooding. Due to leaking roofs, shattered windows, and facades, rain entered unhindered, which particularly caused such consequential damage to apartments and houses that they were no longer habitable. Even seven months after the storm, there was no end in sight to the damage reports. Thousands of birds also fell victim to the hail.

Several hundred people were injured by the storm. The central emergency room in Reutlingen alone reported 75 injured individuals. The Eichert Clinic in Göppingen registered 60 injured individuals. Fatalities directly related to the storm are not known.

The church storm was a tempest that swept across the country on September 20, 1900. It was also widely referred to as the Turn of the Century Weather. That day, a severe southwesterly and westerly storm, one of the worst of its kind on record, hit the country. Extensive damage occurred to both people and property, including the drowning of 17 men on four boats in Arnarfjörður on that fateful day. There were also fatalities in Eyjafjörður. There, the storm struck around noon. The residential house in Rauðuvík on Árskógsströnd, which was then a newly built timber house, was lifted off its foundation and toppled down the sea cliff it stood on. Eight people were inside, and three died when the house collapsed. Two boats were lost in Hríseyjarsund, taking six men with them, and a farmer in Arnarneshreppur later died from injuries sustained in the storm. Across the country, about 30 people lost their lives due to the storm, and there was also immense property damage. In Svarfaðardalur, people remembered and still remember this storm as the Church Storm of autumn 1900. This was because two of the valley's four churches were blown away and shattered into splinters. These were the churches at Urðir and Upsir. The churches at Tjörn and Vellir were shifted on their foundations, narrowly avoiding major damage.

Whole_Text.content: The Ji-Mao Typhoon disaster was caused by Typhoon 23W during the 1939 Pacific typhoon season. The typhoon passed through British Hong Kong on November 23, 1939, prompting the Royal Hong Kong Observatory to hoist the No. 9 typhoon signal twice.

On November 18, 1939, a tropical depression was detected east of Mindanao, which continued to strengthen and move northwestward, intensifying into a typhoon before sweeping across Samar and Leyte on the 19th. The typhoon then generally maintained a westward movement until reaching the western South China Sea on the 22nd. Subsequently, a cold front caused the typhoon to turn northeast, resulting in the rare phenomenon of a typhoon reversing direction to the northeast in the western South China Sea. On November 24, the typhoon passed through Macau and, two hours later, its eye directly crossed Hong Kong. The eye lingered over the Hong Kong Observatory for fifteen minutes, marking the first recorded instance of such an occurrence at the observatory. After causing landslides, the typhoon began transitioning into an extratropical cyclone and continued moving northeast across southern China. The storm gradually weakened as it crossed the Taiwan Strait and made landfall in Taiwan before dissipating on the 26th.

While crossing the Philippines, a weather station in Capiz on Panay Island recorded a pressure as low as 981.0 hPa, and wind speeds exceeding 88 km/h. During its passage, the storm caused a motorboat to sink off Masbate Island, resulting in the deaths of 48 out of 50 people on board. In Balangiga, Eastern Samar, one person went missing, believed to have drowned, and was presumed dead. Significant property damage was also reported in Samar, Leyte, and Capiz provinces.

Typhoon 23W entered within 800 kilometers south of Hong Kong and moved northwest-northward, approaching the eastern waters of Hainan Island. It came within 400 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong but did not further move northward to make landfall in western Guangdong. Two days later, it made a sudden 90-degree turn, creating a rare situation of moving directly from west to east towards Hong Kong, passing about 65 kilometers southeast of the Hong Kong Observatory. The Observatory issued the No. 9 signal twice. The cold air from the northeast monsoon also happened to move southward, and the storm transformed into an extratropical cyclone the next day, moving eastward towards Taiwan. The Observatory headquarters recorded strong winds for one hour, with the highest hourly average wind speed at 65 kilometers per hour, coming from the east.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 8:35 a.m. on November 23, then upgraded to the No. 8 signal at 9:05 a.m. As the storm continued to approach and the wind and rain intensified, the No. 9 signal was issued at 10:05 a.m. At 11:45 a.m., as the wind and rain slightly eased, the Observatory downgraded to the No. 8 signal. However, as the wind and rain intensified again, the No. 9 signal was reissued at 3:51 p.m. At 4:30 p.m., the Observatory downgraded to the No. 5 signal. By 7:05 p.m., all signals were canceled.

When Hong Kong was affected by the rainbands ahead of the storm, gusts reached up to 119 km/h. Rainfall began seven hours before the typhoon's arrival, resulting in a total of approximately 108 mm of rainfall. The heaviest rainfall came from the pre-typhoon rainbands, with 40 mm recorded within one hour. The lowest pressure recorded during the typhoon's passage over Hong Kong was 989.0 hPa. The typhoon caused minor damage in Hong Kong. In Kowloon City’s Tung Tau Estate, a mud wall collapsed, killing two people. In Kowloon Bay, a cargo boat was overturned by the wind, causing five people to fall into the sea, with one person sustaining minor injuries.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gilda (English: Typhoon Gilda, International Number: 6733, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 39W) was the 33rd named tropical cyclone of the 1967 Pacific typhoon season.

On November 8, Typhoon Gilda formed over the eastern waters of the Caroline Islands. On November 18, 1967, Typhoon Gilda made landfall between Hualien and Chenggong in Taiwan, exited between Taichung and Hsinchu, and weakened into a tropical depression in the northern Taiwan Strait. The intense Typhoon Gilda became the "latest typhoon to hit Taiwan in a year" in Taiwan's meteorological observation history at the time. On December 3, 2004, Typhoon Nanmadol replaced Typhoon Gilda as the "latest typhoon to hit Taiwan in a year" in Taiwan's meteorological observation history.

Whole_Text.content: The Dingmao Typhoon occurred on August 20, 1927. On that day, a typhoon passed through the coastal waters near Yangjiang, Guangdong Province, China. The storm caused loss of life and property damage in both Hong Kong and Macau, and it was one of the two occasions that year when Macau hoisted the No. 7 typhoon signal (equivalent to today's No. 10 signal). A newspaper article once mentioned, "Um violento tufão caiu sobre Macau (A violent typhoon struck Macau)." The Central Meteorological Bureau's designation for this typhoon was B124.

According to the path map of the typhoon on August 20, 1927, released by the Macau Meteorological Bureau, the storm formed over the sea south of Guam at 6 a.m. on August 15, moving steadily westward. On August 16, the storm moved west of 140°E longitude and gradually shifted from a west-northwest to northwest direction, intensifying rapidly. On August 18, the Dutch steamship Sapoeroea recorded the typhoon's lowest sea-level pressure at only 886.7 hPa (26.185 inches of mercury) 460 nautical miles (740 kilometers) east of Luzon, making it the tropical cyclone with the lowest sea-level pressure recorded globally at the time, until it was surpassed by Typhoon Ida's 877 hPa in 1958. Later on the evening of August 18 to early August 19, the typhoon made landfall or brushed past the northeastern coast of Luzon, where Aparri recorded a minimum pressure of 969.9 hPa (727.5 mmHg). After passing through Luzon, the typhoon entered the northern South China Sea, and at 6 a.m. on August 19, it was located near the northern coast of Luzon, moving northwest to west-northwest. At 6 a.m. on August 20, the center was northwest of Pratas Island, passing within 10 nautical miles of the island, where winds reached force 11 and the pressure dropped to 967.1 hPa (725.42 mmHg). The typhoon subsequently passed south of Hong Kong and Macau. During the storm, Hong Kong recorded a minimum sea-level pressure of 982.4 hPa, an average wind speed of 98 km/h (53 knots), and gusts of 187 km/h (101 knots). In Macau, the pressure dropped to a minimum of 974.1 hPa (730.6 mmHg), with average wind speeds and gusts reaching 135 km/h and 190 km/h, respectively. Later on the evening of August 20 to August 21, the typhoon made landfall in western Guangdong and gradually dissipated.

The typhoon passed 95 kilometers (60 nautical miles) south of Hong Kong, causing certain damages. Many houses in the Kowloon area collapsed, including over 130 houses in Cheung Sha Wan, and all the squatter huts in Kowloon Tong were blown away. A bus overturned on Salisbury Road. Additionally, 2 ocean-going vessels and 9 fishing boats were damaged. The storm resulted in 15 deaths and 22 injuries. [10][11][12]

In Joaquim Baião Simões' book "Macau and the Typhoons" (1985) [14], it records the typhoon on August 20, 1927, which caused loss of life and immeasurable damage in Macau. The cruiser "Democrata," anchored in the Inner Harbor, nearly sank, and the Governor's Palace was also damaged [3]. The Chinese-language newspaper reported four drowning deaths [2]. After the storm, the South Bay coastline was in complete disarray, with wreckage from numerous fishing boats washed up along the embankment. In the area of Sá Lei Tau, a shipyard was blown down. On Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro and near the Army Club, large trees were uprooted.

Whole_Text.content: The Ji Si Typhoon occurred from August 22 to 23, 1929, when a severe typhoon directly struck Hong Kong and Macau, causing both places to hoist the only No. 7 typhoon signal of that year (equivalent to the current No. 10 signal). In Hong Kong, during the period when the gale signal was hoisted, the Observatory recorded hurricane-force winds for one hour, leading the Observatory to skip the No. 6 signal and directly hoist the No. 7 signal. This was the first time the Observatory had done so since the establishment of the gale enhancement signal.

According to the 1985 publication "Macau and Typhoons (Macau e os Tufões)" by the Macau Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau, this storm formed on August 21 in the southeastern waters of the Dongsha Islands, reached its peak on August 22, made landfall, and dissipated on August 23. According to reports from Hong Kong newspapers at the time, the Hong Kong Observatory believed that the storm formed on the afternoon of August 20 at 19 degrees north latitude, approximately 159 miles west of northern Luzon, moving northwestward. By 2 a.m. on the 21st, it shifted northward and passed east of Dongsha Island at 2 p.m. the same day before turning northwest. By 1:30 p.m. on the 22nd, the storm reached south of Hong Kong, made landfall near Macau, moved inland, and dissipated thereafter. [1]

The storm was closest to Macau on August 22. "Macau and Typhoons (Macau e os Tufões)" recorded that this storm passed through Macau, causing significant impact on the city. During the storm, Macau recorded the highest gusts reaching 220 kilometers per hour (data unverified).

Article_Name: 癸亥風災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Guihai Typhoon occurred on August 18, 1923. On that day, a typhoon passed north of Macau and subsequently entered mainland China, causing significant damage. It marked the second time that year that hurricane signals were hoisted in both Hong Kong and Macau, and it was also the longest hurricane warning ever hoisted in Macau's history. The Central Meteorological Bureau designated this typhoon as B102.

The typhoon that caused this disaster was first observed southwest of Guam on August 11, moving in a northwesterly direction. In the following days, it moved westward. On August 16, the typhoon moved westward at 13 knots (24 kilometers per hour). At 8 PM that day, the ship Steel Traveler entered the typhoon's center near 21°N, 123.2°E, with uncorrected sea-level pressure dropping to 711.2 mmHg (948 hPa) and recording two hours of calm winds, indicating that its intensity had reached typhoon level. On August 17, the typhoon passed north of Batanes in the early morning, entered the South China Sea, and moved west-northwest at a speed of 17.5 knots (32 kilometers per hour). On the morning of August 18, the typhoon's center passed a few miles south of Hong Kong and around noon passed about 10 miles (approximately 20 kilometers) north of Macau, then entered inland China and gradually dissipated.
The storm swept across the southern sea of Taiwan, with wind speeds in Kaohsiung reaching 54 kilometers per hour at one point.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 typhoon signal at 11:25 a.m. on August 17 and the No. 2 typhoon signal at 4:30 p.m. However, the weather in most parts of Hong Kong remained fine that day, with pressure dropping and cloud cover increasing after nightfall. On August 18, the typhoon moved closer to Hong Kong. The Observatory hoisted the No. 6 typhoon signal at 8:23 a.m., and strong winds began to blow in Hong Kong from 9 a.m., prompting the Observatory to hoist the No. 7 typhoon signal at 9 a.m. Hurricane-force winds were recorded in Hong Kong at 10 a.m., with the typhoon's center passing a few miles south of Hong Kong. The lowest pressure recorded in Hong Kong was 971.7 hPa, with the highest hourly sustained wind speed at 72 knots (133 km/h) and gusts reaching 113 knots (209 km/h). Shortly after, the wind direction shifted to east-southeast, and wind speeds rapidly decreased as the typhoon moved away, with strong winds lasting only three hours.

The storm caused severe casualties and damage in Hong Kong, with storm surges occurring in the harbor. The sea level rose to 3.2 meters in the harbor, and a storm surge height of 4.57 meters was recorded in Tai Po. At least 100 people died, including at least 40 fishermen, and one person went missing. The massive waves caused significant damage to the sea and coastal areas. The British Navy submarine HMS L9 was swept out of the naval dockyard by the waves, destroying the dockyard's outer wall and eventually sinking near the Star Ferry Pier on the Hong Kong side. A steamship traveling between China and India was swept from Kowloon Bay to the Yau Ma Tei pier by the waves and sank. Along the coastline from Shau Kei Wan to Stonecutters Island, 20 ships were washed ashore, some severely damaged, with at least two fatalities. Ninety percent of the ships docked at the Taikoo Dockyard sank, resulting in significant losses. In the Shau Kei Wan typhoon shelter, over 300 sailing boats or sampans sank, were damaged, or were stranded. Some sampans in Causeway Bay were even thrown onto the roads. In Yau Ma Tei, eight sampans were piled up on the seawall, with two thrown onto land. The waves also destroyed a monument near the Hong Kong Club, broke wooden planks at the Central Blake Pier, and deformed parts of the Star Ferry Pier. The asphalt on Connaught Road was also overturned.

In Tai Po, the storm surge caused severe damage to the coastline. The seawall near the railway in the Tolo Harbour area was destroyed, disrupting train services. A 40-foot embankment at Tai Po Kau pier was destroyed. Several embankments in Sha Tin were washed away, destroying rice crops. A family of six in the area was hit by the storm surge, resulting in four deaths. Tai O experienced even stronger winds, with 12 houses and 19 huts collapsing, though no fatalities were reported. The storm temporarily disrupted the ongoing East Reclamation Project along the waterfront. After the storm, the reclaimed soil was washed away, but it did not flow into the sea, so the project was ultimately not significantly affected.

Affected by the typhoon, the Portuguese Navy hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 11 at 10:30 a.m. on August 18 and lowered it at midnight the following day, lasting 13 and a half hours, the longest on record. During the storm, Macau recorded a minimum pressure of 963.7 hPa, a maximum hourly average wind speed of 115 km/h, and a maximum gust speed of 200 km/h. According to Joaquim Baião Simões' book "Macau and the Typhoons (Macau e os Tufões)," the typhoon caused significant damage to Macau, destroying and damaging approximately 200 houses and 24 shipyards, with 50 various types of ships sunk. The disaster resulted in over 400 deaths and 52 injuries in Macau.

Article_Name: 甲申風災 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The Jiashen Typhoon (English: 1944 Macau Typhoon) was a tropical cyclone in the 1944 Pacific typhoon season and one of the four typhoons that directly struck Macau in the 1940s.

In the early hours of July 22, due to the impact of the typhoon, rain and strong winds began in Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Marine Department hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 2[1], marking the first time this signal was hoisted since the simplification of the typhoon signal system on October 20, 1943. After the hoisting of Signal No. 2, three ferry routes between Central and Heung To, Tai Kok, and Castle Peak were suspended starting in the morning[1], until the signal was lowered. Regarding land transportation, only passenger bicycles and rickshaws continued to operate in the wind and rain[1]. Businesses along both sides of Victoria Harbour closed their doors and windows tightly, pedestrians were sparse, and the streets were quiet. Many shop signs fell in various locations[1]. Around 8 a.m., a floating corpse was found near the Central Keng Shan Pier[1], suspected to be a victim of a sunken boat, which was later swept away by large waves. The doors and windows of a shop along the waterfront in Chung Sum Kee were destroyed by the wind[1], and one vacant building each on First Street in the Water City District and Gough Street in Central collapsed[1], causing no casualties. The district officer of the lowland area, accompanied by an administrative officer, toured the streets in the wind and rain in the morning[1], giving instructions to citizens on typhoon precautions. By noon, the wind and rain had weakened, and the Marine Department lowered Typhoon Signal No. 2 in the afternoon[1]. The "Hong Kong Maru" ship, originally scheduled to depart from Hong Kong to Guangdong Province at 8 p.m., had to be delayed by a day due to the still-strong winds[1]. Prices rose significantly due to the typhoon's impact on supply, with the price of rice increasing from HK$7.2 per catty on July 21 to a peak of HK$8 on the 22nd[1]. Sweet potatoes rose from HK$2.9 per catty on the eve of the storm to over HK$3[1], and the supply of fish and vegetables was tight, with prices also increasing.

At 11 a.m. on July 20, the Macau Meteorological Department learned of very low pressure in the northern South China Sea and the appearance of a tropical cyclone. They immediately ordered the hoisting of Signal No. 1 at the Guia Fortress, the Maritime Administration, and the Guia Lighthouse. On the afternoon of July 21, the weather in Macau deteriorated with heavy rain, and at around 7 p.m., Signal No. 5 was hoisted, warning of possible strong northwest winds. The city experienced strong winds and heavy rain, and ferry services between the Macau Peninsula and Taipa were suspended. Ships sought shelter in the Inner Harbour typhoon shelter. At around 2 a.m. on July 22, the winds intensified, and Signal No. 9 was hoisted. The Maritime Administration's rescue ferry ventured out to patrol the Outer Harbour in case of emergencies. At around 7 a.m. on July 22, the typhoon appeared to be directly impacting Macau. At 8:30 a.m., the Meteorological Department ordered the replacement of Signal No. 9 with Signal No. 10, the first in three years. The Guia Fortress fired three cannon shots to warn of the approaching hurricane. Macau experienced a day of strong winds and heavy rain, with the Outer Harbour area being the most threatened. However, as the typhoon quickly passed south of Macau without directly crossing it, overall damage was minimal. An unmanned boat sank at sea, the New Reclamation swimming area was destroyed, the Nam Van Friendship Stadium was damaged, and many rooftop drying racks and shop signs were blown away. Several small trees on Avenida de Venceslau de Morais were uprooted. A shipyard in the Areia Preta area collapsed, causing significant cargo losses but no casualties. Streets such as Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro, Rua da Felicidade, Rua dos Mercadores, Rua da Praia do Manduco, and the San Kio district were flooded, with water levels exceeding one foot in some areas. Several old houses on Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro collapsed, injuring a police officer. By midday on July 22, the winds weakened and shifted to a southerly direction. At 12:50 p.m., the Guia Fortress fired two cannon shots to signal the end of the hurricane threat, and Signal No. 6 was hoisted. At 7 p.m., Signal No. 1 was hoisted again, and all signals were removed before midnight.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴貝姬 (1993年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Becky (English: Severe Tropical Storm Becky, International Number: 9316, Taiwan Number: 9317, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 22W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Yeyeng) was the 18th named storm of the 1993 Pacific typhoon season.

On September 14, 1993, a tropical disturbance formed in the Caroline Islands and intensified into a tropical depression the following day, designated as 22W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. It moved west or west-northwest at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour. Initially, Becky remained at tropical depression strength, with maximum winds only reaching gale force. However, after entering the waters of the Balintang Channel, it strengthened into a tropical storm and was named "Becky." At that time, its movement speed significantly increased, moving west-northwest at 30 kilometers per hour into the northern South China Sea. On September 17, Becky intensified into a severe tropical storm about 50 kilometers southwest of the Dongsha Islands and accelerated again, moving at 34 kilometers per hour toward the western coast of the Pearl River Estuary. On the same day, it made landfall in Chixi Town, Taishan City, Guangdong Province. Becky quickly weakened into a tropical storm about 200 kilometers northeast of Zhanjiang City. On September 18, it weakened into a tropical depression near Liuzhou City in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region and dissipated a few hours later in northern Ha Giang Province, Vietnam.

2. The data for Cheung Chau and Chek Lap Kok is incomplete. The Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9:30 am on September 16, when Becky was located about 660 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. Initially, the weather was generally clear with light winds. As Becky approached, the northeast wind strengthened, and squalls and thunderstorms began to affect Hong Kong. The Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 10:30 pm that night. Due to continued strengthening winds, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 2:50 am on September 17. According to the Observatory's tropical cyclone report, Becky was closest to Hong Kong at around 7 am, located about 110 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. In fact, some citizens and former Observatory staff pointed out that Becky was closest to Hong Kong at around 9 am, located about 90 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory, consistent with the Observatory's radar positioning and clear media reports at the time. However, the Observatory overturned the real-time positioning in the 1993 Tropical Cyclone Annual Report and did not acknowledge that Becky had reached hurricane-force winds, meaning it entered within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong at typhoon strength, meeting the conditions for issuing a higher signal. A former Observatory staff member pointed out that starting at around 8 am that morning, Cheung Chau experienced several hours of sustained hurricane-force winds. Before the Cheung Chau wind station went into maintenance mode, it recorded a maximum hourly average wind speed of 139 kilometers per hour, indicating that Becky had reached typhoon strength and brought hurricane-force winds to southwestern Hong Kong. This proves that the Observatory's classification of Becky as a severe tropical storm was a significant underestimation of its intensity, and not issuing the No. 10 Hurricane Signal was a serious mistake. At 8 am that morning, Shek Lau Wan and Wong Chuk Hang also recorded maximum hourly average wind speeds of 99 and 62 kilometers per hour, respectively, which were higher than the 87 and 54 kilometers per hour recorded during Super Typhoon Mangkhut in 2018. The Observatory headquarters also recorded a minimum instantaneous sea-level pressure of 997.3 hPa. As the wind shifted to the southeast, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal at 7:30 am. On that day, Hong Kong generally experienced gale to storm-force winds, with hurricane-force winds persisting in the western and southern areas, offshore waters, and highlands until Becky made landfall in western Guangdong. Showers decreased in the afternoon, and the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 3:10 pm, replacing the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, when Becky was located about 270 kilometers west of Hong Kong. All tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 5 pm. During Becky's impact on Hong Kong, 1 person died, and 130 people were injured. [2]

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 12:00 noon on September 16. On September 17, as Typhoon Becky approached with strong winds and heavy rain, the bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 3 at 12:30 a.m. and Typhoon Signal No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 6:30 a.m. Due to the continued strengthening of winds and the typhoon's closer approach to Macao, Typhoon Signal No. 9 was hoisted at 9:00 a.m. At the same time, the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge recorded the highest hourly average wind speed of 124 km/h, marking the first time hurricane-force sustained winds were recorded in the region. The main station at Mount Fortress recorded a maximum hourly wind speed of 73 km/h, while the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge recorded the highest gust of 166 km/h at 9:23 a.m., with the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure at 982.3 hPa. During this period, coinciding with astronomical high tide, low-lying areas such as the Inner Harbor, San Kio, and Ilha Verde experienced seawater flooding. The water level on Rua Cinco de Outubro even reached thigh height, and the Macao Water Supply Company's plant in Ilha Verde was affected by flooding, temporarily halting water supply. Numerous incidents of structural collapse occurred across the city: one side of the exterior wall and windows of the Global Hotel near Tap Seac Square were blown down by strong winds; a large tree fell in the parking area at Senado Square, crushing several cars; a large section of scaffolding collapsed near the CEM building on Rua do Almirante Sérgio; and many shanties along the Lin Ma Hang and Fai Chi Kei waterfronts were destroyed. The seawall near the old Outer Harbor Ferry Terminal on Avenida da Amizade was severely damaged by waves, and the terminal facilities were also affected. Subsequently, as Typhoon Becky moved away from Macao, the Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau replaced Typhoon Signal No. 8 Southwest Gale or Storm Signal at 10:30 a.m., then Typhoon Signal No. 3 at 1:30 p.m., and finally canceled all signals at 4:00 p.m. Typhoon Becky caused a total of 43 injuries in Macao, with 2 people seriously injured, and over 1,700 people had to take shelter at the Ilha Verde disaster relief center. Due to damage to facilities, hydrofoil ferry services between Hong Kong and Macao remained suspended as of 9:00 p.m. on September 17 and only fully resumed the following day. At the Transmac bus depot in Areia Preta, nearly 50 buses were completely flooded and paralyzed. After overnight emergency repairs, 30 buses were operational the next day.

When Becky struck Hong Kong and Macau, the meteorological departments of both regions underestimated its intensity. On the morning of September 17, 1993, Becky passed about 90 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong and approximately 45 kilometers south-southwest of Macau. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Macau Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau only issued the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal and the No. 9 Signal. However, hurricane-force winds persisted in the western and southern areas of Hong Kong, offshore waters, and highlands, while Macau experienced widespread hurricane-force winds. This not only met the criteria for the No. 10 Signal in both regions but also indicated that Becky was indeed a typhoon. This highlights the poor forecasting ability and accuracy of the meteorological departments in Hong Kong and Macau at the time regarding rapidly intensifying and accelerating tropical cyclones near the coast, as well as their low responsiveness to sudden situations. Although many years have passed since Becky struck Hong Kong and Macau, many residents and weather enthusiasts in both regions still point out in forums that the meteorological departments underestimated its intensity and question the rationale for not issuing higher signals, which continues to spark considerable debate.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Sinlaku (English: Tropical Storm Sinlaku, International Number: 1421, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP212014, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Queenie) was the 21st named storm of the 2014 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Sinlaku" was provided by Micronesia and refers to a goddess in the Kosrae legend of Micronesia.

On November 23, 2014, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 2:00 PM on November 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area. At 1:00 PM on November 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 21W. At 4:30 PM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Bayabas, Surigao del Sur, Philippines. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. 

At 1:00 AM on November 27, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Jagna, Bohol, Philippines. At 2:00 AM, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. Without prior indication that "a tropical depression seems to be forming," the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression at 4:00 AM. At 6:00 AM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Argao, Cebu, Philippines. At 7:30 AM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Jimalalud, Negros Oriental, Philippines. At 10:30 PM, the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Taytay, Palawan, Philippines. 

At 8:00 AM on November 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sinlaku. At the same time, the Central Meteorological Observatory and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. The Central Weather Bureau also upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 10:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

At 8:00 AM on November 29, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 12:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11:00 PM, Sinlaku made landfall along the coast of Tuy Hoa, Phu Yen Province, Vietnam. 

At 2:00 AM on November 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 3:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 AM, the Central Meteorological Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Central Meteorological Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Central Meteorological Observatory ceased numbering it. At 4:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 10:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

Subsequently, in the best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, the intensity of Sinlaku was downgraded to a tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center revised down to 45 knots.

On the morning of November 26 at 7:30 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named the system that had entered its area of responsibility as Queenie, upgraded it to a tropical depression, and issued the first tropical cyclone advisory. [6] At 3:50 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued Signal No. 1. On the afternoon of November 28 at 4:30 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted Signal No. 1. At 7:00 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued the final tropical cyclone advisory for the system.

On the morning of November 28 at 10:00, the Central Meteorological Observatory issued a blue typhoon warning signal. On the morning of November 30 at 6:00, the Central Meteorological Observatory lifted the typhoon warning signal.

At 10:00 AM on November 28, the Hainan Meteorological Observatory issued a Level 4 typhoon emergency response. At 10:00 PM on November 29, the Hainan Meteorological Observatory lifted the Level 4 typhoon emergency response.

The Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center upgraded Sonca to a tropical depression and issued a notice at 8 a.m. on the 27th (local time 7 a.m.). It was upgraded to a tropical storm at 8 a.m. on the 28th, and it is expected that Sonca will make landfall along the coast from Phu Yen Province to Khanh Hoa Province on the afternoon of the 29th. At 11 p.m. on the 28th, Sonca's wind speed increased to 83 kilometers per hour, maintaining its intensity until the afternoon of the 29th. At 5 p.m. on the 29th, the Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center reported that Sonca's wind speed weakened to 70 kilometers per hour before making landfall, and it landed near Binh Dinh Province to Phu Yen Province at 11 p.m. with a wind speed of 65 kilometers per hour. The final warning for Sonca was issued at 8 a.m. on the 30th. 

Regarding the disaster situation, preliminary reports indicate no casualties. Dozens of houses were damaged, hundreds of trees were toppled, blocking some roads. Heavy rain flooded roads, and approximately 210 hectares of crops were submerged.

Whole_Text.content: The Janika storm was a storm that hit Finland on November 15, 2001. During the storm, the highest 10-minute average wind speed was 30 m/s, measured in Kylmäpihlaja, Rauma. In lake areas, the strongest average wind speed ranged between 21–22 m/s. According to the Finnish Meteorological Institute, similar wind speeds had previously been observed on land areas in August 1959 before Janika. The storm caused the most damage in Pirkanmaa, Häme, Eastern Häme, and Uusimaa. The storm claimed at least one life when the son of the Centre Party Member of Parliament Olavi Ala-Nissilä died. The Janika storm and the earlier Pyry storm in November together caused approximately 7.3 million cubic meters of forest damage.

The Lofoten storm of 1849 is reported to have occurred off the coast of Lofoten on February 11, 1849. Hans H.S. Schulze's travelogue from Nordland, published in 1865, mentions a storm on this day in which 500 men were said to have drowned: "No year passes without the sea claiming its victims during the winter fishing; but the loss of a couple of boat crews is considered only a small tribute to the waves. However, in certain years, greater disasters occur, which remain in the fishermen's memory for a long time. On February 11, 1848, as far as I recall, such a day of disaster occurred, and even the bravest fishermen turn pale when they speak of this day. How many people perished is not easy to know, as the fishing villages have little connection with each other; but it was estimated that about 500 men perished..." In Tromsø Tidende on February 25, 1849, a report on the front page states: "In Lofoten, the fishing has started well and is successful in both East and West Lofoten. The weather was very harsh, and many boats are said to have been lost in the storm." Professor Narve Fulsås, in Historisk Tidsskrift (2001), points out that investigations in newspapers from the relevant time cast doubt on both the date and the number of casualties, suggesting that a figure as high as 500 fatalities is likely an exaggeration. He believes Schulze, in his book published 16 years later, must have gotten the year wrong. However, the Tromsø newspaper confirms that there was a storm in 1849 and that many boats were lost. It is impossible to obtain exact information about the accident. Fulsås argues that no one at the time was capable of having such a comprehensive overview. Furthermore, it is difficult today to conduct a follow-up investigation since both the church and parish records in Vågan were destroyed in the Vågan church fire in 1865. In the church book for Buksnes municipality in Nordland (1849), there is a list of 24 people who perished at sea on February 11. Seventeen widows were left behind in the municipality after this tragedy.
Zeljko was a storm that swept across Central Europe on July 24, 2015, causing severe damage in some areas. Two people died as a result of the storm.

The low-pressure system Zeljko moved with hurricane-force gusts from the North Sea across Germany and neighboring countries. Afterwards, the low-pressure system continued towards Sweden. The DWD had warned of hurricane-like gusts with speeds of around 110 km/h. Zeljko eventually reached up to 100 km/h across the area. On the Brocken in the Harz, the storm peaked with winds of 158 km/h.

In the Netherlands, a person died when a tree fell on their car. In Slovakia, a woman was killed by lightning. Several other people were injured. In the Netherlands, highways were closed, train traffic was blocked, and flights were canceled at Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport. In North Rhine-Westphalia, fire and rescue services responded to more than 1,100 incidents. Twelve people were injured there due to storm-related effects.
