Storm Gorm (in the United Kingdom; Clodagh, in Germany; Nils II) was a storm that hit all of Denmark on Sunday, November 29, 2015. The storm made landfall on the west coast of Jutland, resulting in major flooding in places such as Hvide Sande. In the Limfjord, the water level rose by about 1.6 meters after the storm, which was, however, less than during Storm Egon in January of the same year. The storm's strongest winds swept across the country, with the central part of the country being particularly hard hit. The storm closed most of Denmark's bridges, including both the old and new Little Belt Bridge, the Vejle Fjord Bridge, the Great Belt Bridge, and the Øresund Bridge. Train traffic was suspended in many parts of the country; for example, all S-trains were canceled during the storm's worst hours. Copenhagen Airport experienced delays on many flights. Police in Southern Jutland, Central Jutland, and Funen advised against all unnecessary travel. A football match between FC Midtjylland and FC Copenhagen was canceled due to the storm. In East Jutland, 37,000 residents lost power as several high-voltage lines were hit by flying debris. In Sweden, nearly 50,000 households lost power as a result of the storm. Around 31,000 were in southern Sweden, but 5,000 homes on Gotland were also affected. In Brabrand near Aarhus, the roof of a residential block was blown off. However, there were no injuries. Many trees, weakened by the two previous storms Allan and Bodil, fell during Gorm. In the Lake Highlands, between 7,000 and 7,500 m³ of forest were toppled, and in Randers and on Djursland, around 2,000 m³ fell. A 74-year-old man with dementia from Nykøbing Sjælland was the only fatality of Storm Gorm. He was found dead on November 30, 2015.

Storm Freja was a storm that hit Denmark on November 7, 2015. It was predicted by DMI and named the same day. During the brief low-pressure passage, the Limfjord Bridge and the Øresund Bridge had to close. The inn Peter Lieps Hus in Dyrehaven north of Copenhagen was severely damaged by a falling tree.

Storm Helga was a storm with hurricane-force gusts that hit North Jutland on Friday, December 4, 2015. The storm made landfall at Thyborøn and moved northeast to Skagen. It peaked during the morning and was particularly strong at Hirtshals and Skagen. The storm came just a few days after Storm Gorm had closed most of the major bridges in the country. The highest gust was measured at 34.5 m/s. Train services between Aalborg and Frederikshavn were canceled between 06:00 and 13:00, and replacement buses were deployed instead. The shipping companies Color Line and Stena Line canceled ferries from both Hirtshals and Frederikshavn.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴麗莎 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Lisa was one of the tropical cyclones of the 1996 Pacific typhoon season. Lisa formed as a tropical depression in the northern part of the South China Sea, about 170 kilometers northwest of Dongsha, on the morning of August 6. It moved northeast, passing near Shantou City, Guangdong, that evening, then made landfall in Chencheng Town, Dongshan County, Zhangzhou City, Fujian. It weakened and dissipated inland on August 7. Lisa caused the deaths of over 90 people in mainland China.

Shortly after Lisa formed in the South China Sea, Hong Kong hoisted the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9 a.m. on August 6. At that time, it was generally cloudy with moderate northerly winds. As Lisa made landfall near Shantou that evening, Hong Kong gradually shifted to southwesterly winds, and the No. 1 Signal was taken down at 8:30 p.m. Lisa was closest to Hong Kong at around 10 a.m. on August 6, located approximately 160 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. The Observatory headquarters recorded the lowest instantaneous sea-level pressure of 998.7 hPa at 6 p.m. that evening. During Lisa's impact, no major damage was reported in Hong Kong.

Article_Name: 1911年台灣南部颱風 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 1911 Taiwan Southern Typhoon (English: 1911 Formosa Typhoon), designated as Typhoon B051 by the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan, was a typhoon that struck southern Taiwan in August 1911. It caused severe impacts in the south, resulting in at least 290 deaths, 262 injuries, and the collapse and destruction of numerous houses, making it the most impactful typhoon during the early Japanese colonial period. In particular, about 80% of public infrastructure in Tainan Prefecture was damaged, including the collapse of the first-generation wooden West Market building and damage to the Five Concubines Shrine at Chihkan Tower, among other severe disasters. Early houses were mostly wooden structures, which suffered heavy losses in this typhoon, leading to subsequent public building reconstructions using more durable materials and methods such as brick and reinforced concrete. [Ref 1]:78-80

In late August 1911, a typhoon formed in the southern Pacific Ocean. This typhoon passed through the Philippines, Taiwan, and East Asia, causing significant damage. On August 21, meteorological observations from Guam and Yap Island indicated that a typhoon was gathering west of the Mariana Islands, moving west or west-northwest. By August 23, the typhoon began affecting the Philippines, with areas about 500 miles (805 kilometers) east of Luzon experiencing pressure drops and wind direction changes due to the typhoon's circulation. On the 24th, signs of the typhoon's arrival were observed on the small northern Philippine island of Basco. Early on the 26th, the pressure at the Basco weather station began to plummet, wind speeds increased, and rainfall was recorded. Between midnight and 7 a.m., the wind direction shifted from north-northeast to north, then to northwest-north. By 7 a.m. on the 26th, the pressure recording paper dropped below the lower limit of 715 mmHg (953.3 hPa). At 8 a.m., the wind direction shifted to northwest, but the rain stopped. At 8:20 a.m., Basco entered the typhoon's eye, the sky became calm, and the sun was visible. Sustained wind speeds dropped to level 4, though strong gusts still occurred. At 9 a.m., wind speeds suddenly increased, and the wind direction shifted from northwest to west-southwest. For several hours afterward, hurricane-force winds persisted, with the wind direction changing to southwest. By noon, the pressure recording paper showed a rise above 715 mmHg (953.3 hPa), and the pressure continued to rise as the wind weakened and the typhoon gradually moved away from Basco. Due to the pressure recording paper dropping below its limit, the lowest pressure recorded locally is unknown. However, based on the pressure curve, it is estimated that the lowest pressure recorded in Basco may have reached 690 mmHg (920 hPa) or lower.

After passing Basco, the typhoon approached Taiwan, with Hengchun being the first to be affected. The pressure continued to drop. At 10 p.m. on August 26, Hengchun recorded a minimum hourly pressure of 702.9 mmHg (937.1 hPa) and a maximum 10-minute sustained wind speed of 34.4 meters per second. According to the Central Weather Bureau's path map, the typhoon did not make landfall in Hengchun but passed very close to its western coastal waters before possibly making landfall in southwestern Taiwan. At 4:45 a.m. on the 27th, Tainan recorded a minimum pressure of 726.8 mmHg (969 hPa) and a maximum 10-minute sustained wind speed of 38.2 meters per second (or 54.5 meters per second according to another source [Reference 2]), the highest sustained wind speed ever recorded in Tainan. Tainan's 24-hour rainfall on the 27th was 384.9 mm, ranking fourth in daily accumulated rainfall [Reference 1:81]. During the typhoon, Tainan's total rainfall was 423.8 mm, while Hengchun's total rainfall was 515.4 mm. The chief scientist at the Hengchun Weather Station stated that the typhoon's intensity was extremely strong, with almost no houses left undamaged. Unfortunately, the anemometer cups were blown away, so the maximum wind speed could not be recorded. However, he estimated that the maximum wind speed could have reached 70 meters per second.

After passing Taiwan, the typhoon moved northwest-north and made landfall in China. By August 28, its remnants were located southwest of Shanghai, moving northwest. On August 29, it moved west of Shanghai and dissipated inland.

79 houses were completely destroyed, 78 were severely damaged, and 366 were slightly damaged. 28 livestock and 62 small animals died, and 30 small boats were damaged. The buildings, public schools, monasteries, and churches in the historic town of Busuanga suffered severe damage. The church was blown down, leaving only bare walls. One-third of the houses made of sturdy materials were destroyed. The total estimated loss exceeded 50,000 pesos.

The typhoon caused severe flooding in the southern and northern regions, resulting in at least 290 deaths, 262 injuries, 23,601 houses completely destroyed, and 22,686 partially destroyed. Since most early buildings were made of wood, the Taiwan Governor-General's Office adopted brick and reinforced concrete for public building reconstruction plans after the disaster. For example, Taipei City experienced flooding due to the typhoon, with areas like Dadaocheng severely affected by collapsed houses. The government took this opportunity to implement urban improvement and street house reconstruction plans, introducing architectural and facade style elements from European architecture for street rebuilding. In 1912, the following year, areas such as Beidou, Nantou, and Daxi, which were affected by the typhoon and flooding, also drafted urban improvement plans. Tainan suffered severe damage from the storm. Preliminary statistics on building damage in the Fucheng area showed that 86 private houses were completely or partially destroyed, with many others flooded, and six warehouses damaged. Regarding public buildings, 80% of Tainan's administrative offices were damaged, including the Tainan Office Affairs Room, General Affairs Section, and the east and west markets. Historical sites such as the Five Sons Shrine of Chihkan Tower were damaged, and decorative ceramic figures on the roof of the Liangguang Guild Hall were peeled off. In the Anping area, nearly 200 houses were completely or partially destroyed, with two injuries and two deaths, and four ships capsized in the harbor. At that time, the largest market in Fucheng, the West Market, saw its entire first-generation wooden structure destroyed. Therefore, when rebuilding the West Market in 1912, durability was considered, and the most advanced R.C. construction method in Taiwan at the time was used to build three buildings, with the central building being two stories high. The storm also caused the Zhuoshui River railway bridge to be washed away, disrupting the north-south railway line.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Mindulle (International designation: 1005; JTWC: WP062010) was the fifth tropical cyclone to form in the 2010 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Mindulle" was provided by North Korea, meaning the dandelion flower. In Taiwan, it is translated as "Minduli."

As early as August 17, a broad low-pressure area formed northeast of Luzon, Philippines. At that time, this low-pressure area remained stationary in the Luzon Strait due to the influence of the high-pressure ridges over the western Pacific and southeastern China. On August 18, the high-pressure area over southeastern China weakened, and sudden rain began to appear in southern China, causing the system to start moving westward. However, it was also affected by strong vertical wind shear in the northern South China Sea, showing no signs of developing into a tropical cyclone. Despite this, the low-pressure area did not dissipate; instead, its storm circle continued to expand. Later, on August 20, the vertical wind shear affecting the northern South China Sea began to weaken, and the Japan Meteorological Agency classified the system as a tropical disturbance after it entered the South China Sea. By midnight on August 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, as it had already moved to the northern South China Sea near the Dongsha Islands. 

At 8 a.m. on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded the system to a tropical depression, as it was located about 670 kilometers south of Hong Kong, within the 800-kilometer range of Hong Kong. However, due to the weak intensity of the tropical depression and its storm circle being concentrated in the central South China Sea, it did not bring immediate severe weather to Hong Kong, only causing slight swells in the southern waters of Hong Kong. Therefore, the Hong Kong Observatory did not issue the Standby Signal No. 1. The United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified the system as a tropical depression in the afternoon of August 22, designating it as the sixth tropical cyclone warning (06W) issued in the western Pacific. 

On the morning of August 23, the system intensified into a tropical storm, named Pabuk, and was expected to generally move toward the Gulf of Tonkin. That evening, the Hong Kong Observatory and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded Pabuk to a severe tropical storm. On August 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for the system. On the morning of August 25, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and a low-pressure area, respectively.
This time, the landfall of Tropical Storm Pugongying did not cause any casualties in Vietnam.
The China Meteorological Administration stated that tropical storm Pugongying would slightly pass through some outer cloud systems and brush past Hainan Island before making landfall in Vietnam.

On the evening of August 23, during the bus hostage incident in Manila, the Philippine police's assault operation was indirectly affected due to the influence of the outer cloud system of Tropical Storm Kompasu.

At 8 a.m. on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded this low-pressure area to a tropical depression. At that time, it was already about 670 kilometers south of Hong Kong, within the 800-kilometer range of Hong Kong. However, due to the tropical depression's relatively weak intensity and its storm circle being concentrated only in the central South China Sea, it did not bring immediate severe weather to Hong Kong, only causing slight swells in the southern waters of Hong Kong. Therefore, the Hong Kong Observatory did not issue a tropical cyclone warning signal. However, under the influence of its outer rainbands, Hong Kong experienced showers in the following one or two days.

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Urd was a hurricane that hit Northern Europe on Christmas Day and Boxing Day, December 25 and 26, 2016. In Denmark, Norway, and the Faroe Islands, wind gusts in several places exceeded the hurricane threshold of 32.6 m/s, and on the Faroe Islands, the average wind speed was measured at 52 m/s. The wind came from Iceland and areas north of it. In the United Kingdom, it was named Storm Conor. In Germany, it was named Barbara, which should not be confused with another storm that passed over the British Isles. The storm was named by the Norwegian Meteorological Institute, which is why it was not given a male name starting with I, as it would have been if it had been named by DMI. On the Faroe Islands, Urd set a Faroese record for wind strength, as wind gusts of 78.7 m/s at Norðadalsskarð reached over double hurricane strength, while the average wind speed was 52 m/s. In Norway, Urd also exceeded hurricane strength at certain measuring stations. The highest measured wind speed in Norway was 53.3 m/s, recorded at Elvershei at the top of Røldal Ski Center at midnight on Boxing Day. In Scotland, an average wind speed of 44.2 m/s was measured at a weather station located at an altitude of 1,237 meters. The highest measured wind speed in Denmark was recorded in Thorsminde, where it reached 37.8 m/s in gusts.

In Denmark, Urd did not have the status of a hurricane, as the wind speed remained below the hurricane threshold of 32.6 m/s in sustained winds, although in some places it exceeded the threshold in gusts. Both the highest wind speed in sustained winds (over ten minutes) and gusts were measured in Thorsminde, where the recorded figures reached 29.4 m/s and 37.8 m/s, respectively. The wind speed was suitable for wind turbines, which meant that the electricity price was on average negative on both December 25 and 26. Urd caused no personal injuries but resulted in material damage, partly due to a storm surge that took several meters of the coastline. The Storm Council declared a storm surge in certain parts of the country on December 27, 2016. The storm surge caused rising water levels in several areas of the country. In the Limfjord, the water level reached 2.8 meters above normal, while on the west coast of Jutland, it reached as high as 3.4 meters. The area around Roskilde Fjord was also affected. In addition to material damage, Urd also impacted fishing, as it both prevented fishermen from going out to sea and displaced fish, resulting in fewer catches. The chairman of the fish traders estimated just before New Year that 10% of the normal catch was landed. This also affected cod prices, which were expected to double compared to the normal price. Both before and during Urd's impact, up to 1,500 people were on duty to minimize the damage. Urd caused flying debris and broken trees in North Jutland, where authorities advised against going outside due to the danger to life. In some places, scaffolding was at risk of collapsing. Additionally, Urd disrupted traffic, including cutting power to train lines on Zealand due to fallen trees, causing delays in Jutland, and canceling the ferry between Gedser and Rostock. However, overall, fewer damages occurred compared to Allan, Bodil, and Gorm. The Øresund Bridge was temporarily closed, and at other times, wind-sensitive vehicles were advised against crossing the Øresund Bridge, Svendborgsund Bridge, and Vejlefjord Bridge. Subsequently, 36 practice grenades were found at Jægerspris. They had been buried under the sand but were exposed by Urd. At Risø DTU, the water came within one meter of a building housing 5,000 barrels of nuclear waste. The building is located 2.43 meters above sea level and is the lowest-lying building in the area. The building was also at risk during Storm Bodil in 2013, when the water came within 40 cm of the building.

In western Norway, Urd has been a hurricane in several places, causing 10,000 households to lose power, trees to fall, and a roof to be blown off a house. In southern Norway, waves of up to 25 meters and elevated water levels in the Oslo Fjord were forecasted. Both road, ferry, and air traffic were affected and, in some places, canceled, and authorities advised against all unnecessary travel. Urd also reached hurricane strength in certain areas of Sweden, where SMHI issued a storm warning for the southwestern part of the country. In Gothenburg, the Älvsborg Bridge was closed. Between December 26 and 27, certain railway lines in southern Sweden were closed. Similarly, the ferry route to Frederikshavn was canceled. Swedish wind power plants set a record by producing 5.7 million kWh in one hour, compared to the usual 2.0-2.4 million kWh.

The Faroe Islands were hit by several hurricanes and storms around Christmas and New Year. It started with a storm on December 20, with hurricane-force gusts of at least 49 m/s.  
Hurricane Barbara hit the islands on Christmas Eve and lasted until midday on Christmas Day. The hurricane had an average wind speed of 30-40 m/s throughout the evening, and a gust at Norðadalsskarð of 70 m/s broke the record of 66.9 m/s, which was measured on March 7, 1997, at Mykines Lighthouse. The emergency center in Tórshavn received 256 reports of storm damage, most of them from Suðuroy. The hurricane caused central Faroe Islands and Klaksvík to lose electricity for about an hour late on Christmas Eve. Hurricane Urd hit the islands at midday on Christmas Day and lasted until the morning of the second day of Christmas, with an average wind speed of 52 m/s. Hurricane Urd caused significant damage to buildings, cars, and boats, and a woman was injured, breaking her leg when a gust of wind knocked her over. Klaksvík was severely affected, with several cars flying through the air. Roofs and house claddings were torn off several houses and flew through the air, causing even more damage. In the village of Kambsdalur in Eysturoy, an entire factory hall was torn from its foundation and flew through the air. The villages around Skálafjørður were also heavily affected by damage. In Tórshavn, there was also significant damage, as in several other places in the Faroe Islands. According to the Rescue Service in Tórshavn (Tórshavnar Sløkkilið), they received about 130-150 reports of damage in Tórshavn and central Faroe Islands, and they lost control of the situation as it was not possible to drive between all the villages. For example, a man in Norðadalur was alone in trying to save a building. A young woman from Runavík went into labor during the hurricane, and since it was not advisable to drive to the National Hospital in Tórshavn due to the bad weather, she had to give birth at home. However, a midwife and two porters braved the storm and drove to her home to assist with the birth, which went well. The radar installation on top of the Sornfelli mountain, built by NATO in 1963 for warning against attacks from the east by bombers, was heavily damaged during Hurricane Urd on the second day of Christmas. There are two domes on Sornfelli, both of which were damaged during the storm; one was completely torn from its foundation, while the other was damaged. The domes were established as an extension of the American/Canadian DEW-Line (Distant Early Warning Line). After the hurricane, the radar is inoperative and needs repair. There are 352 plates in each dome, and ten years earlier, each plate cost 24,000 kroner. The radar usually sends images of the airspace over the Faroe Islands to air traffic. The rescue organizations in the Faroe Islands, which are largely based on volunteers, had radio equipment inside the dome on Sornfelli that was blown away in the storm, and all their equipment was destroyed. It was a gift from the Netherlands and had a value of 400,000 kroner. For unknown reasons, it was not insured. It was also very windy on the night of December 28, and there was some damage, for example, part of the railing on the bridge over Sandá, which connects Tórshavn and Argir and opened earlier in the year, was torn loose. There were also reports of fallen trees and roofs being torn off. According to the police in the Faroe Islands, they received about 650 reports of damage in one week, while they usually receive about 800 reports in an entire year. On the evening of December 29, 2016, there was another hurricane in certain parts of the Faroe Islands, which came quite unexpectedly as no hurricane warning had been issued. There was more damage, including in Tvøroyri, where part of the roof blew off a pub by the harbor, as well as other damage to windows and house claddings in the central part of the town. There was also damage in Klaksvík, where a roof was torn off a house, and on the outskirts of Tórshavn, where a container was blown over a cliff and later ended up on a busy road leading from the capital to the northern part of the island of Streymoy. However, the police managed to close the road before half of the container tipped over the edge and onto the roadway. The police received over 20 reports of damage. In some places, gusts of wind were measured at 62.7 m/s, and the average wind speed was 43.4 m/s. Several of SEV's wind turbines in Húsahagi near Tórshavn and in Neshagi on Eysturoy were damaged during the Christmas hurricanes in 2016. One of the wind turbines in Neshagi measured wind speeds of up to 76 meters per second during the Christmas hurricanes. In the same location, during another hurricane, wind gusts of up to 82 m/s were measured. The Norwegian salmon farming company Marine Harvest's Faroese division had been experimenting with salmon farming at Sandsvág near the village of Sandur. It was still in the experimental stage when Hurricane Urd and the other hurricanes around Christmas hit the Faroe Islands. The company had two pens with 50,000 salmon in each pen, and the winter of 2016/17 was the first winter with salmon in the pens; before that, they had conducted measurements with empty pens. After the hurricanes around Christmas 2016, Marine Harvest found that the pens had withstood the hurricanes well, but the salmon had not; a significant portion of them had died. They therefore decided to slaughter the surviving salmon as well. There had been very high waves and strong ocean currents at Sandsvág during the hurricanes, which the salmon apparently could not tolerate. Marine Harvest planned to investigate further before deciding whether to continue with salmon farming at Sandsvág. On January 2, 2017, the two major insurance companies in the Faroe Islands reported that they had received approximately 2,400 claims for damages due to the Christmas hurricanes, which they estimated at around 45-50 million Danish kroner. Tryggingarfelagið Føroyar had received 1,700 claims, which they estimated would cost 30 million kroner, while Trygd had received 700 claims, which they estimated would cost 15-20 million kroner. However, it was too early to say exactly how extensive the damages were. By January 16, 2017, the number of damages from the Christmas hurricanes in the Faroe Islands had risen to 3,000 and was estimated to cost insurance companies 75 million kroner. The largest and most expensive damage occurred when a commercial building in Kambsdalur was torn from its foundation and blown away. Tryggingarfelagið Føroyar received a total of 2,335 claims for damages, which were estimated to cost between 40 and 45 million kroner, while the insurance company Trygd received a total of 1,011 claims for storm damages, which were estimated to cost over 30 million kroner to compensate.

Hurricane Urd was a hurricane that hit Northern Europe on Christmas Day and Boxing Day, December 25 and 26, 2016. In Denmark, Norway, and the Faroe Islands, wind gusts in several places exceeded the hurricane threshold of 32.6 m/s, and on the Faroe Islands, the average wind speed was measured at 52 m/s. The wind came from Iceland and areas north of it. In the United Kingdom, it was named Storm Conor. In Germany, it was named Barbara, which should not be confused with another storm that passed over the British Isles. The storm was named by the Norwegian Meteorological Institute, which is why it was not given a male name starting with I, as it would have been if it had been named by DMI. On the Faroe Islands, Urd set a Faroese record for wind strength, with gusts of 78.7 m/s at Norðadalsskarð reaching over double hurricane strength, while the average wind speed was 52 m/s. In Norway, Urd also exceeded hurricane strength at certain measuring stations. The highest measured wind speed in Norway was 53.3 m/s, recorded at Elvershei at the top of Røldal Ski Center at midnight on Boxing Day. In Scotland, an average wind speed of 44.2 m/s was measured at a weather station located at an altitude of 1,237 meters. The highest measured wind speed in Denmark was recorded in Thorsminde, where it reached 37.8 m/s in gusts.

In Denmark, Urd did not have the status of a hurricane, as the wind speed remained below the hurricane threshold of 32.6 m/s in sustained winds, although in some places it exceeded the threshold in gusts. Both the highest wind speed in sustained wind (over ten minutes) and gusts were measured in Thorsminde, where the recorded figures reached 29.4 m/s and 37.8 m/s, respectively. The wind speed was suitable for wind turbines, which meant that the electricity price was on average negative on both December 25 and 26. Urd caused no personal injuries but resulted in material damage, partly due to a storm surge that took several meters of the coastline. The Storm Council declared a storm surge in certain parts of the country on December 27, 2016. The storm surge caused rising water levels in several areas of the country. In the Limfjord, the water level reached 2.8 meters above normal, while on the west coast of Jutland, it reached as high as 3.4 meters. The area around Roskilde Fjord was also affected. In addition to material damage, Urd also impacted fishing, as it both prevented fishermen from going out to sea and displaced fish, resulting in fewer catches. The chairman of the fish traders estimated just before New Year that 10% of the normal catch was landed. This also affected cod prices, which were estimated to double compared to the normal price. Both before and during Urd's impact, up to 1,500 people were on duty to minimize the damage. Urd caused flying debris and broken trees in North Jutland, where authorities advised against going outside due to the danger to life. In some places, scaffolding was at risk of collapsing. Additionally, Urd disrupted traffic, including cutting power to train lines on Zealand due to fallen trees, causing delays in Jutland, and canceling the ferry between Gedser and Rostock. However, overall, there was less damage than during Allan, Bodil, and Gorm. The Øresund Bridge was temporarily closed, and at other times, wind-sensitive vehicles were advised against crossing the Øresund Bridge, Svendborgsund Bridge, and Vejlefjord Bridge. Subsequently, 36 practice grenades were found at Jægerspris. They had been buried under the sand but were exposed by Urd. At Risø DTU, the water came within one meter of a building housing 5,000 barrels of nuclear waste. The building is located 2.43 meters above sea level and is the lowest-lying building in the area. The building was also at risk during Storm Bodil in 2013, when the water came within 40 cm of the building.

In western Norway, Urd has been a hurricane in several places, causing 10,000 households to lose power, trees to fall, and a roof to blow off a house. In southern Norway, waves of up to 25 meters and elevated water levels in the Oslo Fjord were forecasted. Both road, ferry, and air traffic were affected and in some places canceled, and authorities advised against all unnecessary travel. Urd also reached hurricane strength in certain areas of Sweden, where SMHI issued a storm warning for the southwestern part of the country. In Gothenburg, the Älvsborg Bridge was closed. Between December 26 and 27, certain railway lines in southern Sweden were closed. Similarly, the ferry route to Frederikshavn was canceled. Swedish wind power plants set a record by producing 5.7 million kWh in one hour, compared to the usual 2.0-2.4 million kWh.

The Faroe Islands were hit by several hurricanes and storms around Christmas and New Year. It started with a storm on December 20, with hurricane-force gusts of at least 49 m/s.  
Hurricane Barbara hit the islands on Christmas Eve and lasted until midday on Christmas Day. The hurricane had an average wind speed of 30-40 m/s throughout the evening, and a gust at Norðadalsskarð of 70 m/s broke the record of 66.9 m/s, which was measured on March 7, 1997, at Mykines Lighthouse. The emergency center in Tórshavn received 256 reports of storm damage, most of them from Suðuroy. The hurricane caused central Faroe Islands and Klaksvík to lose electricity for about an hour late on Christmas Eve. Hurricane Urd hit the islands at midday on Christmas Day and lasted until the morning of the second day of Christmas, with an average wind speed of 52 m/s. Hurricane Urd caused significant damage to buildings, cars, and boats, and a woman was injured, breaking her leg when a gust of wind knocked her over. Klaksvík was severely affected, with several cars flying through the air. Roofs and house claddings were torn off several houses and flew through the air, causing even more damage. For example, a man in Norðadalur was alone trying to save a building. A young woman from Runavík went into labor during the hurricane, and since it was not advisable to drive to the National Hospital in Tórshavn due to the bad weather, she had to give birth at home. There are two domes on Sornfelli, both of which were damaged during the storm; one was completely torn from its foundation, while the other was damaged. The domes were established as an extension of the American/Canadian DEW-Line (Distant Early Warning Line). After the hurricane, the radar is inoperative and needs repair. The rescue organizations in the Faroe Islands, which are largely based on volunteers, had radio equipment inside the dome on Sornfelli that was blown away in the storm, and all their equipment was destroyed. It was a gift from the Netherlands and had a value of 400,000 kroner. For unknown reasons, it was not insured. It was also very windy on the night of December 28, and there were some damages, such as part of the railing on the bridge over Sandá, which connects Tórshavn and Argir and opened earlier that year, being torn loose. There were also reports of fallen trees and roofs being torn off. According to the police in the Faroe Islands, they received about 650 reports of damage in one week, while they usually receive about 800 reports in an entire year. Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Kompasu (International designation: 1611; Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP132016) was the 11th named tropical cyclone of the 2016 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kompasu" (コンパス) was used for the third time, previously in 2004 and 2010. This name, provided by Japan, refers to the constellation Circinus. Kompasu was the 7th tropical cyclone under the "monsoon gyre" and the 6th storm to pass close to Japan, classified as a typical tropical cyclone that transformed into an extratropical cyclone after passing Japan.

On August 16, 2016, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Guam. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W at 9 PM. On the evening of the 17th at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of the 18th at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," but the Japan Meteorological Agency subsequently declared it dissipated at 8 AM. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a tropical depression at 8 PM. On the morning of the 19th at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours from "low" directly to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it at 9:25 PM. On the 20th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm at 2 AM and assigned it the number 13W. Subsequently, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm at 8 AM, naming it Kompasu and assigning it the international number 1611. At 10 PM on the 21st, Kompasu made landfall in Kushiro City, Hokkaido. The Japan Meteorological Agency assessed it as having transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 2 AM the following day.
