Whole_Text.header: The impact of Typhoon Vicente on the Hong Kong and Macau regions
Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Vicente was the most severe storm to impact Hong Kong and Macau during the 2012 Pacific typhoon season. Vicente struck the Pearl River Estuary at peak intensity, becoming the most notable typhoon disaster in the region in over a decade. It prompted the Hong Kong Observatory to issue its first No. 10 Hurricane Signal in nearly 13 years and led the Macau Meteorological Bureau to hoist the No. 9 Signal, also for the first time in nearly 13 years. Since Vicente was closer to Macau, the decision of the Macau Meteorological Bureau not to hoist the No. 10 Signal sparked widespread controversy. In Hong Kong, the storm also led to a major uproar over a plastic pellet spill incident that was only revealed 10 days after the typhoon.

Vicente entered within 800 kilometers of Hong Kong as a tropical depression on the morning of July 21, moving rapidly westward at a speed of about 25 kilometers per hour, approximately 720 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. However, the Hong Kong Observatory did not issue a "Special Weather Alert," handling it differently compared to tropical cyclones Talim and Doksuri earlier that year. At 3:40 PM that day, the Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal, with Vicente located about 540 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. The Observatory stated that Vicente's organization was "relatively loose" at the time and that it was still some distance away from Hong Kong, making it unlikely to issue the No. 3 Signal that evening, though it would consider doing so the next day. 

Under the combined influence of an anticyclone over southern China and Vicente's subsiding air currents, Hong Kong experienced hot and hazy weather that day, with temperatures in most areas rising to 34 degrees Celsius or above, and some areas recording highs of 37 degrees Celsius. The Very Hot Weather Warning was in effect until 7:45 PM. The hot weather also triggered convective rain, with a strong thunderstorm area forming in eastern Guangdong and crossing Hong Kong at sunset, bringing thunderstorms to the region. The Observatory issued the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal at 5:35 PM, which remained in effect until 6:40 PM. As the thunderstorm area passed through Hong Kong, it brought brief strong gusts, with sustained wind speeds temporarily surging. Sai Kung, Kai Tak, and Cheung Chau recorded brief strong winds. However, as the thunderstorm area weakened suddenly while crossing Hong Kong, the heavy rain only brought 20 to 30 millimeters of rainfall to eastern Hong Kong, falling short of the Amber Rainstorm Warning standard. Only the eastern coast of Sai Kung experienced heavier rainfall, recording 40 millimeters. After the heavy rain, double rainbows appeared in some parts of Hong Kong. 

The strong gusts brought by the rainstorm caused a scaffolding structure on Wang Chin Street in Kowloon Bay, near the MTR Shatin to Central Link International Mail Centre, to collapse entirely. Additionally, over a dozen people kayaking, rowing, and surfing fell into the sea, but fortunately, there were no casualties. 

On July 22, Vicente continued to approach. The Observatory stated that it was unlikely to issue the No. 3 Signal in the morning but would consider doing so in the afternoon. Later, it revised its statement, saying it was unlikely to issue the No. 3 Signal in the afternoon but would consider doing so if Vicente moved closer or the winds strengthened. As Vicente's movement slowed and it stalled about 350 kilometers south-southeast of Hong Kong, the No. 1 Signal remained in effect throughout the day, and the Observatory did not issue the No. 3 Signal, postponing the decision to the morning of July 23. Following the earlier impact of Severe Tropical Storm Talim, the Observatory once again reminded parents to pay attention to storm updates before sending their children to school. 

The weather in Hong Kong remained hot that day, with widespread areas recording maximum temperatures of 32 degrees Celsius or above. However, Vicente's outer rainbands also brought squally showers and occasional thunderstorms to Hong Kong.

Whole_Text.header: Moving north and approaching, the weather is deteriorating.
Whole_Text.content:
As Vicente shifted to a more northerly direction and further intensified into a severe tropical storm, the Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 5:20 a.m. on July 23 [9], when Vicente was located about 320 kilometers south-southeast of Hong Kong [10]. The Observatory subsequently stated that the No. 3 Signal would be maintained during the day, and unless Vicente accelerated towards the coast of South China or further intensified, the chance of issuing the No. 8 Signal during the day was low. Winds in Hong Kong began to strengthen significantly in the morning, with strong northeasterly winds affecting widespread areas in the afternoon, and occasional gale-force winds affecting offshore and highland areas [11]. 

As Vicente accelerated north to northwest-northwest, the Observatory announced at 11:45 a.m. that the No. 8 Signal might be issued around dusk. With Vicente rapidly intensifying into a typhoon, the Observatory issued a "Special Weather Alert" at 2:05 p.m., stating that Vicente would pass within 200 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong, and the Observatory would consider issuing the No. 8 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. At this time, the weather in Hong Kong deteriorated rapidly, with squally showers and occasionally heavy rain. The Observatory issued a "Special Report on Tropical Cyclones" at 3:45 p.m., announcing that the No. 8 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal was expected to be issued by 6 p.m. or earlier. After 4 p.m., Cheung Chau, one of the eight designated automatic weather stations in the Observatory's wind measurement network, began recording gale-force winds [12]. 

Under the impact of strong winds, a giant tree over 20 meters tall collapsed in Siu Sai Wan, crushing a minibus [13]; in Central's Connaught Road Central, wooden boards were blown up by strong winds, injuring several pedestrians, one of whom was directly knocked unconscious by the boards.

The Observatory issued the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal at 5:40 PM, when Vicente was located about 170 kilometers south of Hong Kong. The Observatory predicted that Vicente would move northwest by west, passing about 150 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong, and stated that the No. 8 signal would be maintained during the evening. After the No. 8 signal was issued, foreign objects were found on the tracks at MTR Ngau Tau Kok Station and Mong Kok East Station, but as train services had already been reduced to limited service, there were only slight delays without significant disruption. Additionally, Kowloon Motor Bus announced at 8:40 PM that all routes would be suspended, and Citybus and New World First Bus also announced the suspension of most services. Winds in Hong Kong rapidly and significantly strengthened, and shortly after nightfall, many areas were already affected by gale-force winds from the east to northeast, with signs of further intensification.

At 8:45 PM on the same day, the Observatory stated that Vicente had slightly intensified and was taking a more northwesterly path, coming closer to Hong Kong. It was expected that Vicente would pass about 100 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. The Observatory further indicated that if winds in Hong Kong strengthened further, it might need to issue a higher tropical cyclone warning signal, urging the public to stay updated on the latest storm information. At 11:20 PM, the Observatory issued the No. 9 Gale or Storm Signal, when Vicente was located about 110 kilometers south-southwest of Hong Kong and had rapidly intensified into a severe typhoon. This was the first No. 9 signal in three years since Typhoon Molave directly hit Hong Kong in 2009. The Observatory noted that "in the past few hours, Vicente has rapidly intensified into a severe typhoon" and stated that Vicente was still taking a northerly path, approaching Hong Kong, and would pass within 100 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. However, it did not mention whether the No. 10 Hurricane Signal would be issued. This was also the first time in the Observatory's history that the term "rapidly intensified" was used, and it marked Vicente as the first severe typhoon under the Observatory's new tropical cyclone classification system to trigger the issuance of the No. 8 or higher signal.

Winds in Hong Kong further strengthened to storm force and shifted to blow from the east to southeast. In particular, wind speeds at Cheung Chau, Cheung Chau Beach, and Waglan Island exceeded 110 kilometers per hour, approaching hurricane force.

Whole_Text.header: East Rail Line paralyzed for 8 hours
Whole_Text.content: Approaching midnight, shortly after the No. 9 signal came into effect, the MTR switched from maintaining limited services to suspending services on elevated and ground-level sections. Limited services were maintained on the Kwun Tong Line (Yau Ma Tei to Choi Hung section; now Choi Hung to Whampoa section), Tsuen Wan Line (Lai King to Central section), Island Line (Sheung Wan to Heng Fa Chuen section; now Heng Fa Chuen to Kennedy Town section), and West Rail Line (Hung Hom to Tsuen Wan West section; now Tuen Ma Line Tsuen Wan West to East Tsim Sha Tsui section), while other sections were suspended. The incident originated from a tree collapse at Tai Po Market Station, which blocked the tracks and damaged cables, causing a power outage and an immediate paralysis of the East Rail Line. Even after repairs, services could not resume before the end of the operating hours. The Kwun Tong Line trains were also affected, with passengers causing a commotion at Choi Hung Station. Due to the power outage, some passengers were trapped on trains and had to spend the night in the carriages. Eight East Rail Line trains lost power, with one train experiencing a complete blackout in three carriages. Over a thousand passengers were affected, forced to stay overnight in train carriages and station halls. Meanwhile, other sections also experienced power trips, and power supply began to return to normal at 2:44 a.m. the next day, but by then, no trains were running. The MTR opened stations for passengers to rest, but passengers expressed strong dissatisfaction with the MTR's arrangements and criticized the lack of an earlier service suspension. The East Rail Line was paralyzed for nearly eight hours, and limited services were only restored south of Fo Tan Station at the scheduled first train departure time. Services north of Fo Tan Station remained suspended until 7:35 a.m. on July 24, when the fallen tree at Tai Po Market Station was cleared, allowing full service to resume.

Whole_Text.header: The No. 10 signal was first issued in 13 years.
Whole_Text.content: In the early hours of July 24, Vicente directly struck Hong Kong, with its eyewall coming very close to areas in the southwestern part of Hong Kong, such as Cheung Chau. Coupled with its increased movement speed of 20 kilometers per hour, it created a "semi-circle effect," placing Hong Kong in its "dangerous semi-circle." The automatic weather station at Cheung Chau Beach first recorded a maximum 10-minute average wind speed of 127 kilometers per hour at midnight, reaching hurricane levels. The main station at Cheung Chau also began intermittently recording hurricane-force winds after midnight, which later became sustained, with wind speeds surging to over 130 kilometers per hour. As the two near-sea-level automatic weather stations in Cheung Chau successively recorded hurricane-force winds, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 10 Hurricane Signal at 12:45 a.m. on July 24 without prior notice. At that time, Vicente was centered about 100 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters. This was the first No. 10 signal in nearly 13 years since Typhoon York struck Hong Kong in 1999, and the first "issued" rather than "hoisted" No. 10 signal since the closure of the Cheung Chau Signal Station. The Observatory stated that "Vicente's eyewall was very close to the southwestern part of Hong Kong, bringing hurricane-force winds to the area; frequent squalls and heavy rain were also affecting Hong Kong," and urged residents not to leave sheltered areas and to closely monitor broadcasts regarding tropical cyclone warnings. The Observatory also issued a landslip warning at 1:10 a.m., a yellow rainstorm warning signal and a special report on flooding in the northern New Territories at 1:55 a.m., along with a thunderstorm warning issued at 12:15 a.m., resulting in five warnings being in effect simultaneously. This was the first time since Typhoon Molave struck Hong Kong in 2009. Vicente was closest to Hong Kong between 1 a.m. and 2 a.m., passing about 100 kilometers southwest of the Observatory headquarters. Many areas in Hong Kong experienced gale to storm-force winds from the east to southeast, while the southwestern regions, offshore areas, and high grounds were continuously affected by hurricane-force winds.

As Vicente began to move away, Hong Kong was no longer affected by the typhoon. The Observatory issued the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal at 3:35 a.m. that day, with Vicente located about 120 kilometers southwest of the Hong Kong Observatory headquarters at the time. Hong Kong experienced southeast gales to storms. Vicente made landfall near Taishan and weakened into a typhoon. Winds in Hong Kong gradually subsided, and storm-force winds were no longer observed after sunrise, though strong winds continued to affect most areas. The Observatory announced at 7:45 a.m. that the No. 3 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal would be issued around 10 a.m., and by 10 a.m., winds in most areas had dropped below gale force. The Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 10:10 a.m., with Vicente located about 230 kilometers west of Hong Kong, having weakened into a severe tropical storm. At sunrise, fallen trees at Tai Po Market Station on the East Rail Line had not yet been cleared, and services on the section north of Fo Tan Station were suspended until around 7:35 a.m. Fallen trees also affected Light Rail services at San Hui Station, disrupting some routes. The Observatory canceled all rainstorm warnings at 10:40 a.m. As Vicente weakened and moved further away, winds across Hong Kong generally subsided, with most areas experiencing winds below strong wind levels except for offshore and highland areas. The Observatory announced at 1:45 p.m. that the No. 1 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal would be issued in the next one to two hours, and at 2:40 p.m., the No. 1 Standby Signal was issued, with Vicente located about 370 kilometers west of Hong Kong, having weakened into a tropical storm.

The Observatory stated at 6:45 PM that all tropical cyclone warning signals would be canceled when the winds in Hong Kong further weakened. Although the winds in the city had already eased at that time, offshore and highland winds remained strong, with the Cheung Chau automatic weather station still recording strong winds after nightfall. At 10:45 PM, the Observatory announced that Vicente's circulation no longer covered Hong Kong; under the combined influence of a high-pressure ridge over southeastern China and a broad monsoon trough, offshore and highland areas were still affected by strong winds. Finally, at 11:15 PM, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals, with Vicente located approximately 600 kilometers west-northwest of Hong Kong at that time. Due to the influence of the monsoon trough, offshore and highland winds remained strong, and the Observatory issued a Strong Monsoon Signal one minute later, which was canceled at 5:20 AM the following day. During the effective period of the Strong Monsoon Signal, winds in Cheung Chau remained at strong levels, and Sai Kung also recorded brief strong winds. Over the next two to three days, Hong Kong was intermittently affected by heavy rain due to the combined influence of Vicente's residual rainbands and the broad monsoon trough, with the Observatory issuing multiple Amber Rainstorm Warnings. By July 28, Vicente's residual low-pressure area and the broad monsoon trough dissipated, and a high-pressure ridge over southeastern China extended to the Guangdong coast, leading to gradually improving weather. 

The Observatory issued a press release on the day after Vicente dissipated (July 26, 2012), describing the rapid intensification of Vicente from a tropical storm to a severe typhoon within two days as "unprecedented" among tropical cyclones for which the No. 10 signal was issued. Over two months later, on October 5, 2012, the Observatory finally completed Vicente's report and uploaded it to its website, making it the tropical cyclone report that took the longest time to produce since Typhoon York, surpassing the time taken for Typhoon Dujuan in 2003 and Typhoon Nuri in 2008.

Whole_Text.header: The highest wind speed in over a decade.
Whole_Text.content: During Vicente's impact on Hong Kong, all eight designated automatic weather stations in the Observatory's wind measurement network recorded strong winds, with four stations recording gale-force winds, two recording storm-force winds, and one even recording hurricane-force winds. Both the No. 3 and No. 8 signals met the criteria. The measured wind speeds in many parts of Hong Kong were the highest since Typhoon York in 1999, with wind speed data from many automatic weather stations approaching records set by Severe Tropical Storm Becky in 1993 and Typhoon Ellen in 1983. Some automatic weather stations established in recent years even recorded record-breaking wind speeds. Based on the eight automatic weather stations in the revised tropical cyclone warning system of 2013, with Lau Fau Shan replacing Wetland Park, five stations recorded gale-force winds. This was the second time since the adoption of this wind measurement network that two stations recorded storm-force winds, the fourth time that widespread strong winds were recorded, and the fourth time the No. 8 signal met the criteria. The airport recorded a 10-minute average wind speed of 96 km/h, tying the record set during Typhoon York in 1999. Cheung Chau even recorded hurricane-force winds, marking the first time since the adoption of the wind measurement network in 2007 that a reference automatic weather station recorded hurricane-force winds. Except for the failures at Stanley Wong Ma Kok and Tap Mun stations, all automatic weather stations across Hong Kong recorded strong winds or higher, an unprecedented occurrence since the Observatory launched the "One District, One Station" initiative in 2007, which ensured at least one automatic weather station in each of Hong Kong's 18 districts, doubling the number of stations. During the storm, the highest 10-minute average wind speeds recorded at Cheung Chau, the airport, Kai Tak, Sai Kung, Tsing Yi, Wetland Park, Ta Kwu Ling, and Sha Tin were 140, 96, 85, 83, 52, 50, 47, and 47 km/h, respectively. In the southwestern regions of Hong Kong, offshore areas, and highlands, hurricane-force winds persisted, with Cheung Chau recording the highest 10-minute average wind speed of 140 km/h, the highest since Typhoon Ellen in 1983. The Cheung Chau Beach automatic weather station, operational since Typhoon Koppu in 2009, recorded a record-breaking 10-minute average wind speed of 127 km/h. Additionally, the exposed and elevated Ngong Ping recorded a 10-minute average wind speed of 197 km/h and a maximum gust exceeding 250 km/h before the anemometer malfunctioned. According to the Observatory's Vicente report, Ngong Ping recorded a maximum gust of 256 km/h. In Victoria Harbour, the automatic weather station at the Kowloon Star Ferry Pier recorded a 10-minute average wind speed of 87 km/h, approaching storm-force levels, with the highest hourly average wind speed reaching 83 km/h, both records being the highest since Typhoon Ellen in 1983. The Kai Tak automatic weather station recorded a 10-minute average wind speed of 85 km/h and a maximum hourly average wind speed of 70 km/h, the highest since Severe Tropical Storm Becky in 1993. Additionally, a weather enthusiast "chased the wind" at the Hung Hom Pier, where their anemometer recorded storm-force average wind speeds and gusts reaching hurricane-force levels of 152 km/h. Due to the exposure to easterly winds, Hung Hom Pier is a popular spot for weather enthusiasts to measure wind speeds.

Whole_Text.header: Over a hundred people injured, record-breaking tree collapse.
Whole_Text.content: During the storm, 138 citizens were injured and sought treatment at public hospital emergency rooms, making it the typhoon with the highest number of injuries since Typhoon York in 1999, which caused 2 deaths and 500 injuries. Among them, 72 people required hospitalization, and 268 people stayed at temporary shelters set up by the Home Affairs Department, fortunately with no fatalities. Additionally, the Development Bureau, Highways Department, and Leisure and Cultural Services Department received reports of 2 landslides, 7 flooding incidents, and 8,800 cases of fallen trees, with the number of fallen tree reports breaking records. During the period when the No. 10 signal was in effect, the Observatory also issued other warnings, including the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal, Landslip Warning, Thunderstorm Warning, and Special Flooding Report for Northern New Territories. This No. 10 signal was one of the farthest recorded instances of a tropical cyclone center from Hong Kong (Typhoon Vicente passed approximately 100 kilometers southwest of the Observatory headquarters) and was tied for the second shortest duration of a No. 10 signal (lasting 2 hours and 50 minutes), alongside Typhoon Elsie in 1975, second only to Typhoon Alice in 1961 (when the No. 10 signal lasted only 2.5 hours). Due to the impact of fallen trees and landslides, some sections of hiking trails had to be temporarily closed, including Section 7 of the Wilson Trail (near Shing Mun Reservoir), the Tai Lam Forest Track from Tsuen Kam Section to Tin Fu Tsai Section, Butterfly Garden, Section 10 of the Wilson Trail (from Sir Edward Youde Memorial Pavilion to Nam Chung), Beilou Road, Fung Hang Family Walk, the main and middle falls of Wu Tong Tsai, Kap Lung Ancient Trail, Tai Mong Tsai Cycling Track, and Barbecue Site No. 10 at Tai Mong Tsai.

Whole_Text.header: The glue disaster was concealed for 10 days before being revealed.
Whole_Text.content: During Typhoon Vicente's impact on Hong Kong, a Sinopec cargo ship anchored in southern waters had six containers blown into the sea, spilling six bags of chemical polypropylene pellets, totaling 150 tons, which spread across southern Hong Kong waters and beaches. However, the government and Sinopec did not disclose the incident. It was first discovered by a Discovery Bay resident involved in marine conservation and was only brought to public attention in early August through media reports, gaining widespread concern. Some fishing groups worried that the abundance of pellets in the waters might affect fisheries and urged the authorities to address the issue promptly. Starting from August 4, citizens and various environmental groups voluntarily brought tools to beaches like Discovery Bay to carry out "pellet cleanup" actions. Netizens referred to the incident as the "Hong Kong Pellet Disaster." Later that year, Typhoon Kai-tak hit Hong Kong, and after the No. 8 signal was raised, the pellet disaster also affected Macau.

Whole_Text.header: The initial stage of the storm is hot weather.
Whole_Text.content: Vicente entered within 800 kilometers of Macau on the morning of July 21, and the Macau Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Signal No. 1 at 6 p.m. that day [46], with Vicente located about 570 kilometers east-southeast of Macau at the time [47]. Since Vicente was still a tropical depression at the time, the bureau stated that the chance of hoisting Signal No. 3 that evening was low and would consider changing to Signal No. 3 the next day depending on the situation. Due to the anticyclone over South China and the subsiding airflow on the periphery of Vicente, Macau recorded a high temperature of 36 degrees Celsius that day, with the corresponding "temperature index" reaching the "orange heat" level for the first time that summer. Vicente strengthened into a tropical storm but slowed down on July 22. The bureau stated at 6 a.m. that the chance of hoisting Signal No. 3 in the morning was low [48]; later at 12 p.m., it stated that it would consider changing to Signal No. 3 in the afternoon depending on the situation [49], and again at 6 p.m., it announced that the consideration would be postponed to the evening [50]. The weather in Macau remained hot during the day, with a maximum temperature of 33 degrees Celsius, classified as the "yellow heat" level. As Vicente remained stationary, Signal No. 1 was ultimately maintained throughout the day, and the bureau stated that it would consider changing to Signal No. 3 on the morning of the 23rd [51].

Whole_Text.header: The weather is deteriorating, and the wind is strengthening.
Whole_Text.content:
As Vicente intensified into a severe tropical storm and moved northward, Signal No. 1 was maintained for over 36 hours. The Meteorological Bureau hoisted Signal No. 3 at 6:30 a.m. on July 23, when Vicente was located about 340 kilometers south-southeast of Macau. The bureau predicted that Vicente would slowly move northwest toward the western coast of Guangdong and stated that the chance of hoisting Signal No. 8 in the morning was low. During the day, Vicente moved northwest-northward, and Macau's weather rapidly deteriorated with strong winds and heavy rain. The wind also significantly strengthened, with strong winds prevailing across the region. As Vicente accelerated its approach, the bureau announced at 1 p.m. that it would consider hoisting Signal No. 8 before evening. Later, at 4 p.m., as Vicente intensified into a typhoon, the bureau stated that it would consider hoisting Signal No. 8 within a few hours. At 5:51 p.m., the bureau officially announced that Signal No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal would be hoisted at 7 p.m.

At 7 p.m., the Meteorological Bureau hoisted Signal No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal, with Vicente located about 160 kilometers south-southeast of Macau. Shortly after nightfall, strong northeast winds accompanied by heavy rain were observed in many areas. The bureau reported that the highest wind speed recorded at the Taipa Grande station reached 61 kilometers per hour. The three major bridges were intermittently affected by gale-force winds, leading to full closures, while the lower deck of the Sai Van Bridge was opened. At 8 p.m., the bureau reported that in the past hour, the highest average wind speed recorded at the Friendship Bridge was 63 kilometers per hour, while the highest gust recorded at the Taipa Grande station was 94 kilometers per hour. Vicente was expected to make a direct impact on Macau in the early hours of the following day, passing within 100 kilometers south of Macau. Signal No. 8 was expected to remain in effect for some time, with heavy rain and strong winds anticipated due to the rainbands.

At 9 p.m., the bureau reported that Vicente was approaching Macau further. In the past hour, the highest average wind speed recorded at the Friendship Bridge was 64 kilometers per hour, while the highest gust recorded at the Taipa Grande station was 100 kilometers per hour. By 11 p.m., Vicente was located about 100 kilometers south-southeast of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters, beginning to make a direct impact on Macau (passing within 100 kilometers of Macau). At that time, the wind in the region intensified sharply, with widespread areas experiencing easterly gales. The bureau reported that in the past hour, the highest average wind speed recorded at the Friendship Bridge exceeded 80 kilometers per hour, while the highest gust recorded at the Taipa Grande station exceeded 100 kilometers per hour. Due to the typhoon, Macau was expected to experience heavy rain and strong winds during the early hours, with minor seawater flooding possibly occurring in the Inner Harbor area. However, the bureau stated that Signal No. 8 would remain in effect until dawn, and unless the typhoon's center directly passed over Macau, the chance of hoisting a higher signal was low. At 10 p.m., the bureau also predicted minor seawater flooding in the Inner Harbor area but did not immediately issue a storm surge warning. It was not until flooding had already begun in the Inner Harbor that the bureau issued a Yellow Storm Surge Warning at 12:30 a.m. on July 24.

Whole_Text.header: The eye of the storm approaches, No. 9 signal hoisted for the first time in 13 years.
Whole_Text.content:
Although the Meteorological Bureau stated that if Vicente's eye did not pass over Macau, they would not consider issuing a higher storm signal, Vicente continued to strengthen on the evening of the 23rd, moving northwest and heading directly towards the vicinity of Macau, passing within 50 kilometers southwest of Macau. Macau was already enveloped by Vicente's storm and hurricane range. When Vicente moved to about 70 kilometers south of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters, wind speeds on two of Macau's three major bridges surged to hurricane levels, with the Friendship Bridge recording an average wind speed of over 85 kilometers per hour and maximum gusts exceeding 120 kilometers per hour. At 1:12 a.m. on the 24th, the Meteorological Bureau stated that Vicente would "further approach Macau within the next two to three hours," predicting a significant increase in wind strength in Macau and not ruling out the possibility of issuing a higher storm signal. At 1:47 a.m., the Meteorological Bureau finally announced that the No. 9 storm signal would be issued at 2:15 a.m.  

At 2:15 a.m., the Meteorological Bureau simultaneously issued the No. 9 storm signal and a red storm surge warning. At that time, Vicente was centered about 50 kilometers south-southwest of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters. The Bureau stated that, as wind speeds in Macau had exceeded 110 kilometers per hour in the past hour and Vicente's eye was further approaching Macau, the No. 9 storm signal was issued. The Friendship Bridge recorded an average wind speed of over 85.3 kilometers per hour and maximum gusts exceeding 123.5 kilometers per hour. Vicente became the first typhoon since Typhoon York in 1999 to directly hit Macau, nearly 13 years later, and the first time since Macau's return to China and the establishment of the Macau Special Administrative Region, as well as the first time in the 21st century, that the No. 9 storm signal was issued.  

Due to the combined effects of the storm surge and rising tides, severe flooding occurred in the areas of San Ma Lou and the Inner Harbor within an hour of the yellow storm surge warning being issued. The situation later worsened, with water depths exceeding 1 meter. Roads in the Inner Harbor area, such as the Water Market to San Ma Lou and the coastal streets of San Lei Tou, were closed, reaching the highest storm surge warning standard. However, the Meteorological Bureau did not issue a black storm surge warning. The instantaneous minimum pressure at the Taipa Grande station was 964.2 hPa (sea level pressure adjusted to 977.1 hPa), recorded at 2:29 a.m., less than 15 minutes after the No. 9 storm signal was issued. At that time, Vicente was centered about 45 kilometers south-southwest of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters.  

Vicente was closest to Macau at around 3 a.m., passing about 40 kilometers south-southwest of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters. Macau was directly swept by Vicente's eyewall. As Vicente began to directly hit Macau and before making landfall in Taishan, the city experienced widespread east to southeast gales, with all three major bridges briefly experiencing hurricane-force winds, with 1-minute average wind speeds exceeding 120 kilometers per hour. However, the Meteorological Bureau did not issue the No. 10 storm signal. At the same time, the region was hit by frequent heavy rain and strong winds, combined with rising tides and storm surge-induced seawater backflow, exacerbating the flooding situation in the Inner Harbor.

The Meteorological Bureau stated at 4 a.m. that after Vicente made landfall, they would consider lowering the storm signal. At 4:15 a.m., as Vicente made landfall along the coast of Taishan, Guangdong Province, the hurricane within Macau subsided. The No. 9 storm signal lasted less than three hours, and the Meteorological Bureau replaced it with the No. 8 southeast storm signal at 5 a.m. At that time, Vicente was located about 60 kilometers west-southwest of the Meteorological Bureau headquarters. The Bureau stated that the No. 8 southeast storm signal would remain for some time, but an hour later, they announced that they would consider replacing it with the No. 3 storm signal within two to three hours depending on the situation. After the tide receded, the inner harbor of Macau began to drain, and the Meteorological Bureau canceled all storm surge warnings directly at 6:30 a.m. By this time, the winds in Macau had slightly weakened and were no longer affected by the storm, but wind speeds remained at gale levels. 

As Vicente accelerated away, the Meteorological Bureau announced at 8 a.m. that they would consider replacing the signal with the No. 3 storm signal within one to two hours. At 8:45 a.m., they revised this to replacing it shortly. However, Macau was still within Vicente's gale range, and the winds had not yet further subsided. At 9:30 a.m., the Bureau replaced the signal with the No. 3 storm signal. At that time, Vicente was located about 140 kilometers west of Macau. However, Macau was still affected by gale-force winds, and the three major bridges continued to record sustained wind speeds of 70 kilometers per hour until noon. The Bureau stated that the No. 3 storm signal would remain for some time and later announced it would last at least until 5 p.m. However, at 4:20 p.m., the Bureau removed all storm signals. Due to the combined effects of Vicente's residual rainbands and a monsoon trough, Macau experienced unstable weather with occasional heavy rain for the next three days.

During the storm, a crane at a construction site in Taipa violently swayed and tilted 45 degrees, prompting firefighters and police to evacuate some residents of the Supreme Flower City and block four nearby roads. The developer stabilized the crane's base on the 27th and spent two days dismantling it. Additionally, an iron pillar on the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge was on the verge of collapse and required emergency removal. The bridge was only partially open to traffic starting at 7:30 PM on the 24th.  

During Vicente's impact on Macau, the Civil Protection Center received 254 incident reports, with 16 residents injured, mainly due to traffic accidents, falls, and being struck by falling objects, but fortunately, no fatalities occurred. Sixteen people were accommodated in disaster shelters. There was one power outage, nine cases of flooding, ten scaffolding collapses, four cases of swaying cranes, 61 fallen trees, 48 cases of aluminum windows falling, 25 cases of canopies falling, and 19 cases of advertising signs falling.  

The landscape lighting at the piers of the three Macau-Taipa bridges was severely affected by strong winds and waves as high as five to six meters. Many spotlights had shattered glass, detached brackets, or were swept away entirely by the waves. Brackets, electrical conduits, and other components were scattered, and electrical boxes were water-damaged. Out of the original 2,500 spotlights, 250 were completely destroyed or lost and required new installations, while over 700 needed component replacements. The Friendship Bridge, being in the most exposed position, suffered the most damage, with 180 new spotlights installed and 460 requiring part replacements out of the original 1,100.  

Additionally, part of the roof of Arena A at the Macau East Asian Games Dome was lifted, causing leaks. In the residential complex "One Oasis," windows in 20 units shattered, and residents had to use boards to shield against wind and rain, but these measures were unsuccessful.

During Vicente's impact, Macau recorded the highest wind speeds in over a decade across widespread areas, following Typhoon York and even the severe tropical storm Becky in 1993. Based on hourly average wind speeds, all 10 automatic weather stations in Macau recorded strong winds, with five stations recording gale-force winds. The Taipa Grande station, where the Meteorological Bureau headquarters is located, recorded an hourly wind speed of 83 km/h, the highest since York's direct impact, which recorded 108 km/h. All three major bridges recorded sustained wind speeds exceeding 100 km/h, with Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge, Sai Van Bridge, and Friendship Bridge's northern peak recording 115, 114, and 106 km/h, respectively. Based on 1-minute average wind speeds, seven stations recorded gale or storm-force winds, with the three bridges averaging 132, 125, and 122 km/h, respectively. Despite incomplete data due to network congestion, it was confirmed that all three bridges were affected by hurricane-force winds. Notably, the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge and Friendship Bridge recorded sustained 1-minute average wind speeds exceeding 130 km/h and 120 km/h at 1:00 a.m. and 1:10 a.m., respectively, indicating that the 10-minute average wind speeds also reached hurricane levels. The total rainfall recorded at various Macau rain stations during the storm is as follows: After the Meteorological Bureau canceled all storm signals the next day, Macau continued to be affected by Vicente's rainbands. The Meteorological Bureau issued a heavy rain warning signal at 3:10 a.m. on July 25 and canceled all heavy rain warnings at 5:00 a.m. The daily rainfall recorded at Taipa Grande, Mount Fortress, Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park, Coloane substation, and Ka Ho sewage treatment plant on that day was 115.0, 135.8, 138.4, 132.4, 117.0, and 116.0 mm, respectively, marking the highest daily rainfall since July 2001. After Vicente's impact, the Meteorological Bureau temporarily suspended the publication of real-time observation data from the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge wind speed station on its website. The bureau stated that the station's fixed bracket was damaged during the storm, and to ensure traffic safety on the bridge, the station's operations were temporarily halted. Subsequently, the wind speed station was repaired during routine maintenance work on the bridge, and real-time data from the Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge wind speed station was re-released on October 25, 2013.

The performance of the Meteorological Bureau in handling Vicente was criticized for being slow to respond, with a significant difference compared to the neighboring Hong Kong Observatory, leading to widespread controversy and criticism. Macau Meteorological Bureau Director Fong Soi Kun later stated that Vicente's movement path was highly variable, affecting the bureau's ability to forecast the typhoon, as it was a type of typhoon encountered only once in over a decade. He admitted that the ability to forecast such types of typhoons is relatively weak because the wind conditions need to be assessed before deciding on the relevant storm signal, making it impossible to provide an accurate time for signal changes. However, he emphasized that the timing of the signal change this time was appropriate, though there was a deviation in the storm surge forecast. He also believed that Macau's typhoon forecasting mechanism and expression methods are similar to those of Hong Kong, attributing the issue to language communication problems that led to some residents being unable to accurately grasp storm information, and welcomed suggestions from the public to the bureau.

Whole_Text.header: Typhoon Signal No. 8 warning is too short.
Whole_Text.content: The Meteorological Bureau stated at 4 p.m. on the 23rd that it was considering issuing the No. 8 typhoon signal within a few hours. At 5:51 p.m., it officially announced that the No. 8 typhoon signal would be hoisted at 7 p.m. At that time, the Hong Kong Observatory had already issued the No. 8 signal for more than 10 minutes. The Meteorological Bureau was accused of being "a step behind" Hong Kong, leading to a decline in its credibility. Additionally, the warning time was only slightly more than one hour, coinciding with the busy rush hour, causing traffic paralysis in Macau. Traffic jams occurred across all districts in Macau for several hours, with residents taking three times longer than usual to get home. Macau Legislative Assembly member Lam Heong Sang criticized the untimely forecast and lack of consideration for the public, suggesting that the authorities extend the warning time to two hours or more (in line with the Hong Kong Observatory's "Special Tropical Cyclone Warning Bulletin"). Crisis teams from various departments were also criticized for acting independently, resulting in low response efficiency and a complete failure of the emergency mechanism. Many areas in the city reportedly had no traffic police on duty, leaving no one to direct traffic, and some vehicles took the opportunity to drive against traffic, creating dangerous situations. Macau Meteorological Bureau Director Fong Soi Kun pointed out that on the evening of the 23rd, Vicente was closer to Hong Kong than to Macau. He stated that typhoons and heavy rain would inevitably cause inconvenience to residents, but the bureau prioritizes ensuring public safety. On August 14, the Meteorological Bureau announced that it would adjust its wording, considering that terms like "in the next few hours" could lead to differences in understanding depending on when the public receives the information. They would replace such terms with "around a certain number of hours." However, they did not immediately adopt Lam Heong Sang's suggestion to extend the official warning time to two hours or more. It was not until four years later, during Typhoon Haima, that a No. 8 typhoon signal warning exceeding two hours was issued for the first time.

During the storm, Macau experienced the largest storm surge since Typhoon Ketsana's direct hit in 2009, with severe flooding in the Inner Harbor area caused by seawater backflow, reaching depths of over 1 meter, meeting the criteria for a black storm surge warning. However, the Macau Meteorological Bureau did not issue the highest storm surge warning. Additionally, the bureau delayed issuing yellow and red storm surge warnings. Although a minor seawater backflow was forecasted on the evening of the 23rd, the yellow storm surge warning was not issued until 12:30 a.m. on the 24th. By around 1 a.m., severe flooding had already occurred in the Inner Harbor, New Road, and the area near Rua da Praia do Manduco, leading to full road closures. However, the red storm surge warning was only issued at 2:15 a.m. when the No. 9 typhoon signal was hoisted. Many businesses suffered significant losses due to water damage to their goods, and the bureau faced criticism for ambiguous information about seawater backflow, with the storm surge notification mechanism being deemed ineffective for early warnings. Afterward, Director Fong Soi Kun stated that the forecasting models from major meteorological centers indicated only minor flooding, and there was a deviation in the release of storm surge information, failing to meet the original goal of issuing warnings six hours in advance. He later mentioned that the storm surge warning system was introduced in 2009 and had not been implemented frequently, resulting in a lack of experience.

Whole_Text.header: Late hoisting of signal number 9 and refusal to hoist signal number 10.
Whole_Text.content:
The Macau Meteorological Bureau hoisted the No. 9 typhoon signal at 2:15 a.m. on the 24th, while the Hong Kong Observatory had already issued the No. 10 hurricane signal for an hour and a half, resulting in a temporary two-level tropical cyclone warning difference between Hong Kong and Macau. Macau's three bridges recorded a one-minute average wind speed exceeding 118 km/h starting at 1 a.m., and subsequent reports showed that the average wind speed over the past hour at 2 a.m. reached level 11, highlighting the delay in hoisting the No. 9 signal. Many netizens in discussion forums criticized the Meteorological Bureau for dereliction of duty, demanding the resignation of Director Fong Soi-kuan. Hong Kong netizens joined the discussion, accusing the Macau Meteorological Bureau of "not hoisting the No. 10 signal when it should, and hoisting it when it shouldn't," mocking that during Fong Soi-kuan's tenure, there was no need to hoist the No. 10 signal because "it would take over a decade or even 20 years to encounter a typhoon eye passing through," thereby criticizing Macau's stricter criteria for the highest typhoon signal compared to Hong Kong, which only requires hurricane-level winds recorded at any sea-level location within its territory.

Several members of Macau's Islands Community Advisory Committee also criticized the Meteorological Bureau for misjudgment, pointing out that the typhoon's path suggested Macau should have been more affected than Hong Kong, forming a stark contrast with the Hong Kong Observatory's issuance of the No. 10 hurricane signal. They questioned the standards used by the Meteorological Bureau to determine typhoon signals and urged a review of the tropical cyclone warning mechanism. Director Fong Soi-kuan responded that the standards for hoisting the No. 10 signal in Macau and Hong Kong are different. In Macau, in addition to an average wind speed of 118 km/h, the typhoon center must also pass through Macau. The highest recorded average wind speed this time was 115.2 km/h, which falls within the range of the No. 8 signal. The No. 9 signal was hoisted due to the severe impact caused by Vicente's approach, but the conditions for hoisting the No. 10 signal were not met.

Later, Director Fong Soi-kuan explained, along with unofficial analyses, that generally, the closer Macau is to a tropical cyclone, the stronger the local winds. However, unlike Hong Kong, Macau was not affected by continuous strong rainbands, which could have further intensified the winds through downbursts accompanied by heavy rain. Additionally, Vicente's eyewall had a gap, and when it was closest to Macau, this gap rotated over Macau, placing it between the eyewall and the stronger spiral rainbands. As a result, Macau did not experience the full impact of the eyewall, and the hurricane conditions within Macau were not as sustained as those in Hong Kong's Cheung Chau, leading to the discrepancy in signals between the two regions. Due to Hong Kong's larger area compared to Macau, the chance of recording hurricane-level winds at any sea-level location in Hong Kong is higher than in Macau, which also increases the likelihood of the Hong Kong Observatory issuing the highest signal compared to the Macau Meteorological Bureau. Some netizens also believed that the Meteorological Bureau had no intention of hoisting the No. 9 signal and only did so "reluctantly" when Vicente was just 50 km away from Macau and all three bridges recorded hurricane-level winds.

Eventually, five years later, Typhoon Hato forced the Meteorological Bureau to hoist the No. 10 signal, leading to Fong Soi-kuan stepping down and facing disciplinary action the following year. Subsequently, the Meteorological Bureau revised the criticized overly strict criteria for issuing the No. 10 signal, adopting a more lenient standard based on a 10-minute average wind speed and no longer requiring the typhoon center to pass over Macau.

Whole_Text.header: Hoist the No. 3 typhoon signal too early.
Whole_Text.content: The Meteorological Bureau hoisted the No. 3 signal at 9:30 a.m. on the 24th, 40 minutes earlier than the Hong Kong Observatory, which was farther from the storm center at the time, issued the No. 3 tropical cyclone warning signal. A similar situation occurred during Typhoon Koppu's direct hit in 2009, leading to further criticism of the Meteorological Bureau. Some citizens complained that the bureau was too quick to hoist the No. 3 signal, leaving insufficient time to prepare for work, while others felt the timing was appropriate. Director Fong Soi-kuen stated that the decision to hoist the No. 3 signal at 9:30 a.m. that day was correct. Subsequently, Macau's average wind speed was below 63 kilometers per hour, necessitating a lower signal. The Meteorological Bureau predicted that gusts in the city would reach 60 kilometers per hour in the afternoon, and up to 70 kilometers per hour on the bridge.

Article_Name: 熱帶低氣壓WP012017 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Depression WP012017 (Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Auring, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP012017) was the first tropical cyclone to form in the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. This low-pressure area formed east of the Philippines, developed into a tropical depression the following day, and made landfall in the Philippines on the 8th. It weakened into a low-pressure area due to wind shear, terrain, and the northeast monsoon, with its movement becoming slow. Its residual cloud bands later reorganized and moved southeast of Vietnam but weakened and dissipated again under the influence of the northeast monsoon.

On January 5, 2017, a low-pressure area formed in the southeastern waters off Mindanao, Philippines. The United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 96W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 PM the following day. At that time, the easterly flow of the subtropical ridge guided the system westward at a speed of about 15 kilometers per hour, approaching central Philippines. However, strong vertical wind shear suppressed its development, leaving the system loosely organized with an exposed low-level circulation center. Nevertheless, the abundant latent heat supplied by the waters of the Northwest Pacific allowed the system to develop slowly. As the system gradually consolidated and began to rotate on the 7th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" at 8 AM and simultaneously issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 9 AM, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center followed suit at 5 AM on the 8th, assigning it the tropical cyclone number "01W." The Hong Kong Observatory followed at 6:45 PM.

Computer models consistently predicted that the low-pressure system would sweep across the Philippines and then move into the southern South China Sea, eventually making landfall in Vietnam. The system continued westward, approaching central Philippines, ultimately making landfall on Siargao Island. It then moved into a weak point of the subtropical ridge, becoming trapped in a saddle-shaped pressure field, which slowed its movement. Although the saddle field provided good low-level convergence, the terrain of the Philippines had a greater-than-expected impact on the system, cutting off its moisture supply for an extended period, causing signs of cloud dissipation. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning at 5 PM, and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded the system back to a low-pressure area at 8 AM on the 10th. Its remnants later moved into the southern South China Sea via the Sulu Sea.

The system absorbed energy from the South China Sea and attempted to re-strengthen, successfully resisting strong vertical wind shear and gradually repairing its low-level circulation center, which also expanded significantly. The Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression at 2 AM on the 11th. However, as vertical wind shear increased, its intensity weakened, and its cloud clusters dissipated. The Japan Meteorological Agency subsequently downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 AM. Later, the system reorganized, and a more robust cloud cluster reappeared on satellite imagery. The Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression again at 4 PM. On the 12th, increased vertical wind shear caused the system's cloud bands to be significantly separated, leaving the low-level circulation center fully exposed and creating a convection void. By the 13th, convection erupted again around the low-level circulation center as the system attempted to repair itself, but there were no signs of the center being covered by cloud bands, and the low-level circulation center remained exposed. On the same day, the system became trapped in a saddle-shaped pressure field near Vietnam and slowly drifted northward. This was due to the subtropical ridge being unable to extend westward under the influence of another low-pressure area. Absorbing energy from the sea, the system strengthened again, prompting the Joint Typhoon Warning Center to assess its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "medium" at 1 AM on January 14. The rating was further upgraded to "high" at 8:30 AM, and a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert was issued simultaneously. By the 15th, decreasing wind shear created more favorable conditions for the system to absorb energy from the sea and repair its low-level circulation center. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical depression at 9 AM. However, the strong winter monsoon moved southward on the 16th, weakening the system again, causing its cloud clusters to dissipate and convection to vanish. The system then made landfall in Dam Doi District, Ca Mau Province, Vietnam. After landfall, the system was disrupted by terrain, making its low-level circulation center difficult to identify. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 PM that day. Its remnants later moved into the Gulf of Thailand but failed to reorganize. The Hong Kong Observatory's isobaric weather chart at 2 AM on the 17th showed that the system had dissipated.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded 01W to a tropical depression at 11 a.m. on the 7th and named it Olin. Due to Olin's proximity to the Philippines, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration immediately issued Signal No. 1. Olin made landfall on Siargao Island, bringing heavy rain and strong winds, reaching gale-force levels. However, Olin later moved slowly over the Philippines and eventually weakened into a low-pressure area, prompting the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration to cancel the Signal No. 1 warning that had been in effect for two days. Nevertheless, the remnants of Olin's low-pressure system continued to bring unstable weather and heavy rain to the Philippines, resulting in the drowning of a 15-year-old girl named Villaflores in Cebu Province on her way to school (despite classes being suspended).
Although the circulation of 01W did not directly affect Hong Kong, it caused the Quiming effect, bringing a few showers to Hong Kong during the nights and early mornings of the 13th to 16th.

Whole_Text.content: In mid-December 1951, an unusually intense storm of wind and rain struck Israel. The storm, which lasted about 11 consecutive days, affected most parts of the country except for the southern Negev and caused widespread flooding and significant property damage. Particularly severe damage was inflicted on dozens of immigrant transit camps across the country as well as on the city of Tel Aviv-Jaffa, where several neighborhoods were flooded.

The unusual storm began on December 13, 1951, and lasted until December 24, 1951. The strong winds (at speeds of up to 80 kilometers per hour) toppled and uprooted hundreds of tents and temporary housing structures in transit camps, felled thousands of trees, roof tiles, shutters, and billboards, and severed electricity and telephone lines across the country. In Tel Aviv alone, more than 2,000 telephone lines were damaged. Due to the flooding, buildings in older settlements were damaged and even collapsed, and transportation connections to dozens of settlements were cut off for an extended period. Roads were also blocked due to fallen trees. Thousands of residents were evacuated from their homes. In the first days of the storm, the Galilee, the central region, the Judean Hills, and Jerusalem were primarily affected. On December 18 and afterward, the storm severely impacted many settlements in the central region and Tel Aviv. In some places, between 5% and 20% of the average annual rainfall fell in a single day. The peak was in Rishon Lezion, where 174 millimeters of rain fell on December 20. By December 24, the amount of rain in Rehovot and Lod exceeded the annual average: in Rehovot - 562 millimeters (annual average 495) and in Lod 513 millimeters (annual average 505). In Tel Aviv, 12 consecutive days of rain until December 24 brought an amount of rain equivalent to 75% of the city's average annual rainfall.

The storm's impact was particularly severe on dozens of transit camps across the country because their residents lived in tents and various lightweight structures that were not built to withstand the strength of the winds. The drainage infrastructure in the camps was also far from sufficient. The wind uprooted tents, blew away tin shacks, and even overturned huts. Residents of the tents and structures that were lost lost a significant portion of their belongings. It was necessary to evacuate thousands of families from the camps who had lost their homes. They were housed in public buildings in established settlements. Hundreds of children from the camps were transferred for the winter to cooperative agricultural settlements. Hundreds were absorbed into youth immigration institutions. In the northern region, the Tzemach and Osherat transit camps were affected, with part of Osherat flooded and its residents moved to Nahariya. From the Nahariya transit camp, 400 families were evacuated. On December 21, the Nahariya transit camp was flooded again after its residents had already returned to it. In Haifa and its surroundings, the Neve David, Kiryat Amal, and Tira transit camps were affected, with a strong water flow hitting Tira on the 20th of the month. Some of their residents were evacuated to public buildings and nearby settlements. From the Tira transit camp alone, 200 families were evacuated. In the central region, many transit camps were affected, including Agrobank, Beit Lid, Netanya, Jalil (near Herzliya), Petah Tikva, Hiriya, Bnei Brak, Sakiya B, Holon, Rishon Lezion, and Rehovot. Transit camps established in low-lying areas particularly suffered from severe flooding. Thus, on December 20, the Rishon Lezion transit camp, established within a stream channel, was severely affected. On the same day, the Petah Tikva transit camp turned into a water lake. About 2,000 residents were moved from it to public buildings in Petah Tikva. The Hiriya and Rehovot transit camps were completely flooded. After the flooding on the 20th of the month, about 1,300 residents were evacuated from Hiriya to Tel Aviv, and about 1,000 were moved to Ramat Gan. In Jerusalem and its surroundings, at least seven transit camps were affected, including Talpiot, Mekor Haim, Nes Harim, Aminadav, and Qatra (near the Staf). The road to the Alar and Dir al-Hawa transit camps in the Jerusalem corridor was blocked on December 13, and since then, there was no connection between them and the outside world, with their residents subsisting on emergency food rations. On December 16, jeeps carrying food supplies set out for them, but they sank in the mud, and only the next day did their cargo reach the camps on foot. The road to the Mekor Haim transit camp was disrupted for about ten days due to road flooding, and food supplies were brought to it by mules. On December 23, several temporary structures in the Talpiot transit camp collapsed. On December 17, it was reported that by that day, 900 out of 11,000 tents in the transit camps had been severely damaged. On December 24, the Jewish Agency, which was responsible for the transit camps, announced that about 5,000 people had been evacuated from them during the storm, and another 7,000 children had been evacuated and housed in cooperative agricultural settlements, youth immigration institutions, and women's organizations. On the same day, hundreds of transit camp residents returned to their homes.

Whole_Text.header: Assistance operations for the transit camps
Whole_Text.content: The authorities, Jewish Agency workers, police officers, and IDF soldiers provided assistance to those affected in the transit camps during the stormy days and helped evacuate them to temporary housing. On December 20, hundreds of volunteers, including workers from the Histadrut and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, went to work in the transit camps. Dozens of Histadrut buildings were made available to the evacuated residents of the camps. Assistance efforts in the transit camps intensified on December 22 after the weather improved. It was decided to delay the return of residents to the camps as a precaution. Some were relocated to schools, where classes were therefore not held. About a thousand volunteers from Tel Aviv went on December 23 to nearby transit camps to provide assistance. Among them were workers from the Jewish Agency, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Maccabi, women's organizations, youth organizations, the inter-kibbutz seminar, and other institutions. Members of Kibbutz Givat Brenner worked overnight to transfer 200 children from the nearby transit camp to the kibbutz. In Kfar Saba, local residents went out to assist with repairs in the neighboring transit camp. A plan to house children from the Qatra transit camp near Jerusalem (now Even Sapir) in the nearby Monastery of St. John in the Wilderness was canceled at the last moment due to concerns about the reaction of religious parties, and the children were transferred to Kiryat Anavim the following day. On December 24, work groups went out to carry out repairs in the transit camps of Petah Tikva, Saqiya, Hiriya, Givat Brenner, Rehovot, Rishon Lezion, Magdiel, and Kfar Ono. The residents of the transit camps protested against the harsh living conditions they were forced to endure. On December 24, about a thousand transit camp residents demonstrated in front of the Jewish Agency offices in Tel Aviv to protest the living conditions in the camps. The police arrived at the scene to secure the offices. In at least one incident, on December 15, transit camp residents threw stones at cars in Emek Hefer. In one of the camps, the camp manager was beaten by residents.

On December 13, the storm hit the Galilee. The waters of the Jordan River rose to the point where it could not be crossed. Farms in the Hula Valley were damaged. The kibbutzim Amir, Kfar Blum, and Sde Nehemia faced the threat of flooding after the drainage canals dug in the valley failed the test. The water flow in the Hula area rose to 120 cubic meters per hour - four times the normal rate. The storm burdened ships sailing in the Mediterranean Sea. On December 14, a Turkish cargo ship sank near the port of Haifa. At least two of its crew members perished. In the northern coastal plain and the Haifa Bay area, very large areas were flooded. Kibbutz Ein HaMifratz was flooded, as well as an area in the moshav Bustan HaGalil. Damage was caused to fruit orchards and vegetable fields. Train traffic between Haifa and Nahariya was disrupted. Work at the Haifa port was halted on December 18 due to the storm. On the same day, water flooded basements and sites near the coast in Haifa, including municipal facilities. The areas of Shal Bridge and Hof Shemen were particularly affected. Houses were flooded in the neighborhoods of Wadi Rushmiya, Halisa, and Arad al-Raml. In some places, water accumulated to a height of one meter. Urgent pumping and drainage operations were required. During the night between December 18 and 19, firefighters and municipal workers responded to dozens of calls for help due to the flooding. The Haifa-Acre road was flooded by the overflow of the Naaman River. The road to Tel Aviv was also flooded near Atlit and was temporarily closed to traffic.

On the night between December 20 and 21, thousands of dunams of agricultural land in the Hefer Valley were flooded due to the overflow of the Alexander River, causing significant damage. That same night, a populated area of 10 dunams in central Netanya was flooded. The entrance to the city was blocked by water. On December 24, transportation between Petah Tikva, Ramat Gan, and Rosh HaAyin was cut off. The largest flooded area in Petah Tikva was in the legendary Paja neighborhood. In Rishon LeZion, several houses faced the risk of collapse due to the flooding. The road to the village of Betania near Ashdod was cut off by water on the 21st of the month, and it was necessary to send planes to drop food supplies to its residents.

Tel Aviv-Jaffa suffered severe damage during the stormy days, mainly due to the Ayalon River overflowing its banks on three different occasions. The river first overflowed on December 15, flooding several streets in the city. It overflowed again on the night between December 20 and 21, flooding fields and streets. The neighborhoods adjacent to the river—Hatikva, Ezra, Shapira, Montefiore, Nahalat Yitzhak—were flooded and cut off from the rest of the city. The water flooded basements, stairwells, and apartments on the lower floors of buildings. Hundreds of families were evacuated during the night, and some residents had to flee their homes to avoid drowning. The water level in the Montefiore neighborhood reached over a meter, requiring the use of boats from the Tel Aviv port and the navy to evacuate residents. Rescuers operated in the flooded neighborhoods with dedication, even risking their own lives. On the night of December 20, the neighborhoods of Nouzha, Sakhnat Darwish, and Givat Aliya in Jaffa were also affected. Hundreds of residents were evacuated from dilapidated buildings in Jaffa to public buildings. The Tel Aviv municipality provided clothing and food to the evacuees, and donations were collected from the public for this purpose. On the morning of December 21, the situation in Tel Aviv worsened further: the area from Sarona to the Gali Gil pool turned into a lake, and several cars and buses were stranded and flooded. The city center was also flooded, and transportation there was severely disrupted. The bridges over the Ayalon River and the Yarkon River, as well as buildings in the exhibition grounds, were flooded. That morning, all transportation routes to Tel Aviv were cut off except for the road to Jerusalem. Hundreds of cars in the city were damaged by rainwater intrusion. Hundreds of telephone lines were out of service due to water damage. School classes were canceled. Residents of the flooded neighborhoods in Tel Aviv returned to their homes on the 22nd of the month and found extensive destruction after the water rose to a height of a meter or more. In many homes, all the contents were ruined. On the night between December 23 and 24, the Musrara River overflowed its banks for the third time. The neighborhoods adjacent to the river were flooded again. Those who had already returned to their homes there had to evacuate once more. Six hundred people were evacuated from the neighborhoods during the night, some by boats, and were housed in schools. The Yarkon River did not overflow its banks. Some access roads to and from Tel Aviv, including to Ramat Gan, Netanya, and Rishon Lezion, as well as the railway line to Haifa, were blocked by water. In the large area of Jaffa, a two-story building collapsed. Damage was caused to the Sarona Bridge, La Guardia Bridge, and the Hatikva neighborhood bridge. On the morning of December 24, the water level in the Musrara River began to recede, and the storm subsided significantly. The damage caused by the flooding to the neighborhoods of Tel Aviv was estimated at half a million liras. An inspection of the houses in the flooded neighborhoods found that ten houses needed to be demolished immediately, and repairs were required in dozens of other houses before they could be used for living again. Many residents of the flooded neighborhoods lost all their belongings. On the morning of December 27, about 1,300 residents of the neighborhoods who could not yet return to their damaged homes were still under the care of the municipality. Hosting the evacuees in schools in Tel Aviv made it difficult to resume classes, so they were concentrated in three schools to allow classes to resume in the others.

In addition to the damages in the transit camps in Jerusalem and its surroundings, basements in the city were flooded during the storm, and it was necessary to pump the water out of them. On December 18, residents were evacuated from homes in the Musrara neighborhood whose stability had been compromised, and some houses there indeed collapsed. Train traffic to the city was also disrupted. On December 18, roads to most settlements in the western Negev were flooded. The road at the entrance to Be'er Sheva collapsed. The Wadi Be'er Sheva bridge was flooded with water at a level of half a meter above the road bridge. The Tel Aviv-Be'er Sheva road was flooded near Ekron (today - Mazkeret Batya) on December 19.

Whole_Text.content: Storm Knud was a storm that first hit southern Norway on September 19, 2018, with both storm winds and heavy rainfall. At Lindesnes, winds of up to 37 m/s were recorded. It was also reported that an elderly man was injured when a garage roof was torn off by the strong winds, and that 60,000 households lost power. The storm then moved over Sweden's west coast and Skåne on September 21, 2018, and SMHI issued Class 2 warnings for all of southern Sweden. At Väderöarna, a maximum wind speed of 32.8 m/s in gusts was measured, which is just above hurricane strength. There were subsequent reports of repeated power outages, fallen trees, and traffic problems. The storm's progression was calmer than expected, and during the night of September 22, all Class 2 warnings, except in Bohuslän, were downgraded to Class 1 with 21-24 m/s, meaning the weather was no longer classified as a storm.

The Aapeli storm (also known as the Alfrida storm)[1] was a powerful storm that struck Finland on January 2, 2019. The storm caused significant and severe property damage, and in addition, one person clearing storm damage in Åland lost their life. During the storm, the waves in the sea areas were very high. The highest average wind speed during the storm – the highest ever recorded in Finland – was measured at Kökar at 32.5 m/s, and the strongest gust exceeded 40 m/s. Electricity was cut off for over 100,000 households, mainly in Southwest Finland.[2] The power outages also caused disruptions in mobile networks. In Denmark, Aapeli's sister storm threw the cargo of a freight train onto a passenger train on the railway bridge crossing the Great Belt. Eight passengers on the passenger train lost their lives in the accident.[2]

Storm Knud was a storm that hit northwestern Denmark on September 21, 2018. The storm made landfall around 3:30 PM and left the country again to continue toward Oslo a few hours later. The strongest gusts were measured at 32 m/s in Hanstholm, which is just below hurricane strength. It had sustained winds at storm strength in Thisted and strong storm conditions throughout West Jutland and Vendsyssel. Several ferries and trains were canceled. In Southern Jutland, a number of trees were uprooted, and the water level on Fanø rose significantly, causing several cars to be flooded. A number of beach houses in Blokhus were overturned.

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Eberhard was a cyclone that hit Central Europe in March 2019. Its wind reached speeds of up to 206 km/h, and 2 people died as a result of this hurricane. The wind tore off roofs, and 320,000 residents in the Czech Republic were left without power. The hurricane struck on March 8, 2019, and dissipated on March 12. The greatest damage occurred mainly in Germany, but also in the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, and Slovakia.

Article_Name: Aiguats del 10 de juny del 2000 a Montserrat - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood of June 2000 was a severe episode of rain during the night and early morning of the 9th to the 10th that spread across the counties of Barcelona and northern Tarragona, causing floods, disruptions, and severe damage. The most serious effects were concentrated in the counties of Anoia, Bages, Baix Llobregat, and Baix Penedès. One of the most symbolic effects of that day was the heavy downpour that severely damaged the surroundings of the Montserrat Monastery, where more than 100 liters per square meter fell in just 45 minutes. The location of the abbey near the stream caused much of the facilities to be flooded with water and soil. Additionally, other corners of the massif suddenly changed their appearance, such as some channels. In this episode, 5 people lost their lives.

A channel rat is a storm depression that develops over the Atlantic Ocean and moves through the Channel to the Belgian and Dutch coasts. It is usually accompanied by sudden storms, heavy rainfall, and strong gusts of wind.  
A channel rat is especially dangerous in winter because gusts of wind can reach up to 130 km per hour. Not so long ago [(since) when?], these storm depressions were difficult to detect. With current computers, this is now possible.

The canal rat owes its name to some characteristics that are comparable to traits attributed to the rat. The depression develops almost stealthily, was previously difficult to detect, and can be fatal.

The summer storm of August 1, 1674, was an exceptional weather situation that caused significant damage in Northwestern Europe after a warm and humid summer day, including severe thunderstorms, hail, and gusts of wind. The storm moved roughly northward from Northern France at a speed of about eighty kilometers per hour over Belgium and the Netherlands to Northern Germany. It resulted in numerous collapsed buildings, many casualties, and a disrupted social life. The greatest damage occurred in the city of Utrecht. There, downbursts (gustnadoes) caused enormous devastation. A bow echo is also said to have occurred.
The first observations of the storm were in the afternoon in the area of Fontainebleau, near Paris.

Around 6 o'clock in the evening, the storm reached Turnhout and Zandvliet, destroying many houses. In the latter place, a church building also collapsed. Several other places were also affected by the storm. In Antwerp, the bridge over the Scheldt was destroyed, and in Brussels, hailstones "as large as marbles" fell.

By 7 p.m., the storm front reached the city of Utrecht. The most famous structure in the city damaged by the downbursts was the Dom Church. The nave of this church collapsed. Towers of four other church buildings also collapsed: those of the Sint-Jacobskerk (now Jacobikerk), Sint-Nicolaaskerk (now Nicolaikerk), Buurkerk, Pieterskerk, and Agnietenkerk. Other damaged structures included houses and several windmills. Trees were damaged or blown over, and many people lost their lives due to collapses. Based on the size of the hailstones that fell during the storm, the storm of 1674 appears to be one that occurs once every 1,000 to 10,000 years. Some saw the disaster as God's punishment for the Catholic arrangement of the church during the French occupation. Shortly after the disaster, Herman Saftleven was commissioned by the Utrecht city council to create a series of detailed drawings of the devastating downbursts and their consequences. The following report appeared in the Oprechte Haerlemse Saterdaegse Courant: "Utrecht, August 2. Yesterday evening at half past seven, a terrible storm arose here, lasting until half past eight; but the worst occurred within a quarter of an hour: the sky was continuously lit and aflame, and it was terrifying to hear the thunder and dreadful winds, accompanied by the collapse of chimneys, roofs, facades, and towers, which brought an uncommon astonishment to everyone, and caused many to speak of an earthquake: the church of the Dom up to the choir lay with pillars and all underfoot as a heap of rubble by half past seven, without the Dom Tower being damaged in any way [...] In the immediate vicinity of the city of Utrecht, various places were also affected; in Vleuten, Jutphaas, Bunnik, Houten, and IJsselstein, church towers collapsed. In other areas of present-day Netherlands, churches collapsed due to the storm in places such as Asperen, Hellouw, Hippolytushoef, and Den Ilp. On a large scale, houses were destroyed in Hilversum and Landsmeer. In places such as Amsterdam, ships broke loose or sank. There was also significant damage in North Holland up to Texel.

Various writers extensively mentioned the terrifying tempest in their diaries. The merchant Gerrit Jansz. Kooch wrote a poem in 139 stanzas about the storm shortly after it occurred, describing the damage in many places. The English diplomat Sir William Temple experienced the storm and wrote a brief account of it. This account was included by the English writer Daniel Defoe in a book where he describes another storm, the December Storm of 1703. In the city of Utrecht, the ruins of the Dom Church remained for more than a century. In 1979, Thea Beckman wrote the youth novel "City in the Storm" about Utrecht and the tornado. In 2018, the Utrecht band Bloodgod released the song "'t Schrickelik Tempeest," also inspired by the devastating storm.
