The Seija storm was an exceptionally strong winter storm that hit Finland on December 13, 2013. The storm has been described as being locally even stronger than the Tapani storm that raged in December 2011. During the storm, the strongest gust measured on land was 29.8 m/s, recorded at Helsinki-Vantaa Airport. At sea, the strongest gust was measured in Rauma, with a speed of 36.8 m/s. The highest average wind speed at sea, 30.7 m/s, was recorded in Kaskinen, matching the existing record for average wind speed. An average wind speed of about 31 m/s has now been recorded in Finland four times (30.5–31.4 m/s). The waves during the Seija storm were severe in Finnish sea areas, especially in the Bothnian Sea, where the significant wave height was nearly 6 meters. Sea levels also rose high on the west coast and in the eastern parts of the Gulf of Finland. The storm cut power to over 200,000 households, the same number as during the Tapani and Eino storms. The highest number of power outages occurred in Southwest Finland, where about 86,000 households were without electricity. The railway network also suffered damage, with four tracks blocked due to fallen trees. According to the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, the storm destroyed forests worth an estimated 15–60 million euros. Rescue services were called 1,040 times for damage control tasks due to the storm. During the Seija storm, up to 20 centimeters of snow fell in Kainuu, parts of Northern Ostrobothnia, and Southern Lapland, which, combined with strong winds, increased the number of power outages, especially in southern parts of Kainuu.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴海馬 (2011年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Haima (English: Tropical Storm Haima, International Number: 1104, JTWC Number: WP062011, PAGASA: Egay) was the 6th tropical cyclone formed in 2011 and the 4th named tropical cyclone. The name Haima was provided by mainland China, referring to the marine animal seahorse.

The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded this tropical disturbance to a tropical depression at 5 a.m. on June 17, 2011, and assigned it the number 06W. At 2 p.m. on June 18, the Central Weather Bureau recorded its central minimum pressure as 1004 hPa. At 10 p.m. on the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression and recorded a central minimum pressure of 1002 hPa. On June 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center briefly upgraded it to a tropical storm but downgraded it back to a tropical depression later that day. On June 20, as the storm approached Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the second tropical cyclone warning signal of the year. On the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again briefly upgraded it to a tropical storm but downgraded it six hours later. 

At 3 p.m. on June 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haima. That afternoon, the Taiwan Central Weather Bureau also upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported a minimum pressure of 994 hPa. At 10 a.m. on June 22, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. By 1 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory recorded a wind speed of 75 km/h and a minimum pressure of 985 hPa. That evening, the Hong Kong Observatory recorded a maximum wind speed of 85 km/h, but it remained stationary for several hours. 

On the morning of June 23, Haima made landfall in western Guangdong. At 8 p.m. that day, the Central Weather Bureau recorded Haima's central minimum pressure weakening to 990 hPa, but it remained a mild typhoon. At 10:10 a.m. that morning, Haima made landfall in the area between Yangxi and Dianbai. Two hours later, influenced by Mirinae, it returned to the sea and made landfall again in Wuchuan City at 4:50 p.m. 

On the morning of June 24, the Central Weather Bureau predicted that Haima would weaken to a tropical depression within 48 hours, but it remained a mild typhoon. Later that day, its center moved away from Hainan Island and the Leizhou Peninsula, heading toward Vietnam. That morning, its center was still in the Beibu Gulf. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau recorded Haima's central minimum pressure rising to 992 hPa, but it remained a mild typhoon. That evening, the Central Weather Bureau recorded Haima's central minimum pressure dropping again to 988 hPa. 

At 2 a.m. on June 25, Haima made landfall in Vietnam, still as a mild typhoon. By 8 a.m., it had weakened to a tropical depression. By that evening, it had further weakened into a low-pressure area.

On June 20, Haima entered within 800 kilometers of Hong Kong in the early morning but slowed down due to strong and widespread convective activity in the central South China Sea. The Hong Kong Observatory stated that it would consider issuing a tropical cyclone warning signal on the evening of June 20. At 9:35 PM on the same day, the Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal, with Haima located about 420 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. On June 21, the Observatory indicated that Haima would maintain some distance from Hong Kong during the day and would consider whether to issue the No. 3 Signal from the evening of the same day to the morning of June 22. 

At 5:45 AM on June 22, the Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal, with Haima located about 330 kilometers south of Hong Kong. That morning, winds in Hong Kong strengthened, with strong easterly to northeasterly winds affecting many areas, including Victoria Harbour. By the evening, widespread areas of Hong Kong experienced strong southeasterly winds, with gale-force winds in offshore waters and high ground. The Observatory stated that unless Haima significantly intensified or took a more northerly route, the chances of issuing a higher warning signal were low. At 8 PM, Haima was closest to Hong Kong, passing about 240 kilometers southwest of the city.

As Haima continued to move west-northwest and gradually moved away on June 23, winds in Hong Kong weakened. At 10:25 AM, the Observatory replaced the No. 3 Signal with the No. 1 Standby Signal, with Haima located about 310 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong. Due to the influence of the subtropical ridge, offshore winds continued to reach strong wind levels, and the Observatory did not cancel all tropical cyclone warning signals until 8:45 PM, when Haima was about 450 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong.

During the storm, four of the eight designated automatic weather stations in the Observatory's wind measurement network recorded strong winds, with one station even recording gale-force winds, meeting the criteria for the No. 3 Signal. Cheung Chau, the airport, Sai Kung, and Kai Tak recorded maximum 10-minute average wind speeds of 84, 59, 53, and 49 kilometers per hour, respectively.

Subsequently, the Observatory published an article titled "Using Aircraft to Collect Tropical Cyclone Data" in its "Observatory Newsletter," stating that during Haima's approach to Hong Kong, it collaborated with the Government Flying Service for the first time. Senior pilot Leung Man-chiu of the Flying Service piloted a Jetstream-41 fixed-wing aircraft equipped with meteorological instruments to approach Haima's center and collect meteorological data. Since then, the Observatory has collaborated with the Flying Service multiple times for this mission, including during the approach of Severe Typhoon Vicente in 2012, which brought the No. 10 Signal to Hong Kong.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted the No. 1 typhoon signal at 10:30 a.m. on June 20. On June 21, during the day, it stated that the chance of hoisting a higher typhoon signal that day was low, but at night, it indicated that a higher typhoon signal might be hoisted the next day. At 10:22 p.m., a tropical depression was located 440 kilometers east-southeast of Macao, moving westward at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour. On June 22, at 12:30 p.m., the No. 3 typhoon signal was hoisted, and all typhoon signals were canceled at 4:15 p.m. on June 23. During this period, classes for kindergarten and special education were suspended. On the morning of June 23, "Haima" was moving west-northwest at a speed of about 18 kilometers per hour, approximately 230 kilometers west-southwest of Macao, and was moving away from Macao. However, the No. 3 typhoon signal remained in effect for some time until the wind in Macao significantly weakened. At 12:47 p.m., "Haima" made landfall in Yangjiang, Guangdong. The Meteorological Bureau stated that the typhoon signal might be canceled in the afternoon, and at 4:15 p.m. that day, all typhoon signals were canceled. At 4:50 p.m. on the same day, a rainstorm warning signal was issued, which was canceled at 6:10 p.m. On June 22, the hourly average wind speeds recorded at Governor Nobre de Carvalho Bridge, Friendship Bridge North Peak, Friendship Bridge South Peak, and Sai Van Bridge were 69.3, 70.6, 72.3, and 69.2 km/h, respectively, with the highest gust reaching 102.2 km/h at one point. This indicated that the Meteorological Bureau's decision not to hoist the No. 8 typhoon signal was incorrect, and it also became the strongest No. 3 typhoon signal on record.

The Central Weather Bureau issued a tropical depression advisory around June 20 and warned that if it strengthened into a tropical storm, sea and land typhoon warnings would be issued. At that time, Haima was passing through the waters near Taiwan as a tropical depression, bringing heavy rain to Taiwan. Since Haima only strengthened into a mild typhoon after moving away from Taiwan, and the Central Weather Bureau had already lifted the tropical depression advisory, no typhoon warning was issued. However, due to the influence of its outer circulation, rainfall continued in the southern and southeastern mountainous areas of Taiwan until the heavy rain advisory was lifted.  
As Haima gradually moved away from Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau downgraded the heavy rain advisory to a rain advisory and continued to issue it until the evening of June 22.

The Provincial Meteorological Bureau initiated a Level 3 meteorological disaster typhoon emergency response at 8:30 a.m. on June 21, 2011, and issued a blue typhoon warning at 4:15 p.m. On the morning of June 23, 2011, at 10:10 a.m., the storm made landfall in the area of Maoming Dianbai and moved out to sea around 12:00 p.m., then made landfall again in Zhanjiang Wuchuan at 4:50 p.m. Both landfalls occurred with the intensity of a tropical storm. At 9:00 p.m. on the same day, Tropical Storm Haima was centered approximately 240 kilometers southeast of Nanning, Guangxi (near latitude 21.4°N, longitude 110.1°E, about 430 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong), and was expected to move westward at a speed of about 14 kilometers per hour, crossing the coastal areas of western Guangdong.
The Provincial Meteorological Bureau initiated a Level 4 emergency response for tropical cyclones at 8:00 a.m. on June 21, and issued a blue typhoon warning across the province at 11:00 a.m.

The circulation of Typhoon Haima affected northern Vietnam, making landfall in the area on the afternoon to evening of June 24, causing at least 6 deaths and 300 injuries, with 3 people missing. At 10 PM (UTC+7) on the same day, Haima was located approximately 90 kilometers southeast of Hanoi, moving westward at a speed of about 14 kilometers per hour. By 8 AM the following morning, Haima had weakened into a tropical depression within the region.

At 3:00 PM on the 25th (UTC+7), Haima was located about 210 kilometers northeast of Vientiane, moving westward at a speed of about 12 kilometers per hour, crossing Laos and weakening into a low-pressure area within its territory.
After the low-pressure area weakened by Haima left Laos, it moved westward, entered northern Thailand, and gradually dissipated near the border.
The low-pressure area weakened after the hippocampus has entered Myanmar and is gradually dissipating.
The southern circulation of the low-pressure area weakened after the hippocampus slightly affects the northern border of Malaysia.

Article_Name: Neurje 18. septembra 2007 v Sloveniji - Wikipedija, prosta enciklopedija

Whole_Text.content: The storm on Tuesday, September 18, 2007, in Slovenia flooded nearly one-fifth of Slovenian territory, triggered several minor landslides, destroyed 12 out of 14 barracks of the Franja Partisan Hospital, and claimed 6 lives. According to civil protection data, the most affected area was Železniki.

Whole_Text.header: Consequences of the storm in the Sora Valley
Whole_Text.content: The water level of the Sora River rose by 2 meters. The narrower regulated riverbeds, which the residents in the past tried to use to gain as much buildable space as possible, were heavily damaged. Within a few minutes, it spilled over the narrow valley area and completely flooded the first floors of the nearest streets. All economic facilities (Domel, Alples, craftsmen's workshops, ...) are also destroyed.
This article about the geography of Slovenia is a stub. Help Wikipedia by expanding it.

The hailstorm of Munich was a severe weather event in southern Bavaria and specifically Munich on July 12, 1984. The event caused the greatest damage to the German insurance industry up to that point.

After a heatwave, a cold front moved over southern Germany from the west on July 11, 1984. Previously, it had caused storms in France and western Germany. In Munich, however, it had already weakened and only led to a cooling without precipitation. The next day, a moist but not too warm layer of air extended up to an altitude of 2200 meters, with tropical warm air above it. Even higher up, the air cooled significantly. Due to a low-pressure system coming from the west, the moist air began to rise, facilitated by strong solar radiation and the release of condensation enthalpy, leading to the formation of cumulus clouds.

The first relatively harmless hail fell around 6 p.m. in Ravensburg. The intensifying thunderstorm cluster moved northeast, causing damage to cars and houses around 7 p.m. in the Landsberg am Lech area and reached the western part of Munich shortly before 8 p.m. Likely intensified by warm, moist air over the lakes (Ammersee and Starnberger See) near the city and extremely hot air over the city itself, the hailstorm caused significant damage in the southeastern parts of Munich (especially in the districts of Trudering and Riem) and the neighboring communities of Haar, Vaterstetten, and Grasbrunn. The northern part was hardly affected; for example, the Olympic Stadium's tent roof was not damaged. The slowly weakening storm moved further east over the northern district of Ebersberg, with Anzing being particularly hit by hailstones as large as tennis balls. It then moved along the German-Austrian border toward the Czech Republic. The entire path of the cell was extremely long, about 300 km. In Munich, the hailstorm lasted between 20 and 30 minutes, with the entire storm over the city lasting about two and a half hours. The largest confirmed hailstone had a diameter of 9.5 cm and a weight of about 300 g. However, it is likely that even larger stones fell. The storm left a hail layer up to 20 cm high, which only melted the next day. Fire departments had to handle over 3,800 operations.
Several hundred people were partially seriously injured. There were no direct fatalities, but several people died from heart attacks or during cleanup efforts.

Within a short period of time, more than 70,000 buildings were damaged. More than 200,000 vehicles were dented to an extent previously almost unknown. Damage also occurred to airplanes at the Munich-Riem and Oberpfaffenhofen airports. Aircraft were damaged, and smaller ones were even completely destroyed. The Munich tram had to suspend operations on several lines because overhead lines were damaged or switches were blocked. In addition, the hail destroyed the crops of various agricultural areas and disrupted traffic. The storm caused total damage of 3 billion DM, of which only 1.5 billion was insured. In November 1683, a very severe storm raged in the North Sea region. Eight warships of the national fleet were lost off the Dutch coast. The fleet, under the command of Lieutenant Admiral Willem Bastiaensz Schepers, on its way home from Scandinavian waters, was caught in the North Sea by a heavy storm that escalated into a hurricane over five days. During the night of November 15, 1683, the following ships were lost:[1] In total, this disaster claimed the lives of approximately 1,200 people, making it one of the greatest disasters in Dutch history.

The storm of April 2, 1973, was a severe storm that swept over Holland and Northern Netherlands in April 1973. Belgium remained virtually unaffected this time, unlike the storm of November 13, 1972. The storm originated east of Newfoundland and moved over Ireland, Great Britain, the North Sea (where the lowest air pressure of 968 millibars was recorded), the Netherlands, and Germany to Finland.

A real storm was only mentioned when the depression was near Ireland. At that moment, it was still a relatively small storm. Then the wind force increased due to a further drop in air pressure. Around 5:00 PM, the core of the storm reached the Wadden Islands. During the storm, the highest hourly average wind speeds over land (28 m/s, wind force 11) were measured at IJmuiden and Lelystad. Over the sea, an hourly value of 30 m/s was measured at Texelhorst. For comparison: Maastricht recorded an hourly average of 14 m/s. Just after 3:00 PM, wind force nine (storm) was officially observed by the measuring stations in Vlissingen and Hoek van Holland, and shortly thereafter also by IJmuiden. Then the wind force increased significantly. Around 5:30 PM, the core of the depression passed over Vlieland. The heaviest storm field occurred on the southern side of the depression, which, on its way eastward, passed over southern North Holland, South Holland, Utrecht, and Gelderland.

Once again, many trees fell victim to the storm. Many trees that had barely survived the storm of November 13, 1972, were now lost after all. The Veluwe in particular took a hit.  
The short, intense storm mainly caused damage to businesses. In the Westland, significant destruction was caused to greenhouses. In Beverwijk, for example, considerable damage was done to the Wijkerbaan shopping center and the Uiverhof, where dozens of windows were shattered. The sea defenses escaped serious damage.

In various countries, there were casualties to mourn. In the Netherlands, three people lost their lives due to the storm. In Great Britain, three deaths also occurred. In Germany, a train was hit by a falling tree, resulting in several deaths (exact number unknown).

The most famous victim of the storm was the Norderney, the broadcasting ship of the offshore radio station Radio Veronica. It was torn from its mooring outside territorial waters and thrown onto the beach at Scheveningen. The crew had to hastily throw the transmission crystals overboard to avoid being caught with a ready-to-operate transmitter on board. The crew was timely rescued by a lifeboat.
Tropical Storm Fabio is the 7th of the 2006 hurricane season for the northeastern Pacific Ocean basin. The name Fabio had already been used in 1982, 1988, 1994, and 2000.

Article_Name: Tempêtes de fin décembre 1999 en Europe — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.header: End of December 1999 storms in Europe
Whole_Text.content: For articles with the same name, see Storm of the Century. The storms of late December 1999 in Europe are two intense mid-latitude depressions with rapid development, named Lothar and Martin, which crossed Western Europe on December 26, 27, and 28, 1999. These two extremely powerful extratropical bomb cyclones caused major wind damage. The two depression systems caused the death of 140 people and nearly 19.2 billion dollars (2006) in material damage.

Although the media mentioned hurricanes, these storms did not have their structure. Indeed, no tropical cyclone can develop over waters with a temperature below 26°C. Thus, the last hurricane of the 1999 season occurred in November in the Caribbean, as mentioned in the report of the National Hurricane Center, the regional meteorological center specialized by the World Meteorological Organization for monitoring tropical cyclones in the North Atlantic. The mention of hurricanes referred by analogy only to the wind force according to the Beaufort scale.

In December 1999, Europe was struck by three strong depressions. On December 3, the Anatol storm devastated Denmark and northern Germany. At the end of that month, two other storms followed one another less than two days apart and were considered by the media as the storm of the century in Europe. The first, Lothar, was a compact depression that passed quickly without changing the zonal flow of atmospheric circulation, which allowed the next one, Martin, to follow closely. The latter storm, being of large diameter, was associated with a modification of the circulation that prevented other depressions from following it. These storms have two points in common:

Lothar is the name given to the storm that rapidly crossed northern France on the morning of Sunday, December 26, 1999. Moving from west to east along an approximate line near the forty-ninth parallel, this depression reached Finistère at around 2 a.m. and Strasbourg at 11 a.m., traveling at an average speed of 100 km/h. The most violent winds ravaged a strip about 150 km wide along a curve starting from the tip of Brittany, passing through Normandy, Île-de-France, Champagne-Ardenne, Lorraine, and Alsace. Lothar continued its path toward Germany, causing significant damage to infrastructure and forests such as the Black Forest. It caused unprecedented damage to forests in France, Switzerland, Germany, and Denmark. Mountain winds reached speeds of 259 km/h. The depression formed off the coast of Newfoundland before crossing the Atlantic Ocean in less than twenty-four hours. Exceptionally in Europe, the deepening of this storm intensified over land, reaching an atmospheric pressure of 960 hPa (960 mb), likely due to strong interaction with jet streams whose speed was around 400 km/h at just 9,000 meters altitude. According to a subsequent study by the Zentralanstalt für Meteorologie und Geodynamik (ZAMG), the Austrian meteorological service, Lothar was followed by a secondary cyclogenesis trough that passed through Belgium and southwestern Germany, generating winds of over 90 km/h.

This second very deep depression (down to 965 hPa at 4 p.m. in Brittany) crossed France at a significant speed (around 100 km/h) from the afternoon of Monday, December 27, 1999, to the following night. It developed off the coast of Brittany on December 27, reaching the region's coast around 4 p.m., before moving towards Nantes (7 p.m.), Romorantin (10 p.m.), Dijon (1 a.m. on December 28), and Alsace (4 a.m.). The regions most severely affected by the wind were Brittany, the Atlantic coast, particularly Charente-Maritime and Charente (198 km/h on Île d'Oléron), and then all areas south of a La Rochelle - Mâcon line, including the Côte d'Azur (gusts of 160 km/h unofficially recorded in Cannes). The wind continued to blow in Corsica on the morning of Tuesday, December 28, causing strong waves on the western coast. The storm also affected Spain, western Switzerland, and northern Italy. North of the depression, a cold air injection caused snowfall sticking to the ground in northern Brittany and Normandy from the afternoon of the 27th. During the night, the snow reached northeastern France up to the Genevois, leaving flakes south of the Paris region. Meanwhile, significant amounts of rain caused flooding along its path. In some areas of the Alps, snowfall lasted two days, with the snow layer reaching about two meters.

After the 1987 storm, European meteorological services improved their numerical weather prediction models. In 1999, Météo-France was able to predict the occurrence of the two storms. Based on existing models and exceptional variations in measured temperatures and pressure, Météo-France was able to issue a severe weather warning 24 hours before the Lothar storm. Météo-France forecasters at all levels work closely with Civil Security services. On December 26 at 5:25 a.m., the Interministerial Crisis Management Operations Center (COGIC) of the Directorate of Civil Defense and Security (DDSC) received a phone call from Météo-France announcing that strong winds were heading towards Île-de-France and the eastern, northern, and central parts of the country. This phone report was confirmed by the issuance of a meteorological alarm bulletin (BAM) at 6:45 a.m., confirming a phenomenon of strong winds averaging 80 km/h, with gusts of 120 km/h, potentially reaching 140 km/h locally. While the population was warned of an exceptional weather event, the strength of the gusts exceeded the forecasts. At 7:30 a.m., Météo-France announced an update to the BAM, reporting a windy episode that could last one to two hours in Île-de-France and the central region, with winds potentially reaching 140 km/h or even 160 km/h locally. At 8:15 a.m., Civil Security, at the request of Météo-France, prepared a press release to warn residents of the affected areas of the significant risks that the announced winds could generate. The press alert, initially relayed by the national bulletins of the Radio France group, came as the Lothar storm was already hitting Normandy. The short time between the alert issued by Météo-France and the occurrence of the storm did not allow for earlier communication to the population about the severity of the phenomenon. Furthermore, the alert was issued at the end of the night, the day after Christmas celebrations, a time when media are less followed, and populations are harder to mobilize.

Thanks to the monitoring of depression systems, Météo-France issues warnings for storm Martin on the morning of December 27. They mention wind gusts of up to 130 km/h inland and 150 km/h on the coasts and highlands. An alert bulletin is also issued for snowfall in Brittany. As was the case with storm Lothar, the population remains largely unprepared due to insufficient anticipation in the alert chain and underestimation of the wind's strength. Awareness of the phenomenon's intensity, both by public authorities and the population, only occurs from 7:50 PM with the dissemination of the first information on major damage (collapse of the glass roof of La Rochelle station) in France Info's regular bulletins.

MeteoSwiss experienced many difficulties with this system. Its numerical weather prediction models initially indicated weak depressions coming from the Atlantic. It was only on the morning of December 26 that alerts were issued following an adjustment of these models. Several local emergency service officials did not realize the importance of the storms and did not take the necessary measures, partly because it was during the Christmas holidays. Deutscher Wetterdienst (the German service) was criticized for not issuing an alert for Lothar. A post-analysis mentions that there was a computer problem in its communication system.

In France, the human toll of the two storms amounts to 92 deaths (drownings, accidents, hypothermia, falling trees or rocks, etc.) and around 2,000 injured. Transport and distribution infrastructures are seriously damaged. The storm has significant repercussions on forestry and agricultural activities, as well as on certain sectors of commercial activity.

Nearly 540 high and very high voltage lines and more than a thousand electrical pylons are out of service, representing about 8% of the electricity transmission network. Power outages affect 3.6 million households - or 10 million French people. Some departments are largely without electricity (Orne, Creuse, Corrèze, Haute-Vienne, Cantal, Lot-et-Garonne), and others entirely (Vosges, Charente-Maritime). Due to energy shortages and pollution affecting water distribution, 2.5 million residents must obtain water from stores. To restore its network, EDF relied on the help of about twenty countries, which provided personnel (1,500 technicians) and specialized equipment. A large part of the road network is impassable on Monday, December 27, including major routes such as the A10 motorway and National Route 10. Nearly 20,000 km of roads and forest trails providing access to massifs are damaged. Out of 32,000 km of railway tracks, 20,000 km are rendered unusable. The mobilization of 18,000 railway workers allows 95% of installations to be restored by December 31. Rail traffic returns to normal after a week. The costs of restoration and operational losses for SNCF amount to 510 million francs. Numerous flights are canceled, and some airports (Bordeaux-Mérignac, Clermont-Ferrand) are closed. Nearly one million subscribers are without landline telephone service due to fallen trees on overhead telephone lines and the rapid depletion of backup batteries in telephone exchanges and relay antennas. Nearly 3,500 mobile phone relay antennas (Itinéris, SFR, Bouygues Télécom) are out of service. The restoration of telephone networks cost approximately 1 billion francs for France Télécom, 100 million francs for SFR, and nearly 20 million for Bouygues Télécom. The near-identical reconstruction of France Télécom's telephone network will not be completed until April 2001.

The forestry and agricultural damage is considerable, particularly in the timber sector. Hundreds of thousands of trees have been felled, with waterlogged soils contributing to their instability. The first estimate of this damage, carried out by the Regional Forest and Timber Services (SRFB), evaluates the volume of felled (windthrow) and broken (breakage) wood at 140 million cubic meters (with a margin of error of 30%, i.e., between 98 and 182 million). The most affected regions are Lorraine (29.5 million cubic meters), Aquitaine (27.7), and Limousin (16.3). The resistance of trees varied depending on species and geographical areas: poplars from the Garonne and oaks from the Adour resisted better than pines from Médoc and Douglas firs from Limousin, with mountains faring better than plains. A subsequent and more precise assessment of the damage raised the windthrow volume to 176 million cubic meters. The extent of the damage, partly linked to poor forestry management, led foresters to question the practices that had prevailed until then. While viticulture was relatively spared, market gardeners and horticulturists saw thousands of hectares of greenhouses destroyed. Hundreds of thousands of fruit trees were felled or damaged in southwestern France, notably plum trees in Lot-et-Garonne and walnut trees in Périgord. The reconstruction of these orchards took about fifteen years. However, the livestock sector suffered the most significant damage (drowned animals, damaged or destroyed buildings). Stocks of fodder and silage were waterlogged, and cows had to be milked manually due to a lack of electricity, leading to the loss of several million liters of milk. Power outages affected artificial incubators, freezers, and refrigeration facilities. Many food businesses relying on cold storage (supermarkets, restaurants, bakers, caterers) lost their entire stock during a period of high activity. Order and transport flows were disrupted, and the sector was affected by technical unemployment measures. On the Atlantic coast, the storm surge reached 40 to 60 cm, and 1.5 to 2 m in Charente-Maritime. A quarter of the oyster farming facilities in the Marennes-Oléron basin were completely destroyed. However, some sectors benefited from unexpected expenditures, such as construction, public works, producers of building materials, and DIY equipment manufacturers.

The cost borne by insurance companies is significantly higher than that of the 1990 storms, which amounted to 8.6 billion francs. The French reinsurance group Scor estimated the total damages at nearly 33 billion francs. In 2000, the French Federation of Insurance Companies (FFSA) estimated the damages at 44.3 billion francs (6.75 billion euros), excluding deductibles, damages whose undeclared costs remained the responsibility of individuals and businesses, operating losses due to the temporary closure of factories, workshops, and shops, as well as the partial destruction of forest heritage. Compensation in France reached 7.5 billion euros under the "storm" guarantee and 275 million euros for floods. Half of the compensation was financed by reinsurers, while the rest was covered by the reserves of insurance companies and the Central Reinsurance Fund (CCR). Insurance companies were led to define stricter loss criteria, and reinsurance companies (Munich Re, Swiss Re, etc.) increased their rates by 5 to 30%. Faced with a significant decrease in the provisions of the Central Reinsurance Fund, public authorities significantly modified the surcharge rate for natural disasters, the deductibles applicable in the event of a claim, and the conditions of reinsurance. The financial burden on the state for the restoration of French forest heritage reached 2 billion francs in emergency aid in 2000, 12 billion in subsidized loans at 1.5%, 6 billion francs in subsidies over ten years for reconstruction, and 2 billion francs in "storm" amendments to state-region plan contracts.

According to insurers and authorities from different countries: Coastal regions such as the island of Oléron have been particularly devastated. Many historical monuments have also been affected, such as the Valmy mill.

Whole_Text.header: Response of emergency and intervention services

Whole_Text.content: The first interventions were carried out by the CODIS and the operational centers of the national gendarmerie and public security, which were on constant alert. The coordination of rescue operations was relayed with varying degrees of effectiveness in the departments by the prefects through the establishment of crisis command posts. At the level of defense and security zones, the implementation of rescue efforts included the use of the interregional civil security coordination centers (CIRCOSC), but several affected zones (Center-West, Center-East) did not have any. At the national level, the government activated the decision support operations center (COAD) of the Ministry of the Interior and the joint operations center (COIA) under the Chief of Defense Staff. The COAD organized the dispatch of reinforcement columns of firefighters from the SDIS of departments spared by the storm and the assembly of the Civil Security military units (UIISC) dispersed across various operational theaters (floods in Venezuela, the Erika shipwreck in Brittany). The army's intervention began quickly with the spontaneous engagement of units, initiated by corps commanders or base commanders, in the form of patrols aimed at ensuring the safety of people and the preliminary clearing of the road network. Within 48 hours, the COIA took over the coordination of army interventions in liaison with the military defense districts. Additionally, local initiatives attempted to compensate for the delayed arrival of rescue efforts in some isolated areas: creation of essential needs hubs at the cantonal level (Doubs, Charente-Maritime), visits to residents without means of contact by postal workers (Creuse), and a generator exchange program (Cantal).

The French public service Météo-France implemented a vigilance map system on its website and on television in October 2001 to call for vigilance in the affected departments. This concept has been adopted by many national meteorological services in Europe since then. Following these storms, a specific safety plan was established in French schools starting in 2002. Its objective is to prepare teaching teams, staff, and children in educational facilities for crisis situations. As early as 2000, EDF, then the manager of the electricity distribution network in France, set up a Rapid Electricity Intervention Force (FIRE) composed of 2,500 volunteer technicians (2,300 initially), divided into 16 autonomous regional teams that can be mobilized at any time to restore electricity distribution to subscribers using heavy logistical means (generators, helicopter resources). By early 2007, although some areas remained untreated, most zones with fallen trees had been cleared.

Whole_Text.content: On the night of December 3 to 4, 1863, a very severe storm raged in the North Sea region. Along the Dutch coast, a total of 36 ships were lost. Hundreds of people lost their lives. The largest shipwreck was that of the German barque Wilhelmsburg on the Boschplaat near Terschelling. In this stranding, 258 passengers and 3 crew members perished. The passengers were emigrants on their way to America. Because they were locked in the ship's hold, they were unable to save themselves. The drowned were buried in a mass grave near the church in Hoorn. Captain Ernst Christian Kross, who was among the dead, received his own grave with a headstone that still stands in the cemetery. Furthermore, 17 British fishing vessels were lost near Texel, with more than 60 men perishing, mostly from Barking near London. Many other casualties occurred elsewhere. More than 200 ships were stranded on the British coasts, with dozens of people drowning. Several Ostend fishing boats also sank, with crew members losing their lives.

Storm Tuva was the name of the storm that swept over southern Norway and Götaland in Sweden on January 31, 2008. On Koster, hurricane-force gusts reached a strength of 35 meters per second, and on Väderö, 34 meters per second. Skåne was also affected by the storm. In Skåne, 3,000 households were left without power. The storm was caused by a low-pressure system that formed over the Labrador Sea southwest of Greenland. This system passed by Iceland on January 30. The low-pressure system was named "Resi" by the Free University of Berlin. On Thursday, January 31, the air pressure dropped to 950 hectopascals, and the storm slowly moved over the North Sea in a straight path over the Faroe and Shetland Islands. During Thursday, a large area around the center of the low-pressure system was hit by the storm. At the same time, there were severe weather events. In the Irish Sea, the cargo ferry "The Riverdance" was shipwrecked. The Faroe Islands were paralyzed by a massive snowstorm. In Norway, Sörlandet and Östlandet were affected. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute named the extreme weather Tuva. Over southern Sweden, both a warm front and a cold front passed. In total, more than 27,000 households were affected by power outages during the storm. On Friday, February 1, the low-pressure system moved over the North Sea down to Stavanger in southern Norway. The two weather fronts, which brought heavy precipitation, later moved northward over Sweden. On February 2, the low-pressure system split. Two low-pressure centers formed over northern Scandinavia, each with approximately 970 hectopascals. Shortly thereafter, the low-pressure zone significantly weakened. On February 3, a new low-pressure system formed over the North Sea, dominating the entire weather situation in Western Europe. Storm Tuva was already the third storm to pass over Sweden in 2008.

On February 3, a new low-pressure system formed over the North Sea, dominating the entire weather situation in Western Europe. Storm Tuva was already the third storm to pass over Sweden in 2008.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Molave (international designation: 0906, JTWC designation: 07W, Philippine designation: Isang) was a tropical cyclone that affected the Philippines and southern China in mid-July 2009. Molave formed from an area of meteorological disturbances east of the Philippines on May 14. Initially moving northwest, Molave became a tropical storm the following day. Under reasonably favorable meteorological conditions, Molave continued to gradually intensify and became a severe tropical storm, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), on July 17. Molave became a typhoon the next day, at which point it reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 120 km/h, shortly before making landfall in southeastern China at this intensity. Shortly thereafter, Molave began to weaken rapidly over land and completely dissipated on June 19. Even without directly hitting the Philippines, its outer rain bands caused heavy storms in the archipelago. At least five people died in that country as a result of the cyclone's direct effects. In China, two fishermen went missing at sea when their boat was caught by the strong sea agitation caused by the typhoon.

Molave originated from an area of meteorological disturbances that persisted about 280 km east-southeast of Yap, Federated States of Micronesia, on July 10. Initially, the system only exhibited a poorly defined and elongated low-level cyclonic circulation. However, mid-level convective activity was favorable for the system's continued organization. The disturbance gradually developed, and by July 11, the system already had a more defined low-level cyclonic circulation with good upper-level outflow. Additionally, the system was located in an area with favorable meteorological conditions for its development, such as low wind shear. However, later that day, the system failed to establish itself, and its areas of deep convection began to fragment. Its low-level cyclonic center became less defined. Furthermore, the upper-level outflows from another nearby tropical disturbance negatively affected the system. The following day, the disturbance lost definition and was no longer monitored. However, during the night (UTC) of July 13, the system reorganized, and the sudden increase in areas of deep convection associated with the formation of a low-level cyclonic circulation led the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, the U.S. Navy agency responsible for monitoring tropical cyclones, to issue a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (TCFA) for the system, indicating that the disturbance could become a significant tropical cyclone within 12 to 24 hours. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), the meteorological agency designated by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) for monitoring tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific Ocean, noted the system's evolution and classified it as a weak tropical depression early on July 14. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) also classified the system as a tropical depression hours later, assigning it the Filipino name "Isang." Later that night, the JTWC issued a second TCFA for the system, extending the timeframe for the disturbance to become a significant tropical cyclone. On the morning (UTC) of July 15, the JMA classified the system as a full tropical depression with the continued organization of the disturbance. With the formation of defined storm bands and the establishment of good upper-level outflows enhanced by the presence of an upper-level anticyclone just southwest of the system, the JTWC classified the system as a tropical depression that same morning (UTC), assigning it the designation 07W. That night (UTC), with the formation of more areas of deep convection and the consolidation of its low-level cyclonic center, the JTWC upgraded the depression to a tropical storm. At that time, there were modest outflows associated with a tropical upper tropospheric trough, and the low wind shear allowed the system's intensification trend to continue. The system continued to gradually intensify as it moved west-northwest. By noon (UTC) on July 16, the JMA also classified the system as a tropical storm and named it "Molave," a name submitted to the typhoon naming list by the Philippines, referring to a type of hardwood used in ornament crafting in one of the languages spoken in that archipelago. Molave continued to move northwest under the influence of a subtropical high to its northeast. On the morning (UTC) of July 16, a second, smaller low-level cyclonic circulation separated from Molave. Initially, Molave was unable to develop rapidly; the tropical upper tropospheric trough that provided good upper-level outflows transformed into an upper-level low-pressure area, negatively impacting the cyclone with associated wind shear. However, from the morning (UTC) of July 17, Molave began to intensify more rapidly with the sudden consolidation of its low-level cyclonic circulation. Despite the intrusion of dry air into the cyclone, Molave was able to intensify more quickly due to the formation of new areas of deep convection facilitated by the establishment of good meridional upper-level outflows. The nearby upper-level low-pressure area moved away, reducing wind shear. Additionally, the warm waters in the region further favored the storm's development. The JMA noted the system's evolution and classified it as a severe tropical storm that same morning. During the morning (UTC) of July 18, Molave experienced a brief period of disorganization but quickly resumed intensification, becoming a typhoon by noon (UTC) on July 18, according to the JMA. Near the southeastern coast of China, Molave began to exhibit a small eye surrounded by intense areas of deep convection, and hours later, the JTWC also classified the system as a typhoon. However, Molave had at that point reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 120 km/h and a minimum central atmospheric pressure of 975 mbar, according to the JMA and JTWC. Molave's intensification trend was interrupted when the typhoon made landfall on the coast of China's Guangdong province, near Hong Kong, at its peak intensity. As Molave's cyclonic center crossed the coast, interaction with land began to negatively affect the cyclone, which rapidly lost its associated areas of deep convection and consequently began to weaken. As a result, the JMA downgraded Molave to a severe tropical storm early that evening (UTC). The JTWC also downgraded Molave to a tropical storm hours later. Over southeastern China, Molave quickly weakened, and the JMA downgraded Molave to a simple tropical storm early on the morning (UTC) of July 19. The JTWC issued its final advisory on Molave hours later as the system continued to degrade over China. The JMA downgraded Molave to a tropical depression and also issued its final advisory on the system later that morning (UTC).

On July 15, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) issued public storm warnings at level I, the lowest of five levels, for two provinces on the Philippine island of Luzon. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a typhoon warning on July 16. The following day, the Hong Kong Observatory, responsible for the city's meteorology, raised a level I storm warning, the lowest of 10 levels. The Macau government acted similarly. On July 18, the alert level in Hong Kong had risen to level III, which remained in effect for about seven hours before the Hong Kong government decided to raise the alert to level VIII. Later that day, the storm warning in the city was raised to level IX and remained so for about three hours before the alert level was downgraded as the typhoon passed over the region. The Vietnamese government also warned the country's population about the presence of Molave near its territory; the country had already suffered from the effects of tropical storm Soudelor in the region days earlier. The Guangdong (Canton) government requested that all vessels return to ports as Molave approached the region. More than 1,600 fishermen returned to ports, and another 600 were prevented from going to sea. Additionally, the government sent more than 20 million SMS messages to alert residents about the approaching typhoon.

Although Molave did not directly hit the Philippines, its outer storm bands caused heavy rains in the archipelago. More than 248,000 people were affected in 31 municipalities across six Philippine provinces. 495 people were left homeless due to floods and landslides in the region and had to resort to emergency shelters. Molave caused five deaths in the Philippines, leaving one person injured. Most of the deaths were caused by drowning in floods and flash floods. A landslide destroyed five houses and damaged three others in Rizal province. At least 545 families were isolated by floods and landslides. The total damages caused by Storm Molave in the archipelago amounted to 380,000 Philippine pesos (7,900 dollars). In Taiwan, Molave's outer storm bands caused heavy rains; accumulated precipitation reached 235 mm in Kaohsiung. However, no impacts associated with Molave were reported in the country. In southern China, Molave caused more than 320 mm of rain, triggering floods, flash floods, and landslides. In Nanning, the floods caused serious traffic accidents. A vessel with seven people on board was adrift during the storm's passage off the coast of Shantou. Rescue teams reached the vessel on July 20 and safely rescued everyone on board. Two fishermen went missing when their boat capsized due to the strong waves caused by the typhoon. Molave's remnant system reached northern Vietnam, causing torrential rains. The floods affected large areas of rice fields as well as several communities. In Bac Lieu province, 32 homes were completely destroyed. In Soc Trang province, five other homes were destroyed, and 41 others were damaged, leaving seven people injured. In Phu Tho province, more than 300 homes lost their roofs, and 96 electricity poles were knocked down due to strong winds.

Whole_Text.content: The hurricane in Finland on August 28, 1890 ("August storm") was the only storm considered a hurricane in Finland until the Lyly storm hit Finland in early November 2024. Exact wind speeds are not known due to the inadequacy of measuring devices at the time, but meteorologist Pauli Jokinen has presented estimates in his thesis of average wind speeds on the Baltic Sea at 30–35 m/s, on land areas at 17–23 m/s, gust peaks likely at 27–40 m/s, and possibly over 40 m/s in downdrafts caused by convection. According to some claims, the average wind speed in Helsinki was even 50 m/s. A photograph from Honkanummi in Vantaa shows broken pine trees, the highest scaffolding of St. John's Church in Helsinki collapsed, and hail fell. The storm was extensive and lasted significantly long in one location. In southern Finland, tens of thousands of trees fell, with the thickest trunks having a diameter of 40 cm. The storm claimed at least three lives.

The Mauri storm was a powerful low-pressure system, the remnants of the tropical cyclone Debby that originated in the Atlantic, which felled forests in Northern Finland on September 21–22, 1982. Forest damage was observed over a wide area extending from Oulu to Inari. The highest 10-minute average wind speed on land was measured in Oulu at 19 meters per second. The strongest sustained wind speed over sea areas, 29 meters per second, was recorded in Moikipää. Gusts reached wind speeds of 40–50 meters per second. The storm, which rose from the Bay of Bothnia, surprised residents, particularly in Tornio and Kemi as well as other coastal municipalities. The Finnish Meteorological Institute's weather forecasts had not warned of the storm in advance, instead predicting brisk southerly or southwesterly winds for the area. The storm's unexpected nature was further emphasized by the fact that the previous day's weather had been sunny and warm. According to eyewitnesses, the storm broke out completely unexpectedly in the afternoon of September 21, 1982. Millions of cubic meters of forest were felled; in the city of Rovaniemi alone, about 4,000 trees were toppled. In addition to the wind, damage was caused by the high sea level, which destroyed the marinas in Kemi and Tornio. The highest official water level measurement was from Kemi: +201 cm. Even east of the Saariselkä fell area, at the Jaurujoki River, the storm felled about 265,000 cubic meters of forest; this destruction area was incorporated into the Urho Kekkonen National Park the following year. When the timber market was flooded with storm-damaged wood in the fall of 1982, the price of raw wood plummeted. On the other hand, the clearing of storm damage was facilitated by the fact that permanent snow fell unusually late in the fall of 1982. The Mauri storm is suspected to have generated at least one tornado, which felled trees in clusters toward a central point. There were two fatalities: a couple who sought shelter in their vacation cabin on Vitagrunn Island in Tornio. The cabin was torn from its foundation by the storm winds and carried about a kilometer across the water, smashing into the mainland's rocky shore in Laivaniemi, Tornio. The wind also hurled boats weighing thousands of kilograms far inland.

Becky was a storm[2] or cyclone that formed in the Atlantic Ocean on November 6, 2010, and in the following days crossed the United Kingdom and several other countries as a strong low-pressure system. Wind gusts exceeding 180 km/h, rough seas, and heavy rainfall caused two fatalities.

Whole_Text.content: The August storm of 1967 was a hurricane-strength storm in Estonia that caused significant damage on August 6–7, 1967, in the Haapsalu district (now Lääne County), Harju district (Harju County), and Rapla district (Rapla County). Parts of the northern Pärnu district (Pärnu County) and the western part of the Paide district (Järva County) were also affected. The hurricane, referred to as the "storm of the century," had wind speeds consistently reaching 30–35 m/s over two days. The storm felled broadleaf and coniferous forests in Harju and Lääne Counties in entire swathes. Local people were unable to clear the fallen trees from the forests, and forestry workers from Ukraine and Belarus came to assist. In the Haapsalu district alone, one million cubic meters of storm-felled timber were removed, and sawmills had work until 1970. In central Estonia, a tornado passed through the forest, further felling trees. The storm was accompanied by heavy rain and lightning, which struck houses in several places. On the island of Aegna, the wind destroyed 5% of the forest (1,500 cubic meters), and it took nearly five years to clear the windfall. Several city and manor parks, such as Haapsalu Castle Park and Padise Manor Park, were completely devastated by the hurricane. The main building of Põlli Manor was so severely damaged during the storm that it was later decided to demolish it. The structures of the Türi ski jump tower could not withstand the great storm and were never rebuilt. A special issue of the magazine "Eesti Loodus" was published about the August storm of 1967.

The famine in Somalia from 1974 to 1975 was the result of a severe drought, referred to in Somalia as Dabadheer (the drought "with a long tail," i.e., the prolonged drought). It affected nomadic livestock herders primarily in the northeast of the country, leading to the death of 1,500 people and millions of livestock, thereby causing losses to Somalia's most important export commodity.

Even before the drought, Somalia was affected by food shortages and dependent on imports. The first official recognition of the drought and famine occurred in a speech by President Siad Barre on October 21, 1974, followed by the declaration of a state of emergency on November 29. Shortly thereafter, a National Drought Relief Committee and corresponding committees at regional, district, and village levels were established. In the most affected areas of Sanaag, Togdheer, Bari, Nugaal, Mudug, and Galguduud, camps with medical facilities and educational offerings for those affected were set up. These camps were managed by camp committees, each consisting of a teacher from the Rural Development Campaign, a health officer, an agent of the National Security Service, and three representatives of the camp residents. By November/December 1974, about 112,000 people had moved into these camps, with an additional 3,000 to 5,000 arriving daily. By May 1975, the number of drought refugees had reached 772,000. The state mobilized extensive resources and redirected funds intended for rural development projects into emergency relief measures. Foreign aid initially came mainly from the Soviet Union, later also from Western countries, as well as from Nigeria and Uganda within Africa.

While the number of human casualties remained relatively low at around 1,500 according to the official estimate from February 1975, the loss of millions of cattle, sheep, goats, and camels led to greater macroeconomic problems and the loss of livelihoods for numerous livestock herders. Around 90,000 nomads who had lost their livestock were relocated from camps in the north to agricultural settlements in southern Somalia starting in mid-1975, and another 15,000 were resettled along the coast. From 1976 to the mid-1980s, efforts were made with international support to provide them with new livelihoods in agriculture or fishing. However, the yields from these projects often fell short of expectations, leading many settlers to leave these settlements again.
