The Heisei 6 Drought (1994 Drought) refers to the drought that occurred from 1994 (Heisei 6) to the following year in regions ranging from northern Kyushu to the Kanto area.

In 1994 (Heisei 6), Japan experienced a trend of low rainfall from spring across various regions, with rainfall during the rainy season being less than half of the average. From July to August, there were consecutive days of record-breaking high temperatures, and many observation points from western Japan to the Kanto region recorded the highest temperatures since observations began (16 years later, the summer of 2010 was hotter than this year, but due to higher spring rainfall, it did not result in a drought). With continued clear skies, rainfall in many areas remained at about 30-70 percent of the average. As a result, especially in regions such as northern Kyushu, the Seto Inland Sea coast, and the Tokai region, the supply of tap water became difficult, and water supply restrictions, such as scheduled water outages, were implemented. The impact affected 16.6 million people, and the damage to agricultural crops amounted to 140.9 billion yen [1].

In April 1994 (Heisei 6), the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka City was nearly 100 percent, but the rainfall during the rainy season was about half of the average, and the dam's water storage continued to decrease. After the rainy season ended on July 1, intense heat persisted daily, and the dam's water storage began to decrease rapidly. As a result, the Fukuoka Prefecture and the Kyushu Regional Construction Bureau of the Ministry of Construction established a Drought Countermeasures Headquarters on July 6, initiating measures such as calls for water conservation. On July 9, water intake restrictions from the Chikugo River began, and by mid-July, many municipalities in Fukuoka Prefecture had established Drought Countermeasures Headquarters. On July 13, the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka Prefecture fell below 60 percent, and on July 14, the Fukuoka District Meteorological Observatory issued the "First Information on Low Rainfall and High Temperatures" for northern Kyushu, calling for caution against water shortages. By July 20, the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka Prefecture dropped below 50 percent, and on July 21, nighttime water outages began in Dazaifu City. Although rain from Typhoon No. 7 fell on the night of July 25, the situation did not improve, and nighttime water outages began in Onojo City on July 27 and in Fukuoka City on August 4. 

Although the water shortage temporarily stabilized in early August, it worsened again in late August, and by August 20, the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka Prefecture fell below 25 percent. On August 22, nighttime water outages began in Chikushino City as well. On September 2, emergency releases of some water for power generation were conducted from Matsubara Dam and Shimoike Dam. On September 27, the reservoir rate of Terauchi Dam reached 0 percent, and the use of dead water (water accumulated below the intake point) began. Although it started to rain in September, the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka City remained around 30 percent even in October, leading to prolonged water outages. During the year-end and New Year period from December 28 to January 4 of the following year, water outages were temporarily lifted as a special measure. 

On March 3, 1995 (Heisei 7), the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka Prefecture reached its lowest point at 15.2 percent, but from April onward, significant rainfall began, and on May 17, water outages were lifted in Dazaifu City. By late May, the dam reservoir rate in Fukuoka City recovered to 68 percent, and on June 1, water outages in Fukuoka City were lifted. The water outages in Fukuoka City lasted 295 days, surpassing the drought of 1978-1979 (Showa 53-54), but water supply during supply hours was maintained, and complaints to the city's waterworks bureau were about one-fifth of those during the previous drought.

Kitakyushu City was considered to have little risk of water outages due to securing abundant water sources from the Onga River. However, as the water level at the Onga River estuary dam fell below sea level, nighttime water outages were implemented from September 12 to October 10. In Nagasaki Prefecture, water supply restrictions were imposed in 25 municipalities, including Nagasaki City and Hirado City. Particularly in Sasebo City, time-specified water outages were conducted for 213 days from August 1 to March 6 of the following year, resulting in a severe situation with an average daily water outage time of 20.5 hours.

In the Shikoku region, the rainy season ended on July 2, but the water level of the Sameura Dam, the largest reservoir in Shikoku, began to decrease from June. On June 27, the Kagawa Prefecture Drought Countermeasures Headquarters was established. Takamatsu City, which relied on the dam as its water source, started water supply restrictions on June 29, implemented nighttime water outages from July 11, and limited water supply to five hours from 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM starting July 15. On July 25, Typhoon No. 7 made landfall in Kochi Prefecture, bringing over 500mm of heavy rain in some areas of Shikoku, which slightly restored the water levels of major dams. However, after the typhoon dissipated, the region was hit by another heatwave, causing the water level of the Sameura Dam to continue declining, eventually drying up completely at 0% on August 19. The water outage in Takamatsu City lasted for 67 days until September 30, and water supply restrictions continued for 139 days until November 14. In Matsuyama City, although rain fell due to Typhoon No. 7, the water shortage was not resolved. Nighttime water outages began on July 26, the day after the typhoon made landfall, and from August 1, water supply was limited to eight hours from 1:00 PM to 9:00 PM, and from August 22, it was further reduced to five hours. As a result, Dogo Onsen in the city was forced to shorten its operating hours. On September 1, the supply of industrial water was stopped, leading to the suspension of operations at some factories. The water outage lasted for 124 days until it was lifted on November 26.

In many rivers flowing through Hiroshima Prefecture, the lowest flow rates since the start of observations were recorded, and water intake restrictions were implemented in rivers such as the Numata River, Ashida River, and Ota River. In Higashino Town (later Osakikamijima Town), nighttime water outages lasted for 70 days, and in Fukuyama City, water supply restrictions extended for 290 days. In the western part of Hiroshima Prefecture, the trend of low rainfall continued even after September, and water intake restrictions persisted in the Yahata River and Kose River until May of the following year. In Okayama Prefecture, water intake restrictions were implemented in the water systems of the three major rivers: the Yoshii River, Asahi River, and Takahashi River. Particularly, water intake restrictions in the Takahashi River system lasted for 138 days from July 16 to November 30 (including days when restrictions were temporarily lifted). In Kurashiki City, a drought countermeasures headquarters was established on July 15, and water supply restrictions began on July 20. Furthermore, nighttime water outages started on August 9, and from August 25, water supply was limited to 8 hours a day, with the outages continuing until September 29. In the industrial areas of the Mizushima district, including steelworks and chemical plants, production cuts became unavoidable. At the Asahi Kasei Mizushima Plant, water had to be secured through maritime transport from Yamaguchi Prefecture and Miyazaki Prefecture.

The water storage volume of Hikihara Dam, located upstream of the Ibo River in Hyogo Prefecture, was 52% on July 19, but dropped to 28% on August 2 and to 8% on August 14. As a result, nighttime water outages began in Himeji City, which relies on the dam as a water source, starting on August 22. By September 6, the water storage rate of Hikihara Dam had dropped to 1%, nearly drying up, and the use of dead water began on September 10. Nighttime water outages in Himeji City continued for 71 days until November 24. The water level of Lake Biwa continued to drop sharply from around June, recording a historic low of minus 123 centimeters on September 15. Consequently, water intake restrictions were implemented for 44 days from August 22 to October 4, and water supply restrictions due to pressure reduction were carried out in Kyoto City and Osaka City, which rely on Lake Biwa as a water source.

Nighttime water outages were implemented in 13 cities and towns in Aichi Prefecture from August 17 to 31. Some factories that use large amounts of water were forced to reduce production. Toyokawa City was also on the verge of unavoidable water outages, but emergency water diversion from the Sakuma Dam in the Tenryu River system to Toyokawa was carried out from September 12 to 16, preventing the water outages.

In the upper reaches of the Tone River, a major water source for the Kanto region, rainfall in June was about 60 percent, and with the end of the rainy season on July 12, concerns about water shortages arose. As a result, the Kanto Regional Construction Bureau established a drought countermeasures headquarters on July 13, and Tokyo followed suit on July 15, initiating measures. From July 22 to September 19, water intake restrictions were implemented in the Tone River system, and from July 29 to September 8, Tokyo imposed water supply restrictions of up to 15 percent. However, except for a very small number of areas, there were no water outages in the Kanto region.

The Fukuoka City Drought of 1978-1979 (Shōwa 53-54) was a drought that lasted from May 1978 (Shōwa 53) to March 1979 (Shōwa 54) in Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture. Triggered by precipitation from the summer of the previous year, 1977 (Shōwa 52), to the following spring being less than 70% of the average, recovery was delayed due to reliance on dams as water sources, leading to water supply restrictions with scheduled water outages for 287 days.

Fukuoka City experienced urbanization along with rapid economic growth, which led to an increase in water demand. During the 1950s, the increase in water demand outpaced the securing of water sources, resulting in repeated water supply restrictions almost every year. However, the situation eventually improved, and after 1968 (Showa 43), water supply restrictions were not implemented except for 1975 (Showa 50). 

Since there are no major rivers within Fukuoka City, dam construction was promoted to meet the increasing water demand. Six dams, including Egawa Dam, Kuhara Dam, Minamihata Dam, Sefuri Dam, Magaribuchi Dam, and Zuibaiji Dam, became the main water sources. However, the construction of these dams was delayed due to other projects, and the development could not keep up with urbanization. Additionally, a "jinx" emerged where water storage rates in the dams would recover due to heavy rain after preparations for water supply restrictions began. Furthermore, relatively low water rates compared to other cities led to lenient judgments regarding waterworks management.

Until June 1977 (Showa 52), precipitation was at normal levels, and the storage rate of the six dams (total storage capacity of 39.06 million tons) was over 90%. However, from July onward, there was a trend of low rainfall, and by September, the storage rate had fallen below 50%. From December of the same year to April 1978 (Showa 53), precipitation was about half of the average, and by early February, the dam storage rate had dropped to 25%. The city waterworks bureau anticipated recovery with the usual spring rains and did not take special measures.

Contrary to the waterworks bureau's expectations, the low rainfall continued, and from March to May 1978, precipitation remained less than half of the average. The dam storage levels continued to decline. Even in May, rainfall was about one-third of the average, and as the dam storage rate began to fall below 30%, the Fukuoka City Waterworks Bureau issued a water crisis declaration on May 10, calling for water conservation. On May 15, a drought countermeasures headquarters was established, and starting May 20, 10 days after the crisis declaration, nighttime water outages from 9 PM to 6 AM (9 hours) began.

After the start of the nighttime water outage, there was no rain, and by May 25, the reservoir rate had worsened to 17.4%, leading to stricter water supply restrictions with a 9-hour supply (15-hour outage) from noon to 9 p.m. Due to issues with valve operations during the outage and concentrated water usage during the short supply period, water pressure dropped in residential areas and housing complexes on higher ground, leaving approximately 19,000 households without any water even during supply hours. Numerous complaints were filed with the city water bureau, prompting the authorities to dispatch water trucks to the housing complexes. From May 27 onward, water trucks from the 4th Division of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force were deployed to supply water to higher ground areas.

On June 1, there was a 5-hour water supply from 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM (19 hours of water outage), leaving over 40,000 households without any water. Emergency water diversion from the Terauchi Dam in the Chikugo River system began, and the Ministry of Health and Welfare requested major cities to dispatch "water supply support teams." The Maritime Self-Defense Force's escort ship "Takanami," minesweeper "Teuri," and transport ship "Motobu" were mobilized for maritime water transportation, and water supply vehicles were dispatched from Osaka City and Kobe City as well. On June 6, the "Fukuoka City Drought Countermeasure Strengthening Emergency Measures Guidelines" were implemented, initiating measures such as water supply restrictions for large-scale users and high-altitude areas, and the permanent stationing of administrative personnel. As of June 10, the dam's water storage rate had dropped to 14.3%. On June 10, heavy rain from the rainy season began, and on the following day, June 11, water supply restrictions were eased, resulting in an 8-hour nighttime water outage from 10:00 PM to 6:00 AM the next morning. Although the rainfall in June was slightly above average, the dam's water storage rate remained around 30%, so from June 26 onward, the water supply was changed to 10 hours from 11:00 AM to 9:00 PM.

The water storage did not recover, and the rainy season ended unusually early on July 5th, leading to continued hot days and a worsening water shortage. On July 27th, the water supply hours were shortened to 8 hours, from 1 PM to 9 PM. The rainfall from July to September was about 40% of the average, and the dam's water storage continued to decrease. On September 1st, the water supply hours were further reduced to only 6 hours, from 3 PM to 9 PM (4th water supply restriction). On September 7th, the 4th Engineering Battalion of the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force began pumping up the dead water (water accumulated below the intake) from the Terauchi Dam. The water storage rate of the Egawa Dam had already fallen below 1% and dried up, and the overall storage rate of the six dams recorded a minimum of 6.8% on September 15th.

Citizens were preoccupied with securing water, leading to a lifestyle of using water stored in buckets and plastic tanks. As a result, plastic containers became scarce. To save water for washing dishes, many households used paper plates and cups, shared the same dishes among siblings, or reused a single water bottle. Some received water from acquaintances or relatives outside Fukuoka City, while others, including households and businesses, purchased medical-grade distilled water. In residential areas on elevated ground, long lines formed for water trucks, and some people temporarily relocated outside the city (drought evacuation).

In most schools, swimming lessons were canceled, and school lunches relied heavily on canned and frozen foods due to the inability to secure water for cooking. Universities took measures for temporary closures.

40% of the water supply is consumed in buildings, and since the water flow is better than in general households, there have been demands from citizens to strengthen water supply restrictions to buildings. Additionally, a large amount of water is used for building air conditioning, and many buildings stopped air conditioning to conserve water. In the city's accommodations, agreements were made to limit shower use in guest rooms. Some restaurants and other establishments that use large amounts of water posted notices asking customers to refrain from using the toilets for defecation, and some businesses were forced to close. Furthermore, even during water supply hours, low water pressure sometimes caused red rust to mix in, leading some barbershops to wrap gauze around showerheads for hair washing.

In the event of a fire, water supply to the affected area was to be restored by operating valves, but due to the risk of delays in operation, a tanker truck carrying water was dispatched to follow the fire truck.

Water supply to ships using Hakata Port was limited to the minimum amount necessary for the voyage to the next port of call. Ferries connecting Iki Island and Tsushima did not take on water at Hakata Port but instead received water at their destinations. Water supply to railways was also restricted, causing disruptions to schedules due to water supply at each stop.

During the Kyushu Grand Sumo Tournament held from November 12 to 26, the usual two-week advance arrival of wrestlers and related personnel was shortened to 7 to 10 days before the event due to water shortages. Measures such as relocating lodgings outside the city and drilling wells on the premises of lodgings were taken to address issues with bathing, laundry, and cooking. However, despite the shortened stay, many sumo stables faced a de facto price increase as bathing fees remained unchanged. Notably, the Nishonoseki stable and Kokonoe stable, which shared expenses and contracted with nearby public baths, were charged double the usual fees, prompting them to build separate bathing facilities. Additionally, the Hanaregoma stable, Futagoyama stable, and Tatsutagawa stable, which set up lodgings in Momochi near Hakata Bay, could not use well water due to its salinity. The Hanaregoma stable installed a 4-ton water tank (later adding 1 ton), while the Futagoyama stable installed a 1-ton water tank on the roof of their lodging. The Tatsutagawa stable secured water for daily use by storing it in 120-liter plastic buckets. Despite these challenges, sumo remained highly popular, and Tokitsukaze Oyakata (director in charge of the Kyushu tournament for the Japan Sumo Association) expressed his gratitude in a post-event interview, saying, "I was pleased to feel the warm support for sumo."

On September 15, Typhoon No. 18 passed over the northern Kyushu sea. Although the expected amount of rain did not fall, the dam's water storage rate began to improve slightly. After October, rainfall returned to normal levels, and the dam's water storage rate recovered to around 20%. On November 1, water supply was eased to 7 hours from 2:30 PM to 9:30 PM, and on December 1, it was further eased to 9 hours from 1:00 PM to 10:00 PM. During the year-end and New Year period from December 20 to January 10, 1979 (Showa 54), water supply restrictions were exceptionally lifted. Although the dam's water storage rate had recovered to about 27%, the city water bureau warned on January 11 that if sufficient rain did not fall after spring, drought could recur, and resumed a 12-hour water outage from 10:00 PM to 10:00 AM the next morning. As a fundamental measure against water shortages, the "Guidelines for Water-Saving Use, etc." were implemented nationwide for the first time on February 1. By late February, the dam's water storage rate had recovered to about 35%, and on February 24, the water outage was eased to 6 hours at night from midnight to 6:00 AM. Rainfall from February to March was slightly above average, and the dam's water storage rate recovered to 49.2% by March 24, leading to the complete lifting of all water supply restrictions on March 25. At a press conference announcing the full lifting of the 287-day-long water supply restrictions, then-Mayor Kazuma Shindo was seen shedding tears.

In Fukuoka City, water conservation has been strengthened as a lesson from water shortages, and many newly constructed or renovated buildings have started using reclaimed water systems. Additionally, water intake from the Naka River, Mikasa River, and Tatara River has been enhanced, along with the development of new water resources. In Fukuoka Prefecture, three new dams—Hase Dam, Ino Dam, and Narufuchi Dam—were constructed in the Tatara River system, while in the Naka River system, the redevelopment of Minamihata Dam was carried out, increasing its reservoir capacity by excavation. As of 2018, the Gokayama Dam is being constructed upstream of the Minamihata Dam. Furthermore, in the Chikugo River system, the largest in Kyushu, Egawa and Terauchi Dams were built, and in 1984, the Chikugo Weir was constructed. This allowed water intake from the Chikugo River via the weir, and efforts were made to supply water from the Kikuchi River system using the Ryumon Dam. Water supply has significantly improved. In 2005, the seawater desalination center "Mamizu Pier" in Nata, Higashi Ward, began operations, enabling the supply of up to 50,000 cubic meters of freshwater per day from seawater. In 2011, the Northern Fukuoka Emergency Connection Pipe, which facilitates mutual water supply between the Kitakyushu City Waterworks Bureau and the Fukuoka City Waterworks Bureau/Fukuoka District Waterworks Association, began operations. In emergencies, it can supply up to 50,000 cubic meters of water per day, equivalent to drinking water for 2.5 million people, to 18 cities and towns, including Fukuoka and Kitakyushu. Measures were also taken to address water outages in high-altitude residential areas, which had become a significant issue, by advancing water distribution control and strengthening inter-system coordination. During the 1994 water shortage in Fukuoka City, long-term water supply restrictions were implemented, but water supply during designated hours was maintained, and water trucks were not deployed. TOTO, headquartered in Kitakyushu City, launched its water-saving CS series products in May 1976, which then spread nationwide. Subsequently, other companies in the same industry entered the market, and water-saving products have now become the standard. However, when using reclaimed water systems (treated water), there are cases where equipment damage is accelerated or worsened, particularly in systems that supply water for handwashing, lower body washing, and toilet flushing from a shared source.

The 1981-1982 Okinawa Drought refers to a drought that occurred in Okinawa Prefecture from July 1981 to June 1982. Precipitation dropped to two-thirds of the average, and river water volume fell to one-third of the average, leading to water supply restrictions with scheduled water outages for 326 days. This marks the longest period of water supply restrictions in the history of urban water systems in Japan.

At that time, nine years had passed since the reversion of Okinawa, and with economic growth and the spread of water supply systems, water demand was increasing. As water sources for the water supply, three dams managed by Okinawa Prefecture (Zukeyama Dam, Tengan Dam, and Kin Dam) and the Fukuchi Dam managed by the national government (Okinawa General Bureau) in the northern part of Okinawa Island were used, but water shortages had become chronic, and water supply restrictions were repeated almost every year. In particular, in 1977, water supply restrictions were implemented for 169 days. As a result, redevelopment of the Fukuchi Dam through heightening began, and the construction of five new dams (Henoki Dam, Haneji Dam, Fukugawa Dam, Kanna Dam, and Amu Dam) in the northern part of Okinawa Island was initiated. In 1981, rainfall during the rainy season was less than half of the average, and water usage increased due to rising temperatures, causing the water storage levels of each dam to continue to decline. By the end of June, the total water storage of the three prefecture-managed dams had fallen below 60% of full capacity, and the Fukuchi Dam had fallen below 80%. As a result, on July 1, the Okinawa Prefecture Drought Countermeasures Headquarters meeting was held, and from July 11, nighttime water outages from 8 PM to 6 AM the following morning began across almost the entire Okinawa Island, except for a small part of the northern region.

After the start of nighttime water supply restrictions, no rain fell, and by July 13, the water storage rate of the three prefecture-managed dams had dropped to 28.2%, leading to alternate-day water supply restrictions starting on July 16. Alternate-day water supply restrictions involved dividing Okinawa Island into two zones, alternating water supply and suspension every 24 hours for each zone. Although nighttime water supply restrictions temporarily resumed on July 22, alternate-day restrictions were reinstated on August 24. Typhoon No. 18 passed west of Okinawa Island from August 30 to 31, causing wind damage but failing to bring the expected rainfall, exacerbating the water shortage. On October 18, an attempt was made to induce artificial rainfall by spraying water from a Self-Defense Force P-2J aircraft over Fukuchi Dam, but it was ineffective, and by October 20, the water storage rate of the three prefecture-managed dams had dropped to 5.1%, nearly drying up. On October 21, Typhoon No. 24 passed east of Okinawa Island, bringing significant rainfall, but it was insufficient to restore water levels, and water supply restrictions continued. In response to this situation, 5,000 poly containers were sent as relief supplies from Fukuoka City, which had experienced a drought in 1978. During the year-end and New Year period from December 30 to January 3, water supply restrictions were temporarily lifted as a special measure. After the New Year, water supply restrictions resumed on January 4, 1982, and on January 14, an attempt was made to induce artificial rainfall using dry ice, but only about 5 millimeters of rain was achieved. The water level of Fukuchi Dam, which was relied upon, continued to drop, and by February, the storage rate fell below 40%. With no rain expected in weather forecasts, water supply hours were further reduced by four hours starting February 15, resulting in 20-hour water supply every other day. Dams under construction at the time were completed one month ahead of schedule through rushed construction, with Fukugawa Dam beginning water storage on February 22 and Anba Dam on March 1, enabling water transfer to Fukuchi Dam. Fukuchi Dam recorded its lowest storage rate of 32.4% on March 21.

On March 27, significant rainfall occurred in the northern part of Okinawa Island, and as rain continued afterward, water restrictions were eased to alternate-day water supply starting April 12. On May 3, there was another significant rainfall, and from May 8, the restrictions were further eased to nighttime water supply. Although heavy rainfalls on May 28 and June 2 caused flooding in various areas, they brought much-needed relief to the water shortage. The storage rates of the three prefecture-managed dams recovered to over 90%, with Fukuchi Dam exceeding 70%, and both Fukugawa Dam and Anba Dam nearly reaching full capacity. As a result, all water supply restrictions were lifted on June 7.

In Okinawa Prefecture, water supply restrictions lasting up to about two months were implemented in 1988 (Showa 63), 1989 (Heisei 1), 1991 (Heisei 3), and 1993 (Heisei 5). However, the dams under construction were gradually completed, and the redevelopment of Fukuchi Dam and Zukeyama Dam increased water storage capacity, gradually alleviating water shortages. On the other hand, due to repeated experiences of water shortages, large water tanks began to be installed on the roofs of many houses in Okinawa Prefecture.

The drought in Korea is a drought that began in June 2015, and the main reason for the drought is that the amount of rainfall was less than half the average. On June 19, the water level in Soyang Dam reached 152.24 m, which is the lowest water level recorded in South Korea since June 24, 1978, when the water level was 151.93 m and Soyang Lake had completely evaporated. North Korea, on the other hand, was severely affected by the drought, and the United Nations provided nearly $110 million in aid.

Article_Name: Sequía en el Sur de Ecuador de 1968, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Drought in the South of Ecuador in 1968
Whole_Text.content: It was one of the strongest natural phenomena the country faced, which, with records dating back to 1946, affected the highlands of the southern region of Ecuador in the 1960s, specifically the province of Loja. The great drought, as it was known, caused the largest wave of internal migration in the country, resulting in the departure of approximately 164,183 people over these 20 years, along with other factors. Most of those affected were economically active individuals, aged between 20 and 40 years. It occurred during Ecuador's last dictatorship, at a time when agrarian reform was implemented, which attracted migrants to the most populated cities, such as Quito, Guayaquil, and the surrounding cities, as well as to the coast, in the province of El Oro, during the banana industry boom. Its most critical point took place in 1968, when crops such as corn, vegetables, beans, and rice were produced by the hectare in the province. Loja's culture developed an independent inclination from the country, stemming from the Peruvian-Ecuadorian war and this drought, influencing politics, such as agrarian reform; society, such as migration; gastronomy, with low-cost dishes like repe lojano; and art, such as murals.

Article_Name: 2019年中国长江中下游干旱 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.header: Drought in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River in China in 2019
Whole_Text.content: In the summer and autumn of 2019, a six-month-long extreme drought occurred in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River in China, affecting seven provinces: Jiangxi, Hunan, Hubei, Jiangsu, Anhui, Zhejiang, and Fujian. Precipitation in the drought-affected areas was 20-80% less than the same period in previous years, with Hubei and Jiangxi experiencing the lowest levels since 1961, and Anhui experiencing the second-lowest levels for the same period. The drought event went through two phases. The first phase lasted from late July to mid-November, during which moderate to severe meteorological drought was widespread in most parts of Hubei, northern Hunan, northern Jiangxi, and most of Anhui, with extreme drought in eastern Hubei and southern Anhui. Two rounds of rainfall in mid-to-late November alleviated the drought in eastern Hubei and northern Hunan. The second phase lasted from late November to the end of December, during which precipitation in southern Jiangxi and most of Guangdong was 50-90% less than the same period in previous years, and the drought persisted. Article_Name: 2021年臺灣旱災缺水危機 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2021 Taiwan drought and water shortage crisis was a large-scale drought event that occurred in early 2021 in the western region of Taiwan's main island, leading to varying degrees of water pressure reduction, water rationing, fallow farming, and business closures. It was the most severe drought since 1947 and was referred to as the "century drought." This drought was alleviated between late May and late June by several waves of plum rain fronts, showers, and southwest monsoon rains, and the Central Drought Response Center was deactivated on June 22. By late July to early August, significant rainfall brought by Typhoon In-Fa, Typhoon Lupit, and southwest monsoon fronts restored normal water conditions across Taiwan's main island and the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen, and Matsu by August 5, marking the end of this drought.

The 2021 drought was caused by a short and insufficient rainy season during Taiwan's 2020 plum rain season, followed by a typhoon season without any typhoons making landfall or approaching Taiwan. The two most critical water collection periods for reservoirs in western Taiwan experienced low rainfall, resulting in low reservoir storage levels, which relied solely on summer showers for replenishment. Subsequently, the autumn and winter dry seasons in the southwest, which are typically low in rainfall, made it difficult to alleviate the drought. Hopes were placed on spring rains from February to April to ease the drought, but due to factors such as the La Niña phenomenon, the 2021 spring rainfall was the lowest on record, causing reservoir storage levels to continue to decline. In May, the Pacific high-pressure system abnormally strengthened and extended westward, and the plum rain front developed further north, leading to high temperatures and low rainfall in Taiwan, delaying and reducing the plum rain season. With no hope of replenishment, reservoirs in western Taiwan gradually reached critical alert levels, and some areas in central Taiwan began implementing water rationing measures in early April.

In the southwestern Pingtung region, however, abundant and well-developed groundwater resources prevented the area from entering a drought alert status by May, despite low rainfall. This was due to water resource reserves and utilization, including the Erfeng Irrigation Canal, designed by Shinpei Goto during the Japanese colonial period, which was restored in early 2017, and the Dazhou Artificial Lake, completed in 2018, which serves as a groundwater recharge lake. The lake has injected 50 to 70 million tons of water into the underground aquifer, acting as an underground reservoir.

In contrast, northern and eastern Taiwan did not face water shortages due to abundant rainfall brought by the northeast monsoon during the 2020-2021 autumn and winter seasons. The Feitsui Reservoir had surplus capacity to assist the Shimen Reservoir's supply area during the water shortage, extending the Shimen Reservoir's supply period.

Long-term observations indicate that rainfall brought by typhoons contributes approximately 40% of Taiwan's annual precipitation. However, the strong Pacific subtropical high-pressure system in 2020 resulted in a lack of typhoons for Taiwan. Climate model assessments suggest that human-induced climate change will significantly strengthen the Northwest Pacific subtropical high-pressure system. This implies that under climate change, Taiwan will face long-term drought challenges with reduced precipitation in the future.

Whole_Text.header: Development and allocation of water resources
Whole_Text.content:
In 2017, the Lin Chuan Cabinet of the Executive Yuan deployed relevant water conservancy projects in the Forward-looking Infrastructure Development Program to address Taiwan's climate change and uneven drought and flood conditions. After several years of construction and implementation, the related facilities proved effective during this drought. In July 2020, the Ministry of Economic Affairs preemptively deployed measures, strengthened management and allocation, and accelerated the completion of related water resource construction and the Drought-Resistant Water Source 1.0 Plan. In 2021, to cope with the current drought, the government and private sector sought various ways to develop emergency water sources, and the second Su Tseng-chang Cabinet launched the Drought-Resistant Water Source 2.0 Plan in March.

The number of drought-resistant wells in Taichung increased from 25 to 88, with drilling operations running 24 hours a day. By the end of the month or early May, the daily water supply could reach 115,000 tons, equivalent to the water usage of 500,000 people. Emergency deployment of CPC Corporation drilling experts with specialized equipment drilled three deeper wells near Liyutan Reservoir, adding approximately 15,000 tons of water daily, expected to be completed by the end of April.

After Kaohsiung's water status turned to orange in April, the city government, in collaboration with the Water Resources Agency, drilled 62 wells and allocated water from Chengcing Lake Reservoir. By May 5, the reservoir's water storage increased to 92%, holding 2.42 million tons, resolving Kaohsiung's May water crisis of turning to red status.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs urgently added a seawater desalination plant in Taichung, with the first phase supplying water on May 15, increasing the daily water supply by 13,000 tons. By the end of May, the daily supply increased to 15,000 tons. The Wuxi riverbed water guidance project in Taichung added 55,000 tons of water daily.

The Kaohsiung City Government and the Water Resources Agency completed subsurface water facilities such as Xingtian, Xipu, and Dazuan upstream of the Gaoping River weir as part of the Forward-looking Infrastructure Development Program. These facilities were initially completed in 2020, supplying 400,000 tons of raw water daily and 300,000 tons of backup water. The backup water has been activated in response to the current drought.

In Taichung, water from construction sites of major projects like Lafayette and CMP was tested and filtered to meet tap water standards before being integrated into the tap water system. In Tainan, groundwater quality from the Guiren construction project was tested and found suitable for domestic use. The Tainan City Government installed large-scale RO water purification equipment, expected to supply 350 tons of water daily into the tap water pipeline.

On March 13, Taipei Mayor Ko Wen-je stated that Taipei had begun expanding water support, transporting 910,000 tons of water daily to New Taipei, Keelung, and Taoyuan to facilitate the transfer of water from Shimen Reservoir to Hsinchu and Miaoli.

From September 2020 to April 22, 2021, the Water Resources Agency's rain enhancement team conducted 45 artificial rain enhancement operations in reservoir catchment areas across northern, central, and southern Taiwan. These included 32 ground-based operations, 8 high-altitude flare operations, 2 drone-based experiments, and 3 Air Force aerial operations.

At noon on May 17, the Water Resources Agency released rain enhancement flares at Bao'er, Yongheshan, and Mingde Reservoirs. However, Deputy Director Wang Yifeng stated that due to weak cloud systems, the rainfall was minimal, rendering the artificial rain enhancement operation "almost ineffective."

Domestic sewage and industrial wastewater, after treatment at sewage treatment plants and further precision filtration and purification at reclaimed water plants, can be used for non-domestic purposes, preventing competition for water between industrial, domestic, and agricultural uses.

The Central Drought Disaster Response Center decided in a meeting on March 24 that due to severe water conditions in parts of Miaoli, Taichung, and northern Changhua (Changhua City and parts of Hemei and Huatan), a red alert for zoned water supply will be implemented starting April 6. Additionally, from April 1, the water alert in Kaohsiung will change from a yellow alert for reduced pressure water supply to an orange alert for reduced water supply, and in Lienchiang, the alert will change from a green alert for water conservation reminders to a yellow alert for reduced pressure water supply. The zoned water supply areas are divided into two zones, with water supplied for five days and cut off for two days, aiming to save 15% of water. Due to the drought in central reservoirs, the Central Drought Disaster Response Center announced that parts of Miaoli and Taichung would enter a "5 days on, 2 days off" water restriction for residential use starting April 6, affecting approximately 1.064 million households. This is Taiwan's third large-scale zoned water supply in nearly 20 years. The Central Taiwan Science Park and Houli Science Park, which have dedicated pipelines, will reduce supply but not stop it. Although rainfall in April remained unsatisfactory, several emergency water supply measures proved effective, and on May 6, the Central Drought Disaster Response Center decided to maintain the current water alert levels. Due to the continued decline in the water storage rate of Shimen Reservoir, the water alert in Taoyuan City and Linkou District of New Taipei City was changed to an orange alert for reduced water supply starting May 21. At the end of May, consecutive afternoon thunderstorms increased the water volume of the Gaoping River and raised the water storage rate of Chengqing Lake Reservoir. On May 29, the water alert in Kaohsiung was changed from an orange alert to a yellow alert for reduced pressure water supply. From June 4 to June 6, Typhoon Choi-wan and the plum rain front brought abundant rainfall to Taiwan, alleviating the water situation. Starting June 6, the red alert for zoned water supply in Miaoli, Taichung, and northern Changhua was lifted, ending the longest water restriction in history.  

In response to the "5 days on, 2 days off" water restriction, the Taichung City Government's Sports Bureau temporarily closed public swimming pools in Taichung starting April 6. Only three locations—the competition pool at the North District National Sports Center, the Wuri heated swimming pool, and the Zhongxing swimming pool—were designated for priority use by athletes during training sessions. To reduce inconvenience caused by water cuts, the Water Corporation decided to undertake emergency pipeline construction, utilizing a deep well drilled last year at the Water Resources Planning and Experiment Institute in Wufeng to support parts of Caohu in Dali District, Taichung City, with an expected daily water supply of 2,000 tons upon completion.  

In response to water restrictions, the Changhua County Government temporarily opened the swimming pool at the Changbei Sports Center from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. starting April 6. The county government also guided public and private swimming pools and sauna operators to suspend operations. However, similar to the guidance for car wash businesses to suspend services, some operators expressed dissatisfaction. To find water sources, many residents applied for legal well drilling, with the number of monthly applications for legal water rights and well drilling in 2021 significantly increasing compared to the previous year, mostly for agricultural use.  

In Chiayi City, starting March 23, all elementary and middle schools suspended swimming pool courses, replacing them with indoor courses such as water safety and lifesaving education. In Chiayi County, starting April 1, schools suspended the use of swimming pools, and swimming classes were replaced with alternative courses. Public-private partnership and private swimming pools were left to comply with central policies on their own.  

In Tainan City, starting April 22, water taps in 76 large parks under its jurisdiction, except for public restrooms, were shut off to enforce water-saving measures, with an estimated monthly water savings of about 2,000 tons. Additionally, starting April 26, water supply to saunas, car washes, and swimming pools was stopped. Some car wash operators expressed dissatisfaction after being notified, as the regulations only controlled legal operators but failed to restrict illegal ones. Schools also temporarily suspended swimming classes. To encourage water conservation among residents and businesses, the Tainan City Government introduced incentive measures, offering vouchers worth thousands of dollars for meeting specified water-saving targets. Since the suspension of water supply to swimming pools would affect athlete training, considering the importance of uninterrupted training and the impact of competition results on educational advancement, four public swimming pools were designated as centralized training bases for Tainan swimming athletes.  

The Kaohsiung City Government's Sports Development Bureau announced that starting April 1, six self-managed public swimming pools—Qijin, Sanmin, Gushan, Youchang, Jiaxian, and Dongmen—would be closed. Starting April 19, all 10 self-managed public swimming pools under the bureau (International Pool, Sanmin Pool, Xinxing Pool, Qijin Pool, Gushan Pool, Zuoying Pool, Youchang Pool, Nanzi Pool, Jiaxian Pool, and Dongmen Pool) would suspend operations in line with the city's water restriction and drought response measures. Outsourced and managed swimming pools would not replenish new water but would enhance water filtration frequency to maintain water quality. Additionally, the four swimming pools at incinerator feedback facilities (Central, Southern, Gangshan, and Renwu) under the Kaohsiung City Environmental Protection Bureau reduced their daily sessions from four to two starting April 1. However, due to the continued severity of the water situation, these four swimming pools were completely closed starting April 19 and would reopen only after the water alert was lifted.  

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai announced on April 16 that starting April 17, tap water supply to car washes and public and private swimming pools would be stopped. Additionally, the Southern Region Water Resources Office and the Water Corporation initiated a well-drilling project, aiming to increase daily water supply by 160,000 tons by the end of the month and up to 300,000 tons in May to ensure that Kaohsiung's water situation does not enter the red alert stage of "5 days on, 2 days off."

The central and local governments took advantage of the opportunity presented by the exposed bottoms of multiple reservoirs to deploy manpower to remove silt. The Water Resources Agency stated that the desilting volume in 2020 reached 14.4 million cubic meters, which is 2.6 times the average of previous years. The desilting volume in 2021 also increased compared to the same period in 2020, with 7.6 million cubic meters desilted from January to April. By May 16, 8.96 million cubic meters had been desilted, far exceeding the average before 2016. By the end of May, the total desilting volume of reservoirs nationwide had reached approximately 10.01 million cubic meters, the highest for the same period in history.

The bamboo shoot yield in Taichung City has decreased, and the bamboo shoots are smaller. The Taichung City Agriculture Bureau estimates the disaster damage to be about 23 hectares. In Dali District, lychees have been significantly affected by drought this year, with a high fruit drop rate. On May 5, the Council of Agriculture of the Executive Yuan announced that Xinshe, Shigang, and Waipu districts in Taichung City are designated areas for "Kyoho grape" agricultural natural disaster cash relief, with an estimated loss of NT$15.23 million for Kyoho grapes and NT$2.25 million for peanuts. 

In Changhua, the bamboo shoot yield has also decreased, with green bamboo shoots expected to sprout in May, estimated to have a 30% reduction in production. Changhua cabbage has been reported to suffer from "tip burn," with dry leaves and cores, poor appearance, low purchasing willingness from traders, and falling prices.

In Chiayi County's Alishan area, tea and bamboo shoots have been severely affected. Tea plantations in mountainous areas such as Gukeng and Zhanghu in Yunlin have also experienced tea tree wilting, death, and stagnation in tea leaf growth, leading to reduced production areas and lower yields compared to the past. These conditions have met the standards for agricultural natural disaster cash relief, and subsidies can be applied for.

In Baihe District, Tainan City, the lotus industry has been affected by irrigation water shortages. The city government has initiated natural disaster relief and coordinated with relevant departments to allocate water sources for irrigation.

In Kaohsiung, plum and tea tree farmers have reported losses. The local government has confirmed that the disaster meets the threshold for disaster recognition. The city’s Agriculture Bureau will seek natural disaster cash relief and low-interest loans for the plum and tea tree industries. Additionally, agricultural losses have been reported for Yuhebao lychees and black-leaf lychees. After joint inspections by the city government and farmers' associations, subsidies for affected farmers are being planned.

According to the Council of Agriculture of the Executive Yuan, agricultural losses across Taiwan due to drought have exceeded NT$500 million. Before the arrival of the May rainy season, agricultural losses may continue to expand. Assistance has been provided to farmers to implement relevant farmland management measures during droughts to reduce losses.

Whole_Text.header: Rivers, lakes, and reservoirs dried up.
Whole_Text.content:
The longest river in Taiwan, Zhuoshui River, has dried up due to prolonged drought and lack of rain. The riverbed has cracked, and west of the Ziqiang Bridge, which connects Erlun Township in Yunlin and Zhutan Township in Changhua, the river has even experienced a break in flow. Residents have found dead tilapia and eels on the riverbed, which have dried up after exposure to the scorching sun.  

Several reservoirs have seen water levels drop to record lows in recent years, revealing structures that were previously submerged. For example, the old Route 3 in the Liyutan Reservoir in Miaoli has reappeared due to the low water levels. The Yong'an Bridge in the Yongheshan Reservoir has also resurfaced, attracting many visitors eager to witness the sight.  

The water level of Sun Moon Lake has dropped significantly, and by mid-April, it was 13 meters below the full water level. The lakebed has dried up, the land has cracked, garbage at the bottom of the lake has been exposed, and even grasslands have appeared. The Nantou County Government is uncertain whether the 2021 Sun Moon Lake Swimming Carnival can proceed as scheduled. Nantou County Education Director Lu Zhengwei stated that Sun Moon Lake serves important functions such as hydropower generation and domestic water supply. The lowered water level has affected water quality, making it unsuitable for the event. In addition to closely monitoring weather and water conditions, they are considering flexible adjustments to the registration dates.  

The water level of Sun Moon Lake once dropped to a historic low of 735.85 meters, 12 meters below the full water level, and by mid-May, it remained around 735.5 meters. Due to the low water levels, the Chaowu Pier and Xuanguang Temple Pier were temporarily closed starting April 1, and the Shuishe Pier was closed from April 23. Only the Ita Thao Pier continued operations with chartered boats.  

At Shimen Reservoir, the low water level and excessive silt accumulation have caused significant inconvenience for residents of Jiangmu Island in the upstream catchment area. Their primary mode of transportation, sampan boats, has been stranded and unable to operate.

After the implementation of water restriction measures, the sales of bottled water in stores doubled. Many stores also specifically set up drought-resistant sections, with a significant increase in demand for products such as bottled water, water storage barrels, disposable tableware, and disposable underwear.

From January 6, CPC Corporation Taiwan has successively shortened car wash service hours by two hours in areas with an orange water alert, including Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Chiayi, Tainan, and Kaohsiung. Additionally, in response to the "5 days on, 2 days off" measure, car wash services in Miaoli, Taichung, and Changhua will be suspended starting a week earlier on March 31.

On the afternoon of May 13, due to an operational error by personnel at the Luzhu North Extra High Voltage Substation in Kaohsiung City, a bus grounding incident occurred, causing four coal-fired units at the Xingda Power Plant to trip, leading to a large-scale power outage in Taiwan that affected nearly ten million households. The main reason for the outage was the simultaneous tripping of multiple units combined with high electricity demand during the afternoon. Additionally, several thermal power units that could have immediately responded were under maintenance, and hydropower units such as Sun Moon Lake and Deji Reservoir were unavailable due to drought conditions, resulting in a temporary power shortage and a drop in grid frequency. Taiwan Power Company implemented emergency rolling blackouts by region.

In April 2021, the effective water storage capacity of Taiwan's main reservoirs, except for the Feitsui Reservoir, fell below half.  
On May 5, the Zengwen Reservoir adjusted its water release, channeling it to the Wushantou Reservoir after power generation to meet various water needs such as domestic and industrial use. After this round of water release, the water storage rate of the Wushantou Reservoir temporarily rose above 50%.  
On May 10 at 10 a.m., the water level of the Deji Reservoir reached 1325.95 meters, with a storage rate of 3%. Starting from 10:12 p.m. on May 11, water supply for downstream domestic use was stopped. By the morning of May 12, the water level was 1325.59 meters, with a storage rate of only 2.77%. On May 24, the water level dropped to 1321.99 meters, with a storage rate of only 1.10%, setting a new 47-year low.  
After several rounds of Meiyu fronts and afternoon thunderstorms from late May to early June, the water storage capacity of the Deji Reservoir rebounded to 20% on June 14.

Whole_Text.content: In addition to water restriction policies and water source development measures, private religious groups and government officials have responded to this severe drought by holding and participating in multiple rain prayer ceremonies. On March 7, 2021, the Irrigation Agency and Dajia Jenn Lann Temple co-hosted a rain prayer ritual. Following ancient traditions, the ceremony included offerings to the Rain God and the Shangyang bird, with 3,000 attendees dressed in white and holding incense for worship. Jenn Lann Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao and Taichung Mayor Lu Shiow-yen, along with five directors from water and agricultural departments, participated throughout. On March 15, the Taoyuan Ferry Yacht Association held a Mazu water pilgrimage event, inviting the Shui Zhong Tudi Gong from Baiji Fuxing Temple and 28 temples from the Daxi area to join. A total of 18 boats participated in a nearly three-hour lake pilgrimage at Shimen Reservoir to pray for blessings and rain. On April 14, Xiantian Temple in Dongshi, Chiayi County, held its first rain prayer ceremony in 300 years, burning 17 green dragons and 7,000 longevity gold papers on-site to petition the Dragon Kings of the Four Seas for rain to alleviate the drought. On April 17, residents of the Sun Moon Lake area initiated a rain prayer event, welcoming Mazu from the Tainan Zhengyi Luermen Mazu Temple. Participants carried Mazu statues around the lake, took boats, and rode cable cars, conducting a "land, sea, and air" pilgrimage to pray for rain. In Dalin Township, Chiayi County, Shengxian Temple held a "Rain Prayer Grand Ceremony" for Guan Sheng Dijun's return, with Chiayi County Magistrate Weng Chang-liang wearing traditional Han attire to lead the prayer. On April 18, Lingxiao Baodian Wulong Temple in Yongkang District, Tainan City, held a rain prayer ceremony led by 11 Taoist priests. Following ancient customs, they used four symbolic water jars representing divine beasts to conduct the ritual. On April 19, Yicheng Tang Guan Di Temple in Kaohsiung held a rain prayer ritual, inviting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai to serve as the chief officiant. The temple displayed the "Thunder and Lightning Flag," symbolizing rain prayers, hoping to end the drought quickly. On April 25, Songshan Cihui Temple held a national protection and peace prayer ceremony, attended by Vice President Lai Ching-te and Taoyuan Mayor Cheng Wen-tsan, who prayed together for rain and water for Taiwan. On April 29, Tainan Mayor Huang Wei-che conducted a rain prayer ritual at Anping Kaitai Tianhou Temple following ancient customs, presenting a "Rain Petition Document" and performing the ancient "Shangyang Dance." Simultaneously, all 37 administrative districts in Tainan held rain prayer ceremonies at local temples, with district chiefs leading the rituals. From late May to early August, Taiwan experienced abundant rainfall, and reservoirs reached full capacity, ending the drought. After consulting through divination, Anping Kaitai Tianhou Temple sent the Shangyang back to the heavens at around 6 a.m. on August 7, with Mayor Huang Wei-che serving as the chief officiant.

In early April 2021, Typhoon Surigae unusually formed in the western Pacific, but according to forecasts, it would not approach Taiwan or bring significant rainfall to the region. The actual situation was as predicted, with the typhoon not bringing any rain. On April 19, Central Weather Bureau Director Cheng Ming-dean published an analysis article, stating that based on the latest Meiyu (plum rain) index chart, Taiwan might have a chance to experience drought-relieving Meiyu after late May. On April 30, the Central Weather Bureau held a press conference on the outlook for the Meiyu season. Forecast Center Director Lu Guo-chen pointed out that this year's widespread and sustained rainfall during the Meiyu season might occur after late May, with the total rainfall for the Meiyu season from May to June likely to be below average to normal.

From the afternoon of April 28 to the morning of April 29, a relatively complete frontal rainband passed through Taiwan, bringing brief showers or thunderstorms to areas from central to northern Taiwan and the northeastern region, as well as brief showers or thunderstorms in the southern mountainous areas. This provided more abundant rainfall for counties and cities in central and northern Taiwan, with reservoirs receiving some inflow. As of 4 p.m. on April 29, the total rainfall across Taiwan was 15.97 million tons, equivalent to 1.5 days of water usage for the entire island. However, due to the rapid movement of this frontal system, significant relief from drought is still expected to come during the plum rain season.

On May 24-25, a frontal system approached Taiwan, with vigorous development of convective cloud systems, leading to short-term heavy rainfall in the afternoon across various regions. Not only did heavy rain fall in Taipei and New Taipei City, but localized heavy rain also occurred in the mountainous areas of Keelung, Yilan, northern Kaohsiung, and Hualien. This rainfall brought approximately 18.15 million tons of water to Taiwan, with the Feitsui Reservoir and Shimen Reservoir benefiting the most, positively impacting water conditions. However, southern reservoirs gained little from this rainfall and still faced water shortages. Nevertheless, the increased flow in the Gaoping River and the improved storage rate of Chengqing Lake eased water conditions in the Kaohsiung area, changing the water alert signal to a yellow light.

From May 30 to June 1, a more complete plum rain front brought significant rainfall to Taiwan, resulting in positive growth in reservoir storage rates across the island. The estimated inflow to reservoirs nationwide was 136 million tons, equivalent to two weeks of water usage for the entire island. The Water Resources Agency estimated that the Shimen Reservoir in the north benefited the most, with an inflow of approximately 26 million tons. However, storage rates remained low, and several more rain events would be needed to fully alleviate the drought.

From June 4 to June 6, Typhoon Choi-wan and a plum rain front brought abundant rainfall to Taiwan, easing water conditions. This plum rain front contributed approximately 210 million tons of rainfall to reservoir catchment areas across the island. The Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei received about 42 million tons, while the Shimen, Baoshan, and Baoshan Second Reservoirs collectively gained 16.56 million tons. In central Taiwan, the Yongheshan, Liyutan, and Deji Reservoirs collectively increased by 22.7 million tons. The Sun Moon Lake and Wushe Reservoirs in Nantou gained about 11 million tons, the Nanhua Reservoir in Tainan about 32.1 million tons, and the Zengwen and Wushantou Reservoirs about 41 million tons. This rainfall also allowed the red light water rationing measures in Taichung and northern Changhua to be lifted, with Changhua and Yunlin switching to green light water reminders, and Nantou and Kaohsiung returning to normal water conditions.

From June 21 to June 25, a plum rain front lingered near Taiwan, bringing rainfall across the island. The Central Weather Bureau stated that the most significant impact of this stationary front occurred on June 22 and 23, with the main rainfall areas being the western half and northeastern regions. Meteorologist Wu Derong, reflecting on the soon-to-end plum rain season on June 25, noted that although three typical stationary plum rain fronts brought rainfall, without the additional two mobile fronts, consecutive afternoon thunderstorms, and the southwest monsoon delivering substantial rainfall to central and southern Taiwan, the record-breaking 56-year drought would not have been so easily alleviated.

From July 23 to July 25, Typhoon In-Fa passed over the northeastern waters of Taiwan, prompting the Central Weather Bureau to issue a sea typhoon warning. Although Typhoon In-Fa did not make landfall in Taiwan, its outer circulation brought abundant rainfall to areas from central to northern Taiwan, with an estimated reservoir inflow benefit of approximately 330 million tons. This rainfall effectively replenished reservoirs in central and northern Taiwan, returning water conditions to normal in Taoyuan and Miaoli, and changing Taichung's water alert from an orange light for reduced water supply to a yellow light for reduced pressure water supply.

From July 31 to August 1, Taiwan was affected by a southwest airflow, resulting in significant rainfall in areas south of Taichung. Rainfall accumulation reached 521 mm and 512.5 mm in Yuyoushan, Kaohsiung, and Dahan Mountain, Pingtung, respectively. Several towns experienced flooding and waterlogging, with some roads disrupted. The Central Weather Bureau named this event the "110731 Southwest Airflow Heavy Rain Event." This heavy rain brought approximately 100 million tons of precipitation to Taiwan, with the Nanhua Reservoir and Zengwen Reservoir benefiting the most. Although the Deji and Wushe Reservoirs in the central mountainous region received rainfall, their recovery was slower.

From August 6 to August 8, after Typhoon Lupit weakened into a tropical depression upon making landfall in Fujian Province, it turned and made landfall in Taiwan, bringing several days of disastrous heavy rain. From 2 a.m. to 8 a.m. on August 7, a total of over 2.3 billion tons of rainfall was recorded in just six hours.

Kuomintang Chairman Johnny Chiang presided over the KMT Central Standing Committee meeting on the afternoon of March 10, criticizing the ruling party's "well-digging" policy as "a laughingstock" during his speech. On March 25, the Kuomintang held a press conference, where Culture and Communications Committee Chairwoman Wang Yu-min stated that the government allocated large budgets for forward-looking infrastructure projects but failed to address Taiwan's water shortage issues, questioning where the budget money was spent. Deputy Chairwoman Wang Hung-wei criticized President Tsai Ing-wen for not inspecting reservoirs during the drought, likening her absence to being "invisible," and questioned how such disregard for water conditions could raise public awareness of the crisis.

On March 25, DPP member Hsieh Pei-fen stated that in response to Taiwan's most severe drought in 56 years, the government had already activated contingency mechanisms last year, accumulating water-saving measures amounting to 800 million cubic meters, roughly equivalent to the capacity of four Shimen Reservoirs. She expressed hope that before the rainy season arrives, the people of Taiwan can unite and exert their strength to overcome this challenge. Regarding the KMT's criticism of the DPP's water management policies, Hsieh Pei-fen urged the KMT to recognize that political bickering cannot solve Taiwan's most severe drought in 56 years, but rather unity and collective effort are needed to overcome the difficulty.

On October 10, 2021, the 110th National Day celebration of the Republic of China featured the theme "Defending Taiwan." The "National Drought Relief Team" was invited to participate in the National Day parade. Representatives of contributors included personnel from the Water Resources Agency, Taiwan Water Corporation, 14 reservoir artificial rainfall enhancement teams, meteorological experts, the National Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology, National Taiwan University, and related cooperative manufacturers such as Chin Mei, Jutai, Guotong, Xinwen, Zhengdong, Quanhe, and Guangyun. Drought relief equipment independently developed by the Taiwanese people also participated in the parade. The Ministry of Economic Affairs stated that in response to this drought, the central and local governments collaborated through various proactive measures, including artificial rainfall enhancement, pipeline connections, groundwater from construction sites, emergency desalination, and assistance from the military in transporting water and operating water purification vehicles. With the cooperation of all citizens in water conservation, the challenge of the century-long drought was successfully overcome. Through the National Day celebration, it is hoped that the entire nation will join in expressing gratitude to these heroes who protect Taiwan.

After experiencing the impact of this century's severe drought, the Su Cabinet has strengthened the promotion of diverse water sources such as reclaimed water. At the beginning of 2022, the Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced amendments to certain provisions of the "Reclaimed Water Resources Development Act," removing the condition that reclaimed water must only be used in areas at risk of water supply shortages, significantly expanding the scope of reclaimed water usage. In the future, development projects above a certain scale will be required to use a certain proportion of reclaimed water. The applicable scope of reclaimed water, usage ratios, and the definition of "certain scale" will be reviewed every three years. On April 29, the amendment was passed in the Legislative Yuan without objection in its third reading.

The BBC reported that approximately 90% of the world's most advanced chips are produced in Taiwan, so Taiwan's drought could negatively impact the global electronics industry. In addition to the potential impact on the electronics industry, Taiwanese farmers are the most affected. The causes of this drought include not only climate change, with a significant decrease in the number of rainy days in Taiwan since the 1960s, but also excessively low water price adjustments leading Taiwanese people to take water for granted, water pipe leaks causing massive water resource waste, and the Taiwanese government's neglect of water resource management, which are the root causes of water shortages.

The Wall Street Journal pointed out that Taiwan, which accounts for two-thirds of the world's semiconductor manufacturing capacity, is experiencing the most severe drought in half a century. This comes at a time when the world is facing the most severe chip shortage in recent history, significantly increasing the pressure on Taiwan. Although the Taiwanese government has provided exceptional water allowances to semiconductor manufacturers to prevent major short-term impacts, the ongoing water shortage may force the water-intensive semiconductor industry to make adjustments. This could also lead to farmers, who urgently need water resources, being forced to abandon irrigation and leave their land barren due to water being prioritized for industrial zones. Due to climate change, water shortages may become a more persistent issue in the coming years.

The Tokyo Great Drought refers to a severe water shortage that occurred in Tokyo in the early 1960s. The one in 1964 was particularly severe and was also called the Olympic Drought or the Tokyo Desert.

The Tokyo metropolitan area was not originally a land blessed with abundant water resources, and until the 1960s, Tokyo's water supply relied heavily on the Tama River system, including the Ogouchi Dam. However, the Tama River system had a limited catchment area, resulting in insufficient supply, and the Arakawa River system also had the drawback of being difficult to manage due to significant fluctuations in water volume. Particularly in postwar Tokyo, water demand surged at a pace far exceeding expectations due to various factors such as rapid population growth, the spread of water supply systems, increased industrial water demand driven by high economic growth, the proliferation of electric washing machines and flush toilets, urban sprawl, and unregulated development. Consequently, from 1958, Tokyo began to experience droughts almost annually. The water supply from the Yodobashi Water Purification Plant in the Tama River system had already reached its limit, and abnormal weather conditions from 1960 to 1962, with average rainfall less than half of normal levels, exacerbated the prolonged drought in the Tama River system, leading to chronic large-scale water shortages in Tokyo. Starting in October 1961, Tokyo implemented a 20% water supply restriction, which was intensified to 35% in July 1962. During this period, water was unavailable from taps between 10 PM and 5 AM, as well as from 10 AM to 4 PM, affecting not only households but also manufacturing industries that relied on industrial water. 

As a countermeasure against water shortages, the Kanamachi Water Purification Plant for water intake from the Edogawa River was expanded in 1960, but this was far from solving the problem. In the spring of 1960, the government and the Liberal Democratic Party urgently established a Special Committee on Water Resource Measures. After inter-ministerial coordination, the Water Resources Development Corporation (now the Japan Water Agency) was established in May 1962 to comprehensively and systematically develop water resources on behalf of the government. Large-scale water resource development projects were initiated, such as connecting the Tone River and the Arakawa River via the Musashi Canal, to make the Tone River, with its wide basin area, a new major water source for Tokyo. However, the completion of the upstream dam group on the Tone River was not expected until 1967. To address the immediate crisis, construction of the Akigase Intake Weir and Asaka Canal for water intake from the Arakawa River began in November 1963. Additionally, in 1963, water intake from the Edogawa River was strengthened through the Edogawa System Expansion Project, and in 1964, surplus water from the Nakagawa River was diverted to the Edogawa River through the Nakagawa-Edogawa System Emergency Expansion Project, among other initiatives.

The water shortage in Tokyo in 1964, just before the Tokyo Olympics, was particularly severe, with little rainfall since May that year. By summer, the total water storage of the Ogouchi Dam, Murayama Reservoir, and Yamaguchi Reservoir had dropped to 1.6% of their full capacity, and the lakebeds dried up and cracked. By July, the water shortage had reached an extremely critical level. On July 22, an emergency meeting on Tokyo's water shortage was held by the national government, the Water Resources Development Corporation, and Tokyo officials, concluding to expedite water supply from the Tone River. Additionally, Ichiro Kono, the minister in charge of the Olympics, ordered the completion of the Akigase Intake Weir to be moved up from October to the end of August, considering the global attention on Tokyo during the Olympics. Meanwhile, the Social and Labor Committee of the House of Representatives addressed the water shortage disaster, pursuing the authorities on a bipartisan basis as a "humanitarian issue."

As the water shortage persisted into August, the government dispatched 25,000 Self-Defense Force personnel to assist, providing 7,000 cubic meters of emergency water supply to hospitals and households over 16 days using 215 water trucks. Additional support included water supply assistance from the Metropolitan Police Department and the U.S. military, as well as an emergency water diversion of 100,000 cubic meters per day from Kanagawa Prefecture. Eventually, Tokyo's water supply restrictions were raised to 45%.

From August 6, the fourth water supply restriction began in 17 wards of Tokyo, with water cut off for 15 hours a day. Pools and flush toilets were banned, and businesses such as barbershops, dry cleaners, ice makers, soba shops, sushi shops, and butcher shops were forced to close. Medical institutions could no longer perform surgeries and stopped seeing patients except for emergencies. Tokyo residents struggled with bathing, cooking, and laundry, mobilizing buckets, basins, and pots to secure water. People took days off work to wait for water trucks, collapsed from overwork while carrying water, experienced miscarriages, evacuated to areas with water, faced water theft, and fought over water, causing significant disruption to daily life. Newspapers frequently referred to the parched and dusty scenes in Tokyo as the "Tokyo Desert."

On August 13, artificial rain experiments began with airplanes spraying water over the Ogouchi Dam. On August 15, the water-saving target was raised from 45% to 50%. On August 20, long-awaited heavy rain fell in the water source areas, and on August 25, the Akigase Intake Weir was finally completed after rushed construction, allowing water from the Arakawa River to be channeled to the Higashimurayama Water Purification Plant. This marked a turning point in the severe water shortage. Ultimately, the water supply restrictions lasted a total of 1,259 days (about three and a half years).

In March 1965, the Musashi Waterway connecting the Tone River and the Arakawa River was almost completed (actual completion was in March 1967), and subsequently, the Tone River system saw the completion of the Yagisawa Dam in 1967, followed by the Shimokubo Dam and the Tone Ozeki in 1968. Tokyo's water supply came to rely 80% on the Tone River and Arakawa River systems, significantly reducing the risk of water shortage disasters in Tokyo. Since then, a large-scale water shortage comparable to the great Tokyo drought of that time has not occurred in Tokyo.
The drought of 1540 was an adverse climate event that impacted many populations in Europe and America. Temperatures in Central Europe exceeded 40°C, and some have called it a "megadrought."

1540, the year of Valdivia's arrival in the Mapocho Valley, was a year of drought, which caused famine among the indigenous people. The drought map of 1540 shows that the impact was in central Chile and extended to the Plata Basin.

The so-called "mega-drought" of Mexico and Yucatan, which began in 1540, caused epidemics and famines, and did not end until 1570; in Durango, the drought of 1540 extended until 1579 (or 1580, according to some), and was the worst of the last 700 years. This Mexican drought of 1540-1579 is placed within the framework of the "epic drought" —or mega-drought— of North America that extended until 1600 or 1605 and has been the worst of the last millennium and a half. In Spain, 1540 was a year of drought, with particular effects in the autumn and winter; in any case, in southern Spain, the drought of 1540 is simply described as "severe." The unusual droughts of the 16th century were the prelude to the Little Ice Age in Spain. The drought of 1540 in Europe was so severe that water cost more than wine, and the smoke from forest fires obscured the sun. The Rhine, Elbe, and Seine rivers were passable on foot; the Thames, lacking fresh water, was filled with seawater. The drought began in November 1539 and lasted eleven months.
In North Africa, Morocco, Algeria, and at least parts of Libya were not exempt from the drought of 1540.
