Whole_Text.content: For homonymous articles, see Water War. The water war in Chile refers to a series of crises affecting water resources in Chile at the beginning of the 21st century. Since the late 2000s, the country has faced a severe shortage due to years of drought. However, this shortage is compounded by significant socio-economic and political issues, including inequality in access to the resource, the constitutional framework, and challenges related to the extractive industry.

The year 2021 is the fourth driest year ever recorded in Chile. This year is part of a much longer drought period that has lasted since 2008, with the driest year being 2019; this decade is the driest in all of Chilean history. Several lakes completely disappeared during the 2010s, notably the Laguna de Aculeo. In 2019, 34,000 animals died due to a lack of water. The retreat of Chile's glaciers is very significant. For instance, forecasts indicate that the Maipo River will see its flow decrease by forty percent between 2019 and 2070 due to the retreat of its originating glacier. It is, however, the source of supply for 80% of its watershed. Precipitation in the Chilean Andes decreases by thirty millimeters every ten years on average, leading to a reduction in glacier mass of between eight and fifteen billion tons. Between 2000 and 2020, 98% of Andean glaciers retreated, losing an average of one meter in thickness, with the Andes being the most affected mountain range in the world by glacier melting. In the southern Andes, the planimetric retreat can reach nearly nine kilometers, and the annual measured decrease exceeds one meter. Historical precedents have been recorded, notably the drought of 1924-1925, considered until then the worst in Chilean history, and that of 1967-1969, locally referred to as the "silent earthquake." The latter is characterized by a precipitation deficit of more than 80% in the regions of Valparaiso and Bernardo O'Higgins; it caused the death of thousands of animals, the destruction of numerous fruit crops, and a water shortage affecting not only populations but also hydroelectric production.

In parallel, the risk of flooding is also increasing, particularly due to the rise in extreme weather events, but also their worsening caused by soil impermeabilization, which is mainly due to extensive urbanization. Fires have reduced the vegetation cover capable of retaining water, and drought has rendered the soil unsuitable for infiltration, so even a minor rainfall can become a disaster, as in 2017 when a five-millimeter rainfall caused floods that deprived six million residents of access to drinking water[3].

The institutional context is marked by a uniqueness unparalleled in the world. Indeed, the country's Constitution explicitly states that water rights are treated as private property. The management of water resources is codified by the Water Code (es) dating back to 1981, during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet. Water is considered a tradable asset, and water allocations can therefore be sold and purchased under the control of the General Directorate of Water (es), "Dirección General de Aguas." This entity grants "water rights," which consist of a maximum annual volume of water pumped per year and a maximum instantaneous flow rate. However, after the resource is pumped from its natural source, it completely exits the control of the DGA and can be sold to anyone. The directorate only has authority over the upstream resource, which it can decide to close temporarily or permanently. Water rights follow market laws, and allocations are granted based on priority, on the one hand, and financial power, on the other, as the cost of the allocation is high. Acquired rights are also transferable as private property[1],[7]. Furthermore, the Constitution allows the State to grant third parties free and unlimited usage rights and does not define any priority use of water. In particular, consumption and domestic use are not legally prioritized over economic uses of the water resource. Aquifer management committees are provided for by regulations, but representation is proportional to extraction, which only benefits large users[4],[7]. One of the few actions available to authorities is the prohibition of aquifer usage rights, but this is only used as a last resort when levels are already very low due to overexploitation[8]. Indigenous populations in Chile are particularly dispossessed because they do not view water as a marketable commodity and therefore have not submitted applications for allocations[7].

Thus, the disappearance of the Aculeo lagoon mentioned above is less due to the precipitation deficit than to the acquisition of water rights from the lake's tributaries by large agricultural plantations and private estates, which have pumped the main tributaries, notably to transform annual crops into fruit tree plantations. Indeed, during the 1990s, agro-food companies successively obtained rights to all the water from each of the lake's tributary rivers and extracted the majority of it. More broadly, 59% of the country's water resources are allocated to forestry and 37% to agriculture. The water supply for the population is covered by 2% of the available resource. The fruits cultivated thanks to the extraction of water resources are mainly avocados, grapes, and citrus fruits, primarily for export. Consequently, it is mainly the poorest rural populations, but also modest urban populations, who suffer the most from water shortages. Similarly, the extractive industry is also very water-intensive. Located in the extremely dry Atacama Desert, it nevertheless has underground aquifers buried beneath the salt flats, which it uses notably for the extraction of copper and lithium, the latter particularly in the Salar de Atacama.

As early as 2019, the issue of water was one of the reasons behind the 2019-2021 protests; demonstrators notably chanted the slogan "the problem is not the drought, it's the theft." By the end of 2021, more than half of Chile's population lived in an area suffering from a "severe water shortage," necessitating the declaration of a rationing state and the supply of hundreds of villages by tanker trucks. In 2020, Chile ranked eighteenth globally for high water stress, according to the World Resources Institute. In April 2022, President Gabriel Boric signed a reform of the Water Code, making water a public good intended for human use and recognizing its impact by climate change. On September 4, 2022, the Chilean people were invited to vote on a new constitution. However, the adoption of this new constitution was rejected by a large majority.

The drought in Europe in 1473 was a drought lasting 14 months. It affected both Western Europe as well as Central and Eastern Europe. Measured by its duration and spatial extent, it was the most outstanding heat and drought year of the past millennium. The weather pattern and its impacts were reconstructed based on coherent reports in contemporary historical documents. An investigation of stalagmites (speleothems) in northeastern Hungary indicates a warm-dry period in the 1470s. Affected present-day countries included: (southern) Sweden, Denmark, England, Ireland, Belgium, Netherlands, France, Switzerland, Germany, Poland, Ukraine, western Russia, Austria, Czech Republic, Slovak Republic, Hungary, Italy, Croatia, Serbia, parts of Spain.

The dating in the 15th century follows the Julian calendar. To align with the Gregorian calendar, 9 days must be added to a Julian date. Estimates of temperature development can be derived from weather descriptions in connection with plant phenological (phenology) as well as snow- and frost-related observations in the form of indices. Historical climatology. Additionally, tree ring data were used.

The winter of 1473 in Metz was "rainy," in Basel "without snow and ice." "In February" (i.e., early March), the cherry trees in Basel began to bloom as a result of record-high temperatures in the preceding weeks. April was "hot." At the beginning of May, the vines began to bloom. In the following month, "the heat was almost unbearable." At the beginning of June, the cherries were ripe, and a month later, the first grapes. During the same period, wheat was harvested. White grapes were harvested in French Metz starting on August 13, and red Pinot Noir grapes in French Beaune starting on September 5. The harvest was abundant, but in some places, the grapes had dried out, and the fermentation of the grape must left much to be desired. Overall, the vegetation development was consistently 4–5 weeks early. In the autumn, the cherry trees bloomed again. In November, in some places, the cherries ripened for the second time. In December, flowers bloomed in Basel at "spring-like" temperatures. The following winter of 1474 was again rainy without frost in eastern France, and the Baltic Sea became ice-free early. In Central Europe, the "high mountains" – presumably the peaks of the Black Forest at altitudes of 1200 to 1500 meters – remained without snow throughout the winter, as recorded by the Basel jurist Johannes Knebel in his diary. Snowfall beginning on March 2, 1474, ended the 14-month-long warm period.

Some chroniclers recorded the beginning and end of the period without significant rainfall. Parts of Spain were largely dry during the winter half-year of 1472–1473, the Seville area from September 1472 to May 1473. In Zierikzee, located 50 km northwest of Rotterdam, no rain fell from May to October 1473. In Bohemia, the drought lasted three and a half months, in Breslau from May 2 to November 20, in Basel during the nine weeks from June 29 to mid-September. In the Italian Po Valley around Modena, there was hardly any rain during the 14 months from early 1473 to March 1474.

Springs, streams, and small rivers dried up completely, larger rivers like the Moselle turned into trickles, shallow waterways in the Netherlands stank. Rivers like the Rhine and Danube could be easily crossed. Rivers in western Russia experienced low water levels. In late summer, many deciduous trees in the Basel area shed their leaves and looked "like at Christmas." Swarms of migratory locusts plagued Europe in the following years.

Whole_Text.header: Impacts on economy, society, and health
Whole_Text.content: The mills stood still, leading to shortages of flour and bread, and in some areas, drinking water dried up. Widespread forest, bush, and settlement fires broke out. In Northern Italy and parts of Spain, crop failures and famines followed long autumn and winter drought periods. In Spain, "Conversos" – converted Jews – were blamed as scapegoats for the misery and burned at the stake. Numerous deaths in the Netherlands, England, and Hungary were attributed to the heat and/or the associated infectious diseases ("Pestis").[4] This likely included cases of bacterial dysentery.

Heat summers were and are often triggered by dry spring periods, which significantly dry out the soil, amplifying the effect of summer solar radiation. The year 1473 marked the peak of several warm winters, springs, and hot-dry summers from 1471 to 1474. The drought of 1473 lasted longer than the drought of 1540 in Europe, covered a larger area, and affected several years with varying intensity, whereas the drought of 1540 was a relatively isolated climatic event. The multi-year heat surge in the early 1470s is unique during the European Little Ice Age from 1340 to around 1900. The Old World Drought Atlas, primarily based on tree ring data, confirms the nearly pan-European dimension of the 1473 drought. It was part of a transatlantic drought period that lasted from 1437 to 1473. In the southwestern part of today's USA, it was the worst in the last 1000 years. This extreme period is attributed to a hydroclimatic factor, possibly due to long-term changes in the surface temperature of the North Atlantic.

Article_Name: Seca na região Norte do Brasil em 2023-2024 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Drought in the Northern region of Brazil in 2023-2024
Whole_Text.content: The drought in the Northern region of Brazil between 2023 and 2024 is a large-scale climatic event that began in the second half of 2023 in Brazil. It is considered one of the worst droughts in the region's history, mainly caused by El Niño, the warming of the northern Atlantic Ocean, and environmental crimes. It is characterized by low precipitation levels in the northern region of the country, primarily impacting the states of Amazonas, Acre, Roraima, Amapá, Rondônia, and Pará. In the state of Amazonas alone, more than 630,000 people were affected by the drought. A study conducted by the World Weather Attribution (WWA), a consortium of scientists from various countries studying the causes and effects of climatic events, attributed human activity as the main factor responsible for the drought, accelerating ongoing climate change. Furthermore, the study concluded that the poorest and most isolated populations in the Amazon were the most affected by the climatic event.

Paleoclimatic indicators suggest that the Amazon region has experienced periods of severe drought thousands of years ago. The most recent known events occurred in the years 1912, 1925, 1964, 1980, 1983, 1997/1998, 2005, 2010, and the most recent in 2023. The causes of these events have generally been associated with variations in the temperature circulation patterns of the Pacific and tropical Atlantic oceans, mainly due to natural causes. However, recent studies have suggested the influence of human actions in causing droughts, whether through deforestation or intentional fires, which can extend the dry season in the region and delay the onset of the rainy phase.

In the year 2005, the Amazon experienced a major drought that affected about 700,000 square kilometers in the region, considered the largest of the century. According to NASA scientists, the drought during this period damaged the forest cover in a widespread manner, such that its effects were still visible 5 years after the event. Researchers indicated that the causes of the event, which mainly affected the southern region of the Amazon between the Madeira and Solimões Rivers, were the increases in the surface temperature of the Atlantic Ocean.

Five years later, another severe drought hit the same region, this time considered the most drastic in history, but this time it affected the central and eastern Amazon regions more intensely. The damages were greater than the previous drought, causing a significant reduction in river levels, especially affecting riverside populations who were isolated due to their dependence on rivers for transportation. Scientists from Inpe indicated that the cause of this drought was the simultaneous occurrence of the El Niño phenomenon along with the warming of the tropical waters of the North Atlantic. A study published in the journal Science concluded that during the 2010 drought, the Amazon rainforest received 57% less rainfall than usual, while during the 2005 drought, there was 37% less rainfall. Another conclusion of the study was that carbon emissions in 2010 from the decomposition of dead vegetation in the forest were higher than those during the 2005 drought. In July 2023, scientists were already warning about the possibility of the El Niño phenomenon increasing wildfires in the Amazon region due to its influence on changes in Pacific Ocean temperatures and the disruption of the region's rainfall patterns.

According to studies by the Scientific Center of the European Union, all nine countries in the Amazon basin experienced the lowest rainfall volumes in the last 40 years for the period from July to September 2023. Additionally, between August and November, maximum temperatures were 2 to 5ºC above the historical average, characterizing the heatwaves that affected the region. In the state of Amazonas, rainfall ranged from 100 to 350 millimeters below normal, which corresponds to about half the expected volume for the area. On September 29, Governor Wilson Lima of Amazonas declared a state of emergency in 55 municipalities in the state for six consecutive months, in addition to determining actions to mitigate the effects of the drought. By early November, a state of emergency was declared for all 62 municipalities in the state. Along with the historic drought, the region faced a severe environmental emergency related to intense wildfires, which in October alone accounted for about 3,900, the worst scenario in the last 25 years. On October 6, the state government of Acre declared a state of emergency due to the abrupt reduction in the levels of the Acre, Purus, Juruá, Tarauacá, Envira, Iaco, and Moa rivers. In Pará, the drought mainly affected the western region of the state, where the level of the Tapajós River dropped to 55 centimeters (the lowest mark since the 2010 drought), but it also affected the southwestern and southeastern regions, as well as the Marajó region. In November, 24 municipalities in the state declared a state of emergency, while 21 municipalities had their emergency situation recognized by the Ministry of Integration and Regional Development. The Federal Government released about R$32 million to the state to combat the effects caused by the drought. On October 19, the Federal Government of Brazil recognized the emergency situation caused by the drought in the municipality of Tartarugalzinho, the first city in Amapá to enter a state of emergency. However, on November 22, the state government of Amapá extended the emergency decree to all its 16 municipalities due to the intense drought. In the state of Rondônia, only on December 15 was a state of emergency declared, which was instituted for the entire state along with a water crisis committee to mitigate the effects of the prolonged drought in the region. In Roraima, it was found on December 21 that the entire state region presented areas of moderate or severe drought according to the Drought Monitor of the National Water and Basic Sanitation Agency (ANA), marking the first time the state appeared in the survey. According to studies by the Laboratory of Terrestrial Climate System Modeling (Labclim) of the State University of Amazonas (UEA), rainfall in the state of Amazonas is expected to normalize only in February 2024.

The impacts of the drought period strongly affected the Rio Negro, which on October 24, 2023, recorded the lowest level in its entire measurement history (which began in 1902): 12.70 meters, surpassing the record of 13.63 meters from 2010. As a consequence, there were significant changes in the river's landscape, navigation losses, difficulties in the flow of production from the Manaus industrial hub, and the early closure of the school year for riverside community schools near the river in the capital of Amazonas (two weeks earlier than usual). In the Rio Purus, the impact was also notable, with the fifth worst drought in history since measurements began in 1967 by the Brazilian Geological Service. The impacts of its reduced level affected more than 140,000 people, just along the river's course. During an erosion event, the Rio Solimões, in turn, recorded the lowest level in history in October 2023, according to information from the Brazilian Geological Service, reaching 3.61 meters at the Manacapuru station. This level is lower than the previous record set during the 2010 drought: 3.92 meters. In some sections of the river, such as in the municipality of Tefé, large sandbanks formed, hindering mobility and the lives of local communities. The Rio Branco, located in the state of Roraima, recorded a level of 0.60 meters on November 29, the lowest level since 2016, when the El Niño phenomenon also affected the region. On December 21, the level dropped to 0.44 meters. On the same date the previous year, it had recorded a level of 3.11 meters. The low level of the Rio Madeira caused the Santo Antônio Hydroelectric Plant in Rondônia to halt operations for two weeks (from October 2 to 16). This was the second time in history that the plant had to suspend its operations, and in 2022 it had achieved the fourth-largest electricity production in Brazil.

Starting in August 2023, the capital Manaus was affected by large clouds of smoke, intensified by the arrival of drought in the region. On October 11, the World Air Quality Index (WAQI), which measures levels of particulate matter and pollutant gases such as ozone and carbon monoxide in the atmosphere of cities worldwide, indicated that the city of Manaus was the second city with the worst air quality on the entire planet. According to Ibama, these events were due to fires occurring in the Metropolitan Region of Manaus. The smoke extended until the month of November, when a sandstorm also occurred in the Amazonian capital, caused by wind gusts on the dried-out ground, raising large amounts of dust and dirt.

In some regions of the states of Amazonas and Pará, water temperatures above expected averages were identified. Fish and reptiles, being ectothermic, have difficulty surviving when they reach certain body temperature limits, in addition to the fact that warmer waters show a reduction in dissolved oxygen concentration, which can lead some animals to death. An example of this was Lake Janauacá (near Manaus), which during the 2023 drought recorded temperatures between 31.8°C and 38°C, oxygen concentration close to 0.38 mg/L (Conama's resolution establishes that the limit value for the preservation of aquatic life is 5.0 mg/L) and, consequently, a series of dead fish, alligators, and even turtles. In Lake Tefé, 521 kilometers from Manaus, a total of 159 pink river dolphins and tucuxis died from September to the end of 2023. During this period, temperatures of up to 41°C were observed in certain parts of the lakes, in addition to record air temperatures in nearby municipalities. Furthermore, about 117 of these same animals were found dead in the city of Coari, near Tefé. The Chico Mendes Institute for Biodiversity Conservation (ICMBIO) suspects that the drought in the region may have contributed to these occurrences. According to climatologist Carlos Nobre, collected data demonstrate that the Amazon rainforest is being rapidly destroyed due to the combination of drought and fires, predicting an increase of up to 300% in tree mortality. A study coordinated by Dr. Cristhiana Paula Röpke from Inpa, with support from the Amazonas State Research Support Foundation (Fapeam), found that the drought led to a reduction in fish diversity and an increase in dominant species relative to the total number of individuals. The climatic phenomenon affected fish movement, access to food, and indications of when to reproduce.

There were significant economic impacts in the state of Amazonas, especially due to the difficulty in transporting production from the Manaus Industrial Hub, fish deaths, and a reduction in tourism in the region. Some areas, such as the Tumbira Community in the Rio Negro Sustainable Development Reserve (RDS), where about 70% of the economy is focused on community-based tourism, suffered severe economic losses. According to the Institute for Conservation and Sustainable Development of the Amazon (IDESAM), community-based tourism, pirarucu management, and timber forest management were severely impacted during the crisis caused by the drought in the Amazon region. In the Ituxí Extractive Reserve (municipality of Lábrea), located in southern Amazonas, where pirarucu management is one of the main sources of income, a high mortality rate of this fish species was reported. Additionally, the difficulty in transporting products left local merchants and producers without alternatives during the river drought period, forcing local leaders to stockpile food for the long term. Due to the intense drought, combined with an increase in product demand, about 33 companies in the Manaus Free Trade Zone had to bring forward collective vacations to October, which usually occurred at the beginning of December. According to the president of the metalworkers' union of Amazonas, between 15,000 and 17,000 workers were laid off earlier than expected. According to IBGE data, industrial production in Amazonas fell by 5.7% in October compared to the same period the previous year. In November, compared to the previous month, industrial production dropped by 4.2%. On an annual comparison, the state's production decreased by 10.3% in November 2023. The Amazonas industry also incurred over R$1.4 billion in additional costs due to the lack of inputs and difficulty in transporting final products. Furthermore, there was an 83% drop in imports via the waterway mode in the state due to the historic drought. In western Pará, fish mortality affected more than 33,000 fishermen, who were left without a source of income when the region's rivers and lakes dried up. The economic impact on this population was so significant that the federal government provided two minimum wage payments as defeso insurance for the affected population.

The people most affected by the drought were indigenous and riverside communities, who mainly survive on resources from the region's rivers and were almost completely isolated due to the low river levels. In the municipality of Lábrea, in southern Amazonas, about 90% of the villages suffer losses in food, health, and transportation due to the dry season. In the Jarawara/Jamamadi/Kanamati Indigenous Land, the drought in the Purus River basin affected 10 villages due to the impossibility of transporting students, the entry of health teams, and especially fishing activities. In the Caititu Indigenous Land, the occurrence of fires caused the death of animals, destruction of crops, and health problems for the territory's inhabitants. Munduruku villages in the Kwatá-Laranjal Indigenous Land, living near the Canumã River bed (a tributary of the Madeira River), had to dig wells to obtain water during the dry season, faced difficulties in transporting people and goods in the region, affecting their livelihood. In the municipality of São Gabriel da Cachoeira, where 93% of the population identifies as indigenous, the drought affected indigenous villages that rely on fishing and farming, as there was a significant fish die-off, worsening water quality, energy rationing, and school closures. In the city of Tefé (Amazonas), the riverside population faced difficulties obtaining drinking water as the streams dried up completely and turned into overheated sandbanks. Thus, the population had to fetch water from the city and carry it over long distances to their homes. Additionally, in the same municipality, sections of the Solimões River dried up completely starting in September 2023, forming large sandbanks and affecting the lives of Kokama, Ticuna, and Maioruna indigenous peoples in the Porto Praia de Baixo Indigenous Land. The difficulty of accessing the territory due to the drought hindered fishing and the journey to the city, which indigenous peoples use to sell their products. In the Murutinga/Tracajá Indigenous Land, in the municipality of Autazes near Manaus, the river almost completely disappeared along the village's banks, affecting the supply of drinking water, making transportation difficult, and causing fish deaths, impacting more than 3,000 people. In the municipality of Beruri (Amazonas), in one of the curves of the Purus River, two people died and three others went missing due to the formation of a crater worsened by the intense drought. Furthermore, the accident in Vila Arumã (formed by a riverside community) destroyed about 45 homes, a health post, a school, and three churches. The crater formed on September 30 due to an erosive process exacerbated by illegal deforestation in the region and the drought, as trees have the capacity to maintain soil integrity, which, when it dries very abruptly as it did in 2023, increases pressure on the riverbed and intensifies the effect of "fallen lands" (natural collapse of riverbank slopes). Nine leaders of indigenous communities in Roraima reported suffering from water shortages, vegetation death (affecting livestock feeding), and cassava crops that are not being harvested in the necessary quantity and quality for the production of flour, beiju, starch, and other traditional foods.

An archaeological site containing rock carvings with human features, which had already appeared during the 2010 drought at Ponta das Lajes (near the confluence of the Negro and Solimões rivers), reemerged during the drought in October in Manaus. The severity of the river level reduction this time exposed more carvings than the previous drought and even a human feature carved into rock. The site, which includes a beach covered with stone slabs, is located on the banks of the Negro River and covers an area of approximately 150,000 square meters. According to archaeologists from Iphan, the carvings, whose estimated age is between two thousand and one thousand years, are testimonies to the way of life of pre-colonial peoples who inhabited the Manaus region. Three other previously unknown archaeological sites were revealed by the drought that occurred in 2023. These bring historical records and more information about the way of life of the peoples who inhabited the region during the pre-colonial period. One of them is the Forte São Francisco Xavier, located on the banks of the Solimões River in the municipality of Tabatinga (Amazonas), near the tri-border area with Peru and Colombia. The fort, which was buried and submerged due to land collapses, was built with thick wood and has an irregular hexagonal shape. According to Iphan, the fort marks Portuguese dominance in the Amazon region during the colonial era and was the last stop for those heading to the Andes. In the city of Anamã (Amazonas), another archaeological site called Costa do Goiabeira was found, where ceramic funerary urns were discovered. Another discovery occurred in the municipality of Urucará (Amazonas), where new rock carvings were found, similar to those seen at the Ponta das Lajes site.

Article_Name: 2022年长江流域干旱 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.header: Drought in the Yangtze River Basin in 2022
Whole_Text.content: In 2022, the Yangtze River Basin experienced a rare drought spanning summer, autumn, and winter. This drought event was a compound drought caused by abnormally low precipitation during the summer and autumn seasons combined with abnormally high temperatures, extending into the winter drought and lasting an unusually long time. Among these, the high-temperature drought characteristics across the entire basin in August were the most significant. At the peak of the drought, over 50 million people were affected, more than 7.5 million people required assistance, water levels in multiple reservoirs along the Yangtze River approached dead water levels, and the areas of Poyang Lake and Dongting Lake were severely reduced. This also triggered wildfires, power shortages, and other issues, resulting in direct economic losses exceeding 50 billion yuan.

The drought in the Yangtze River Basin began in July 2022 [1]. During this period, precipitation in some upstream and downstream areas of the basin was 50% to 80% less than usual, leading to mild to moderate drought [1]. From July to August, the Yangtze River Basin was controlled by the westward extension of the Western Pacific Subtropical High, preventing cold air from the north from moving southward, which suppressed rainfall and further intensified the drought [4]. From August to October, precipitation in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River and areas south of it was about 90% less than usual, resulting in severe to extreme summer-autumn consecutive droughts. Temperatures in August were 2 to 4 degrees Celsius higher than usual, with some areas 4 to 6 degrees higher, and the abnormal high temperatures covered the severely drought-affected regions. With the end of the East Asian summer monsoon, the drought area shrank somewhat from November to December [1].

Entering September, due to the influence of the autumn rains in western China, temperatures in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River basin were lower than average, while temperatures in the middle reaches remained 2 to 4 degrees Celsius higher than average, overlapping with areas experiencing severe drought. From October to November, temperatures across large areas of the Yangtze River basin are expected to remain predominantly above average.

In December, influenced by strong cold air, the basin's temperature was approximately 2 degrees Celsius lower than average. As a result, the Yangtze River Basin experienced a rare consecutive drought spanning summer, autumn, and winter. This drought event was a compound drought caused by abnormally low precipitation in the late summer and autumn seasons combined with abnormally high temperatures, and it extended into the winter drought, resulting in an unusually long duration.

Research shows that the high-temperature and drought events in the Yangtze River Basin in 2022 were influenced by the synergistic effects of mid-high latitude and tropical circulation [5]. From July to August in summer, the Yangtze River Basin was under the control of the westward-extending Western Pacific Subtropical High, making it difficult for cold air from the north to move southward, which was unfavorable for precipitation [4]. Against the backdrop of climate warming, the probability of concurrent high-temperature and drought events has significantly increased, further exacerbating the drought conditions in the Yangtze River Basin [1].

Article_Name: Crisis hídrica en Petorca, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The water crisis in Petorca corresponds to the megadrought phenomenon that originated in the 1990s in the province of Petorca, Valparaíso region, Chile.

Petorca is characterized by its mountainous geography and the presence of rivers such as the Petorca, which originates from the union of the Sobrante River and the Pedernal River, which have historically been sources of water for human consumption and agriculture.

Since the 1990s, the agro-export industry has grown significantly, increasing the demand for water for crops that require large amounts of this resource, such as avocados. This claim is emphatically denied by representatives of the area's agro-industry, whose business representatives argue that avocados consume less water than other species, attributing the scarce water availability to the "lack of state investment in reservoir and irrigation infrastructure." The water crisis has had a devastating impact on the communities of Petorca. Many families have lost access to drinking water and are forced to rely on water trucks for supply, which represents a significant cost and an additional burden in their lives. Additionally, the lack of water has affected family farming, which used to be a source of livelihood and trade for the region's inhabitants. Since 2006, rainfall in the area has not reached normal yearly levels, affecting the available flows for human consumption and agricultural use. In 2010, MODATIMA emerged, an organization dedicated to defending the right to water access for farmers, workers, and residents of the Petorca province. Due to the reduction of flow in the Petorca, La Ligua, and Aconcagua river basins, on November 24, 2010, the Ministry of Public Works declared a water emergency for these valleys in the Valparaíso region. On February 9, an agricultural emergency was declared in seven communes of the Valparaíso region: La Ligua, Petorca, Cabildo, Zapallar, Papudo, Putaendo, and Nogales. In 2014, the National Institute of Human Rights issued a report on the water crisis, where up to 65 illegal drainage works were found diverted for avocado cultivation. In 2016, during the administration of Governor Mario Fuentes Romero in Michelle Bachelet's second government, the province of Petorca was declared a water scarcity zone. This allowed for the provision of water truck services to deliver water to the population. As a long-term solution, it was proposed to direct water from the Aconcagua and Maipo rivers, among other measures. In 2017, only 4,763 hectares of avocado trees were surveyed in the basin, a 45% decrease compared to 2008. In 2018, 4,778 people had to receive drinking water supply via water trucks. Sebastián Piñera's second government implemented strict control of wells from which water is extracted, the formation and empowerment of Vigilance Boards among farmers to monitor and demand compliance with the law, and allocated a budget of $173,000,000 for the construction of the Las Palmas reservoir with a capacity of 55 million cubic meters, set to begin operations in 2024. Another less advanced project is the construction of the Pedernal reservoir with 31 million cubic meters for the irrigation of 1,800 hectares. In Los Quinquelles, a coastal area of the La Ligua commune, a desalination plant has been built. In 2020, the water scarcity in the La Ligua and Petorca areas was addressed in the episode "Avocado Wars" of the Netflix series Rotten.

Article_Name: Pożar Puszczy Noteckiej – Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia

Whole_Text.content: Polish Noteć Forest fire August 10, 1992, 16:27 0 The Noteć Forest fire – the second largest forest fire in Poland after World War II (after the fire in Kuźnia Raciborska), which took place in the Noteć Forest on August 10 and 11, 1992.

The forest caught fire at 4:27 PM on August 10, 1992, between Miał and Drawski Młyn due to sparks from the blocked brakes of a train on the Poznań–Krzyż route. Despite the immediate firefighting efforts, the fire spread quickly, partly due to the low humidity of the undergrowth. The fire lasted until 12:30 AM the next day and was extinguished thanks to a sudden storm, which put out the fire in just 15 minutes, saving the remaining part of the Noteć Forest. Within nine hours, nearly 6,000 hectares of forest, 19 farm buildings, and three farms were burned. There were no human casualties.

The removal of the effects of the fire lasted three years. The Regional Directorate of State Forests in Piła deployed all its forest districts to work. Five thousand people, including 4,000 loggers, worked on clearing the burned forest. One million cubic meters of wood were harvested from the burned area. On the site of the burned forest, 80 million seedlings were planted, significantly changing the structure of the future forest stand. Before the fire, pine accounted for 99 percent, and birch only 0.4 percent of the tree species composition. In the new forest stand, pine accounts for only 74 percent, birch for as much as 18 percent, and oak and larch for 2 percent each. This is the most species-diverse fragment of the forest stand in the Noteć Forest. Along the railway tracks, 8-meter-wide firebreaks (devoid of vegetation) were created, as well as biological safety strips 50 to 100 meters wide, covered exclusively with deciduous species – resistant to fire. Deciduous tree strips were also created across the entire area of the former burned site; they divide it into many sections, serving as natural barriers to potential fires. In the area of the restored forest, no further than 1.5 kilometers apart, tanks with a capacity of 40–60 thousand liters were installed (each can supply about 20 firefighting vehicles). Natural terrain depressions, where water appeared, were also deepened, creating nine water reservoirs.

In 2004, an exhibition dedicated to the fire and the elimination of its effects was created at the Chamber of Natural and Forest Education in Potrzebowice on the initiative of the local forest district.

Article_Name: Πυρκαγιά στη δασική περιοχή του Ρούντι Ρατσιμπόρσκιε - Βικιπαίδεια

Whole_Text.header: Fire in the forest area of Rudy Raciborskie
Whole_Text.content: The fire in the forest area of Rudy Raciborskie was the largest fire that occurred in Poland and Central Europe after World War II. The fire that affected the forest in the area of Kuźnia Raciborska, Kędzierzyn-Koźle, Rudy Raciborskie, and Rudziniec lasted from August 26 to August 30, 1992, and burned 9,062 hectares (90.62 km²).

The fire started on August 26, 1992, around 1:50 p.m., and moments later it was noticed in forest area 109 (on the railway line connecting Racibórz with Kędzierzyn-Koźle), in the forest section of Rudy Raciborskie, near the town of Solarni. The meteorological conditions were extremely favorable for the fire - temperatures above 32°C were recorded on August 30 in Kalisz and 38°C in Łódź. There was a strong southern wind. A mountain wind was blowing in the Tatra Mountains, and the humidity of forest litter was extremely low. The possible cause of ignition was a spark from the train's braking wheels. The fire was extinguished only four days later and completely put out by September 12. The massive use of PZL-Mielec M-18 Dromader aircraft[3] dropping water at the fire's front played a significant role in the firefighting process. Additionally, about 1,100 fire trucks, helicopters, 50 railway tankers, and 6 locomotives, as well as heavy equipment such as engineering tanks, plows, and bulldozers, participated in the firefighting operation. In total, about 10,000 people were involved in the firefighting operation.[4] The destruction in the forest areas of Rudy Raciborskie, Rudziniec, and Kędzierzyn had the characteristics of an ecological disaster. Two people lost their lives in the fire: firefighter Andrzej Kaczina from the Fire Service Headquarters in Racibórz, who was posthumously promoted to the rank of chief, and his friend Andrzej Malinowski from the volunteer fire service in Kuźnia Raciborska. Fifty people were hospitalized, and about 2,000 were slightly injured and received assistance on-site. Fifteen fire trucks and 26 mechanical pumps were burned. The fire's hot ash destroyed 70 kilometers of fire hoses. A total of 9,062 hectares burned, 6,212 hectares in the then Katowice Voivodeship and 2,850 hectares in the then Opole Voivodeship. Buildings and production units were not damaged.[4] Since 1993, in August, a two-day memorial has been held for Kaczina and Malinowski - initially a cycling race, later an international wrestling competition combined with mass sports events, a two-day festival, and star concerts to honor the firefighters who lost their lives in the fight against the fire.

Whole_Text.content: The Tuntsa forest fire was the largest forest fire in Finland's recent history. It raged from the end of June 1960 in the Tuntsa wilderness in the northern parts of the Salla municipality and even more extensively on the Soviet Union's side. The fire likely started from a lightning strike, and its spread was facilitated by the hot summer. There were two fire areas on the Finnish side: in the Papuoiva–Puitsi–Peuratunturi area and another in the Kuskoiva–Nuolusoiva area. Nearly 500 men were involved in extinguishing the fire in Finland. On the Finnish side, the fire destroyed about 20,000 hectares, while on the Soviet side, the fire area was approximately 100,000 hectares. About half of the burned area on the Finnish side was actual forest land, while the rest consisted of sparsely forested barren and wastelands as well as treeless fell areas. The forestry-related damages caused by the fire were ultimately minor, but the fire disrupted the region's reindeer husbandry by destroying the best winter pastures for reindeer. After the fire, a large-scale "Tuntsa soot logging" operation was organized to salvage the remaining timber in the area. The logging operation was the largest in Europe and at its peak employed a thousand people and hundreds of tractors. During the logging operation, which continued until 1967, a total of about 300,000 cubic meters of wood was salvaged from the burned area. For the first time, a grapple machine was tested in timber harvesting, and chainsaws were also widely adopted during the operation. After the timber harvesting, efforts were made to regenerate the Tuntsa fire area forest through sowing and planting, but this was only partially successful, and part of the burned area remained permanently treeless. The traces of both the fire and the timber harvesting are still visible in the area. There is also a dense road network, originally built for the soot logging operation.

Article_Name: Incendi de l'Alt Empordà de 1986 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Alt Empordà fire of 1986 was a forest fire that took place in this region from July 19, 1986, until, after five days and six nights, its end on July 25. In total, it burned more than 19,612 hectares of forest and agricultural land across 21 municipalities in the Alt Empordà. The Albera mountain range was completely devastated, and the fire involved the crash of one of the firefighting planes, resulting in the death of its four occupants and contributing to the spread of the fire. It is unknown whether the fire was intentional or not, though negligence is suspected. The fire started between the Coll de Panissars and El Pertús and reached as far as Cadaqués, Roses, and Figueres. It did not penetrate the Empordà wetlands because a small fire that had occurred a week earlier had burned the area and acted as a firebreak. The tramuntana wind — which reached speeds of over 120 km/h at times — contributed to the fire's spread southward. Throughout the period, the fire had more than 80 active fire points, and the firefighting efforts were overwhelmed by the scale of the tragedy. The weather conditions for the fire's spread were very unfavorable, and there were other simultaneous fires in Catalonia. This meant that, despite the involvement of around 60 ground vehicles, 400 firefighters, and Spanish and French firefighting planes, the resources dedicated to extinguishing the fire were very limited, allowing the fire to spread almost freely for much of the time.

A French DC-6 aircraft, which was participating in firefighting tasks, crashed on July 19 at Puig de les Canals while heading from south to north during the first day of the fire. All occupants died. The explosion widened the fire on the left flank and facilitated its spread. A couple of hours later, French firefighters crossed the border to recover the pilots' bodies; they accessed the site via the track at Coll del Pla de l’Arca (Coll de l’Auleda). On their way there and back, the fire burned through an area of holm oak forest, where it eventually stopped on its own. Nevertheless, the assistance of French water bombers, which dampened the track area to allow firefighters to reach the plane, contributed to recovering the bodies and returning to France via the same route. Meanwhile, and without knowledge of the French firefighters' recovery of the bodies, a judicial and forensic team from Figueres, accompanied by the Spanish Civil Guard, approached the site to also retrieve the victims' bodies. However, they found that the bodies were no longer there, and the route they had taken was surrounded by flames. The convoy of vehicles they were traveling in—a Renault 4, a Seat 127, a funeral car, and another judicial vehicle—had to follow a very rough track and exit through Le Perthus, in Northern Catalonia and under French jurisdiction. The remains of the crashed aircraft have remained there since then, as it was deemed logistically and economically unfeasible to remove them at the time. A few meters away, a multicolored marble plaque was erected in tribute to the four victims: pilot Jean Pierre Davenat, co-pilot Jacques Ogier, mechanic Roland Denard, and assistant Jack Le Bel. For a few years, a forest track was established for exclusive access by off-road vehicles to hold commemorations. Later, however, the area became covered by regenerated oak forests after the fire, and various parts and debris from the plane, such as the last remaining propeller until 2016, were looted. The site where the aircraft is located became a tourist attraction for hiking and a regular route for geocaching enthusiasts.

Whole_Text.content: The forest fire in Froland 2008 ("Mykland fire") started on June 9, 2008, in Mykland in Froland municipality; after six days, the fire covered an area of about 30 km² (30,000 acres) before firefighters gained control on June 14, 2008. This made it the largest forest fire in Norway since World War II, though not the most expensive. The fire may have caused damages exceeding 60 million kroner.

The forest fire started on June 9 as a result of sparks from a forestry machine. The forest fire particularly threatened the settlement of Mykland in Froland municipality. After four days, as many as 250 people from the Home Guard, the fire department, and the Civil Defense were involved in the firefighting efforts. Several helicopters, including two from the Armed Forces, participated in the firefighting efforts. The fire was so large that the smell of smoke from it could be noticed in Kristiansand and on the other side of the Skagerrak in Thisted, Denmark.

Over 15 cabins burned to the ground or were severely damaged as a result of the fire. Five high-voltage poles also burned down in the affected area, leading to power outages in some areas. Somewhere between 20,000 and 30,000 acres of forest were affected by the wildfire. Over 70 people were evacuated from their homes. The economic loss was estimated at 30 million kroner after three days of wildfire.

Personnel from local and regional fire services directed the firefighting efforts, along with the police's incident management. Additionally, personnel from the Civil Defense, Home Guard, and Armed Forces contributed. The number of personnel was increased as the fire developed, and at its peak, between 250 and 300 people were involved. At one point, better aerial firefighting support was requested, and receiving support from the EU was considered. Italy offered a firefighting aircraft, but the Government's crisis council - led by Minister of Justice Knut Storberget - deemed the 16 helicopters that were eventually deployed to be sufficient.

In December 2008, NIVA stated that the forest fire had an unexpected and undesirable effect on the water in the area. Sulfate in the soil, originally deposited by acid rain, has subsequently been released by new rainfall and has now ended up in streams, lakes, and rivers. The acidification is worse than in the 1980s. NIVA estimates that all fish and amphibians have been eradicated.

Whole_Text.content: The Flatanger fire in 2014 was a heathland fire that broke out on the evening of January 27, 2014, and spread very quickly in strong winds. The fire claimed no human lives but destroyed or damaged 64 buildings—more than any other fire in Norway since 1945. 23 of the buildings were residential houses or holiday homes. The fire lasted until midday on January 29. King Harald visited Flatanger three days after the fire. The utility company NTE was acquitted in the compensation case. The fire scorched approximately 15 km², making it the largest in Norway since the forest fire in Froland in 2008. The fire caused damages amounting to around 150 million kroner. The Flatanger fire was one of three very large fires in Norway during the winter of 2014. Both these three and many smaller fires occurred after a prolonged (and for the season extreme) drought period, including in Lærdal and Frøya. 500 people participated in the firefighting and rescue efforts, including personnel from 21 fire stations and neighboring municipalities. Two Coast Guard vessels, five helicopters, and a rescue boat were deployed. The Ministry of Justice concluded that the fire services in Flatanger, Lærdal, and Frøya handled the fires well. Following these major fires, the DSB initiated larger units and cooperation between municipalities on fire and rescue services. After the 2014 fire, the leadership of the fire service in Flatanger was transferred to Namsos, while the personnel remain in Flatanger.

The weather had for weeks been characterized by a strong high-pressure system in the east. This blocked the usual passage of low-pressure systems from the west. Instead, the low-pressure systems remained roughly over Great Britain. This led to easterly to southeasterly winds over most of Norway. As a result, Western Norway, Trøndelag, and Northern Norway were in the rain shadow, and in many places, January was the driest on record. In Trondheim, the relative humidity was measured at 33% on January 26. Flatanger received only 2 mm of precipitation in the last three weeks before the fire. Additionally, the ground was snow-free after an unusually mild period early in the month. In many places, the dry wind was very strong, with gales and occasionally small storms in exposed areas. This is not extreme for this part of the Norwegian coast, but the strongest winds usually come from the southwest to northwest. Furthermore, offshore winds are often more uneven and turbulent, as was the case here.

In addition to the major fire in Lærdal, the fire department had struggled with a number of grass and heath fires in Western Norway and Trøndelag. Neither the disaster in Lærdal nor the warnings about the extreme fire danger prevented carelessness with fire from causing new fires. In January 2014, the fire department responded to 14 grass and heath fires in Nord-Trøndelag alone. Most of these fires were extinguished before causing significant damage. The most serious was a grass fire covering 100–200 decares, where a farm sawmill was lost. Flatanger experienced a heath fire the day before the disaster: an approved heath burning got out of control on Aspøya. The fire department allowed the fire to advance in the main direction, where it was stopped by the sea, and where no buildings were at risk. At the end of January, the grass and forest fire danger was very high along the entire west coast from Nord-Rogaland to Nord-Trøndelag. Such were the conditions in Flatanger when the fire broke out.

The fire broke out shortly after 10 PM on January 27 near Uran, at the southernmost point of a peninsula. According to NRK, the fire started when a power line fell onto the dry ground near Uran and sparked. It was discovered by Odd Uran, who was part of the local fire department in Hasvåg. The emergency center in Namsos was alerted at 10:18 PM, and the police at 10:24 PM. A strong southeasterly gale, 20 m/s, and nearly a small storm were blowing. The wind was also uneven and constantly changing direction. The gusts were so violent that the firefighting crews occasionally had to lie down during the extinguishing efforts. The smoke development was so intense that the 25 firefighters could not get ahead of the fire. Neither Askfjellet nor County Road 492 could stop the fire. Thus, it spread very quickly. By 11:10 PM, the fire chief drove from Uran to evacuate the three locations of Håstad and Hasvåg in the northwest and Småværet further west. Reinforcements were called in. By 12:30 AM on the 28th, the residents had been evacuated without injuries, but 139 of 213 buildings were threatened. Within 12 hours of the fire breaking out, 63 buildings had been lost in the three locations – most between 4:00 AM and 6:00 AM. The fire department – with support from many volunteers – established a firebreak to prevent further spread. A 100–150 m wide belt of vegetation was sprayed. At its peak, approximately 250 firefighters from 21 fire and rescue services, 167 from the Civil Defense, and an unknown number of volunteers operated along the frontlines in Flatanger. Five helicopters were requisitioned, but the strong wind initially kept them grounded. The cold created difficulties in maintaining consistent pressure in the hoses and also caused icing. The variable wind was not only damaging. It also spared many houses as the wind suddenly blew the flames in another direction. In some places, the fire's advance stopped because it reached burned-out areas or the sea. The firebreak also held. Hårnes, at the easternmost point of the peninsula, was spared, and inland – towards the southeast – the fire faced headwinds and was stopped. Of the 29 buildings in Uran, only an outbuilding was lost. The fire also failed to jump over the fjords separating the peninsula from the mainland and several smaller islands. And as the day progressed, the wind began to subside. At 10:15 PM, the police reported that the fire was under control, and at 12:15 PM on the 29th – around the same time the firefighting helicopters were deployed – it was declared extinguished. The forest fire helicopter could then be moved to Frøya, where a new, intense heath fire had broken out. The Flatanger fire flared up again on the evening of the 29th – and one last time on February 1, when the settlement in Hasvåg was again threatened. The Civil Defense was called out for the second time. Around 90 buildings had been lost, the police said at a press conference on the afternoon of the 28th. Others feared that over 100 buildings had been lost. The damage turned out to be less than initially feared. Nevertheless, 64 buildings were lost – more than in the Lærdal fire and any other fire in Norway since 1945.

Unlike the fire in Lærdal, it was not difficult to determine the cause of the fire. Several eyewitnesses could confirm that at the point of origin, a live, uninsulated wire had fallen down. This had caused a short circuit, and sparks had ignited the vegetation. The fire was just one of many heath and grass fires that occurred along the coast in the winter of 2014. Several of them were caused by carelessness with fire, despite warnings of very high fire danger. The Flatanger fire was barely extinguished before a similar fire broke out on Frøya, just west of Sistranda. This location was not threatened, as the strong wind was still southeasterly. The fire spread even faster towards the west and northwest. As a result, several settlements were threatened, and just under 200 people were evacuated. However, by establishing a firebreak, based on two ice-covered lakes, the fire department, with support from volunteers, managed to save this settlement.

Both the fire in Lærdal and the Flatanger fire showed that under unfortunate circumstances, even a modern fire department cannot prevent a fire from spreading from house to house. And this applies not only to old wooden housing where the houses are closely packed but also to regular villa housing and sparsely populated areas. Several pointed out the need for more knowledge about fires of this type. Research leader Anne Steen-Hansen at SINTEF called for an accident investigation commission for fires. She believed that fires under extremely dry conditions were a relatively new phenomenon in Norway and that we should learn from countries with more experience in such situations, such as Australia, California, and countries in Southern Europe. In Sweden, the technical research institute SP warned about the lack of such knowledge throughout the Nordic region. SP also believed that climate change could contribute to a greater risk of fires.

Whole_Text.content: The 1996 Goseong wildfire was a forest fire that started on April 23, 1996, in Jukwang-myeon, Goseong County, Gangwon Province, South Korea, and burned 3,834 hectares of forest in the Goseong County area until April 25. The fire occurred when sparks from improperly handled defective TNT during a disposal process at a nearby army shooting range spread due to strong winds. The fire resulted in 140 displaced people from 49 households and caused a total damage of approximately 22.7 billion won. Currently, the affected area is managed by the National Institute of Forest Science under the Korea Forest Service and is divided into natural restoration zones and artificial afforestation zones for ecosystem restoration and related research.

Around 12:22 PM on April 23, a fire started in Jukwang-myeon, Goseong-gun, Gangwon-do. At 12:40 PM, a temporary wildfire response headquarters was established within the Army's 6123rd unit. At 2:30 PM, Deputy Governor Sim Woo-seok requested full support of the Korea Forest Service helicopters, but due to dry weather, wildfires also broke out simultaneously in Pyeongchang, Yanggu, and Inje, causing delays in deployment. At 3:10 PM, the first Korea Forest Service helicopter arrived and began firefighting efforts. Although additional military helicopters and fire trucks were continuously deployed, significant difficulties were encountered in extinguishing the fire. Around 8:30 PM, another wildfire broke out near the northern boundary line of Gohyangbong in Myeongpari, Hyeonnae-myeon, Goseong-gun, burning 120 hectares of forest. The fire was successfully extinguished by 5 PM on the 24th. Part of the facilities at the Unification Observatory was damaged by the fire.

Around midnight, strong winds of 20 meters per second blew, and as the fire spread to nearby residential areas, forest and public service personnel, along with township office staff, focused all efforts on evacuating residents. Around 2 a.m., as the fire spread, the emergency response headquarters was relocated to the Jukwang-myeon office. Additionally, the fire spread to the northern parking lot of Songjiho Beach, burning the communication cables connecting Sokcho and Goseong along the mountain ridge. As a result, long-distance phone calls were disrupted for 14 hours. The flames, carried by northwesterly winds, spread along the coast and southward to Unbong, Hakya, and Dowon-ri in Toseong-myeon. From 10 a.m., military authorities began restricting tourist access. Furthermore, the emergency response headquarters urgently evacuated 162 residents from farms in Injeong-ri, Sampori, and Unbong Hakya-ri, areas expected to be affected by the wildfire. The wildfire occurred simultaneously across a wide area, making it difficult to extinguish with a limited number of helicopters. Additionally, fallen leaves reignited embers, causing significant challenges. The fire spread both northward and southward from the ignition point, burning most of Jukwang-myeon overnight. To make matters worse, strong winds of 30 meters per second accelerated the spread of the fire. Around 11:15 p.m., concerns arose among residents that the wildfire in Tapdong, Ganseong-eup, could spread to nearby areas, leading to a suggestion to set a backfire. With the help of the fire department, a backfire was set.

Goseong County deployed a total of 20 helicopters to the site, receiving additional support of 11 helicopters from the police and military starting at 5:30 AM. The firefighting workforce also increased, with around 10,000 people participating in extinguishing the flames. The countermeasure headquarters evacuated 27 households, approximately 80 residents, from nearby villages such as Dowon-ri, Hakya 2-ri, and Seonyusil-ri to relatives' homes, military barracks, and senior centers. In the morning, President Kim Young-sam called Prime Minister Lee Soo-sung, instructing him to visit the wildfire site to oversee firefighting efforts, assess the damage, support recovery, and address public concerns. At 2:30 PM, Prime Minister Lee Soo-sung arrived in the Tapdong area to inspect the fire situation, and Kangwon Governor Choi Gak-kyu requested the Prime Minister to declare the affected area a special disaster zone. Additionally, the government was advised to provide rural housing loan support for residents whose homes were destroyed by the fire. The countermeasure headquarters mobilized 4,000 people, including military personnel and local residents, along with 25 helicopters, to the areas around Dowon-ri in Toseong-myeon near Seoraksan National Park and Tapdong-ri in Ganseong-eup, successfully containing the major flames by around 4:20 PM. By 6:10 PM, all helicopters involved in the firefighting efforts had withdrawn, and the countermeasure headquarters officially announced the completion of the firefighting operation. To prevent rekindling, 170 public officials and 15 fire trucks were deployed to vulnerable areas for monitoring.

As the fatigue of public officials accumulated and the possibility of rekindling decreased, all rekindling monitoring personnel were withdrawn at 1:30 a.m.[2]:41 At 6:30 a.m., a small fire broke out in a rice field near the public cemetery in Gajin-ri and was extinguished.[2]:41 After that, it was determined that there were no further fires, so most of the deployed personnel and equipment were withdrawn.[2]:41[12]

Sampo 1-ri village in Jugwang-myeon, Goseong-gun, Gangwon-do, became the area most severely affected, with 38 out of 50 households completely burned down. In particular, the forest area around Tapdong-ri in Ganseong-eup and Dowon-ri in Toseong-myeon, which suffered severe fire damage, was a place where a large amount of wild pine mushrooms were produced, but the fire destroyed an important source of income for the residents. On April 28, a joint investigation by the Korea Forest Service and the Accident Countermeasure Headquarters predicted that it would take at least 40 years to a maximum of 100 years to restore the severely damaged soil in the forest area. It was estimated that an area three times the officially burned area, reaching 10,000 hectares, was ecologically damaged due to the disruption of the food chain and the inability of seeds to spread. The burned area lost its carbon dioxide absorption function, and the ecological corridor connecting the Civilian Control Line and Seoraksan Mountain was expected to be severed for decades.

Whole_Text.header: Cause of fire and punishment of the arsonist
Whole_Text.content: The point of ignition was at the valley of Jukbyeonsa in Majwa-ri, Jugwang-myeon, at the shooting range of the 58th Ammunition Battalion under the 8th Logistics Support Command of the 1st Army Logistics Command. According to the Ministry of National Defense, the incident occurred during the process of detonating 525 defective TNTs by Sergeant Jeong Jae-seok of this unit. Regulations required that the signal kits be removed in advance and all TNTs be incinerated, but Sergeant Jeong Jae-seok dug a 60cm hole at the shared firearms shooting range located at San 33, Majwa-ri, placed the TNT inside, and detonated it. As a result, the signal kits near the pit were launched, and the sparks were carried by strong winds, spreading to the upper valley forest and other areas. The Army arrested Sergeant Jeong Jae-seok, who was the unit's explosive disposal team leader at the time, on charges of arson. Simultaneously, Major Shin Yu-seung, the battalion commander, was relieved of his position, and Colonel Jeong Jae-ho, the commander of the 8th Logistics Support Command, was referred to the military disciplinary committee. However, even within the Ministry of National Defense, there was criticism that ending the disciplinary action for the worst-recorded disaster with just one non-commissioned officer was excessively lenient considering public sentiment. Additionally, the Army rejected broadcasting companies' helicopter operation requests to film the wildfire situation, citing regulatory restrictions, leading to criticism that their punishment was passive while their efforts to prevent disclosure of the truth were active.

Whole_Text.header: The cause of the delayed evolution
Whole_Text.content: The causes of the wildfire not being contained for three days and the significant increase in damage were pointed out to be strong winds, dry weather, rugged terrain, lack of equipment, and shortage of professional personnel. The initial strong winds caused the fire to spread faster, with the wind direction constantly changing and the dry weather making it easier for the fire to spread, complicating efforts to determine the direction of containment. Most of the fire occurred in rugged terrain that was difficult for people to access, so the majority of the containment efforts had to rely on helicopters, which proved ineffective despite the deployment of many personnel. Additionally, Gangwon Province did not have a single helicopter dedicated to wildfire containment, and the available equipment was rudimentary, only suitable for extinguishing residual fires. Over 10,000 personnel were deployed, but only about 2,000 were professionally trained in firefighting. This led to criticism that sufficient budget allocation is necessary for disaster prevention efforts to contain large-scale wildfires. There was also an analysis that the lack of a rapid response system for initial containment exacerbated the situation. Although the Forest Service was requested to provide helicopter support, it took 1 hour and 30 minutes for the helicopters to arrive at the site. Furthermore, even if a fire broke out near a military shooting range, the risk of unexploded ordnance exploding made it difficult to approach, and cooperation from the military was required to carry out containment efforts, highlighting the lack of conditions for quickly extinguishing the fire. Residents criticized that the administrative authorities had left pine trees, which were thinned out for reasons such as removing pine wilt disease, abandoned in the mountains, resulting in the fire spreading quickly to these trees and causing greater damage. Additionally, after the fire broke out, the military did not issue an evacuation broadcast for 13 hours, which residents claimed worsened the damage. Similarly, residents and public officials who participated in the containment efforts expressed dissatisfaction that the military did not respond promptly, exacerbating the situation, and demanded that all those responsible for the wildfire be arrested.

On April 26, 1996, President Kim Young-sam instructed the cabinet to establish comprehensive measures by June of the same year in response to a series of large-scale wildfires, including the wildfire in the Goseong area. The next day, the government held a meeting of relevant ministries at the Government Complex to prepare comprehensive measures for wildfire prevention and decided to provide state compensation to residents of affected areas, as the wildfire was revealed to be caused by the Ministry of National Defense's negligence. Additionally, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries was designated as the central body to lead the "Goseong Wildfire Central Accident Response Headquarters," which would investigate the cause of the fire and assess the scale of the damage. A joint investigation team from relevant ministries was dispatched to the site that day to conduct a detailed investigation into property and forest damage and decided to provide special support to affected farmers, including rice seeds, farming materials, and agricultural funds. The Army also issued orders to mobilize all personnel and equipment from its subordinate units to assist in the recovery of the affected areas. Gangwon Province deferred the collection of property taxes, urban planning taxes, comprehensive land taxes, and local taxes for residents of the affected areas for six months. On June 19 of the same year, the Ministry of Environment announced plans to establish an ecological restoration test site to observe the natural recovery process over 50 to 100 years in areas burned by the wildfire that did not impact residents' economic activities. The natural restoration sites were created in two locations in Goseong County, Guseong-ri and Injeong-ri, with areas of 30 hectares and 70 hectares, respectively. According to a report in April 1997, the Korea Forest Service devised a reforestation plan to expedite the collection of pine mushrooms by residents. However, due to the tight reforestation schedule, it became difficult to procure saplings, leading to the decision to supply fast-growing trees cultivated in greenhouses, which drew criticism from several forestry experts.

In April 1997, 316 residents of Goseong County filed a class-action lawsuit against the state, demanding compensation for damages related to activities such as pine mushroom harvesting. On August 15 of the same year, the 8th Corps District Compensation Review Committee ruled that compensation was dismissed because the fire starter was a civilian who had conducted shooting range facility construction, making the State Compensation Act inapplicable. On December 3, 1998, the Seoul District Court issued a compulsory mediation decision, ordering the state to pay approximately 8.4 billion won to the residents regarding the class-action lawsuit from April of the previous year. As of April 2005, nine years after the fire, natural restoration sites established in two locations in Goseong County showed much higher plant weight and density compared to artificial afforestation sites. However, many areas still had poor soil, and vegetation was sparse, indicating that it would take about 10 more years to restore the appearance of a typical forest. According to a study by the National Institute of Forest Science under the Korea Forest Service in June 2009, 16 species of wild birds were observed in areas affected by the wildfire, recovering to 80% of the 20 species observed in unaffected surrounding areas. As of an April 2010 report, the growth of pine trees in afforestation areas continued after the wildfire damage, but oak trees growing in natural restoration areas showed severe discoloration and cavity phenomena. As of May 2015, most of the pine forests that existed before the incident had disappeared, and broadleaf trees such as oak, sawtooth oak, and azalea, as well as shrubs, had grown to a height of 2–3 meters. On the opposite side of the restoration site, an artificial afforestation area managed by the Yangyang National Forest Management Office of the Eastern Regional Forest Service was established. It consisted of single species such as pine and birch trees and succeeded to some extent in forming a forest. However, due to the wildfire, the soil's capacity had declined, and the height of the pine trees was found to be only 41–71.9% compared to average trees.
