Whole_Text.content: The Mýra fires were significant grassland fires in Hraunhreppur in Borgarbyggð that burned for three days in the spring of 2006. On the morning of March 30, a fire broke out in the grasslands, spreading across a 75 km² area in Mýrar, with a total of about 67 km² burned. These were referred to as "the largest grassland fires in Iceland's history." It is believed that the fire was ignited by a cigarette near Route 54 opposite Bretavatn. The fire spread very quickly, covering about 18 kilometers in the first six hours. The burned area was located between Routes 54, 540, and 537, except for one strip that extended south of Route 537. At its peak, the fire wall was up to two meters high and moved at a speed of tens of meters per minute. The fires were extinguished through extensive firefighting efforts by local residents, the Borgarbyggð fire department, assistance from neighboring municipalities, and a helicopter from the Helicopter Service. No damage occurred to structures, except for fences, but many farms were very close to being consumed by the fire. The farm Hamrar was only a few meters away from the fire at one point. The fires had a significant impact on the area's ecosystem, as the burned area was one of the largest continuous wetlands in the country, making it more accurate to describe the event as a natural disaster rather than an ordinary grassland fire. However, no injuries to people occurred.

Grass fires had already occurred in Reykholtsdalur and Skorradalur, in addition to smaller fires in Grafarvogur. According to sources, the grass fire flared up on the morning of March 30 after a passerby had stopped their car by road 54, opposite Bretavatn and near the intersection of road 539, and carelessly threw a cigarette butt or cigar into the grass verge south of the road. At the time, there was a NNE wind at 13 m/s. The weather in the country had been extremely dry and cold. A cold northerly wind had been characteristic of the last 10 days of March and the first days of April, with strong winds prevailing most of the time. It was very dry in the southern part of the country, while there was snowfall in the northern and eastern regions. Due to the dryness, the vegetation in Mýrar was highly flammable, making it easy for the fire to take hold in the grass that forms under such conditions. Cotton grass, bilberry shrubs, and dwarf birch are widespread in Mýrar, and large areas of this vegetation burned in the Mýrar fires.

The fire spread very quickly, and it is likely that it passed by Fíflholt (though not the farm) in about one hour. The fire wall was about two meters high at this time and moved at a speed of several meters per second. It reached the sea, about 18 km away, in six hours, as there was almost no resistance. By the evening of March 30, the grass fire had spread over a large area between roads 540 and 537, but structures were not under significant threat, except for Skíðsholt, which was saved. By that time, the grass fire had begun to slow down, and farms north of the burned area, Fíflholt, Einholt, Stóri-Kálfalækur, and Akrar, were out of the greatest danger. Farms near the sea were not in significant danger, thanks to favorable conditions. However, it was clear that farms southeast of the area were in significant danger. During the night of March 31, the fire had spread slightly westward, but it had not yet approached the main road. This was due to good weather conditions, as there was little wind during the night. Around 10 a.m., the wind picked up again and shifted to a northerly direction. The fire then crossed Sauravegur road no. 537 over a stretch of about one kilometer, north of the farm Hamrar. This put about 30 km² of land in immediate danger, and the fight turned to saving Hamrar. The farms Laxárholt and Ánastaðir were also in great danger.

The decision was made to try to contain the spread of the fire at the farm Ánastaðir, as it was clear from the experience gained at Hamrar that no risks could be taken and the fire had to be reduced before it reached the road. [citation needed] At Saura, near the origin of the fire, firefighting efforts went well, and it was possible to prevent the fire from creating danger there. [citation needed] By the evening of March 31, the fire had been mostly extinguished. However, it was still burning, mostly near Ánastaðir. The following day, firefighting continued, but by then the farms were out of the greatest danger, and the firefighting efforts were more focused on extinguishing the fire than saving houses. [citation needed] By around 11:30 PM on the evening of April 1, it was clear from the police in Borgarnes that the fires had been extinguished. However, monitoring continued. By then, 67 km² of land had burned. [7][8]

The moorland fires would undoubtedly have become much larger if it had not been for extensive rescue and firefighting efforts by various parties under the direction of the police in Borgarnes. Never before have such extensive measures been taken due to wildfires in this country. At its peak, about one hundred people participated in the operations.

At half-past eight on March 30th, the police in Borgarnes received a report of a grass fire in the area from Fíflholt and the turnoff up to Hítardalur. The police managed the operations and ensured the safety of travelers and residents in the area. [citation needed]

The fire brigade in Borgarnes was the first responder to address the fires. On the afternoon of March 30, when firefighting efforts began in earnest, 12 firefighters, two tankers, and two pump trucks were operating in the area. Initially, the fire brigade's work mainly focused on ensuring the safety of structures in the fire zone, but the battle against the fire was very challenging due to its scale and lack of assistance. The fire brigade worked almost nonstop on firefighting and rescue operations from March 30 to April 1, with a team of about 15 people. Fire brigades from neighboring municipalities, between Akranes and Búðardalur, assisted the Borgarnes fire brigade with the operations from March 31. The Borgarfjörður municipality fire brigade, the Akranes fire brigade, and the Búðardalur fire brigade participated in the rescue operations. A pump truck from the Reykjavík fire brigade, from Reykjavík Airport, along with other equipment from there and tankers from various companies in Borgarnes, were borrowed to help fight the fire. In the end, rescue teams relieved the fire brigades and monitored the area in the final days.

Residents of the area assisted with the operations from the very beginning, and farmers' slurry tankers from all over Borgarfjörður and Mýrar were extremely effective tools in the fight against the fire. They cut away vegetation and created areas that the fire could not cross. Farmers also wet the roads with cow manure and sand slurry, which in most cases ensured that the fire did not spread over them. Farmers were the largest group involved in the firefighting efforts and came from all over Borgarfjörður and Mýrar to assist with the operations. Due to their numbers, it was also possible to ensure safety throughout the entire area. [citation needed]

A helicopter from the Helicopter Service was called in to assist with the operations around noon on March 31. This was the first time a helicopter had been used for firefighting operations in the country. It is believed that the helicopter made a significant contribution in the fight against the grass fire.

At nine in the morning on March 30, the police in Borgarnes received a report of a grass fire. This marked the beginning of operations. Over the next week, about 200 people in total participated in rescue and firefighting efforts across the entire fire area. Operations were mostly completed on April 2 and fully concluded on April 5.

When the notification was received, fire trucks immediately set off from Borgarnes to Fíflholt, where it was reported that the fire was. It quickly became clear that it was not possible to control such an extensive fire, and firefighting efforts focused on saving properties. Soon, farmers from nearby farms also came to assist. With their help, it was possible to prevent the fire from reaching the farms Skíðsholt and Vogur.

On the evening of March 30, firefighting efforts were in full swing, and around that time, about 70 people were working on rescue operations. The organization of the firefighting was good; slurry tankers were used where the fire was most intense, and in addition to extinguishing the fires, the fire brigade also played an advisory role in this regard. The fire brigade was mainly stationed at Skíðsholt, trying to protect residential buildings, but at that time, there was no perceived risk of the fire spreading to other houses. During the night of March 31, the fire spread only slightly, and roads were then wetted with manure and sand.[15] By the morning of March 31, twelve farms had burned. The fire brigade had by then received assistance from companies in Borgarnes, which provided tank trucks for the firefighting efforts. Around ten o'clock, a significant danger arose when the fire crossed Sauravegur, which is believed to have been caused by water that had been pumped onto the road freezing. The fire now threatened an area of approximately 30 km², which included four farms. The police were unaware of this threat until some time later, as Sauravegur was difficult to traverse.[citation needed] Vigorous firefighting efforts were carried out across the entire area throughout the morning and all afternoon. The Akranes fire brigade arrived with reinforcements around one o'clock, joining the Borgarnes and Borgarfjarðarsveit fire brigades and farmers with their slurry tankers. About sixty people worked hard to try to extinguish the fire rather than just contain it, aiming to stop the fire's progress at Ánastaðir and subsequently extinguish it. A helicopter from the Helicopter Service also joined the efforts and proved very effective.[16]

The weather conditions worsened, and it became very windy in the area. Late in the evening of March 31, the fire began to subside, and firefighting efforts were then focused on Ánastaðir, where there was still a large blaze. Despite increased optimism, it was still believed that firefighting would continue for the next week or so. The fire department at Reykjavik Airport arrived in the evening with a pump truck intended to extinguish the fire completely. [citation needed] On April 1, weather conditions improved. A number of rescue team members were called out to relieve the firefighters, as the firefighting efforts were largely coming to an end. There was hope that the fire would be extinguished by the evening. Late in the evening of April 1, the fires were successfully extinguished. However, the area was still monitored to ensure that the fires did not reignite. At that time, it was estimated that up to 150 km² had burned, but it later became clear that this figure was exaggerated. [17][18] On April 2, the police organized watch teams to extinguish embers hidden in moss, as the intention was to definitively prevent the fires from flaring up again. They were now waiting for snow to begin falling, as it was believed that this would finally end the battle. This eventually happened on April 3. The area was monitored for an additional two days, but the guards had little to no action to take.

The Myra fires had a tremendous impact and immediately drew great attention for their scale, which was previously unknown in Iceland. They had a significant effect on the environment and farming across all of Myrar and also led to extensive public debate about the justification of grassland burning and safety preparedness when such massive firefighting efforts were required.

In 1996 and 1997, the Icelandic Institute of Natural History mapped the vegetation in the area that burned, and according to that, most of the area consisted of wet fens and marshlands with ponds and lakes between rocky outcrops. The most common plant community was a cotton grass fen with dwarf birch and bilberry. This type of vegetation is primarily found in Mýrar and southern Snæfellsnes, but is rare elsewhere in the country, making it clear that the area has significant natural value. It appeared that the extensive and highly hummocky cotton grass fen was the most severely affected by the fire, and the dwarf birch is unlikely to recover for many years. The amount of dry grass in this area was as significant as it was due to limited grazing, but the dwarf birch was so scorched that what remained was mostly dead. Heather species also seemed to have been severely affected by the fire, but species that grow in very wet conditions, such as sedges and bog cotton, fared better. This is believed to be because the water level was high, and only the topmost stems burned. Small shrubs and birch also survived well. "In short, the dry grass burns, and the substances that turn into gases rise into the air, such as nitrogen and carbon. However, the minerals remain, the surface becomes black, and therefore heats up more in the sunshine during spring," said Sigurður H. Magnússon, a plant ecologist. He also stated that the future development would likely involve more grasses, which can utilize nutrients very well, and fewer small shrubs and thickets. The marsh fires also affected wildlife. Bird nesting did not begin until a month after the fires, so the impact on birds was limited, but if the fires had occurred earlier, the effects would undoubtedly have been more severe. Birds found new nesting sites that spring, but these effects are not considered permanent. Field mice were also significantly affected, as was the aquatic life in the ponds and lakes in the area. Significant pollution resulted from the fires. Millions of cubic meters of carbon dioxide and other gases were released into the atmosphere, and the black smoke was visible across much of western Iceland as well as from space. A large amount of ash and other substances also entered the groundwater in the area, which is considered a very serious issue. Sigríður Anna Þórðardóttir, the then Minister for the Environment, tasked the Icelandic Institute of Natural History with investigating the effects of the fires on the area's nature. Subsequently, the Institute developed a research plan in collaboration with the University of Iceland, the Agricultural University of Iceland, and the Natural History Museum of Kópavogur. Research began in the summer of 2006 and concluded in 2010. The first results were presented in March 2007, a year after the fires.

In a statement from Borgarbyggð on April 3, it was said that the grassfires in Mýrar were "among the most severe disasters of their kind in the country in decades." With strong efforts and good cooperation from fire brigades, police, various parties who offered their assistance, and especially the residents of the area, the fire was brought under control. Time will reveal what impact the grassfire will have on the ecosystem in the area, but it is important to begin research on this matter as soon as possible. However, it is a great relief that no one was harmed in the battle against the fires and that property damage was kept to a minimum. The nation has gained costly experience and will likely better understand the potential consequences of a grassfire breaking out under similar circumstances as those that arose here. Guðni Ágústsson, the Minister of Agriculture, visited the area in Hraunhreppur. "Severe natural disasters have occurred here. The land is badly burned and damaged. What I admire most is that the farmers, firefighters, and those who fought the fire managed to save so much despite everything," he said in an interview with Morgunblaðið on April 4. The opinion of the responders was that although damage from the fire was largely prevented, grassfires like the Mýrar fires are very dangerous and that measures need to be taken to limit the risk when burning grass.

After thoroughly examining the matter, many, including farmers in the area, concluded that the organization of firefighting efforts was not adequate and that the response was generally lacking. The Fire Prevention Agency, along with fire departments and police across the country, has decided after this grass fire to create a response plan based on the experience gained from the events. It is considered extremely important to be able to handle fires like the Mýra fires in summerhouse areas or other places where grass fires could threaten populated areas.

The forest fire in Bodträskfors in 2006 was a large forest fire that raged in the area northwest of Bodträskfors on the western side of the Lule River in Norrbotten County between August 11 and September 8, 2006. During the 29 days the fire raged, 1,900 hectares were burned. The operation was led by the rescue management from Boden's rescue service. The firefighting involved people from all but two rescue services in Norrbotten County as well as from Sundsvall, Örnsköldsvik, Malå, Ånge, Skellefteå, Lycksele, Storuman, and Finland, as well as from the Southern Roslagen Fire Protection Association, the rescue service at Norrbotten's Air Force Wing (F 21), and 30 people from the Home Guard. No one died or was seriously injured, and no residential houses burned down.

Whole_Text.header: The approximate course of the fire

Whole_Text.content: The fire area was about 300 meters long and 50 meters wide along a forest tractor road when it was first reached after the alarm. The fire became uncontrollable during a smaller operation. Additional resources and a helicopter for reconnaissance and water spraying were brought in, but by 9 p.m., the fire area was about 2.4 kilometers x 400 meters.
In the morning the situation was stable, during the day the wind shifted and many fires broke out.

The fire area quickly increased to around 500 hectares, and the effort focused on enclosing 1,000 hectares with firebreaks. The fire was moving at 5 m/sec and was uncontrollable by noon, which led to some evacuations. At the same time on this day, and on other days, several fires were occurring elsewhere that required resources.
The fire continued.
The fire-ravaged area was 800 hectares, and the northern fire front came 400 meters from the firebreak. A major helicopter operation took place during the afternoon.
The extent of the fire was 800 hectares, and the delimited area was 1,500 hectares. The fire began to come under control.
Smoldering fires occurred, but otherwise, the situation was calm and the risk of spreading was over.
Localized fires were fought, sometimes it burned heavily.
Several fires increased in intensity.
Small fires were extinguished, among other things, with continued water spraying from the air.

Water spraying from the air by helicopters took place continuously throughout the firefighting efforts in the vast area. On August 15, during the fifth day, there were as many as seven helicopters in the air for water spraying, four of which were civilian, as well as a Bölkow 105 for aerial reconnaissance. The First Helicopter Squadron in Luleå participated with, among other things, flight coordination, and the military also occasionally had heavy helicopters in service, two Helicopter 4 (Vertol) and one or two Helicopter 10 (Super Puma). Seven water-bombing helicopters were considered to be the maximum that could simultaneously fit in the airspace.

Info_Box:
Location: Northwest of Bodträskfors, Boden Municipality  
Date: August 11 - September 8, 2006  
Burned areas: Approximately 19 km²

Whole_Text.content: In the early morning of Easter Sunday, April 20, 2014, a fire broke out in the Deelense Veld at National Park De Hoge Veluwe near Otterlo. The fire raged in a 527-hectare area, of which approximately 320 hectares of forest and mainly heathland were burned. The fire department needed three days to fully extinguish the fire. The regional fire department received assistance from across the country, including two firefighting helicopters and a recovery tank from the Defense Department. The fire was the largest on the Veluwe since 1976.

The fire started early in the morning on Easter Sunday. An investigation was conducted at the site of origin by the police and the fire department's fire investigation team. Within a few hours, it was announced that no indications of arson had been found. How the fire actually started remains unclear. Due to a northeasterly wind of four Beaufort, the fire could spread at a speed of about 800 meters per hour. This, combined with the relatively dry vegetation, made it difficult for the fire department to control the fire. Because the first report came in only after more than an hour, the fire had already spread over 800 meters before the first fire truck arrived.

The fire broke out around half past seven, but the first report to the control room in Apeldoorn only came in around a quarter to nine. Subsequently, the firefighting team from Hoenderloo was immediately alerted, followed directly by the professional team from Arnhem-Noord. Upon the arrival of the fire engine from Hoenderloo, the response was immediately scaled up to a first fire brigade company consisting of the firefighting teams from Otterlo, Harskamp, Beekbergen, Ugchelen, Loenen, and Apeldoorn-Centrum. Around half past nine, a third fire brigade platoon consisting of the firefighting teams from Hoog Soeren, Twello, Eerbeek, and Klarenbeek was alerted. Shortly thereafter, the response was scaled up to GRIP 1. In the hours that followed, five more fire brigade platoons were mobilized by the regions Gelderland-Midden and Noord- en Oost-Gelderland.

Around one o'clock in the afternoon, the Gelderland Midden Safety Region (VGGM) scaled up to GRIP 2. A request for assistance was also made to the Twente and Utrecht Land regions. Around a quarter to two, both regions sent a fire brigade platoon.  
Around two o'clock, the VGGM deployed a measurement plan organization.  
Around a quarter past two, the NBBE was alerted. A ground team was formed by the Twente and IJsselland safety regions.  
Around half past two, the Brabant-Noord Safety Region sent a fire brigade company.  
Around four o'clock, the Brabant Zuid-Oost Safety Region sent a fire brigade company.  
Around a quarter to five, the Midden- en West-Brabant Safety Region sent a fire brigade company.  
Around five o'clock, the Limburg-Noord Safety Region sent a fire brigade platoon. The military deployed six off-road fire engines from the Harskamp Barracks and the Artillery Shooting Range. The military also deployed two helicopters for firefighting: a Chinook with 8,000 liters and a Cougar with 2,500 liters. This deployment began around 5 o'clock in the afternoon, nearly six hours after the alert.

The Deelense Veld is a closed nature reserve. The area is a heathland largely overgrown with bentgrass and purple moor grass, containing various fens including the Deelense Was and the Gietense Flessen. The terrain is characterized as easily passable in the larger sections, with some marshy areas here and there. In this terrain, several fire trucks got stuck. Tractors and excavators were used to pull out the stuck fire trucks. In the evening, this task was taken over by a recovery tank from the 43rd Mechanized Brigade of Defense. Unfamiliarity with the terrain and the often shifting wind created dangerous situations. Several times, fire trucks were narrowly saved from the flames. A few times, things went seriously wrong. Fire engines from the Twello and Ede brigades sustained fire damage, the firefighting vehicle from Otterlo was heavily damaged, and the vehicle from Hoenderloo became surrounded by flames due to a change in wind direction and had to be rescued by other brigades. The vehicle from Ede (Lunteren station) had to be abandoned after it came to a halt with a failing gearbox. The vehicle was damaged but technically still operational and could later in the day be used for extended firefighting operations.

Whole_Text.header: Measures National Park De Hoge Veluwe
Whole_Text.content: The nature park traditionally experiences one of its busiest days on Easter Sunday. Normally, about 5,000 people visit the park on that day. The management decided to evacuate the entire 5,000-hectare park at a quarter past eleven. Earlier, the entrance at Hoenderloo had already been closed. From a quarter past eleven, all visitors were asked to head to the park's exits. Around half past one, the staff of the well-known Kröller-Müller Museum in the national park were sent home as a precaution. However, security remained present. Some time later, security, with the help of volunteer firefighters from Otterlo, transferred all the paintings to a fireproof basement as a precaution. This was the first time this had happened since the museum's existence. [source?] Ultimately, the museum was not in any danger.

The fire department gained control of the fire early in the evening. Around eight o'clock, the fire was declared under control. From that moment, extinguishing the remaining fire could begin. Unlike fires in the Strabrechtse Heide and the dunes of Schoorl, there was little occurrence of rekindling flames. A contributing factor was the strong wind that literally blew the fire across the field. Ground fire was therefore minimal. On Easter Monday, a fire brigade company was deployed for extinguishing. In the two days that followed, fewer personnel carried out inspections and extinguished where necessary. Several times, firefighting groups were urgently dispatched because the fire threatened to flare up. However, at no point did it become unmanageable. The firefighting efforts were completely concluded after three days. Later, it was revealed that the fire had burned an area of 527 hectares. Of this, over 320 hectares of nature were destroyed. The remaining 207 hectares were preserved because the fire department stopped the fire or because the area was too marshy to burn. During an inspection round after the fire, a forest ranger found a motor from a V1 rocket from World War II.[1]

The forest fire in Småland in 1868 started on Sunday, August 16, in Lysteryd in Furuby parish east of Växjö and developed until August 21. The fire arose when a farmer, in connection with land clearing, attempted to blast a stone by heating it with fire and cooling it with water. The summer of 1868 was very dry, and a fire ban was in place. The affected area was 15 km long and 10 km wide, destroying cottages and barns in several parishes, namely Furuby, Dädesjö, Gårdsby, and Hemmesjö, which further worsened the year of famine. According to the bailiff's report on August 18, the fire had spread in a northern and northwestern direction, threatening settlements in both Attsjö and Kårestad, and had spread further to Holkaryd, Björnamo, and Skårtaryd. The spread to the west was stopped at the road between Södra and Norra Åreda. The fire was fought by 4,000 men from 15 parishes. At the same time, fires were burning in several other places in Kalmar and Kronoberg counties, including a fire in Häljaryd that covered about 300 acres (approximately 1.5 km²), about 10 km northwest of Lysteryd on August 14, two days before the major fire. The area was estimated to be about 6,000 acres, approximately 30 km². In the County Administrative Board's report to the Ministry of Civil Affairs, the length was stated to be 1 1/2 miles (15 km) and the width to be 1/8 to 3/4 miles (1.2-7.5 km).

Info_Box:
Location: Furuby parish, Dadesjo parish, Gardsby parish, and Hemmesjo parish in Kronoberg County, Smaland, Sweden  
Date: August 16 - August 21, 1868  
Burned areas: Approximately 50 km²?  
Ignition source: Peat burning  
Number of destroyed homes: 5 croft cottages, 6 croft barns, 43 hay barns, etc. [1]

Article_Name: Incendios forestales en Chubut de 2015, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The forest fires in Chubut were a natural disaster (although in some areas their origins seem to have been caused by human action) that occurred in the province of Chubut, in Argentina. The fire began on February 15, 2015, and the provincial government declared a state of environmental emergency on February 25, lasting until the beginning of April when the period of intense autumn rains greatly helped extinguish it. It mainly affected Cholila and other localities located in the northwest of Chubut. The fire started in the Cholila Lake valley, on its shores, near the coordinates 42°27′S 71°44′W / -42.450, -71.733. On April 6, 2015, it was reported that the burned forest area was over 41,000 hectares of virgin forests (almost the same size as Andorra), becoming the most significant fire on record in Argentina, with an area of over 41,000 hectares of native forests affected, surpassed seven years later by the fires in Corrientes in 2022. The fires were concentrated in the Comarca de los Alerces, in the Cholila Lake valley, on its southern and northern margins, in Cerro Cholila, and in the El Turco and Tucu Tucu canyons, with outbreaks in the Jara stream, the Turbio River, and Cerro Radal. It spread to the north and south, reaching the southern part of the Andean Region of Parallel 42, in Lago Puelo and Cerro Currumahuida, having reached the namesake national park to the north and entering Los Alerces National Park to the south. It is the largest forest fire in Argentina's history. In certain areas of the affected region, the outbreaks seem to have been caused by human action, so on Sunday, March 1, some people accused of starting fires were arrested. If the fires in this tourist region were intentionally caused, it was motivated by real estate speculation to later acquire the valuable affected lands at a low price.

200 brigade members were deployed, later joined by 20 civilians, 6 airplanes, and 14 fire engines to combat the fires in the affected areas. The weather conditions were unfavorable due to the phenomenon known as thermal inversion. Internal work was carried out in the forest to prevent the fire from advancing, such as creating 40-meter-wide firebreaks. In addition to the 150 brigade members working on-site and dozens of volunteer neighbors, teams from the City of Neuquén and San Martín de los Andes (from the province of Neuquén), the Province of Buenos Aires, and the Province of Santa Cruz joined the efforts. From the Republic of Chile, three helicopters were sent to stop the fire column. Finally, after 17 days, thanks to the great efforts made by the brigade members and favorable environmental and meteorological conditions, such as a decrease in temperatures in the area, the fire's advance was controlled on the afternoon of March 4, even in the most critical areas. However, on March 23 of the same year, new intentionally set fires appeared in Los Alerces and Puelo National Parks. When the fires seemed extinguished, they reappeared at the end of March (also due to intentional causes), so by the 30th of that month, a large number of ancient and beautiful forests were still being destroyed. On Saturday, April 4, intense autumn rains began to extinguish the main fire hotspots, which led to the return of firefighting brigades from the province of Córdoba, as they were deemed no longer necessary. On the same day (after more than a month of devastating fires), Civil Defense announced that all the fires in Chubut were under control.

The fires reached both Los Alerces National Park in the south and Lago Puelo National Park in the north. The species primarily affected are ñires, lengas, coihues, maitenes, notros, coligüe canes, and alerces (also called lahuanes), the latter being a large conifer (with millennial specimens), the emblematic species of the region. Various species of lizards and rodents, birds, native deer such as huemules and pudús (the huemul is a large deer, while the pudú is a very small deer - one of the smallest in the world - both species are endemic to the southern Andean forests and are endangered).

Due to the need for responses and solutions, given the number of days of fire outbreaks, on February 28, Chief of Staff Aníbal Fernández arrived in the Chubut mountain range to visit the area affected by the fire and replaced the head of the National Fire Management Plan, Jorge Barrionuevo, in light of the uncontrolled advance of forest fires, which at that time were entering the town of Epuyén. Governor Martín Buzzi denounced and accused the real estate sector of causing three of the five fire outbreaks in Cerro Currumahuida and Lago Puelo. He also mentioned: Argentine Defense Minister Agustín Rossi reported that the Armed Forces would increase support for the brigades working in the province of Chubut to combat the fires. On December 28, 2012, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner announced to the public the purchase of 26 firefighting planes for AR$ 57 million, modified to drop up to 2,000 liters of water over affected areas, and the rest of the firefighting planes are distributed among the different provinces due to the higher number of fires recorded during the summer months. Due to the magnitude of the event, the Chilean government provided helicopters from the first days of March. On March 14, 2015, the governor of Chubut announced the creation of the Cholila Interjurisdictional Park. It will cover an area of 220,000 hectares, with intangible zones and areas subject to a management plan. It will border Lago Puelo National Park to the north and Los Alerces National Park to the south.

According to the Chubut government, more than 45,000 hectares had been burned in the provincial territory, and nearly 50 million dollars have been lost in "forestry resources and ecosystem services." A senator denounced that behind the fire were several politicians, including Jorge O'Reilly, owner of Eidico, a company dedicated to the development of private ventures in the northern area of Greater Buenos Aires, which also caused controversy with its arrival in Villa La Angostura. O'Reilly owns the private neighborhood San Esteban in Cholila, covering about 1,000 hectares and 160 plots. The businessman faced several criticisms and complaints regarding constructions on some of these lands, built on public lands in General Pacheco that belonged to Radio Nacional and were irregularly transferred by the former Entel to Telecom, Telefónica, and Startel in 1990, when the company was privatized.

The first evacuations were recorded in the surroundings of Cholila where 20 houses were evacuated. Due to the activation of the fire hotspots, the area known as Cordón Currumahuida was evacuated, and by order of the mayor of the Lago Puelo municipality, the town of Villa del Lago was ordered to be evacuated.

Info_Box:
Location: Comarca de los Alerces and south of the Andean Region of Parallel 42, Chubut, Argentina  
Date: February 15, 2015 - April 6, 2015  
Land use: Forestry  
Reason: Unknown

Article_Name: Incendi d'Andratx de 2013 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The 2013 Andratx fire was a forest fire that broke out in this municipality on the island of Mallorca and was active from July 26 to August 13, 2013, although it was under control from August 2. The fire burned a total of 2,335 hectares in the municipalities of Andratx, Estellencs, and Calvià. This fire burned 2% of the Serra de Tramuntana and was considered the most significant in the history of the Balearic Islands. The fire originated when a 44-year-old resident of Andratx, I.G., held a barbecue with friends near Son Curt. The resident was arrested on Monday, July 29, and admitted to the events. Approximately two-thirds of the burned area consisted of shrubs and carritx, so recovery by 2017 had already progressed relatively quickly. In the pine forest area, however, very few specimens were saved, and the new pines, sprouting from the seeds released by the burned pines, grow at a slower rate. The low humidity and rainfall in the area do not aid recovery, which is why the Ministry of the Environment developed a restoration plan for the affected area. One of the necessary measures was reforestation in areas affected by the 1994 fire, where natural reforestation is not possible because the pine specimens were not yet large enough to produce seeds. Measures were also taken to control the impact of the feral goat, which is very abundant in the area and endangers the growth of young specimens. Research into the reforestation of the area has concluded that terraces are of great help in these processes, as they prevent soil erosion. A small six-hectare fire in July 2021 burned in Coll de la Gramola, an area affected in 2013, which concerns experts about the possibility that the pines born from the burned cones may not survive. The perpetrator of the fire was sentenced in 2020 to two and a half years in prison for a crime of forest fire due to gross negligence, with a mitigating factor for a schizophrenic-type mental disorder.

Article_Name: Incendis forestals de Catalunya de 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The forest fires in Catalonia in 1994 occurred during the summer of that year and are considered the most severe in the country's history. The summer of 1994 was one of the worst in terms of the area affected by fires on the Iberian Peninsula. Catalonia, in particular, was one of the most affected areas, with a total of 76,626 hectares burned that year, and especially severe were the fires in the regions of Bages, Berguedà, and Lluçanès, where more than 45,000 hectares burned. In the history of fires in Catalonia, the flames had never had such an impact nor had such high fire energy been manifested. Those uninterrupted days of fire in July led, from then on, to a change in the perception of fires. During the summer of 1994, 60 fires were reported, 12 of which are considered major fires.

Whole_Text.header: Origin and development of the events
Whole_Text.content:
In Catalonia, two waves of hot and dry air from North Africa caused two waves of uncontrolled wildfires. The first, the most violent, occurred between July 3 and 7, with devastating fires in the northern Baix Llobregat, Central Catalonia, and Alt Ter. The second wave, between July 17 and 18, took place in Priorat, Segarra, and Alt Camp. During those July days, the weather conditions—temperatures of 40 degrees, gusts of 50 km/h of very hot and dry southwesterly wind, and low humidity below 10%—facilitated the rapid spread of fire through the extremely dry forests of Navàs, Castellnou de Bages, Súria, Fonollosa, Balsareny, Callús, and Sant Joan de Vilatorrada, within the Bages region, and on July 6 it spread to Puig-reig and Viver i Serrateix in the Berguedà region. At the same time, a fire caused by sparks from a power line in Gargallà (Montmajor municipality) spread with extreme speed and intensity through neighboring municipalities in lower Berguedà and Lluçanès: Casserres, Montclar, Gironella, Sagàs, Santa Maria de Merlès, La Quar, etc. Another factor that contributed to the fire's advance and hindered its extinction was the abandonment of forest exploitation, which caused the forests to be overloaded with fuel and lacked barriers such as meadows or fields.

More than 3,000 firefighters, 1,400 agents from other security forces, and 20,000 volunteers were mobilized to try to extinguish the flames. In addition to the forests, the damages included 35 burned farmhouses, 40 injured people, and five deaths.

The trial regarding the causes of the fires lasted until 2007, when the Barcelona Court acquitted the head of maintenance at FECSA, who was the only defendant in the trial. However, the Court considered that the fire had started due to sparks from this line, which was not adequately protected against short circuits, and left the door open to claim compensation through civil proceedings. Subsequently, a Barcelona court sentenced Endesa in 2012 to pay 37.5 million euros to a total of 117 forest and agricultural property owners affected by the fire, but at the same time ruled that compensation was not owed to the owners of about 10,000 hectares, considering it to be a different fire. These were a group of property owners from the municipalities of Olvan, Sagàs, Gironella, and La Quar, totaling about 10,000 burned hectares. The judge determined that these properties were affected by a fire different from the one in Gargallà, which in this case would have originated in Casserres. These owners, who had to pay legal costs, filed an appeal.

Whole_Text.content: In addition to Catalonia, forest fires ravaged the entire Catalan Countries during the summer of 1994. This would be the list of the main fires declared that year.

Article_Name: Incendio forestal de Jaén de 2015, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: View of the fire on July 9, 2015. On Sunday, July 5, 2015, a forest fire started in the area of "La Cruz del Muchacho" in Collares, within the municipality of Quesada, in the Spanish province of Jaén, near the natural park of Sierras de Cazorla, Segura, and Las Villas, spreading to neighboring municipalities. It was extinguished on July 29 after twenty-five days. It was one of the forest fires with the largest burned area in Spain and the most severe in the province in the last century.

The fire originated from a lightning strike. On Tuesday, July 7, the fire was brought under control, but due to strong winds and high temperatures recorded during those days of the heatwave, the fire reignited. The front advanced southward, reaching the outskirts of the urban areas of Pozo Alcón, Huesa, and Larva, and in a few hours, the affected area increased from 200 to 1,800 hectares and surpassed 2,000 hectares shortly after. It developed on two fronts: the southwest front headed toward Alicún de Ortega in the province of Granada, while the southeast front moved toward Guadiana Menor and Hinojares, where a firebreak was constructed. On July 9, "Level 1" of the Forest Fire Emergency Plan was activated. The fire remained outside the boundaries of the Cazorla, Segura, and Las Villas Natural Park, about 15 kilometers away, although part of the burned area is of great ecological value, with centuries-old pines, as well as mastic trees, junipers, low forest, and other species typical of the dry Mediterranean climate. Likewise, a large area of reforested Aleppo pine, highly flammable, was destroyed, which had been attempting, with little success, to prevent the advance of desertification spreading from the Levante Almeriense to the north of the province of Granada. As a precaution, 29 people were evacuated from the hamlet of Ceal, Chíllar farmhouse, and Cortijo Nuevo, all belonging to Huesa, as the strong wind carried embers over a thousand meters away, rendering firebreaks and other preventive measures ineffective. The fire also affected several agricultural and livestock areas, burning olive groves and pastures. On Sunday, July 12, the fire was stabilized, moving from Level 1 to Level 0, which allowed the withdrawal of the UME. The remaining resources on-site took appropriate measures to prevent its resurgence, as another heatwave with extreme maximum temperatures occurred in the following days. Evacuated residents were also authorized to return to their homes. Initial estimates, after the fire level decreased, calculated a burned area exceeding 8,000 hectares, although later this figure rose to 10,000 hectares, still not under control. However, other estimates raised the burned area to 14,000 hectares. INFOCA declared the fire under control on the morning of July 15, and it was officially extinguished in the early afternoon of July 29, after twenty-five days.
In the fire, a significant operation was deployed, composed of: [12]​[16]​[20]​[24]​[25]​

After the fire, the need arises to reforest the area, which is highly threatened by desertification, using species native to the Mediterranean scrubland such as rosemary, thyme, mastic, or kermes oak, and in the humid areas, holm oak, ensuring that in case of fire, the forest regenerates easily. In the previous reforestation, Pinus halepensis was mainly used. The first reforestation works began in the autumn of 2015, for which the Junta de Andalucía approved a budget allocation of 2.12 million euros. A year later, the first results began to be seen.

Whole_Text.content: Large-scale forest fires are a recurring problem in Indonesia, particularly on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo. The fires are largely started by people who illegally try to obtain more farmland. One of the reasons for doing this is to expand palm oil plantations. Indonesia aims to become the largest palm oil producer in the world. Some of the fires may start spontaneously due to the smoldering heat in compost. During the dry season, the fires have the opportunity to rage for a very long time due to the lack of rain. Outside Indonesia, there are also other places in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia where many forest fires occur. Due to the forest fires, a huge amount of smoke is produced, which often causes nuisance thousands of kilometers away in surrounding countries, including Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, and Singapore. Within Indonesia itself, schools are regularly closed due to the smoke, flight schedules at airports are disrupted by delayed flights, and warnings are issued for traffic because visibility is greatly reduced by the smoke. The local population often wears dust masks to protect themselves from the smoke. The number of health complaints also increases due to the smoke. In addition to humans, the smoke and fire also pose a threat to the animals living on Sumatra and Borneo, such as the Sumatran tiger. Beyond the direct danger of the fire, their habitat is also shrinking over the years as a large part of the rainforests is converted into farmland. Deforestation in Indonesia is so severe that, with 1.8 million hectares of deforestation per year, it will even be recorded in the Guinness Book of Records. However, this deforestation is not only caused by forest fires but also by commercial logging. The areas where the fires occur are clearly visible on satellite images.

Various measures are being taken against the forest fires, but because there are thousands of fire hotspots, it is difficult to solve the problem. For this reason, people often place their hopes on the onset of the rainy season. The goal of the Indonesian government is to reduce the number of forest fires by 50% in the year 2007. For this, 150 million US dollars is being made available. Some measures that have been taken or proposed: In October 2006, the President of Indonesia, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, indicated that his country would sign the treaty among ASEAN countries on transboundary air pollution caused by smoke.

In 2006, pressure was exerted by the national government on regional governments to address the problem. Identifying suspects is often not straightforward, as the law requires eyewitnesses to testify that someone deliberately started a fire. In September 2006, 75 suspects were identified for causing forest fires. Not only individual farmers were accused, but also companies attempting to expand plantations. It was suggested that farmers with small agricultural areas did not sufficiently realize the risks associated with forest fires. For this reason, it was proposed that better education on the matter was necessary. Over the years, only a few people have received prison sentences in connection with causing forest fires.

Attempts are regularly made to artificially induce rain by spraying rain clouds with chemicals using airplanes. Indonesia even uses military aircraft for this, equipped with special equipment. This method can be effective and alleviate the problem in the short term, but it is highly dependent on the presence of sufficient rain clouds.

The effectiveness of extinguishing the fires in the 'traditional' way by firefighters is very limited due to the scale of the problem. What has been proposed is to drop water bombs from military aircraft over the fire hotspots. This method is very expensive and is therefore hardly or not at all used. For example, in October 2006, a plan was conceived to rent two Russian Ilyushin aircraft from Russia for this method.

Whole_Text.header: Increase in water levels in areas with a lot of compost soil
Whole_Text.content: It was determined that the main areas where forest fires occurred contained a lot of compost soil. Large-scale compost fires are very difficult to extinguish, which is why it has been proposed to raise the water level in areas with a lot of compost soil. One way to achieve this is by building dams.

Whole_Text.header: The pursuit of international cooperation and fundraising
Whole_Text.content: Various countries, including primarily Singapore and Malaysia, want to collaborate with Indonesia to address the problem. In addition to preventive measures taken against the fires, funds are also being raised.

On July 2, 2010, a wildfire broke out on the Strabrechtse Heide, affecting an area of 220 hectares. The regional fire department of Southeast Brabant escalated the response to a full fire brigade company and GRIP 4. At one point, the fire threatened to cross the A67 highway, which was completely closed, but the fire still spread to the area north of the highway. On July 3, the fire department brought the fire under control, although it took almost a week to fully extinguish it.

The Strabrechtse Heide is an area of 1500 hectares. The affected area includes both heathland and forest. In the weeks leading up to the fire, the fens were already dry, and the weather had been continuously warm. The fire started in a forested area on the south side of the A67 road, slightly west of the Hogeweg viaduct, and spread westward from there. In the forested area, crown fire developed, the most dangerous and intense form of wildfire. A water transport system had to be set up with a length of seven kilometers because there was insufficient water available in the area itself for extinguishing the fire.

The regional fire brigade of Southeast Brabant was assisted during this large and prolonged fire by various other fire brigade regions, the KLPD, and the military. Such a fire places a significant strain on the fire brigade organization, and it is virtually impossible to extinguish the fire with their own personnel without endangering fire services in the region. The following regions provided assistance: The Ministry of Defense supported the Southeast Brabant safety region with the deployment of a Cougar helicopter equipped with a so-called bambi bucket. These are bags with a capacity of 2,500 liters that are hung under the helicopter to release water over burning areas. Additionally, two crash tenders from the Royal Air Force, originating from Eindhoven Air Base and Woensdrecht Air Base, were deployed. On Sunday, July 4, the military deployed 100 people to assist with extinguishing the fire. The army also provided a fuel supply vehicle to refuel fire trucks and had engineers ready to dig firebreaks. The National Police Corps was present with a helicopter for observation.

On April 14, 2010, a dune fire broke out in the dunes between Schoorl, Bergen, and Bergen aan Zee. Due to the northeasterly wind with a force of 4-5, the fire was driven towards Bergen aan Zee and threatened the village. The built-up area was therefore evacuated. The four hundred residents of Bergen aan Zee were accommodated in the nearby sports center De Beeck. In 2009, there were also several large fires in this area. These earlier fires were likely arson, but it is not yet certain whether the fire in April 2010 was also deliberately set.

On Wednesday, April 14, the fire department was alerted shortly before 5:00 PM for a dune fire, and barely 20 minutes later, GRIP 1 was declared, escalating to a very large fire. At 5:45 PM, GRIP 2 was declared, followed at 6:11 PM by an escalation to a full fire brigade company and GRIP 3.  
Around 6:30 PM, it was announced that due to the threat of the fire, the built-up area of Bergen aan Zee would be mandatorily evacuated. During the evacuation, a Medical Combination and the mobile unit were deployed, with the latter guarding the evacuated area. On April 15, around midnight, residents were allowed to return home as the fire was sufficiently under control. However, an emergency ordinance came into effect from 12:30 AM that night, barring everyone from the affected dune area.  
Around 1:00 AM, the fire was declared under control. Throughout the night and the following day, extinguishing efforts continued, and the situation was scaled down to GRIP 0.

On Thursday, April 15, at 3:44 PM, the situation was once again escalated to a fire brigade company and eventually to GRIP 3. The fire appeared to have reignited, likely because the fire had continued to smolder underground. This second fire started in the same location as the first fire.  
Since the fire did not threaten Bergen aan Zee this time, there was no evacuation.  
The North Holland North Safety Region was supported by a second fire brigade company from the Kennemerland Safety Region and later also by other safety regions. In total, approximately 200 firefighters were active, in addition to the deployment of other emergency services. These personnel were periodically relieved (every 4-8 hours) over the following days. The Ministry of Defense supported the North Holland North Safety Region with the deployment of two Cougar helicopters equipped with so-called Bambi buckets or fire buckets. These are bags with a capacity of 2,500 liters that are suspended under the helicopter to release water over burning areas.  
In addition to the helicopters, the Defense Ministry also deployed unmanned aircraft of the RQ-11 Raven type to search for underground smoldering hotspots using the onboard infrared camera. On April 17, the municipality of Bergen declared that the fire was officially extinguished. However, the fire brigade would remain in the area until the evening of Sunday, April 18, to monitor the situation.
Although there are no concrete indications of arson, the police are conducting forensic investigations into the cause of the fire. The police suspect arson despite the lack of evidence.

The regional fire brigade Noord-Holland-Noord was assisted during this large and prolonged fire by several other safety regions. Such a fire places a significant strain on the fire brigade organization, and it is virtually impossible to extinguish the fire with their own personnel without endangering fire services in the region. The following regions provided personnel assistance: In the period from April 14 to 17, a total of 70 different fire engines were deployed along with 68 other fire service vehicles such as rescue vehicles, hook-arm vehicles, hook-arm containers, communication and command vehicles, and service cars.

Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata The Tarerach fire is a wildfire that, on August 22 and 23, 2005, destroyed 1,970 hectares of forests and scrubland in the Pyrénées-Orientales, France. It is the most significant wildfire in this department since 1978. It started in the commune of Tarerach before spreading to neighboring communes, moving southeast, driven by the tramontane wind.

The area affected by the fire is at the borders of three historical and natural regions: the Fenouillèdes (Montalba-le-Château commune), the Roussillon (Ille-sur-Têt, Bouleternère), and the Conflent (Tarerach, Rodès, Vinça), which were each independent counties in the past[1].

The fire was reported on August 22, 2005, at 2:13 PM. Firefighters arrived on the scene twenty minutes later. The fire spread quickly: in 2 hours and 30 minutes, it traveled 5 km southeast, covering 700 hectares. With the weakening of the tramontane wind, its progression slowed, but it managed to cross the Têt River (around 5 PM) and then the national road (6:25 PM). Firefighters managed to control the fire on August 23 around 3 AM.
Beyond the destruction inevitably caused by such a fire, the Tarerach fire has led to archaeological discoveries.

The Tarerach fire, with 1970 to 2000 hectares destroyed, is the fourth largest recorded in the Pyrénées-Orientales department, the largest since 1978. It is one of the five "catastrophic fires," meaning those exceeding 1000 hectares, recorded in this department. The human toll is one injury, a firefighter who lost an eye. It appears that the origin of the fire was accidental. The burned area covers part of the Natura 2000 zone known as "Fenouillèdes." Due to the fire, grazing is prohibited in the area for a period of ten years "except for owners or rights holders engaging in developments and operations improving fire protection." The inventory of the natural area of the Natura 2000 zone conducted in 2009 shows an absence of Cork Oak, Cade Juniper, as well as a halt in the spread of Cape Ragwort in the burned area. The fire also brought an end to hunting practices.

The destruction of vegetation by the fire facilitated access to the site. In 2005 and 2006, a team of scientists conducted pedestrian surveys that provided a better understanding of the lives of the inhabitants of the destroyed area from the Paleolithic to the 20th century. These discoveries were documented in a large-format collective work of 504 pages published in 2009, titled "Archaeology of a Burned Mountain." The multidisciplinary study led to the discovery of 74 previously unknown archaeological sites and clarified knowledge of several others: the ruined villages of Ropidera and Casesnoves, as well as two protohistoric oppida. It also showed that the history of settlement in this area, since the Paleolithic, experienced alternating periods of prosperity and decline, or even abandonment. However, it should be noted that the research did not involve excavations, leaving many questions unanswered. It demonstrated human presence on the site since the final Acheulean and Middle Paleolithic, as well as an absence of Neolithic traces, which may suggest the plateau was abandoned during that time. The main contribution of this research lies in the Bronze Age, beginning in the Chalcolithic, with around fifty sites discovered, allowing the reconstruction of the lifestyle of the inhabitants of the time: herders and artisans whose dwellings were centered around an oppidum located on a height, secondary habitats on the slopes, and pastures for livestock in the valleys. Their craftsmanship, in chloritoschist, is unique and not found at any other archaeological site in the region. From the end of the Bronze Age to the Carolingian period, the plateau does not appear to have been inhabited. The fire allowed for the mapping of the village of Ropidera, in good condition, as it was at the time of its abandonment around the 15th century: large stone houses composed of several rooms with enclosures for livestock attached to the dwellings. The size and complexity of the layouts of these houses are surprising, as well as their grouping: in other nearby mountainous areas like Vallespir, medieval settlements are dispersed (Catalan mas). Not far from Ropidera, a kiln of undetermined age was also discovered, likely used for firing clay tiles. The fire also revealed an old pink marble quarry at the southern edge of the burned area, in the commune of Bouleternère. Many medieval buildings in the department use pink marble, which is usually attributed to the quarries of Villefranche-de-Conflent. The discovery of the Bouleternère quarries could challenge this systematic attribution. Nearby, the fire also uncovered a lime kiln likely dating back at least to the late Middle Ages.

Article_Name: Incendios forestales de Canarias de 2007, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The 2007 Canary Islands wildfires were a series of 5 wildfires (3 of them large) that took place in the Canary Islands, Spain, mainly on the islands of Tenerife and Gran Canaria, from July 27 to August 15, 2007. The most affected areas were in locations with remote homes and sparse forests. According to sources from the Ministry of the Environment of the Government of the Canary Islands, a quarter of Gran Canaria was affected, with approximately 20,000 hectares; in the fires on La Gomera and Tenerife, nearly 19,000 hectares were burned. In Gran Canaria, the most affected areas were the municipalities of La Aldea de San Nicolás, Tejeda, San Bartolomé de Tirajana, Santa Lucía de Tirajana, Mogán, and San Mateo. In the province of Santa Cruz de Tenerife, the most affected areas were the north of Tenerife and La Gomera. In the Gran Canaria fire, there were 2 seriously injured individuals, belonging to the Military Emergency Unit, and hundreds of animals died.

The Gran Canaria fire was caused by a forest ranger, who later alerted the firefighters. The Tenerife fire was also caused intentionally, although the identity of the arsonists was never known. On the other hand, the La Gomera fire was accidental and unintentional, causing the least damage.

In the Gran Canaria fire, the exotic bird park Palmitos Park and an adjacent hotel were burned down. Likewise, numerous homes were destroyed by the flames, including that of the then-mayor of Mogán. In the Tenerife fire, numerous vehicles and homes were also lost, including the Masca hamlet.

Article_Name: Incendio de Guadalajara de 2005, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Guadalajara fire of 2005 was a forest fire that ravaged part of the province of Guadalajara (Castilla-La Mancha) from July 16 to July 20, 2005, and claimed the lives of eleven forest firefighters from the extinction teams. Its origin was a barbecue that some hikers neglected at a picnic area near the Casares cave in the municipality of Riba de Saelices. A total of 10,352.57 hectares of wooded land burned, mostly consisting of resin pine, juniper, and oak forests, 2,380.16 hectares of scrubland and pasture, and 154.64 hectares of non-forest surface. The fire devastated 2,400 hectares of high ecological value belonging to the Alto Tajo natural park. Around half a thousand people were evacuated, including entire populations such as Ciruelos del Pinar and Tobillos, among others. The management of the fire by the government of Castilla-La Mancha was harshly criticized from various sectors, alleging that the necessary aerial and ground resources were not sent during the first hours. These criticisms were based, among other things, on the 112 recordings and the fact that the alert level was only raised, and help was requested from the central government when the tragic news of the eleven deaths was known, as acknowledged by the then vice president of the Junta, Máximo Díaz Cano. On December 17, 2005, nearly 5,000 people according to the police, and 10,000 according to the organizers, demonstrated in Guadalajara to honor the deceased and demand accountability.

Whole_Text.header: Origin and development of the fire
Whole_Text.content: On the morning of Saturday, July 16, 2005, a group of nine hikers visited the Casares cave with the subsequent intention of preparing a barbecue at the picnic area located on the left bank of the Linares River, about one hundred meters from the cave entrance. While the majority of the group visited the cave guided by the caretaker Emilio Moreno, the other three members prepared a fire on two built-in grills located in the recreational area and fueled it with dry grass, branches, and pinecones collected from the surroundings. At the end of the visit, the caretaker noticed the fires and warned them that the use of the barbecues was authorized but that he strongly advised against it due to the strong wind blowing in the area, the high temperatures—over 33°C—and the abundance of dry stubble: "I told Marcelino that he could cause trouble with the weather that day. Not even the dumbest person in my village would think of making a barbecue on a day like that, with an infernal wind and next to stubble. That’s just not having any sense." Around 2:40 PM, a spark or ember fell from the southernmost barbecue, which was unattended, igniting the dry grass, and the fire quickly spread northeast through the riparian forest and cereal fields until it reached a forested area of resin pine. The fire, fanned by the strong wind, became uncontrollable and by mid-afternoon forced the evacuation of five hundred residents from the towns of Ciruelos del Pinar, Tobillos, and Mazarete. Ground crews fought the fire throughout the night, and by dawn on Sunday, July 17, it had two active fronts heading toward Cobeta and Luzón, respectively. Throughout the day, more resources joined the fight against the fire, which already included three land-based water-loading planes, two seaplanes—two more joined late in the afternoon—two helicopters, fifteen heavy machinery teams, two BRIF units, as well as several ground crews and teams from the Guadalajara Provincial Firefighting Consortium. Throughout Sunday, July 17, the residents of Mazarete were able to return to their town, but the fire remained active on three fronts: Mazarete-Anquela-Selas, Ciruelos del Pinar-Luzón-Santa María del Espino, and another, irregular one, reaching Villarejo de Medina. The most concerning front was the one threatening Luzón and Santa María del Espino, and at 6:00 PM, the evacuation of both towns was ordered. The GU-951 road, between Ciruelos del Pinar and Mazarete; the GU-944, between Mazarete and Cobeta; and the GU-949, between Mazarete and Ablanque, were closed. The CM-2107 road was only open for firefighting services. Late in the afternoon, rumors began circulating about the deaths of several members of the Cogolludo crew trapped by the fire. At 9:30 PM, the Guadalajara Government Subdelegation confirmed these rumors, and a few hours later, the bodies of eleven forest agents—ten men and one woman—were found on the slope of a ravine. Only one member of the crew survived, having found refuge under the stream of water falling from the damaged truck in which they had tried to escape the flames. On Monday, July 18, the bodies of the firefighters were recovered, and the fronts threatening the towns of Santa María del Espino, Luzón, Tobillos, Mazarete, Anquela del Ducado, and Villarejo de Medina were brought under control. On July 20, all active fronts of the fire were successfully controlled.

The investigation phase of the criminal proceedings against those responsible for the fire was conducted in the Court of Instruction of Sigüenza. Initially, the nine hikers and the forest ranger of the area were charged, but in 2007 the charges were extended to twenty more people, including several high-ranking officials of the Junta de Castilla-La Mancha, who demonstrated before the judge that their work was impeccable. The trial took place in the Provincial Court of Guadalajara between 2009 and 2012 and concluded with a verdict in which only one of the hikers was convicted of a forest fire offense caused by gross negligence, receiving a sentence of two years in prison, a fine of €3,650, and compensation of €10,640,971.14 to the Junta de Castilla-La Mancha for damages caused by the fire. This sentence was appealed by the convicted individual and upheld by the Supreme Court in 2013.

Article_Name: Incendio forestal de Aliaga-Ejulve de 2009, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Aliaga-Ejulve 2009 forest fire was a natural disaster that became the largest forest fire recorded in Spain in the entire year of 2009, with 7,301.14 hectares burned. It occurred on Wednesday, July 22, in the Sierra de Majalinos, within the municipal area of the Aragonese town of Aliaga (Teruel), quickly spreading to the neighboring municipality of Ejulve. Later, it also spread to the areas of La Zoma, Cañizar del Olivar, and Villarluengo. It was considered extinguished on July 27, five days later, after long and arduous efforts by firefighting teams. The fire started at a very critical time when other fires were occurring in the province of Teruel, which, overall, represented the worst natural disaster recorded in Aragon since the Maestrazgo fires of 1994, in which 30,000 hectares burned.

The fire was considered to be caused by the coincidence of various risk factors at the same time: orange alert for high temperatures, strong wind gusts recorded, low relative humidity, and the fall of numerous lightning strikes during a dry storm hours earlier, which triggered several initial fire outbreaks in the Aliaga forest. All these natural circumstances, added to human causes (the significant delay in the arrival of the first firefighting resources), explain the speed with which the fire devastated 7,000 hectares during the first 48 hours, and therefore the difficulty in extinguishing it during the first days of the fire's activity.

The consequences of this fire, with more than 7,000 hectares of forest and woodland burned, were dramatic for the affected populations, who had a diverse natural heritage that was consumed by the flames in just a few hours, especially lush pine and holm oak forests. The fire not only caused the affected area to lose a large part of its natural heritage but also severely impacted the livelihood of part of its population, who depend on the exploitation and conservation of the natural environment and the tourism sector. During its progression, there were particularly critical moments, as the flames reached the vicinity of a fish farm in the Aliaga area that contained eight gas tanks at risk of exploding. And especially because they reached the town of La Cañadilla (Aliaga), where two buildings were burned down. Due to the complexity of extinguishing it and the dangers to health and safety caused by the fire and dense smoke, the residents of La Cañadilla, Cirujeda, La Zoma, Cañizar del Olivar, Ejulve, and Montoro de Mezquita were evacuated from their homes, the A-2403 road between Aliaga and Ejulve was closed, as well as the A-1702 road between Villarluengo and Ejulve. The flames in this last locality came as close as half a kilometer to its urban center. Another direct consequence was the suspension of the fourth edition of the Carrasca Rock music festival, which was scheduled to take place in Ejulve on July 24 and 25, three days after the fire began.

Article_Name: Incêndio na Chapada dos Veadeiros em outubro de 2017 – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.header: Fire in Chapada dos Veadeiros in October 2017
Whole_Text.content: The fire in Chapada dos Veadeiros, which started on October 18, 2017, was an environmental disaster that destroyed about 35,000 hectares of cerrado vegetation in the Chapada dos Veadeiros National Park, in Goiás. The Chapada dos Veadeiros National Park initially covered 625,000 hectares when it was inaugurated in 1961, decreasing in size until it reached 65,000 hectares, which were expanded through a decree on World Environment Day in 2017 to the current 240,000 hectares.

The fire started on the side of the GO-239 highway, which connects the city of Alto Paraíso de Goiás to the village of São Jorge. Fires naturally occur in the cerrado during the rainy season as a result of lightning, and not during the dry season, when fires occur only due to human action. It is speculated that the fire was a counter-offensive by farmers due to the expansion of the park area, which took place in July of this year. The fire lasted about eight days and had a criminal origin. The fire spread beyond the park area and is currently also affecting farms, villages, and private environmental reserves in the surrounding area.

The Brasília Zoo Foundation sent a team to care for the animals affected by the fire. [3] In addition to the firefighters on site, a group of volunteers mobilized to control the fire [9], a group called Rede Contra Fogo, which is raising funds through crowdfunding on the Catarse platform [8]. Also present in fighting the flames are five ICMBio tanker planes, helicopters from Ibama, the Federal Highway Police, the Goiás Fire Department, and the Federal District Military Police [10]. The Minister of Defense, Raul Jungmann, announced this Monday (23) that the Brazilian Air Force will also act in fighting the flames [11].

Article_Name: Incendio forestal de Pegalajar de 2006, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: View of the Serrezuela de Pegalajar in 2018, where the bare patches and areas of sparse vegetation caused by the 2006 fire can be seen. The Pegalajar forest fire in 2006 occurred in the area known as Baldíos de Haza Colorada, on the western slope of the Serrezuela de Pegalajar, within the municipal boundaries of Pegalajar, adjacent to La Guardia de Jaén and Mancha Real, due to a dry storm that swept across Andalusia on the evening of July 11, 2006. The fire started on the night of Tuesday, July 11, at 11:10 PM, from a lightning strike that ignited the dry vegetation. It was considered extinguished on Thursday, July 13, 2006, at 10:00 AM, with a result of 133 hectares burned, 78 of which were forested areas, mostly Aleppo pine, and the rest consisting of scrubland and agricultural land.

On the evening of Tuesday, July 11, 2006, a dry storm crossed Andalusia from west to east, leaving 1,262 lightning strikes in its wake over five hours, from 7:00 PM to midnight, causing up to 18 forest incidents in Andalusia, three of which turned into fires: one in the province of Huelva, which burned 275 hectares, and two in the province of Jaén, one near Pegalajar and the other in Cárchel, with approximately 30 hectares burned in the latter. In the province of Jaén, up to 167 lightning strikes were recorded, more than half of them in the southern half of the province.

The steep slope of the western side of the Serrezuela de Pegalajar, as well as the high temperatures and low humidity, hindered a rapid extinction. The IU parliamentarian for Jaén, José Cabrero, later criticized the Andalusian Regional Government's Department of the Environment for the delay and negligence in executing the forest cleaning project. Likewise, the CCOO union stated in a report on forest fires that the development of this fire was due to the forest's uncleanliness and the significant lack of preventive measures, with excess undergrowth and dry pines in the forest, as well as the absence of clean paths and trails that would have facilitated the extinction tasks for vehicles and forest workers. The Department, for its part, argued that in 1995 and 1996, significant forestry work was carried out on about 90 hectares of this forest, consisting of thinning, enhancement pruning, and waste removal. The forest is publicly owned, belonging to the Pegalajar town council. A total of 119 people, a forest fire vehicle, three helicopters, a ground-loading plane, and the Mobile Meteorology and Transmissions Unit participated in extinguishing the fire. On Wednesday, July 12, following its favorable evolution, it was declared under control at noon. On Thursday, July 13, 2006, at 10:00 a.m., the fire was considered extinguished.

After the extinction work, the following restoration measures for the affected forest were formulated by the Ministry of the Environment: removal of dead vegetation, construction of terraces and barriers using part of the burned wood to prevent erosion processes, reforestation with native species, improvement of infrastructure such as roads and trails, thinning in areas of dense vegetation after a certain period of time.

Whole_Text.content: At noon on July 30, 1993, a large forest fire broke out in Ikaria, in the wider area of Agios Kirykos, which quickly escalated due to strong winds and insufficient firefighting resources. Many people abandoned their homes in the surrounding areas to escape and sought refuge in the town, but several stayed behind to try to save them. Thirteen people lost their lives in the fire, and more than 20,000 acres were burned. The fire claimed the lives of: Poulos Efstratios, 80 years old; Poulou Koula, 73 years old; Poulou Stamatoula, 67 years old; Kirykos Georgios-Eleftherios, 39 years old; Fysidas Ilias, 25 years old; Tsaganos Dimitrios, 21 years old; Bratsis Konstantinos, 68 years old; Peskenis Georgios, 73 years old; Peskeni Aikaterini, 64 years old; Liaris Sideris, 69 years old; Liari Kalliopi, 70 years old; Xyla Georgia, 18 years old; and Xyla Despina, 65 years old. Among them, Giorgos Kirykou (who participated in the Polytechnic Uprising), Ilias Fysidas, and Dimitris Tsaganos lost their lives while trying to save elderly people who were in danger from the fire. For this reason, they were honored by the Academy of Athens. Every year on July 30, memorial gatherings are held at the Poulato site, where a monument was erected in 2000.

Article_Name: Incendios forestales en Chile de 2019, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The wildfires in Chile in 2019 were a series of forest fires that occurred between the Metropolitan Region and Aisén del General Carlos Ibáñez del Campo. A significant number of fires began in January 2019 in Chile. The vast majority of these could have been avoided, and some others were intentional. In total, there were 7,219 fire outbreaks, affecting a total of 80,064 hectares, with an average of 11.1 hectares per fire.
In January 2019, fires occurred that affected more than 2,000 hectares, over 101 homes, and more than 250 victims.
Since the beginning of 2019, more than 35 fires have occurred in the Metropolitan Region.

Just months after the establishment of the administrative division, one of the challenges the area had to face was the occurrence of forest fires. The first occurred in the Santa Ana sector of the Quillón commune and the Paredones sector in the San Carlos commune, which by January 6 were considered controlled. However, compared to the 2017 fires, the number of affected lands was greater, increasing to more than 590 hectares.

Forest fire "Monte Bello", Pitrufquén commune, which affects an area to be confirmed of 346.98 ha. During the current day, the fire was kept under observation by CONAF personnel.  
It was approximately between 12:00 and 13:00 on February 15, 2019, when the second lieutenant of the third fire company of Pitrufquén, Mr. Rodrigo González Dinamarca, declared the first and second forest fire alarms, which was classified as the largest forest fire in 20 years, with around 40 fire trucks working until 4:00 in the morning.
