Whole_Text.content: The 2006 Curonian Spit fire – a forest fire that broke out on May 4, 2006, and lasted for five days in the Curonian Spit, during which 235.66 hectares of forest between Smiltynė and Alksnynė were burned.

On May 4, 2006, around 2 p.m., local residents noticed smoke above the forest. It is assumed that the fire was caused by human activity, with the source located 1.5 km from the 167 Smiltynė–Nida road. According to locals, there was a fisherman's trail in that area. The fire burned mountain and common pine forests, and leftover World War II explosives were detonating. Firefighters from Neringa, surrounding districts, and the Kaliningrad region extinguished the fire, using 19 fire trucks and 2 pumping stations. Nearly 200 soldiers, an Air Force helicopter, and the ship "Šakiai" were deployed. Another helicopter was sent from Latvia. It was calculated that a total of 1,464 people participated in the firefighting efforts.

After extinguishing the fire, firefighters worked at the site for another two weeks until the rain began. Cleanup and pine planting campaigns were organized, involving numerous volunteers, company employees, students, pupils, community members, and the military. In 2013, over 50 hectares were planted with various tree seedlings. An observation deck and trails were established at the fire site. For fire prevention, several kilometers of firebreak mineralized lines were installed throughout the area. Jurgita Mikšytė, head of the Forestry Department of the Curonian Spit National Park Directorate, stated that the fire demonstrated the shortcomings of mountain pines – it was observed that trees previously considered very useful burn very quickly. For fire prevention in the forests of Neringa, a forestry project was prepared, which included cutting firebreaks (gaps for vehicle access) and fire barriers to facilitate easier fire containment, as well as establishing water intake points from the Curonian Lagoon. However, the project was only partially implemented, and when fires recurred in 2014, firefighters had to transport water from Juodkrantė, located 7 km away from the fire site.

Article_Name: Incendio forestal en Bolivia de 2019, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The 2019 forest fire in Bolivia refers to a series of fires that occurred between July and October 2019, considered one of the most severe ecological disasters in the last 10 years. The fires were located in the tropical regions of the Chiquitano forest—considered a public good of our planet—the Bolivian Amazon, and the western Pantanal, affecting populations such as Roboré, Puerto Busch, and San Ignacio de Velasco among the eight regions directly involved in the department of Santa Cruz and also in the department of Beni in Bolivia. It also endangered municipal reserves such as Tucabaca, Noel Kempff Mercado National Park, or Ñembi Guasu, territory of uncontacted Ayoreo peoples. This event resulted in the loss of five million hectares of Chiquitania dry forest, whose land use is forestal and which in recent years has been converted into agricultural production land without prior consultation with the communities inhabiting the region. Fires caused by direct human action are a significant reason for forest loss in the Amazon basin. This situation has sparked controversy over the government's role in control and prevention measures, which experts have described as one of the most complex disasters in Latin America. Similarly, actions taken to control the disaster, such as the initial refusal to request international aid during the crisis, have been criticized.

Whole_Text.header: Expansion of the agricultural frontier and land for livestock
Whole_Text.content: At the end of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st century, the agricultural frontier in Bolivia expanded rapidly, especially in the departments of Santa Cruz and Beni, causing deforestation and savannization of territories to enable them as spaces for livestock raising and export crops, affecting tropical forests, grasslands, and cane fields. One of the most widespread practices for vegetation removal is the so-called "chaqueo," a practice consisting of burning vegetation cover similar to slash-and-burn. A 2010 report by the Friedrich Ebert Stiftung (FES) Foundation placed Bolivia among the countries with the highest deforestation rates, almost tripling Brazil's rate. At that rate of forest loss, the disappearance of forests in Bolivia was predicted by 2100. On April 26, 2019, Foreign Minister Diego Pary and the Minister of China's Customs Administration, Ni Yuefeng, signed a protocol to export 20,000 tons of meat to China, which means $75 million in revenue for the country. For this, it is necessary to expand from 13 million hectares of livestock use to 20 million, as stated in the 2020-2030 Livestock Development Plan, which was presented by ranchers to the President of Bolivia. Miguel Ángel Crespo, an expert in agroecology, predicts that this type of agro-extractivism exacerbates droughts, floods, climate changes, pest outbreaks, and soil erosion. According to Natalia Calderón, director of the Fundación Amigos de la Naturaleza (FAN), 60% of deforestation is due to livestock farming, and significant deforestation expansion has been detected in Charagua and the Chiquitania in Santa Cruz, as reported on July 5. Juan Carlos Ojopi, a member of the Amazon Defense Committee of the Madera River Basin in the department of Beni, expressed his outright rejection, as it endorses the deforestation of lands they were reforesting themselves, fearing that all their work will be cleared and burned. A report by the Amazon Network of Georeferenced Socio-Environmental Information (RAISG) states that Bolivia lost 18.7 million hectares of forests due to clearings and fires between 2005 and 2018.

On February 26, 2001, the then-president of Bolivia, Hugo Banzer Suárez, authorized through Supreme Decree 26075 "permanent forest use" in the departments of Santa Cruz and Beni. On September 30, 2015, during the government of Evo Morales, Law 741 was enacted, approving the expansion of land clearing from 5 to 20 hectares per community member. With the approval of Law 1098 on Ethanol and Plant-Based Additives, the use of genetically modified seeds resistant to droughts was authorized. On July 9, 2019, in Beni, Supreme Decree 3973 was approved, which partly states: "ARTICLE 5.- In the departments of Santa Cruz and Beni, land clearing is authorized for agricultural activities on private and community lands, framed within the Comprehensive and Sustainable Management of Forests and Land, in accordance with specific management instruments approved by the Authority for the Supervision and Social Control of Forests and Land – ABT, and their current Land Use Plans. In both departments, controlled burns are allowed according to current regulations, in areas classified by the PLUS that permit it." The Minister of State in the Office of Environment and Water is responsible for its execution and compliance.

On March 30, 2019, in San Miguel de Velasco, around 1,000 people gathered who felt threatened by the arrival of outsiders authorized by INRA to allow 69 communities to settle on 130,000 hectares of the Chiquitania. The residents reported their helplessness upon seeing these people kill their livestock and burn their lands. Óscar Hugo Dorado Flores, mayor of San Miguel, said he did not authorize any of this. Aida Gil, leader of the Chiquitana Indigenous Organization (OICH), is accused of promoting what locals consider an invasion.
In the first week of August 2019, 2351 fires were recorded in Santa Cruz, while in 2018 around 2858 had been recorded for the entire month.

During the development of the disaster, different techniques have been used to extinguish the fires, including firebreaks, black lines,[92] support from the Supertanker aircraft, support helicopters, and primarily ground strategies developed by firefighters and volunteers. These efforts have been overwhelmed by the fire, which has been classified as sixth-generation[92] and whose associated phenomena cause concern, characterizing it as one of the most complex phenomena in Latin America; heat and smoke columns up to 4000 m high were identified.[6]

On September 10, international experts flew over the disaster area alongside Enrique Bruno from the Emergency Operations Center and mentioned the need to change strategies to control the fires and prevent the emergence of associated phenomena. Experts from the USA, Costa Rica, Ecuador, and other countries stated they had never seen a fire of such magnitude in equatorial forests and identified four factors that contributed to the emergence of such a large fire: drought, high temperatures, winds, and human activity. The experts affirm that the disaster is extreme and suggest the use of heavy machinery to implement firebreaks at a distance. According to Enrique Bruno: "They have a proposal, the only reliable proposal means all the work with machinery creating firebreak lines at a distance, many machines will be needed, we need more bulldozers in all the fire areas. This is a priority, and the Government must take it as such because this is already overwhelming." As of September 17, there are three fire fronts according to monitoring technician and biologist Suri Cabrera Barea: Fire hotspots are being sought by land and satellite, when the winds are from the south the fire decreases and becomes imperceptible, but when it shifts to the north it becomes uncontrollable, many hotspots multiply, and those that had been fought reignite. The expert points out: "The personnel is insufficient for the number of hotspots that multiply, especially on days with higher temperatures and wind. Volunteer firefighters with the greatest possible autonomy are needed, volunteers with drones to help identify heat points, more bulldozers (the fire needs to be stopped with heavy machinery), more water tanks, chainsaw operators with their tools, uniforms for volunteer firefighters, tools, backpacks." Community members, firefighters, and volunteers report a lack of machinery and equipment, which makes the fight against the fire much longer. Additionally, they suffer burns while trying to extinguish the fire.
Starting Wednesday, September 11, the strategy was changed by creating large gaps with heavy machinery near the towns of Limoncito and Roboré.

On September 2, President Evo Morales met with international experts to work on a prevention plan, immediate action on the fires, and post-Chiquitanía recovery. Participants included: The planning takes into account the equipment for monitoring disasters and the training of community members. Vice President Álvaro García announced that 23 million dollars have already been used to mitigate the fire, and there is no budget limit. Manuel Canelas, Minister of Communication, explained that a post-fire plan is being developed.

On September 7, Pablo Miguel Suárez Núñez, a 34-year-old volunteer firefighter who had traveled from La Paz to assist with efforts in Santa Cruz, passed away.[54] The mother of the deceased stated that she felt abandoned by the government and pointed out that the work was done precariously and that at the very least, there should have been a doctor near the firefighters.[101] On Saturday, September 14, firefighters Dylan Vega, Renzo Flores, both from Santa Cruz, and José Elmar Roca Núñez from San Ignacio de Velasco, drowned in the reservoir of the Campeche property while they were resting.[102] In Santa Cruz, the government declared departmental mourning and held a posthumous tribute.[103]

The forest fire has caused different levels of damage in communities near the areas, reaching a distance of 1 km from populated centers such as Roboré. As of September 5, 2019, at least 4,472 affected families and 171 displaced families had been identified due to the disaster.

According to Ever Durán, president of the College of Forestry Engineers of Santa Cruz (CIF-SC), it will take 200 years to reforest the Chiquitanía. According to the College of Biologists of La Paz, along with 80 institutions, they stated that at least 40,000 trees were affected, including oak, cedar, soto, tarará, and yesquero; by September, it is estimated that 40 million trees were lost; according to the Foundation for the Conservation of the Chiquitano Dry Forest (FCBC), the economic loss value would be around 1.14 billion dollars. Erwin Villagómez, a director of veterinarians, explained that the affected areas are sensitive and need to be immobilized, and the wetlands and water currents in the area represent the only water sources in the region. 59.92% of the affected territory consists of floodable savannas.

One of the territories at risk is the Ayoreo community of Santa Teresita, located 10 km from the fire zone. More than 400 Indigenous communities were affected by the fires. Francisca Matos, president of the Indigenous organization of the Sañorama community of San Ignacio de Velasco, Rosa Pachurí Parabá, president of the Organization of Rafaeleñas Women of Velasco (OMIR), and Marina Justiniano, president of the Organization of Chiquitana Indigenous Women of Roboré, who are in the city of Santa Cruz raising awareness about the issues in their communities on September 20, explain that it has not rained in their communities for more than five months, the fire is in Limones, and their families are at risk. They had to come to the city seeking help, as the aid that arrives is for firefighters but not for Indigenous communities. They were forced to sell the animals they had at very low prices rather than see them die from lack of food and water. All are mothers who had to leave the peace of their rural lives, affected by the concerns in their communities. 34% of the burned territory in Ñembi Guasu represents the area where Indigenous people in voluntary isolation live.

On October 2, the Chamber of Deputies of Paraguay requested formal meetings with the executive branch of Bolivia due to the fires on the Chaco border, which were started in Bolivia thanks to a decree authorized by Evo Morales. The one who promoted this resolution was legislator Carlos Sebastián García, from the Patria Querida Party (PPQ - Capital). In that country, the fire affected one million hectares. Víctor Borda (MAS), president of the Chamber of Deputies, accused them of being meddlesome and stated that there would be no type of compensation.

The directly affected protected areas were Otuquis (135,392 ha), San Matías (124,749 ha), Tucabaca (25,780 ha), and Ñembi Guasu (187,787 ha). Experts in the area have identified a total of 10 protected areas at risk, adding six to those already mentioned, which are:

On August 21, a temporary shelter was set up at the biothermal hotel in Aguas Calientes,[112] where animals, mostly injured with burns, dehydration, or malnutrition, were rescued. Biologist Raúl Ernesto Rojas, along with other volunteers working at the shelter, stated that they only find burned bodies or animal bones, and for the living ones, they leave some food in the territory so they can feed. He explained that they stopped counting because there were too many. The biologist, with more than 15 years of experience in natural disasters, had never seen such a level of disaster. A flagship case of this shelter is that of the anteater Valentina, who arrived with all four paws burned and fell into a coma upon entering the shelter, according to veterinarian Flora Cecilia Dorado. They fear that after the fires stop, people will forget about the rehabilitation of the animals.[113] Efforts were made to rescue animals that are partially burned, dehydrated, and malnourished.[114] There is talk of animals wandering in the burned forests, which makes them easier targets for illegal hunting as they are more visible.[115] Toucans and other types of wildlife have also been seen arriving in the city.[citation needed]

During the development of the forest fire, various data have been presented regarding the number of species affected by the event. As the fire progressed and new ecosystems were destroyed, the figures have increased. By the end of September, the fire persisted, so the analyses and quantifications carried out are partial and subject to later reevaluations that may yield higher numbers. Around 500 animal species are at risk in the Chiquitanía alone. In general, more than 1,200 species, including insects like bees, 43 amphibians, 140 reptiles, 788 birds, and 242 mammals, are suffering the consequences of this disaster. During firefighting operations, firefighters have found various evidence of animals that fell victim to the fires, such as reptiles and charred mammals, as well as others fleeing to areas unaffected by the fires, like puma cubs. One of the animals most at risk is the Ameerega boehmei frog, an endemic species that can only be found in the Chiquitano Dry Forest (BSC). There is fear that the fire may reach the territory of the blue macaw. In an evaluation conducted by Ciencia Bolivia and the College of Biologists of La Paz, it was determined that around 1,600 species were lost in the fire. According to Iván Arnold, executive director of the Nature, Land, and Life Foundation (Nativa), the few animals that remain in the fire-affected area are destined to die because they lack food sources and water. Burned peccaries can be observed, which, despite being fast, could not escape, demonstrating how voracious the fire can be. For him, the only way to recover the area is to declare it untouchable and prevent human interference. For Mónica Negrete, a veterinary graduate and activist in the area, she believes that many animals may disappear as they were already endangered. She thinks the jaguar is the most likely to disappear since, without a pack, it must move to nearby areas to find food and may reach livestock areas where it could be considered a threat. There is concern that toucans, macaws, or parrots that usually migrate to Ñembi Guasu may migrate to the city due to the loss of their habitat. Some species identified as victims include:
55 species of endemic flora are identified as being endangered, including orchids, seven species of wild peanuts, pineapples, and cacti.
The National Chamber of Commerce of Bolivia anticipated that this disaster will reduce this year's GDP by half. 300,000 cows are already left without pasture.
The fires caused an environmental emergency, particularly in the municipality of Roboré. Particulate matter levels of up to 310 micrograms per cubic meter were detected.

A contingent of firefighters from La Paz and Oruro who embarked for Chiquitanía on September 4 returned after two weeks, denouncing the lack of equipment and machinery. They explained that despite airplanes dropping water to help extinguish the fire, it was necessary to enter the territory; however, due to the terrain being inaccessible or very distant, the actions could not be completed. The team of 35 people returned with health problems caused by carbon monoxide poisoning. Charlie Tsai, an acupuncture expert, arrived in the area to help with this therapy for the volunteers and firefighters who are fighting the fire and feeling fatigued. He set up in Concepción along with 16 of his students to offer free relief to those on the front lines of the fire. He is part of the Tsu Chi Foundation, which provides humanitarian aid in 55 countries.

On Monday, August 19, the Platform for the Environment and Life declared a state of emergency and demanded that: 1. A national disaster state be declared to streamline resources and means, and to enable international aid; 2. The repeal of Law 741 of 2015 and Supreme Decree 3973; 3. Those responsible for enabling this forestry regulation be identified; 4. Settlements in affected areas be prohibited and their regeneration promoted, preventing changes in land use.[141] The Pan-Amazonian Ecclesial Network (REPAM),[142] expressed concern that the Amazon is at a point of no return due to human intervention combined with climate change. The Center for Legal Studies and Social Research (CEJIS),[143] which defends against threats and violations of the individual and collective rights of indigenous peasant peoples, issued a statement rejecting the central government's justifications for controlled burns, considering it a violation of the rights of Mother Earth. Representing the Chiquitano Nation, the Chiquitano Indigenous Organization (OICH)[144] expressed concern for the more than 35 directly affected communities that lost animals and production due to fires not caused by nature but by burns and deforestation, and demanded the repeal of Law 741 of 2015 and Supreme Decree 3973, dated July 10, 2019. A total of 21 organizations expressed their stance on the matter in August: Unitas, Aprosar, Casa de la Mujer, Cedla, Cenda, Cejis, CER-DET, Ciac, Cidem, Cipca, DNI-B, Fundación Aclo, Fundación Uramanta, IICCA, Indicep, Islap, Kurmi, Mujeres en Acción, Pío XII, Promotur, and Semta.[145] On September 9, Amnesty International sent a letter to Evo Morales requesting the repeal of Supreme Decree 3973. María José Veramendi Villa, a researcher at Amnesty International, stated that authorities should independently and scientifically investigate the causes of the fires rather than making contradictory and unfounded statements.[63] On September 15, the postgraduate unit in human development CIDES of the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés in La Paz issued a statement titled "Chiquitanía in Flames,"[146] adding voices for the government to declare a national disaster, as it impacts nature and the indigenous peoples of the lowlands. It also criticized how authorities are addressing this issue without considering strategic points for heritage conservation and food security, among others.[147] The College of Biologists of La Paz, supported by 80 institutions, issued a statement urging the government to declare the area a disaster zone to expedite international aid. They noted that since the 1980s, the territory being burned has been recognized as a site of importance for biodiversity preservation with high ecological value.[123] The National Council for the Defense of Democracy (Conade) announced the creation of a committee to promote a trial of responsibilities against President Evo Morales for violating human rights. Rolando Villena clarified that this would take place in the next legislature.[148] In Santa Cruz, the College of Agronomists of Santa Cruz (Cinacruz), the College of Veterinary Doctors of Santa Cruz (Comvetcruz), the College of Forestry Engineers of Santa Cruz (CIF-SC), the College of Biologists of Santa Cruz (Colbiocruz), and the College of Environmental Engineers of Santa Cruz (Ciam-SC), in a joint action, explained why it is necessary to declare a national disaster state: the rural area will be affected by pests and diseases, water will begin to run out, as will meat, creating problems in food security; there will be shortages of agricultural products, putting meat exports at risk; there is a risk of contagious diseases and wildlife mortality.[108] On September 24, the National Summit for the Defense of Forests was held, a meeting between activists and professionals in the field, which concluded with the creation of the Intersectoral Coordinator for the Defense of Nature and Peoples. They drafted a manifesto supporting the Indigenous March for Life and the Defense of the Forest and demanded the declaration of a national disaster to activate international aid protocols, the repeal of Law 741, Law 1098, Supreme Decree 3874, and Supreme Decree 3973, a trial of responsibilities for the President, the annulment of contracts related to the expansion of the agricultural frontier, prosecution of those responsible for the fires, the reversal of land allocations, and the registration of firefighters for health insurance, equipment provision, and training.[149]

On Monday, August 26, in the cities of La Paz, Santa Cruz, Cochabamba, Sucre, and Tarija, citizens protested to demand international aid; it was the second time a national mobilization was called due to the fires. On Thursday, August 29, students from Gabriel René Moreno University confronted municipal authorities in Santa Cruz who were holding the Thursday retreat—a celebration in the Plaza 24 de Septiembre—demanding urgency in addressing the fires, as while they were celebrating, the department was burning. Angélica Sosa, President of the Honorable Municipal Council of Santa Cruz de la Sierra, was confronted, and she exchanged shouts with the protesters. On September 5, the Mujeres Creando collective in Santa Cruz threw red paint symbolizing blood and sealed off the Chamber of Industry, Commerce, and Tourism (CAINCO), holding them responsible for the fires. Sarah Vásquez explained that it was necessary to repeal Decree 3973, Law 741, cancel meat export contracts to China, and annul the ethanol and biodiesel project. On September 6 in La Paz, Mujeres Creando peacefully took over the offices of the Authority for the Supervision and Social Control of Forests and Land (ABT), with María Galindo demanding the resignation of Cliver Rocha and holding him partially responsible for the disaster. Hours later, Rocha was removed from his position. On September 10, the CIDOB, in an extraordinary assembly of the Association of Indigenous Councils of San Ignacio de Velasco, called for the great tenth march of indigenous nations against the laws and decrees that destroy our great home, set to depart on September 16 towards La Paz, demanding that international and national regulations on land use and natural resource use be strictly enforced. That same day, the Extraordinary Assembly of Cruceñidad declared a national disaster in response to the National Government's refusal and called for a large assembly in defense of the land. On September 24, Bolivian residents in the United States approached the assembly to demand that Bolivia declare a national disaster.
Different activities that generate economic income in the area had to be suspended due to the disaster.

With almost three months of forests burning, different analysts indicate that the fires have overshadowed the presidential elections taking place on October 20. Daniel Valverde, director of the Political Observatory at the Gabriel René Moreno Autonomous University, pointed out that several parties suspended their electoral campaigns and that the moral or political authority of the parties addressing this issue is diminished. Political scientist Franklin Pareja says that environmental awareness in Bolivia is very low, explaining that when people are scared, it can influence their vote. For the Minister of Government, Carlos Romero, the situation should not be politicized, and he does not believe there will be a political cost in the elections. For Dilma Justiniano Moreno, a professor at UAGRM, the effects will be seen mainly in those in public administration, who have not been able to manage public policies on this issue.

On February 27, 2019, a national emergency was declared through Supreme Decree 3812, which has a duration of 9 months and allows for immediate international aid. On that occasion, it was issued due to the severe flooding problems the country experienced. CAF - Development Bank of Latin America, Peru, and Argentina proposed aid that became effective at the end of August, when the disaster had progressed. The United States, the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), and the United Nations offered technical and economic assistance. Various organizations committed to donating money:

The Panamanian volunteer Abelardo Serrano, a rescuer by profession who was in Chiquitania collaborating, revealed that he mobilized with his own resources and stated that the reality is more serious than what is seen in the media. He entered with a Bolivian team of volunteer firefighters through Chiquitania.

The Minister of Cultures and Tourism, Wilma Alanoca, declared on August 31 that no territory of tourist interest or natural park was affected by the fires. The Santa Cruz Government emphatically rejected these statements. Paola Parada, Secretary of Sustainable Development, stated that the fire affected the Otuquis National Park, the San Matías National Park, the Integrated Management Natural Heritage Conservation Unit Las Lomas de Arena, the Noel Kempff Park, the La Laguna Concepción Natural Heritage Conservation Unit, the Tucabaca Wildlife Refuge, the Marfil Lagoon in San Ignacio, the Sapocó dams in Concepción, the San Rafael Municipal Reserve, and the Ñembi Guasu Municipal Protected Reserve in Charagua. Danilo Drakic, archaeologist and Secretary of Culture of the Autonomous Departmental Government of Santa Cruz, assured that there are more than 200 rock painting sites in the area. Miguel Ángel Crespo, director of Productivity Biosphere Environment (Probioma), stated that this art has existed for 18,000 years and represents evidence of humanity's first steps on the planet. The National Chamber of Tourism of Bolivia (Canotur) determined that many tourism companies suffered economic losses as they promoted tourist packages in areas that are now burned. On September 16, the Ministry of Cultures and Tourism sent a letter to UNESCO to manage evaluation missions for an emergency fund in favor of the tangible and intangible heritage of Chiquitania.

In June, it was discovered that an official from the Authority for the Supervision and Social Control of Forests and Land signed 2,096 resolutions for the illegal clearing of 22,000 hectares, generating 6 million USD between 2015 and 2018, for which eight former employees are under investigation. The suspension of permits for burning was decreed on August 10, three days after the Santa Cruz Government issued a red alert due to severe fires, although permits continued to be issued until the 15th of that month. Subsequently, they contradicted themselves when, on August 27, they extended the deadline for clearing plans and burning authorizations in Santa Cruz despite the fact that the president himself issued the order for an ecological pause. On September 6, Cliver Rocha, director of the Authority for the Supervision and Social Control of Forests and Land (ABT), was removed from his position after the feminist collective Mujeres Creando peacefully took over its facilities, demanding his resignation for being one of those responsible for the extension of controlled burning permits; Omar Quiroga assumed his position.

On August 29, agro-industrialists and ranchers from Santa Cruz and Beni requested not to repeal Supreme Decree 3973 and Law 741, in order to continue with controlled burns and clearings. Marcelo Pantoja from the Association of Oilseed and Wheat Producers (Anapo) explains that making such a request would be an attack on the country's development, while livestock leader Javier Landívar points out that these laws are not the cause of the fires. Alcides Vadillo, a researcher at the Tierra Foundation, fears that if the 1,400 authorization resolutions are confirmed, 2,500,000 hectares would be enabled for clearing, as they would cease to be forest production areas and would be converted to agro-industrial production.

Whole_Text.header: Accusations about the causes of the fires
Whole_Text.content: The Minister of the Presidency, Juan Ramón Quintana, pointed to the opposition as responsible for deliberately setting fire to the San Lorenzo area to attack the government. Carlos Romero, Minister of Government, stated that legal proceedings were initiated against five people who started fires. In an interview, he claimed that individuals of Chilean nationality were behind the fire: "We have five closed investigation cases, and there is another case that we will open immediately. There are people who allegedly caused the fires deliberately. We cannot say they are settlers or community members; we even have people of Chilean nationality involved in a case in San José de Chiquitos." Víctor Borda, President of the Chamber of Deputies, stated: "We do not want to prejudge, but unfortunately, it seems that some people, activists, are using and provoking these fires for political purposes, and that is a crime; they are killing biodiversity." In a meeting with President Evo Morales on September 3, the National Coordinator for Change (CONALCAM), an institution aligned with the government, accused Brazilians and Mennonites of being responsible. In the same statement, they said they would go to Roboré for a demonstration in defense of Mother Earth, but days later decided not to. "We denounce that the foreignization of land, at the hands of Mennonites and Brazilians, brought this industrial logic that today causes deforestation at the expense of life, and the attempts to blame the communities hide that more than 90 percent of the deforested lands in the country end up in the hands of businesses." Firefighters and volunteers reported that while they extinguish the fire, settlers come from behind to reignite it. Alcohol cans were found, and many volunteers left disappointed because even one of the community members complained to the firefighters for extinguishing the fire, saying they would reignite it later. They also mentioned feeling harassed, being watched during meetings, and being followed on motorcycles. Henry Nina, leader of the Interculturals, strongly denied the accusations and pointed to ranchers and agribusinesses. Germaín Caballero, mayor of San José de Chiquitos, stated that farmers who came from Yapacaní, San Julián, and Cuatro Cañadas are the ones causing the fires. Spanish firefighters reported that the fires are being set to exploit the land, with the intention of selling meat and soy to China, and that the authorities are not doing everything possible to extinguish the fire. It is reported that some people are taking advantage of the situation to burn land because they know the government will not impose any sanctions and that there will be a "forgiveness" at some point in the future, allowing them to legally claim the land they burned. Based on what has happened in the past, it is very likely to occur.

The Customs Administration retained material brought from abroad by a person who landed at Viru Viru airport, claiming it was for donation. Willan Castillo, regional manager of Customs, emphasized that according to Art. 197 of D.S. 25870, donations must be consigned to a public or private entity so that they do not have to pay taxes or undergo any procedures. The Bolivian Police returned 20 firefighting equipment items, considering them insufficient. Igor Echegaray, departmental commander of the Police, explained that they work with their own equipment, although they hope the State will provide them with the necessary equipment.

The Minister of Rural Development and Lands, César Cocarico, said that the settlements in the Chiquitanía –1000 according to the INRA– are to guarantee food security in Bolivia. However, the Social Economic Function (FES) indicated that if there is a food function, it refers to small peanut productions. What could be verified is that in places where there should be 40 people, there are only three or four who have cleared the land without permission for this activity.

Whole_Text.header: Rejection of the State to international cooperation
Whole_Text.content: Vice President Álvaro García Linera stated that requesting international aid would be the same as declaring a national disaster, and that international aid is slow, limited, and temporary. He assured that more than 4,000 Armed Forces personnel and 2,000 Police officers were mobilized, and planes, helicopters, and other vehicles were hired to combat the fires. He rejected the declaration by the Civic Committee pro Santa Cruz, asserting that Bolivia has the resources to resolve the issue and that declaring a national disaster is useless, only having a political cost. Jaime Durán, Deputy Minister of Budget, assured that Bolivia has the necessary resources to handle the fire expenses, pointing out that since 2006 Bolivia has been able to take care of its problems.

On September 24, President Evo Morales met with his international counterparts at the 74th session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) and stated that all possible resources were mobilized during the fires. He suggested that authorities leave behind a fairer world and claimed that the causes of climate change are due to capitalism and mercantilism, pointing to transnational companies that control food, water, non-renewable resources, water bodies, technology, and people's personal data. He was accused of using the same rhetoric regarding the environment, despite regulations against Mother Earth existing since 2011. Pablo Solón pointed out that his speech is devalued due to its inconsistency with his actions, as he blames developed countries for the greenhouse effect while failing to comply with the Paris Agreement. According to Leonardo Tamburini, a researcher at the Center for Legal Studies and Social Research (Cejis), the Bolivian government's development model is entirely contrary to the protection of Mother Earth's rights, adhering instead to a capitalist extractivist model. He accuses the president of creating a pro-Mother Earth slogan for external audiences, while his government program lacks concrete measures in favor of nature. Actions contradicting the president's rhetoric include: seven regulations that harm the environment, the approval of 1,400 settlements in forested areas, hydrocarbon exploration and the implementation of hydroelectric projects in protected areas, mining exploitation in forest zones, the expansion of agricultural frontiers for biofuel production, roads that destroy ecosystems, authorization of genetically modified organisms, and policies that negatively impact indigenous peoples occupying the affected territories.

Deputy Gonzalo Barrientos pointed out that the Ministry of Communication spent 2,767,962 Bs on propaganda spots showing actions taken regarding the fires, while analysts criticize these measures given that volunteers lack resources to extinguish the flames. Government-affiliated leader Pedro Vare blamed the media for magnifying the issue, claiming it is a recurring problem every year and that measures are being taken to fight the fires. The President of Bolivia, Evo Morales, defended environmental preservation within the framework of the Paris Agreement, which seeks to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to combat global warming. However, Cecilia Requena, a senatorial candidate, explained that there are no plans for the government to fulfill the commitments of the Paris Agreement made at COP23 in Bonn, Germany, where they pledged to reduce deforestation, a commitment ratified in 2017. This commitment contradicts the Patriotic Agenda, which proposes expanding the agricultural frontier by 10 million hectares by 2025. Gonzalo Colque, president of Fundación Tierra, stated that the territory burned is a result of this initiative. Biologist Marco Octavio Rivera considered the President's discussion of the post-fire stage unfortunate and recommended that authorities contact universities, research institutes, and park rangers who have worked for decades on forest preservation instead of holding poorly technical meetings, especially with those responsible for the fires: settler unions, development corporations, cattle ranching federations, and agribusinesses.

Article_Name: 2019년 부산 산불 - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: The 2019 Busan wildfire (2019年釜山山-) was a wildfire that occurred on April 2, 2019, at Unbongsan in Bansong-dong, Haeundae-gu, Busan Metropolitan City. The weather conditions at the time were very dry. However, the wildfire is reported to have continued until April 6. The cause of the fire is believed to have been concluded as a fire accident caused by local residents burning field ridges. Due to the aftermath of the fire that day, there was also a CNG bus charging station set up at the Daejin Passenger Depot. If the fire had reached the CNG bus charging station, it was expected that it could have surpassed the 2019 Gangwon wildfire, becoming a major human-made disaster and potentially the Korean version of the 2019–2020 Australian bushfires, with the possibility of even causing significant casualties.

Looking at the background of the Busan wildfire that occurred on this day, the fire on Unbong Mountain continued to spread through strong embers. However, as firefighting efforts involving helicopters were halted at sunset, the flames appeared to spread slowly with the wind. According to the Busan Fire and Disaster Headquarters, the lower part of the mountain, where residential areas were concentrated, experienced less fire spread due to the focused deployment of firefighting forces. However, the fire spread overnight toward the peak of Unbong Mountain, carried by the wind. It was concluded that the flames had spread to the peak of Unbong Mountain. Initially, the burned area was reported to be 5 hectares, but it soon expanded to 13 hectares and eventually reached 20 hectares. The area turned into chaos, with flames visible from a distance. According to a testimony from a Fire Agency official, by 6:08 a.m. the next day, the wildfire containment rate had reached 90%. Additionally, the wildfire spread toward the Gochon-ri area in Cheolma-myeon, Gijang-gun. According to fire authorities, on the day of the fire, 17 firefighting helicopters (not fire department helicopters but wildfire suppression helicopters from the Korea Forest Service and leased helicopters from local governments), 29 fire trucks, and 1,200 personnel and resources were mobilized for firefighting efforts. However, due to the dry weather warning and the embers spreading with strong winds, initial containment efforts failed. As a result of the fire, evacuation orders were issued in several cases. The evacuation targets included nearby residential areas, schools, nursing homes, and facilities for people with disabilities. Dongbusan University and Unbong Middle School, which are adjacent to the wildfire site, also suspended regular classes and evacuated students and staff. As a result, the affected area was provisionally estimated to be 20 hectares of forest, with no damage to nearby residential areas or human casualties.

JTBC also reported related news specials. However, from April 2 to 6, wildfires occurred continuously for five days, but unlike the 2019 Gangwon Province wildfire, the news specials were so prominent that they rivaled terrestrial broadcasters, and even the highly reliable JTBC faced criticism for delays in breaking news.

Article_Name: 2020년 고성 산불 - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: The 2020 Goseong wildfire is a wildfire that occurred on May 1, 2020, in Goseong County, Gangwon Province, South Korea.

Initial outbreak: On May 1, 2020, at 8:21 PM, a fire that started in a house in Dowon-ri, Toseong-myeon, Goseong-gun, spread to a nearby mountain due to strong winds, causing a forest fire. The location of the forest fire was 4 km away from the area affected by the 2019 Gangwon Province forest fire. Cause of spread: Strong winds occurred due to the Yangganji wind on the east coast. Around 9:30 PM, the National Fire Agency issued Fire Mobilization Order No. 2 and Fire Response Level 3, deploying 608 firefighting personnel, including 226 fire trucks. Around 10 PM, soldiers from the 22nd Division, nearby residents, and others evacuated to Goseong Sports Complex, Sokcho Sports Complex, Ayajin Elementary School, and Cheonjin Elementary School.

Around 1 a.m., the National Fire Agency issued Fire Mobilization Order No. 3. At 5:28 a.m., firefighting personnel, including 38 firefighting helicopters, were deployed. Around 8 a.m., the wildfire was completely extinguished, and efforts are underway to clean up remaining embers to prevent secondary damage.
There were no human casualties due to the wildfire, but six buildings, including houses and facilities, were completely destroyed, and 85 hectares of forest were lost.

Article_Name: Incendios forestales en La Pampa de 2017, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The wildfires in La Pampa were a series of strong and massive fires in rural areas of the province of La Pampa in central Argentina, which spread to neighboring provinces, being considered some of the largest wildfires in Argentine history in terms of their extent, damage caused, and duration. In total, it was estimated that the fires in the province devastated 1,300,000 hectares of fields and forests. According to biologist Esteban Dussart, a professor at the Faculty of Agronomy of the National University of La Pampa with a master's degree in biological sciences from universities in Belgium, the origin and spread of the 2017 fires were due to the lack of a concrete and rational management plan for native forests, along with political disinterest in them. The causes of these fires were associated with the conversion of land for livestock and agricultural purposes, mainly for soybean cultivation.

During November, the first fires began, with more than 80 outbreaks reported by November 22, 2017, in various parts of La Pampa, burning around 467,000 hectares and causing the death of more than a thousand animals, according to a report by the National Institute of Agricultural Technology (INTA). Between January 24 and 30, 2018, the devastated area increased by 174,000 hectares, totaling more than 600,000 hectares burned by the end of January. Amid the severe fires, whose poor management led the National Government to transfer control of the fires from the Ministry of Environment to the Ministry of Security, around 300,000 hectares were burned in just one month, equivalent to 15 times the area of the entire city of Buenos Aires. Following budget cuts for fire prevention, Sergio Bergman, former Minister of Environment of the Nation and former PRO deputy, was criticized by the opposition and environmental groups for a drastic reduction in the area's budget and for stating that the most useful way to face the fire season was "to pray," describing the extensive fires as "an apocalyptic prophecy" while forest fires also spread through the provinces of Río Negro and Buenos Aires. Meanwhile, the government of La Pampa and the Agricultural Emergency Commission (CEA) declared an agricultural emergency until June 30. By January 17, it was reported that the fires had already burned 800,258 hectares, equivalent to 40 times the area of the Federal Capital. The most affected department by January 2018 was Caleu Caleu, in the southwestern province, where La Adela is located, with more than 450,000 hectares. Other affected departments were Utracán and Chalileo, each exceeding 100,000 hectares burned. In 2017, former President Mauricio Macri transferred the Fire Management Plan to the Ministry of Security led by Patricia Bullrich. Deputy María Emilia Soria requested the interpellation of Bergman for his management of the fires. The magnitude of the environmental disaster had repercussions in international media. The origin of the fires was reportedly linked to soybean agricultural sectors that habitually burn grasslands to intentionally start fires to reduce field maintenance costs. The most significant criticisms against the national government were particularly directed at Minister Sergio Bergman for the delay in responding to the fires. The first and only firefighting plane arrived on January 1, when the situation was critical. According to information published by the Ministry of Modernization, Bergman used only 51 percent of the budget allocated to the National Fire Management System in his first year in office. Due to the handling of the fires and budget under-execution, various opposition deputies called for the minister's resignation. According to official data published by the Ministry of Modernization, only 111 million out of a total of 243 million were executed. In the case of the Environmental Control program, which performs similar functions, 80 million pesos were allocated for 2017, of which only 34 million were executed, just 42.5% of the budget allocated to the Federal Fire Management System, created by law in 2012 to prevent and combat forest and rural fires. By February 2018, the fires had caused the death of two people and more than a thousand head of cattle that month. In January 2018, after his vacation and two months of active fires, Bergman visited the area when the fire was spreading to the neighboring province of Buenos Aires, prompting criticism from various sectors. The Buenos Aires provincial coordinator of the Agrarian Federation criticized the minister's attitude, stating that "the area needs firefighting planes, not officials with their photographers." It was also stated that the money should be spent on firefighting planes, not on transporting national and provincial officials with their photographers to the fire-affected area in southwestern Buenos Aires, where fires began in January 2018. Weeks earlier, during a meeting on December 28 with the agricultural board, various rural representatives had warned Buenos Aires ministers about the severity of the situation in the area due to severe droughts, but officials delayed action for more than a week. Small rural producer groups requested the National Government to respond to the damages they were suffering due to the fires in Buenos Aires, which by the end of January had devastated more than 690,000 hectares. In the following months, the minister's management was questioned, and finally, Minister Sergio Bergman was criminally charged with embezzlement of public funds in various maneuvers to hire firefighting helicopters without bidding and directly. The case was assigned to federal judge Rodolfo Canicoba Corral, with intervention by federal prosecutor Federico Delgado. Days later, it was revealed that a portal had exposed the direct hiring of a Spanish helicopter company despite the bidding process being underway. The company did not have authorization to fly in the country and did not meet the bidding requirements.

Whole_Text.header: October 2020 wildfires in the Western Free State
Whole_Text.content: The West Free State wildfires of October 2020 devastated large areas of farmland in an important agricultural region, the Tokologo and Tswelopele Local Municipalities, during hot and windy conditions. The fires were driven by the wind from Hertzogville in an east and southeast direction and reportedly started on Sunday, October 18, when protesters set a Jojo water tank and/or tires on fire on the R708 road just outside the town. Shortly thereafter, three more fire points emerged, including one between Kimberley and Warrenton, which spread eastward at 10 km per hour. The fourth fire, which started late at night on a farm near Christiana, was quickly extinguished by a team of workers. By Friday, October 23, the fires were largely brought under control, but by Saturday afternoon, fires were still being extinguished.

More than 100 commercial farmers, in addition to smallholding owners, were affected by the fires. 1,800 head of livestock, in addition to game, perished in the fire or suffered burn injuries. Farm buildings and more than 130,000 hectares of grazing land burned down, and there were fears that certain farmers might go bankrupt. A young farmer from Hertzogville sustained 40% third-degree burns during firefighting on October 19 and also had to receive treatment for smoke inhalation. Several other firefighters were also injured.

The Hertzogville protesters were dissatisfied with the quality of water delivered to them. The SAPS arrested 17 suspects for malicious damage to property, while Agri Hertzogville filed a case of arson. Agri Hertzogville also organized aid, and hundreds of people and institutions responded to Saai and Free State Agriculture (FSA)'s calls for assistance. Feed, livestock, and financial contributions were received, and businesses offered to help with lost infrastructure.
The forest fire in Spannarboda in 1914 or the Spannarboda fire was a forest fire that raged in the summer of 1914 in Spannarboda in Fellingsbro parish, Örebro County.

The forest fire was caused by sparks from a train on July 23, 1914, and started one kilometer north of Spannarboda railway station in Fällingsbro. Due to dry vegetation and wind, the fire spread quickly and came to encompass 5,000 acres of forest. The perimeter of the fire was 30 kilometers. Six farms with residential houses, barns, and outbuildings burned down. On July 24, 1914, about 3,000 men worked to extinguish the fire, including 1,200 military personnel. Assistance was requested from the Stockholm fire brigade, which sent two steam pumps and two thousand meters of hose. Both of these pumps worked for over 400 hours. After a week, the fire was contained. The fire boundary was then Spannarboda, Hundmossen, Torshällsmossen, Norrsjön, Stenkärrsmossen, Kvarnmossen, Hallfallsmossen, Svarttjärn, St Lien, Bråten, Fall, and Spannarboda. The fire was the largest forest fire of that summer. Afterwards, a sawmill was built where the fire-damaged forest was processed. The community center Sveaborg in Spannarboda has an exhibition about the forest fire.

The Utah wildfires of 2021 are a series of significant wildfires currently burning across the state of Utah, lasting from June 1 to October 30, as specified by state law. As of June 23, at least 422 fires have burned 57,245 acres (23,166 hectares) across the state. As part of the larger threat of a "very active wildfire season" in the western United States, Utah was also expected to experience an above-average fire season. Drought conditions from the previous fire season, which occurred during the driest year in Utah's history, continued into the 2021 season at more extreme levels due to below-average winter rainfall. On March 17, in response to statewide drought, Governor Cox signed an executive order declaring a state of emergency. On July 4, many cities across Utah began implementing restrictions on fireworks.

Article_Name: Incendis forestals de 1998 a la Catalunya Central - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: Forest fires from 1998 in Central Catalonia
Whole_Text.content: The forest fires of 1998 in Central Catalonia occurred from July 18 to 22 of that year, burning 27,000 hectares of forest and crops, affecting the regions of Bages, Berguedà, Solsonès, and Segarra. It was the fastest fire recorded in Europe up to that point. It was the confirmation that a different type of fire was occurring, caused by increasingly extreme weather conditions and the lack of forest management. In addition to radically changing the landscape, it caused significant disruptions: in the economic activity of farmers, the transformation of black pine forests into farmland, and even the replacement of political references (in Solsonès, it marked the beginning of the end of CiU's hegemony).

The main fire started in Aguilar de Segarra due to the poor condition of Fecsa-Endesa's high-voltage power lines. In many parts of Central Catalonia, temperatures exceeded 35 degrees and humidity was very low. Simultaneously, other small fires occurred in Gironella, Puig-Reig, la Pobla de Lillet, and Castellar de n'Hug, caused by two young men in a state of intoxication.

On Saturday the 18th, the fire, fueled by adverse weather conditions, quickly spread northward towards Castelltallat. INFOCAT level 1 was declared. Around 300 firefighters and 60 fire engines were deployed. Six people were injured. Approximately 1,000 hectares burned. The following day, Sunday, the fire was declared under control, and at 10:15 a.m., INFOCAT level 1 was deactivated, although weather conditions remained adverse. Seventeen trucks and about a hundred firefighters were withdrawn. Forty-three fire engines and eight aerial units continued working. At 5 p.m., extreme weather conditions caused the flames to reignite in the Castelltallat mountain range near the Cal Sec farmhouse, advancing towards Salo and Cardona. In the latter locality, another fire was also declared, advancing towards Clariana. Within a few hours, the two fires merged into a single 25-kilometer front, far exceeding the firefighters' capacity for containment. In 12 hours, nearly 18,000 hectares burned, making it the fastest-recorded fire in Europe at the time. Around 1,000 firefighters, including volunteers, a hundred fire vehicles, a hundred ADF water tanks, and two Spanish state water bombers participated. Several homes in the Castelltallat mountain range and Salo were evacuated. On Monday the 20th, two central command points were established in Solsona and Valls de Torroella. Three French state water bombers joined the efforts. In total, 24 aerial units participated in the firefighting. Around 600 people were evacuated, many of them schoolchildren on trips staying at the Can Bayona and Can Carral houses in the municipality of Clariana de Cardener, who were relocated to the Solsona sports center. The most active fronts affected the Torregassa ridge (Solsonès), the Claret mountain range (Solsonès - Segarra), and Sant Pere Sallavinera (Anoia - Alta Segarra). On Tuesday the 21st, thanks to improved weather conditions, the fire was brought under control, and firefighting efforts focused on preventing the fire from reigniting at any of the multiple risk points. On Wednesday the 22nd, all previously closed roads were reopened, and the most violent hotspots were extinguished.

In April 2007, the trial began at the Jury Court of the Barcelona Court, where the prosecution charged the two young arsonists from Puig-Reig and the private prosecution charged two technicians from Fecsa-Endesa. Finally, in January 2008, the two technicians were sentenced to two years in prison each for a crime of forest fire due to gross negligence. The ruling considers that the fire started due to the poor condition of the electrical installation and therefore holds the company responsible for maintenance, Fecsa, liable to compensate approximately 24 affected property owners with 10,644,600 euros. The two young arsonists were sentenced to one year in prison for a crime of forest fire.

Article_Name: Incendi del Garraf de 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Garraf fire of 1994 was a forest fire that broke out on April 9 of that year in Olivella, in the Garraf massif, burning 4,510 hectares of forest and vegetation, which is nearly half of the surface of the natural park. This vegetation was recovering from the 1982 fire, which destroyed 11,000 hectares. It occurred simultaneously with other fires: at Cala Morisca (also in Garraf); in Subirats (Alt Penedès); in Sant Pere de Llavinera (Anoia); and in Gavà (Baix Llobregat); as well as others in the Tarragona regions and Bages, all fueled by strong winds and high temperatures, which would be a prelude to the wave of forest fires in Catalonia in 1994.

The fire started at 2:30 PM on Saturday, April 9, 1994, in the municipality of Olivella, due to stubble burning by a farmer. Simultaneously, another fire started at Cala Morisca, which forced the closure of the C-246 road and train traffic for 2 hours, and it would merge with the Olivella fire.

From Olivella, the fire spread to the neighboring municipalities of Sitges, Begues, and Gavà. 36 fire trucks, 3 helicopters from the Generalitat Fire Department, and 1 water bomber from the Spanish state, coming from Torrejón de Ardoz, were involved. The following day, 65 vehicles and 200 firefighters were working on it. On Monday the 11th, it seemed that the fire was under control, but in the afternoon, the wind reignited the flames, directing the front towards Sitges. It was not extinguished until 72 hours after it started.

Article_Name: Incendi del Garraf de 1982 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Garraf fire of 1982 was a forest fire that broke out on July 5 of that year in Begues and spread towards the Garraf massif, with a front of 18 km, burning a total of 11,000 hectares in the municipalities of Begues, Olivella, Sitges, Gavà, and Castelldefels. It burned 80% of the surface of the future natural park, which was in the process of being declared. The fire coincided with a heatwave coming from Africa, with record temperatures: in Barcelona, it reached 37.6º, the highest temperature of the century, and the cloud of ashes from the fire 'rained' over the city. It also coincided with the creation of the Fire Brigade of the Generalitat of Catalonia, which had presented its vehicles a few days earlier. That day, around twenty forest fires were declared in the province of Barcelona, with suspicion that most were intentional. All the fire stations of the Generalitat, Barcelona firefighters, Icona, about 1,000 members of the Spanish Army, Urban Guard, and 200 Civil Protection volunteers participated.

The fire originated on the morning of Monday, July 5, 1982, in a shrub area of the municipality of Begues, probably intentionally. The wind and heat favored the rapid spread of the flames. The mayor of Castelldefels reported a lack of coordination among the different intervening bodies, and that the Barcelona Firefighters arrived before the Generalitat Firefighters.

The flames affected several urbanizations of the massif and Castelldefels, where several houses burned. About 2,000 people were evacuated. For 3 days, firefighters from the entire province, 2 Icona water bombers, army soldiers, and Civil Protection volunteers worked there.

In addition to the 11,000 hectares of forest and some burned houses, a Spanish army lieutenant died from smoke inhalation, and the Minister of Governance of the Generalitat, Joan Vidal Gayola, was injured in a car accident returning from Begues. The independence movement denounced the lack of forest policy management, both by the state and the autonomous government, the absence of coordination between different administrations, the ineffectiveness of the Icona equipment transferred to the Generalitat, and in this context, the Terra Lliure attack on the Icona office in Barcelona in August 1982 was understood.

Article_Name: Incendio de Sierra Bermeja, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Sierra Bermeja fire was a forest fire that originated on September 8, 2021, in the municipality of Jubrique in the province of Málaga, in Andalusia, Spain. It was an intentional fire with two focal points, started late on September 8, controlled on September 14, 2021, thanks to rain, and declared extinguished on October 24, 2021. On September 9, it claimed the life of the Almerian forest firefighter Carlos Martínez Haro in the line of duty. It affected a total of 8,401 hectares located in Sierra Bermeja within the municipalities of Jubrique, Júzcar, Faraján, Genalguacil, Casares, and Benahavis, and especially Estepona. Firefighting efforts involved intervention teams from all Andalusian provinces, as well as resources from the State and other autonomous communities. The fire reached a danger level of 2 with 30/30/30 conditions, meaning less than 30% humidity, more than 30 degrees Celsius temperature, and winds of more than 30 kilometers per hour.

Article_Name: Incendi del Pont de Vilomara de 2022 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: Fires of Pont de Vilomara in 2022
Whole_Text.content: The Pont de Vilomara fire of 2022 was a forest fire that started at midday on Sunday, July 17, in the municipality of El Pont de Vilomara i Rocafort (Bages). The emergency services received the alert at 1:04 PM. By 8:45 PM on the same day, it had burned about 1,232 hectares, 194 of which belonged to the Sant Llorenç del Munt i l'Obac Natural Park. The Firefighters of the Generalitat initially announced that the fire had a potential of between 1,000 and 1,500 hectares, and they deployed 121 units. In the evening of the same day, they increased the estimate to up to 6,000 hectares.

El Pont de Vilomara already suffered a fire in 1985, which at that time burned more than 1,800 hectares of the municipal area. In mid-July 2022, a heatwave began that affected much of Western Europe and the United Kingdom, setting maximum temperatures across the region. The rise in temperatures caused a series of forest fires throughout Europe, and the high temperatures led to hundreds of deaths in Spain and Portugal. The United Kingdom issued its first "red" level temperature warning, and several cities were evacuated in Portugal and France. Climatologists linked the extreme heat to the impact of climate change, and experts predicted more frequent episodes of extreme heatwaves in Europe as a consequence of climate change. These are therefore very favorable conditions for the spread of a fire: very high temperatures, very low humidity of 15%, and a sea breeze that pushed the fire northward, where there was an abundant forested area.

The Firefighters of the Generalitat received the alert at 1:04 p.m. about a forest fire declared in the municipality of Pont de Vilomara i Rocafort (Bages). The fire started in the Vallhonesta area, a population center of Sant Vicenç de Castellet. A total of 76 units of the Generalitat Firefighters were deployed, 13 of which were aerial.[10] It is a fire in a large forest area, with significant vegetation continuity, and in one of the areas most affected by drought in all of Catalonia. The fire advanced driven by the south wind, heading towards the Serra del Bitó. The fire reached the Serra dels Ermitanets. The area that could be affected is estimated to be between 1,000 and 1,500 hectares.[10] In the immediate hours after receiving the alert, efforts focused on stopping the fire's advance from the tail, targeting the right and left flanks. Regarding the latter, there was concern about a possible spread towards the center of Pont de Vilomara. The head of the fire advanced strongly and projected secondary outbreaks. Heavy machinery was also used on the tail and right flank. Technical fire maneuvers were carried out to create black zones where the fire could be mitigated.[10] The area contains numerous urbanizations and scattered settlements. According to Civil Protection, due to the proximity of the fire and smoke, residents of the municipality of Pont de Vilomara and the River Park urbanization were asked to stay indoors, and the scattered settlement of Can Riera was evacuated. At 4:30 p.m., evacuations began in areas of Pont de Vilomara closest to the fire, as well as the Les Brucades urbanization in the municipality of Sant Fruitós de Bages.[3] Additionally, Firefighters positioned vehicles to defend the Marquet Paradís and River Park urbanizations if necessary. The municipality of Pont de Vilomara activated its municipal emergency plan, evacuated the municipal pool to allow firefighters to access water, and set up a multipurpose room in case it was needed.[10] The Generalitat Firefighters' ground extinction units were joined by efforts from the Forest Action Group (GRAF), the Operational Support Group (GROS), the Active Forest Prevention Team (EPAF), and aerial resources (MAER). ADF, Civil Protection, the Red Cross, and various security and health bodies also operated in the area.[10] At 5 p.m., it was reported that the affected area already exceeded 400 hectares and that the fire had reached the Sant Llorenç del Munt i l'Obac Natural Park, an area that had been closed off by the Generalitat days earlier due to the high fire risk during the heatwave.[11] Shortly before 6 p.m., the Navarcles City Council also asked residents to stay indoors.[12] At 7 p.m., Civil Protection issued a new statement listing the affected municipalities, including El Pont de Vilomara i Rocafort, Sant Vicenç de Castellet, Sant Fruitós de Bages, Castellbell i el Vilar, and Navarcles.[13] The Chief Inspector of the Firefighters, David Borrell of the Generalitat, appeared before the media alongside the Minister of the Interior, Joan Ignasi Elena, and reported that approximately 1,200 hectares had already burned and that the fire's potential could reach up to 6,000 hectares due to the climatic conditions and strong winds in the area. They also announced that weather conditions were expected to improve starting at 8 p.m., that there were no personal injuries, although it was confirmed that the fire had reached some houses in the town of Pont de Vilomara.[4]
The fire affected traffic and several roads were closed, the BV-1124, the BV-1125, the BV-1129, and the access to the C-55 in the area. Later, the C-16 was also closed in both directions in Manresa.
Throughout the day, the Rural Agents reported on the evolution of the affected area.
