Article_Name: Feux de forêt de 2022 en Gironde — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content:
Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata  
The 2022 forest fires in the Gironde department, France, are fires that, in distinct phases, primarily affected three different areas of the Gironde forest from mid-July to the end of September, requiring the intervention of several hundred firefighters from Aquitaine or other regions and even some European countries. The first fire began accidentally on Tuesday, July 12, around 3 p.m., in a plot of the La Teste-de-Buch forest, a locality bordering the southern part of the Arcachon Basin. A second fire was reported about an hour later, the same day near Landiras, in the south of the department. In the following weeks, it was in the south of Médoc that the forest faced the assault of the flames. Among other factors, the department had only received limited rainfall since August 2021. This rainfall deficit contributed to the drying out of forested areas, which, combined with the heatwave in Western Europe in July 2022, persistent drought, and stormy winds, significantly exposed the region to the risk of forest fires. The exceptional fires of July caused the evacuation of 36,750 residents and ravaged 20,800 hectares of forest (mainly pine) over nearly two weeks before the numerous resources deployed managed to contain them: the La Teste-de-Buch fire after 11 days, on July 23, and the Landiras fire supposedly fully under control two days later, on July 25. On August 9, as a result of the underground spread of the blaze through deep peat deposits, the fire reignited in Landiras and "reappeared" around Saint-Magne, causing the destruction of 7,400 additional hectares between the municipalities of Belin-Béliet, Hostens, Saint-Magne, and extending to the Landes municipalities of Moustey, Saugnac-et-Muret, and Mano, as well as the evacuation of several thousand residents. On Monday, September 12, in the south of the Landes du Médoc, a new fire broke out in the Saumos forest, then spread to part of the neighboring municipality of Sainte-Hélène, where several residents, exposed to smoke, had to be evacuated. This fire destroyed 3,720 hectares. On September 18, a fire burned at least 120 hectares of forest near Arès. In total, these fires burned more than 32,000 hectares of the Landes de Gascogne forest. With 13,800 hectares burned, not counting the fire's resurgence, the Landiras fire is the second largest in recent French history, behind the 1949 Landes forest fire.

During the period from the end of August 2021 to May 2022, the Gironde department experienced the lowest rainfall recorded since 1959. This led the Prefecture of Gironde to impose water restrictions in the department starting in June 2022. On Sunday, July 17, weather conditions deteriorated in France, and fifteen departments along the Atlantic coast were declared on red alert (see Météo-France Weather Vigilance) due to the 2022 European heatwave with record temperatures expected for Monday, July 18. Fifty-one other departments were placed on orange alert.

The fire in La Teste-de-Buch broke out around 3:00 PM on Tuesday, July 12. According to its mayor, Patrick Davet, the origin of the disaster was the result of a serious electrical problem that triggered a fire aboard a utility vehicle traveling on a forest track (Track 214), connecting the departmental road D218, near the Dune of Pilat, to the departmental road D112 leading from the main town of La Teste to the village of Cazaux. A second fire broke out an hour later in the commune of Landiras, between Hostens and Langon. On Tuesday evening, authorities evacuated five hamlets and the village of Guillos near Landiras as a precaution. Five hundred people were evacuated, and no casualties were reported in this fire. Roads D115 and D125 were closed to traffic. In the area near the fire, an evacuation of five campsites with approximately 6,000 vacationers began on July 13 as a precaution. They were relocated to the exhibition center and a shopping center in La Teste-de-Buch. Road D218 was cut off by the fire between Pilat and Biscarrosse beach. No injuries were reported. By the evening of July 12, the fire had consumed 445 hectares of forest in La Teste. By noon the next day, the affected area was estimated at 700 hectares. During the Landiras fire, 800 hectares had burned since Tuesday, July 12, and no injuries were reported. The prefecture then activated two operational command posts managed by the Gironde SDIS to coordinate operations. Nearly six hundred firefighters were mobilized to fight the fire, while volunteers from Civil Protection and the Red Cross carried out support missions for the population. Two Canadair water bombers were deployed, along with two Dash aircraft, with additional reinforcements from other regions of France. By noon, the fire in this area had reached 1,000 hectares.

On the morning of July 14, the area of forest devastated by flames near Arcachon in the territory of the commune of La Teste-de-Buch was estimated at 1,750 hectares, with no injuries reported. Due to the configuration of the forest terrain, consisting of successive dunes, the fire was still not under control as it was difficult to access. Starting at 5 a.m., around sixty people were evacuated from an area north of the village of Cazaux. The D218 road leading from the Pilat roundabout to the Landes locality of Biscarrosse was closed. By early evening, the fire had ravaged 2,900 hectares and two houses, and campsites near Lake Cazaux were under threat. New evacuations took place in the afternoon around Cazaux, and 4,000 evacuees were initially housed at the La Teste-de-Buch exhibition center, which was quickly converted into a reception center. In Landiras, 2,100 hectares burned near Langon on Thursday morning without causing injuries. The fire was not under control, and the D115, D125, and D220 roads were closed to traffic. Guillos and the hamlets of Lahon, Hil, and Petit-Hil were evacuated. By evening, the fire had burned 2,400 hectares and was still not under control. Nearly a thousand firefighters, four Canadair planes, and two Dash planes were mobilized. The prefect, Fabienne Buccio, placed the Gironde department on orange alert due to weather conditions and the possible risk of other forest fires. On the morning of July 15, 3,150 hectares had burned in La Teste-de-Buch, and the fire had reached Lake Cazaux. Evacuations of some 10,000 people from the village continued. The La Teste-de-Buch fire was still not under control, and in Cazaux, three houses and two lakeside restaurants were destroyed. Bulldozers were brought to strategic locations to create firebreaks across the probable path of the fire. About a thousand firefighters, three Canadair planes, and one Dash plane were deployed to fight the fires in both areas that morning. Some individuals were allowed to return to spared sites, and vacationers evacuated since Tuesday from campsites in La Teste-de-Buch near the large dune returned on Friday, July 15, to retrieve their camping equipment and luggage. Most Cazaux residents were not allowed to return to check the condition of their homes or retrieve their pets. New evacuations were carried out throughout the day in Louchats, Origne, Balizac, and La Broque, with around 1,900 evacuees. The fire situation in this area remained out of control. A house in Guillos was destroyed, and other roads in the fire zone remained closed. Greece and Italy provided two Canadair planes to France. Upon their arrival, they were immediately deployed in the south of the country, which was also experiencing fires. President Emmanuel Macron visited the crisis center of the Ministry of the Interior in Paris to be briefed on the progress of the firefighting efforts. Gironde was one of 16 departments on orange alert due to the heatwave. On July 16, some Cazaux residents who had left their homes were only allowed 15 minutes to retrieve belongings and pets, while others were unable to return as their route was again threatened by fire. The La Teste-de-Buch fire was contained but still burning, with the potential to become uncontrollable if temperatures remained high and winds picked up again. Villagrains (a commune of Cabanac-et-Villagrains) was evacuated, as were 1,900 residents of Hostens. In the commune, an evacuation order was issued, but residents were not required to leave; those choosing to stay had to declare their decision. The amount of vegetation and forest burned in the two fires now totaled less than 10,000 hectares. Two new shelters were opened in Saucats and Belin-Béliet. Canadair and Dash planes dropped 6,000 liters and 10,000 liters of water and fire retardant, respectively, on the fire fronts and flanks, attempting to stop or at least slow its progression. So far, four firefighters had been injured, one fire engine overturned, and another was burned. Three thousand buildings had been saved. The president of the Gironde Departmental Council, Jean-Luc Gleyze, advocated for the local positioning of a fleet of Canadair and Dash planes to fight the fire, as some Canadair planes had been moved to other regions of France. Some arrived too late, making it more difficult to control the fire. According to him, if the La Teste-de-Buch fire could be contained between the coast and Lake Cazaux, more resources could then be transferred to Landiras. Jean-Marc Pelletant, mayor of Landiras, stated that a team of Bordeaux prosecutors had arrived and was investigating criminal activity responsible for the fire. The evacuation of 2,100 people from Cabanac (a commune of Cabanac-et-Villagrains) began on July 17, with more than 16,000 people evacuated since Tuesday, July 12. By midday, the prefecture announced that approximately 11,000 hectares had burned in the two fires. 1,500 firefighters from across France were fighting the fire. During the La Teste-de-Buch fire, 3,400 hectares were destroyed, compared to 7,200 hectares in the Landiras fire. The latter fire had a perimeter of 12 kilometers by 6 kilometers with several different advances. By midday, firebreak construction continued, with the La Teste-de-Buch fire being fought on its left and right flanks to protect campsites and homes. During the day at the Landiras fire, the DFCI continued to establish firebreaks. By evening, 3,900 hectares had burned in La Teste-de-Buch and 9,000 hectares in Landiras, after the fire situation worsened in the afternoon, with the former fire reaching the ocean at the Banc d'Arguin and turning south. In Landiras, the fire spread on multiple fronts as the wind shifted. Resources to fight the fire were increased but still needed to be deployed, with three additional planes, two hundred firefighters, and eleven other firefighting vehicles allocated. In the Landiras region, two new shelters were opened in Langon, while one was closed in Saucats. On Monday, July 18, 1,700 firefighters from across France and some neighboring countries were now mobilized to fight the fire. More than 16,000 people had been evacuated, with new evacuations planned in the Landiras region. About fifty victims were housed in shelters on the night of July 17-18. 4,300 hectares of forest had burned in La Teste-de-Buch, and 10,000 people had been evacuated. Since the morning, boating on the western part of Lake Cazaux-Sanguinet and navigation and anchoring in the southern entrance channel of the Arcachon Basin had been prohibited. Evacuations of the communes of Landiras, Budos, and Balizac were underway, with an estimated 3,500 people to be evacuated. On Tuesday, July 19, 6,500 hectares had burned in La Teste-de-Buch, and another 8,000 people were evacuated, bringing the total to approximately 20,000 people. An evacuation of a nursing home in the Dune du Pilat was completed overnight, and part of the La Teste-de-Buch zoo had to be evacuated to the Pessac zoo. In Landiras, 12,800 hectares had burned, and more than 8,000 people were evacuated, bringing the total evacuations to 14,000 people. The Flots Bleus campsite, which hosted the film "Camping" in 2006, was completely destroyed. In La Teste-de-Buch, 7,000 hectares of forest had already burned, and 20,000 people were evacuated. In Landiras, 13,300 hectares had burned, and preventive evacuations took place in Saint-Léger-de-Balson (about 300 people), Saint-Symphorien (about 2,000 people), and even Mano (about 130 additional people), the only commune in the Landes evacuated as a precaution against the possible spread of this fire. In Vensac, the fire started at 8:45 p.m. and had already burned 80 hectares; a campsite and a hamlet were evacuated, totaling 550 people.

The authorities counted a total of 20,800 hectares of forest burned in Gironde on July 20 (13,800 hectares in Landiras and 7,000 hectares in La Teste-de-Buch). Four Canadairs, two Dash planes, and one PUMA water-bombing helicopter from Civil Security are still mobilized, and 2,000 firefighters from Gironde and external departments have been brought in as reinforcements. Following numerous fire protection works carried out the previous day, the spread of the fires was significantly limited over the past 24 hours. For the second consecutive day, the two fires did not present any more active flame fronts and did not progress. The drop in temperatures also facilitated the firefighters' work. No additional evacuations took place on this day. A total of 36,750 people have been evacuated since the start of the fires. On July 21, the fires did not progress but were not yet under control, according to the prefecture. The first reintegrations began, with 6,000 people allowed to return to their homes. An additional 6,500 residents were able to return home on July 22, as the two fires were now contained.

Whole_Text.header: End of the fires and gradual return of residents (July 23 - 25)
Whole_Text.content: On July 23, the fire in La Teste-de-Buch is considered contained. Ground and aerial resources remain mobilized while out-of-area firefighter units gradually return to their departments. More than 19,000 residents return to their homes, as authorities have authorized the reopening of new municipalities in the Landiras area and the entire municipality of La Teste-de-Buch. On July 25, temperatures exceeding 35°C caused the appearance of smoke and flare-ups in the burned area, which were handled by the 1,200 firefighters still deployed. Two days after the La Teste-de-Buch fire, the Landiras fire is considered contained on July 25.

On August 9, in the municipalities of Saint-Magne, Cabanac-et-Villagrains, and Hostens, the resurgence of the Landiras fire led to the destruction of an additional 6,200 hectares within a few hours, the destruction of 17 houses in the municipality of Belin-Béliet, the evacuation of 10,000 people in Gironde and Landes. This resurgence also resulted in the closure of the A63. Firefighters reported two injuries and six burned trucks. 1,000 firefighters were mobilized as of August 10. The evacuation of the town of Béliet, involving 2,500 people, was ordered. Reception centers were opened in the municipalities of Salles, Saint-Symphorien, and Le Barp. During a new assessment on August 11, 7,400 hectares of forest had burned. The area to be monitored covered a perimeter of 40 km, requiring the mobilization of 1,300 firefighters as well as 361 personnel and 101 vehicles deployed as reinforcements from Germany, Greece, Poland, Austria, and Romania. On August 12, 2022, German reinforcements were engaged in Belin-Béliet to address hot spots. On Sunday, August 14, 2022, the head of the SDIS 33 and the sub-prefect of Arcachon, Ronan Léaustic, announced from the VPC that all fires were now under control but not yet extinguished. A long-term effort would continue in the coming weeks to prevent any resurgence. On Wednesday, September 28, 2022, the prefect of Gironde announced in a press release that all fires were now extinguished after two and a half months of struggle.

The scale of these fires required the intervention of a very large number of firefighters — up to 2,000 — with reinforcement columns coming from all over mainland France. The civil security training and intervention units were involved in the fight, notably for opening routes, creating firebreaks, and applying retardant. A large part of the civil security aerial resources group was deployed to these fires, with up to 8 Canadairs and 2 Dash aircraft on July 19.

Several approved civil security associations (AASC) were involved, particularly in the management of emergency accommodation centers, including the French Red Cross (CRF) and the FNPC. Forest defense associations against fires were requisitioned by the prefecture to carry out work on widening and securing tracks and networks. Around fifty companies mobilized 67 machines. On July 25, 131 kilometers of firebreaks and support lines were completed, including a firebreak 300 meters wide and 5 kilometers long located at the border of Landes and Gironde between the Atlantic Ocean and Lake Sanguinet.  

Humanitarian associations and volunteer efforts  
Local humanitarian associations and volunteers organized collections and distributions of goods for firefighters as well as offers of solidarity accommodation starting on July 13. This wave of collection was encouraged by the various municipalities hosting firefighters and regularly making donation appeals via social networks. Supply points and volunteer-run canteens also emerged, such as in Cabanac-et-Villagrains. These points, often managed by volunteers, provided water and food supplies. They also allowed firefighters to have a hot meal.

In La Teste-de-Buch, the fire outbreak was accidental, affirmed the mayor of the commune on July 16. The breakdown of a thermal vehicle, a van, is believed to be the cause of the fire. The vehicle was parked on the side of a track at the edge of the pine forest when it broke down and caught fire, allowing the flames to spread rapidly within minutes. On the other hand, in Landiras, the fire outbreak is suspected to be of criminal origin. An investigation for "destruction by fire of woods, forest potentially causing harm to people" is underway.

If drought and exceptional heat are the triggering elements of these large fires, other causes have favored the fire, such as the cancellation of the planned clearing in 2021[67]. The event also stems from major demographic trends, shortcomings in land-use planning, and the limits of a primarily reactive risk management approach, based on a rapid and massive response to fire outbreaks[68]. Indeed, when urbanization is marked by the presence of numerous scattered neighborhoods and hamlets, it forces emergency services to manage the safety of thousands of people and compels them to disperse their resources to protect homes in a defensive logic, to the detriment of a more offensive strategy focused more on controlling the fire's progression[68]. In a forward-looking approach, integrating the issue of climate change, it would be useful to further mobilize land-use planning tools, which were scarcely utilized in 2022, such as Forest Fire Risk Prevention Plans (PPRIF) (only 13 municipalities across the entire Landes massif) to incorporate fire risk into long-term urban planning[68].

No human loss is to be lamented. On the firefighters' side, authorities report 25 minor injuries, including 12 firefighters from the Gironde Departmental Fire and Rescue Service. However, for the fauna and flora, the consequences are already severe, with many animals and insects having perished in the flames. Five homes were destroyed out of the 2,785 exposed (3 in La Teste and 2 in the Landiras area), 2 photovoltaic panel fields were damaged in Landiras, and in La Teste, 1 restaurant, 1 nightclub, and 5 campsites were destroyed. Following the resurgence of the Landiras fire on August 9, 17 additional houses were destroyed in the commune of Belin-Béliet.

After the fires, the National Forestry Office extracts the burned wood, still healthy and therefore usable, with the aim of cleaning up the forest and selling it. The public institution aims to collect 80,000 m3 of wood "as quickly as possible," before spring and the arrival of insects that could threaten other healthy trees through their proliferation (bark beetles). This represents the volume of ten years of logging. The ONF is expected to sell this material 15% cheaper than green wood, for a revenue of about one million euros. The replanting project is expected to rely on several species, including cork oak, known for its fire resistance, in addition to maritime pine, which will remain the main species.

On Saturday, September 3, 2022, about 1,500 people gathered in Cabanac-et-Villagrains to celebrate the end of the fires and pay tribute to the firefighters. On Saturday, September 10, 2022, a large solidarity concert called Woodlove, featuring eight bands on two stages, was held in Belin-Beliet in honor of the firefighters and volunteers.

Article_Name: Incendio forestal d'Ateca de 2022 - Biquipedia, a enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Ateca forest fire of 2022 is a fire that began on July 18, 2022, in the Community of Calatayud (Aragon), and mainly affected the municipalities of Ateca and Moros, which saw almost the entirety of their municipal territory burned, as well as the municipalities of Villalengua, Torrelapaja, Castejón de las Armas, Embid de la Ribera, Alhama de Aragón, Bubierca, Cetina, and Contamina. The affected area extends over more than 14,000 hectares with a perimeter of 72 kilometers. The affected locations had to be evacuated, and traffic on the Northeast Highway was interrupted for about 30 hours. The Ateca fire was caused during reforestation work carried out by the company Campos Rey, subcontracted by the Dutch company Land Life Company, which aimed to reforest 200 hectares in the Monegrillo area. During these works, on July 18, 2022, a spark from one of the machines working there jumped, starting the fire that spread rapidly, burning 500 hectares on the first day, increasing to 5,500 on the second day, and reaching 14,000 hectares by July 20.

La Teste-de-Buch is a municipality in the French department of Gironde (region Nouvelle-Aquitaine). The municipality had 27,141 inhabitants on January 1, 2022. The municipality is part of the arrondissement of Arcachon. Within its territory are the Dune du Pyla, the highest dune in Europe, and the Lac de Cazaux, the second-largest freshwater lake in France. The municipality consists of the localities La Teste-de-Buch, Le Pyla-sur-Mer, and Cazaux.

The area of La Teste-de-Buch amounted to 180.2 square kilometers on January 1, 2022; the population density was then 150.6 inhabitants per km². The map below shows the location of La Teste-de-Buch with the main infrastructure and neighboring municipalities. The center of La Teste-de-Buch is located in the north of the municipality, on the Bassin d'Arcachon, where oyster farming is practiced. Until 1857, the neighboring municipality of Arcachon was a district of La Teste-de-Buch. Le Pyla-sur-Mer is a seaside resort on the Atlantic coast and at the Dune du Pyla, which was developed from 1915. Cazaux is located in the south of the municipality on the Lac de Cazaux.
The communal forest of La Teste-de-Buch is the last remaining communal forest in France. It is characterized by the right of the municipality's residents to share the use of the wood.

In 2022, this forest was almost completely destroyed by a large wildfire between July 12 and 20, which reduced 70 square kilometers to ashes. What made the large wildfire possible was the preceding drought in the area since August 2021, and a heatwave (with record temperatures such as 42.4 °C on July 18 in Cazaux). It is assumed that an electrical problem with a car on a forest road near the Dune du Pyla ignited the fire.
In the municipality lies the La Teste railway station.

South of Arcachon lies the civilian airfield XAC – Arcachon La Teste de Buch with a hard asphalt runway measuring 1400 by 80 meters and one soft grass strip measuring 1180 by 20 meters. Southeast of the village of Cazaux lies the air force base Base Aérienne 120 Cazaux with an asphalt runway measuring 2408 × 45 meters. The base was established in 1914 as a shooting range for seaplanes that could land and take off on the nearby lakes. Later, it became an airbase for training pilots of land planes. The first foreigners were the American pilots of the famous Lafayette Escadrille from World War I who fought as volunteers. Today, it is still used for transition training of pilots from both domestic and foreign origins.

Article_Name: Incendios de la sierra de la Culebra de 2022, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Fires of the Sierra de la Culebra of 2022
Whole_Text.content:
Sierra de la Culebra, province of Zamora, Spain  
In the summer of 2022, two major fires occurred in the Sierra de la Culebra, in the northwest of the Spanish province of Zamora. They particularly affected the Sierra de la Culebra and its surroundings. The first one started on June 15 between the areas of Ferreras de Arriba and Sarracín de Aliste, and the second on July 17 in the area of Losacio. The cause of both fires was a dry storm phenomenon. The first fire was controlled on June 24, 2022, and the second on August 14, 2022. The flames spread across the territories of 52 localities in the regions of Aliste, La Carballeda, Tábara, Tierra de Alba, and Benavente and the Valles. In the Ferreras fire, 29,670 hectares were affected. In the Losacio fire, the affected area reached 35,960 hectares. These are the two largest fires in the history of Castilla y León, and two of the most devastating in Spain since records began. Despite the starting points of both fires being more than 20 km apart, the affected areas came into contact along a 15 km line. The combined perimeter affected by both fires encompassed an area of nearly 66,000 hectares. Of this area, 34,000 hectares were of high ecological value as they belonged to the natural space of the Sierra de la Culebra, which is part of the Meseta Ibérica biosphere reserve. 48% of this natural space was consumed by the flames during the two fires, in a time span of just over a month.

More than half of the forest mass of the Sierra de la Culebra consists of coniferous forests, as a result of successive reforestation efforts carried out during the 1950s and 1960s on highly eroded land. The resin or maritime pine species (Pinus pinaster) is the most abundant, followed by the Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris). To a lesser extent, there are discontinuous masses of native species such as the Pyrenean oak, holm oak, cork oak, and strawberry tree. The previous major wildfires that the Sierra de la Culebra had suffered date back to the 1990s. In particular, on July 20, 1990, due to a dry thunderstorm, a fire started between the areas of Ferreras de Arriba and Cabañas de Aliste, spreading through Las Torres de Aliste, Pobladura de Aliste, and Villardeciervos, and burned 5,000 hectares. The following year, on July 8, 1991, another fire destroyed 6,784 hectares in the central area of the Sierra de la Culebra, between the villages of Figueruela de Arriba, Linarejos, Santa Cruz de los Cuérragos, Flechas, and San Pedro de las Herrerías. Since then, more localized and smaller-scale forest fires have occurred. Unlike pyrophilic plants such as the Pyrenean oak or holm oak, which have some capacity to regrow after a fire, many pine species do not withstand fire. Their survival mechanism involves producing cones that burst open when exposed to fire, dispersing their seeds to regenerate in cleared, nutrient-rich soil once the fire is extinguished. Following the aforementioned fires of the 1990s, no reforestation or forest management plans were implemented in most of the affected areas, leading to a massive spontaneous reforestation of resin and Scots pine species over the next thirty years among dense shrubland. This resulted in the Sierra de la Culebra being populated by a very dense forest mass composed mainly of shrubland and pine forests, with a high potential for fire propagation.

The climate along the Sierra de la Culebra varies notably. In the southeast of the mountain range, temperatures are higher than in the northwest, while rainfall decreases. Below are the average temperatures and rainfall of Villardeciervos, a municipality in the mountain range that has a meteorological observatory. As can be observed, summers are warm and dry.

The winter of 2021-2022 was the fourth warmest and the second driest winter on record in Spain. The spring of 2022 was also unusually dry. Specifically, May 2022 was the second warmest and driest May in history. During June 2022, a heatwave occurred in Europe, which in Spain lasted from June 12 to June 18, being the second earliest heatwave ever recorded. The Aemet weather station in Villardeciervos recorded a maximum temperature of 35.8°C during the heatwave on June 15, while the minimum temperature during the night of June 17 to 18 was 17.5°C. In comparison, the average minimum temperature for the month of June at that weather station is 11°C. Under these circumstances, Aemet warned of an extreme fire risk starting June 14 across most of mainland Spain, particularly in the northwest of the province of Zamora. These meteorological episodes created very favorable conditions for the spread of the fire on June 15. During July 2022, another heatwave occurred in Spain, lasting from July 9 to July 19. Under these circumstances, the extreme fire risk persisted in the province of Zamora. The episodes of very high maximum and minimum temperatures, as well as minimal humidity levels, facilitated the rapid spread of the fire on July 17.

Whole_Text.header: Chronology of the Ferreras and Sarracín fire

Whole_Text.content: Between 19:00 and 21:00 on June 15, 2022, a dry storm caused 11 fire outbreaks in the province of Zamora, 6 of which occurred in the Sierra de la Culebra. The first three were detected at 19:48 in the area of La Pedrizona, in Ferreras de Abajo. The other three were detected simultaneously at 20:08, one of them in the municipality of Sarracín de Aliste and two others in Ferreras de Arriba. Due to strong erratic winds, they quickly spread through the aforementioned municipalities. At 22:20, level 1 was declared in the Forest Fire Operation of Castilla y León.

At 1:40 on the 16th, level 2 was declared in the Forest Fire operation of Castilla y León due to the unfavorable evolution of multiple fire outbreaks. More than 100 professionals from the forest fire fighting operation of the Junta de Castilla y León worked throughout the night to extinguish it. During the morning and afternoon of the 16th, resources and personnel from the Military Emergency Unit, the Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, the Community of Madrid, and Galicia joined the firefighting efforts. The arrival of east winds with gusts of up to 40 km/h and high temperatures of nearly 40°C made extinguishing the fires difficult. By 5:30 PM, the estimated burned area was 900 hectares, of which 738 corresponded to the Ferreras de Arriba fire, 127 to the Sarracín de Aliste fire, and 28 to the Ferreras de Abajo fire. Throughout the day, a bulldozer operator was injured after suffering burns to his hands during firefighting tasks. During the afternoon and night of the 16th to the 17th, the fire spread uncontrollably to the west, becoming beyond the capacity for extinction.

The strong shifting winds early in the night, with gusts of up to 54 km/h, the high nighttime temperatures, and the rugged terrain with steep slopes and high rockiness complicated the firefighting efforts during the night. All of this, combined with the inability to use aerial resources, resulted in the fire advancing nearly 15 km in a straight line overnight and forced the evacuation of the municipalities of Cabañas de Aliste, Palazuelo de las Cuevas, Las Torres de Aliste, Pobladura de Aliste, Mahíde, San Pedro de las Herrerías, and Flechas. The high severity of the burned areas during the night in the mountain ranges of Ferreras de Arriba, Cabañas de Aliste, and Las Torres de Aliste, as well as the records of fire spread and wind direction and speed, indicate that a very intense explosive phenomenon of firestorm was generated in the early hours of the morning, where the fire created its own wind currents through a strong convective column. Unlike other areas of the fire, this sector experienced the total incineration of the existing forest mass. More than 220 people worked overnight on firefighting efforts. On the morning of the 17th, the first estimates from the emergency operation indicated an approximate burned area of 7,000 hectares, although other estimates already suggested figures of 14,000 hectares. The southerly wind forced the evacuation of the towns of Boya and Villardeciervos. During the afternoon of the 17th, weather conditions worsened, with constant southerly winds of 30 km/h, erratic behavior, and gusts of up to 70 km/h, leading to very high propagation speeds that rendered firebreak attempts and technical fire efforts ineffective. At 7:00 PM, the Villardeciervos base was evacuated. Additionally, during the afternoon of the 17th, the towns of Villanueva de Valrojo, Sagallos, Codesal, and Cional were evacuated. More than 400 people were working on extinguishing the fire, including 92 resources, 23 of which were aerial. In the afternoon of the 17th, the Ferreras de Abajo hotspot got out of control, forcing the evacuation of the municipalities of Ferreras de Abajo and Ferreras de Arriba, as well as the closure of the N-631 road.

Official estimates on the morning of June 18 were of 19,700 hectares burned. A total of 111 resources and 480 professionals from the Junta de Castilla y León's operation had been deployed, along with personnel from the Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, the Military Emergency Unit, and the communities of Galicia, Cantabria, Extremadura, Madrid, and Castilla-La Mancha. Evacuated residents from Boya, San Pedro de las Herrerías, Cabañas de Aliste, Mahíde, Pobladura de Aliste, Las Torres de Aliste, and Palazuelo de las Cuevas were able to return to their homes on the morning of the 18th due to the absence of nearby flames. Villardeciervos, Villanueva del Valrojo, Ferreras de Arriba, Ferreras de Abajo, Codesal, Cional, Flechas, and Otero de Bodas remained evacuated. During the afternoon of the 18th, the fire forced the closure of the Orense-Zamora high-speed rail line. Winds of nearly 40 km/h, with strong gusts of 50 to 70 km/h, pushed the flames northward, and estimates indicated an approximate area of over 25,000 hectares burned. Around 4:00 p.m., the fire crossed the N-631 near Val de Santa María. The wind gusts were so intense that the fire spread through embers over distances of up to 500 meters. By 9:00 p.m., the fire had crossed the Agavanzal reservoir. More than 500 professionals and 110 resources from the forest fire-fighting operation of the Junta de Castilla y León (INFOCAL), the Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge (MITECO), the UME, and the communities of Galicia, Extremadura, Cantabria, Madrid, and Castilla-La Mancha continued working to contain the flames. During the afternoon, the municipalities of Melgar de Tera, Olleros de Tera, Calzadilla de Tera, Pumarejo de Tera, Junquera de Tera, Milla de Tera, Vega de Tera, Val de Santa María, Villanueva de las Peras, and Litos were evacuated. The town of Calzada de Tera was placed under confinement.

On June 19, the fire was declared stabilized within its perimeter, which covered around 31,000 hectares. The N-631 road and the Orense-Zamora high-speed rail line became operational again. A total of 665 professionals from INFOCAL, the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITECO), the UME, and the communities of Asturias, Cantabria, Castilla-La Mancha, Galicia, Extremadura, and Madrid continued working on the extinction efforts.
The fire was declared under control on June 24 at 9:00 PM, after 10 days since it began.

Around 18:00, lightning from a dry storm sparked several fires in the area of Losacio (Zamora). Due to strong winds, the fire spread with great intensity towards the north. The fire was declared level 2 in the Castilla y León Forest Fire operation around 20:00, after forcing the closure of the ZA-902 road and the Zamora-Ourense railway line. Before 21:00, San Martín de Tábara, Ferreruela, and Sesnández de Tábara were evacuated. The fire had reached such magnitude that it generated its own wind system with characteristics of a firestorm, causing it to spread with great intensity and making it beyond extinction capacity. The Junta of Castilla y León requested support from the Military Emergency Unit. In this context, during the last hour of the evening, a forest firefighter died after being surrounded by flames due to their rapid advance. Additionally, 9 forest firefighters were injured to varying degrees from burns and smoke inhalation. Two other people were seriously injured in an accident related to the fire situation. Late on the 17th and during the early hours of the 18th, the towns of Tábara, Escober de Tábara, Olmillos de Castro, Abejera, and Riofrío de Aliste were evacuated due to the rapid advance of the fire. In just four hours from the start of the fire, the flames had devastated 10,000 hectares.

Early in the morning, the town of Litos was evacuated, and the N-631 road and the high-speed rail line between Zamora and Sanabria were closed. At the same time, a second fatality from the fire was identified: a shepherd from Escober de Tábara who was caught by the flames in the area of Ferreruela while out with his sheep on Sunday afternoon. The flames were advancing so quickly that by the morning of the 18th, the towns of Villanueva de las Peras, Bercianos de Valverde, Santa María de Valverde, Morales de Valverde, and Pueblica de Valverde were evacuated. By midday and early afternoon, the towns of Ferreras de Abajo, Pumarejo de Tera, Melgar de Tera, Santa Marta de Tera, Santa Croya de Tera, and Santibáñez de Tera were evacuated. By late afternoon, Faramontanos de Tábara, Abraveses de Tera, Micereces de Tera, Aguilar de Tera, and San Pedro de Zamudia had been evacuated. Late at night, the evacuated towns also included Villaveza de Valverde, Friera de Valverde, Perilla de Castro, Navianos de Alba, Pozuelo de Tábara, Moreruela de Tábara, and Santa Eulalia de Tábara.

During the early hours of the 19th, the towns of San Pedro de las Cuevas and the urbanization of La Encomienda were evacuated. In the morning, the Army was activated for monitoring tasks. By midday, due to improved conditions, only 14 villages remained evacuated, with the inhabitants of 19 localities being rehoused: Ferreruela, San Martín de Tábara, Olmillos de Castro, Tábara, Abejera, Riofrío, Ferreras de Abajo, Melgar de Tera, Pumarejo de Tera, Santa Croya de Tera, Santa Marta de Tera, Santibáñez de Tera, Abraveses de Tera, Perilla de Castro, Pozuelo de Tábara, Moreruela de Tábara, Santa Eulalia de Tábara, San Pedro de las Cuevas, and the urbanization of La Encomienda. During the afternoon of the 19th, due to the improvement in weather conditions, the fire's advance was brought under control, except in the area of Pueblica de Valverde.
During the early hours of the 20th, significant progress was made in controlling the fire. By morning, all roads were reopened, as well as the high-speed rail line between Zamora and Sanabria.
The forest fire was brought under control on the afternoon of August 14. A total of 31,500 hectares in the Sierra de la Culebra reserve and other bordering areas had been burned.
After forty-five days, the fire was declared extinguished at 09:45 on Wednesday, August 31.

In the case of the Ferreras and Sarracín fire, the number of hectares affected varies depending on the source. According to data provided by Sentinel-2 on June 26, 2022, within the Copernicus Program, the affected area is 27,242 ha with some degree of severity, with a perimeter encompassing 29,670 ha. The area affected by a significant degree of burning would be 25,216.6 ha. However, from the time the Sentinel-2 data was obtained until the fire was extinguished, reproductions of the fire continued to occur in initially unburned vegetation islands, so the final area affected by the fire was greater than that provided by Sentinel-2. Of the affected land, about 21,000 hectares belonged to the natural area of the Sierra de la Culebra. In the case of the Losacio fire, initial estimates indicated an affected area of between 32,000 and 34,000 ha. According to data provided by Sentinel-2 on August 4, 2022, within the Copernicus Program, the affected area is 31,473.1 ha, with a perimeter encompassing 35,960 ha. As in the previous case, from the time the Sentinel-2 data was obtained until the fire was extinguished, reproductions of the fire continued to occur in initially unburned vegetation islands, so the final area affected by the fire was greater than that provided by Sentinel-2. Of the affected land, about 13,000 hectares belonged to the natural area of the Sierra de la Culebra.

Four people lost their lives during the fire that started in Losacio: a forest firefighter died after being surrounded by the flames due to their rapid spread; a shepherd from Escober de Tábara also died, caught by the flames in the area of Ferreruela; a resident of Sesnández passed away a month after the fire due to severe burns suffered while fleeing the flames, as well as a resident of Tábara. Additionally, 9 forest firefighters were injured with varying degrees of severity from burns and smoke inhalation. Two other people were seriously injured in an accident related to the fire situation. On October 25, after three months in the ICU due to burns suffered, a fourth man from Tábara passed away. Rest in peace.

The Ferreras and Sarracín fire affected the territories of 24 localities: Sarracín de Aliste, Cabañas de Aliste, Las Torres de Aliste, Pobladura de Aliste, Mahíde, San Pedro de las Herrerías, Boya, Codesal, Cional, Villardeciervos, Villanueva de Valrojo, Val de Santa María, Otero de Bodas, Ferreras de Arriba, Ferreras de Abajo, Litos, Melgar de Tera, Olleros de Tera, Calzadilla de Tera, Pumarejo de Tera, Junquera de Tera, Milla de Tera, Vega de Tera, Villar de Farfón, and Villanueva de las Peras. The Losacio fire affected the territories of 33 localities: Losacio, San Martín de Tábara, Ferreruela, Sesnández de Tábara, Tábara, Escober de Tábara, Olmillos de Castro, Abejera, Riofrío de Aliste, Villanueva de las Peras, Bercianos de Valverde, Santa María de Valverde, Morales de Valverde, Pueblica de Valverde, Ferreras de Abajo, Pumarejo de Tera, Melgar de Tera, Santa Marta de Tera, Santa Croya de Tera, Santibáñez de Tera, Faramontanos de Tábara, Abraveses de Tera, Micereces de Tera, Aguilar de Tera, San Pedro de Zamudia, Villaveza de Valverde, Friera de Valverde, Perilla de Castro, Navianos de Alba, Pozuelo de Tábara, Moreruela de Tábara, Santa Eulalia de Tábara, and San Pedro de las Cuevas.

The Junta of Castilla y León maintained the medium risk of fires during the month of June, despite the heatwave, and did not declare the high-risk wildfire season until June 27. This meant that, until June 27, the firefighting operations available in that autonomous community did not reach 25% of those planned for the high-risk wildfire season. The vice president of the Junta, Juan García-Gallardo from the Vox party, promised aid measures on social media, including the donation of jerseys by the Vuelta Ciclista a Castilla y León and the organization of a solidarity concert in the fall to raise funds. That jersey raffle only raised 250 euros, while the so-called "benefit concert" was not held within the planned timeframe. Additionally, the initial benefit concert was replaced in March 2023 with the announcement of a concert to be held on June 3 as a "tribute to those affected." The event entailed a cost of 160,000 euros instead of raising funds to mitigate the wildfire damages, as initially announced. "Solidarity is that residents can attend this concert for free," stated García-Gallardo. Following the controversy generated, some groups withdrew from the concert days later. Finally, after the withdrawal of the headlining group Fangoria—who claimed to have been announced "without their knowledge or consent"—the Department of Culture, Tourism, and Sports decided to cancel the concert, which has been described by local press as "the story of a fiasco."

Article_Name: Incendio forestal d'Anyón de Moncayo de 2022 - Biquipedia, a enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The forest fire of Anyón de Moncayo in 2022 is a fire that began on August 13, 2022, in Anyón de Moncayo (Aragon), and burned an area of 6,000 hectares, with a perimeter of 50 kilometers. 1,500 people had to be evacuated from the towns of Anyón de Moncayo, Vera de Moncayo, Alcalá de Moncayo, Ambel, Bulbuent, Trasmoz, Talamantes, El Buste, and the Sanctuary of Mercy.

Forest fires in Russia in 2022 are ongoing large-scale forest fires, which since May have affected only the territory of Siberia. Fire outbreaks occurred in the Krasnoyarsk and Altai Territories, Irkutsk, Kemerovo, Omsk, Kurgan regions, and Khakassia. The total area of the fires (as of May 15) was about 20 thousand hectares, and since the beginning of 2022, more than 100 thousand hectares. Possible causes of the fires include careless handling of fire during picnics on May holidays, short circuits in power lines and substations, or the ignition of dry grass, as well as deliberate arson. On August 10, 2022, the area of forest fires in Russia increased by 15% in one day. In the Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug, more than 110 thousand hectares were being extinguished. Smoke from forest fires in Yugra reached the Volga region—four districts of Bashkiria were covered with smoke. As of 00:00 on August 21, the total area of forest fires in the Russian Federation increased by more than 17 thousand hectares in one day. There were 90 forest fires active over an area of 102,883 hectares, where active extinguishing efforts were underway. In Yakutia, seven fires were being extinguished over an area of 80,889 hectares. Fires were also being extinguished over significant areas in the Ryazan region (7,470 hectares), the Komi Republic (6,741 hectares), the Nizhny Novgorod region (5,200 hectares), the Mari El Republic (700 hectares), and the Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug (113 hectares). Two fires were being extinguished on specially protected natural territories over an area of 1,101 hectares in the Ryazan region—in the Oka Reserve and the Meshchera National Park. On August 26, the area of forest fires in Russia increased by more than 12 thousand hectares, reaching 122.5 thousand hectares. The largest fires were in Yakutia, where 74,667 hectares were affected by fire, Komi (15,722 hectares), the Ryazan region (14,000 hectares), the Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug (6,992 hectares), and the Nizhny Novgorod region (6,500 hectares).

Whole_Text.header: Forest fires in the Ryazan region
Whole_Text.content: In August, a major forest fire occurred in the Ryazan region. On August 18, smoke from the fires in the Ryazan region reached Moscow. By August 21, the area of active wildfires in the Ryazan region was about 160 hectares, with a total of approximately 8.6 thousand hectares affected by fire, according to the press service of the regional Ministry of Emergency Situations. The report stated that all necessary measures were being taken to extinguish the fires and protect settlements. Starting from August 20, smoke began to appear in the neighboring Moscow region and Moscow. On August 22, the regions were enveloped in dense haze, and a state of emergency was declared in the Ryazan region. On August 25, it became known that at least eight fire trucks sent from Moscow to combat the fires in the Ryazan region had burned in the forest fires. On August 27, the area of forest fires in the Ryazan region increased by 10% in a day, reaching 19 thousand hectares. In the settlements of Peredeltsy, Malinovka, and Kriusha, an excess of harmful substances in the air (carbon monoxide) was detected. On August 30, 2022, the area of forest fires in the Ryazan region grew by 2 thousand hectares in the past day, exceeding 22 thousand hectares.

Since the beginning of the fire season in Russia, more than 6,000 fires have occurred, and the total area affected by fire has exceeded 860,000 hectares, the Ministry of Natural Resources of the Russian Federation reported. Of these, 467.7 thousand hectares (54%) are in the Far East, and 306.9 thousand hectares (35%) are in Siberia, according to a statement on the official Telegram channel of the department. At the same time, the ministry emphasized that not a single forest fire that started since the beginning of the 2022 fire season has spread to populated areas. The Ministry of Natural Resources clarified that this year federal funding for combating forest fires has been increased from 6 billion rubles to 14.2 billion rubles.

Article_Name: Incendio forestal en Tierra del Fuego en diciembre de 2022, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Forest fire in Tierra del Fuego in December 2022
Whole_Text.content: On November 30, a fire started 12 kilometers from the town of Tolhuin, Argentina, near the provincial natural reserve Corazón de la Isla. The fire spread quickly due to weather conditions and wind, which reached 90 km/h during the first days. As of December 9, 2022, 7,500 hectares had been burned, much of it native forest.

On November 30, the flames were detected from the Lago Escondido detachment. The outbreaks are believed to have started near the Río Claro and a tourist stop called "Refugio Fueguino." Three groups with a total of 30 brigade members were deployed to the area.

On December 2, provincial authorities communicated with families living within the reserve. Residents reported the lack of state intervention in the hotspots of the area, particularly during the first day at Estancia el Carmen. On December 4, the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development added 30 brigade members to control the fire through the National Fire Management Service. On December 6, 1,500 hectares were reported burned. There were 70 brigade members in the area, a helicopter, and a water bomber plane according to official information. The provincial government declared a "total ban on lighting fires in wilderness areas" for 90 days to prevent the emergence of new fire outbreaks. By December 9, 7,500 hectares had been burned. Around 1,000 brigade members were working in the area. On December 10, a total of more than 9,000 hectares had been burned, and active hotspots remained. It is being investigated whether it was caused by human negligence. On December 12, more than 10,000 hectares were reported burned. The National Fire Management Service confirmed that the homes and people residing near the area were not in danger. On December 13, it was reported that the fire had spread to rural areas adjacent to the reserve. On December 14, it was reported that more than 12,000 hectares had been burned. Another 20 brigade members from the National Fire Management Service and Navy personnel were expected to carry out monitoring tasks in the affected areas. On December 19, the government of Tierra del Fuego announced for the first time the containment of the fire; however, it was expected that the meteorological development of the area would assist in this. On December 29, the general fire containment began despite not being fully controlled, as there were still hot spots of fire in the reserve.

On January 6, the authorities of Tierra del Fuego stated that the general fire was mostly contained and was under control, divided into 6 sectors. On January 10, a new fire broke out near the Villa Marina complex, close to National Route 3, 60 kilometers from Ushuaia and 40 kilometers from Tolhuin. Three lost areas were also reported. At the beginning of February, Infobae declared that by that time, more than 10,000 hectares had already been consumed, and the fire was described as "uncontrollable." On February 28, the Ushuaia24 site reported that the fires were under control.

On March 2, Clarín reported that 150 brigade members are still working in the affected area and more than 12,000 hectares remain burned (as stated in December). It was also reported that the fire reached the road connecting the island with the town.

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about meteorology or climatology. edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The cold wave of February 1986 in France is an intense cold wave that affected a large part of France from February 5 to 28. On February 7, a storm hit Brittany and Vendée. From February 9 to 11, temperatures ranged between -10 and -15°. From February 13 to 24, it snowed every day in several regions such as Brittany, the Centre, Pays de la Loire, Burgundy, and the Rhône-Alpes region.

Article_Name: Vague de froid de l'hiver 1954 en France — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.header: Cold wave of the winter of 1954 in France
Whole_Text.content: This article is a draft concerning meteorology or climatology and history. During the first week of 1954, an initial cold wave accompanied by snowfall hit the north and northeast of France. Temperatures dropped below −10°C; −16°C was recorded in Strasbourg, −18°C in Nancy, and even −30°C in Wissembourg. At the end of January and the beginning of February, a second cold wave affected the entire country. Major rivers froze, and in Dunkirk, an ice sheet formed. Temperatures reached as low as −25°C in Luxeuil-les-Bains, −21°C in Mulhouse, and −13°C in Paris. On February 5th and 6th, a snowstorm struck Languedoc-Roussillon in the extreme south of France; in two days, 85 cm of snow fell in Perpignan, 40 cm in Carcassonne, and 30 cm in Montpellier. The extreme severity of the temperatures led Abbé Pierre to make his famous radio appeal, known as the 1954 call. This appeal triggered a massive influx of donations and introduced the French to the Emmaus Movement, created in 1949, which was then in full development.

The cold wave in Europe in January 1985 was the harshest since 1956. It began on January 6 and lasted approximately two weeks. It brought unusually low temperatures and snowfalls to the Basque Country; for example, in Donostia, thermometers reached -6°C, and 15 cm of snow accumulated on the streets. A skiing competition was organized on the Kontxa promenade, and the lowest temperature ever recorded in Gasteiz, -16.8°C, was registered. Most transportation and roads were completely cut off. In Europe, there were hundreds of deaths.

Article_Name: Onada de fred de 1956 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The cold wave of 1956 was a cold spell in February 1956 that affected the entire Northern Hemisphere and, especially, Western Europe, and stands out in most meteorological records as the coldest month of the entire 20th century for many areas of the Catalan Countries. Three strong pulses of an intense cold wave occurred during the first twenty days of the month. At the Fabra Observatory, -10 °C was recorded, and in the city of Barcelona itself, it reached -6.7 °C (with the average February temperature of 1.6 °C at the Fabra Observatory, which is the lowest of any month since 1914), at Turó de l'Home -19.8 °C, -6.4 °C in Tortosa (Roquetes Observatory), and -13.5 °C in Lluc; at Estany Gento (2,150 meters above sea level), -32.0 °C was reached, the lowest temperature recorded in Spain and still unbeaten. The wave came from the British Isles and Scandinavia and affected all of Europe, with -35 °C in Saint Petersburg, -32 °C in Innsbruck, -29 °C in Moscow, and -35 °C in Munich, and rivers such as the Garonne, the Loire, the Rhine, and the Danube froze. The month of February of that year is remembered for the socioeconomic changes suffered in the counties of Girona. In the city of Girona, it reached -10.5 °C on February 3 (and especially in Empordà) as a result of the continuous cold waves (for nearly 24 consecutive days, minimum temperatures were negative, and very often below -5 °C). The most significant cold air invasions occurred between Thursday, February 2, and Sunday, February 5, and between Saturday, February 11, and Monday, February 13, 1956. Even today, contemporaries of that time call it and remember it as the Year of the Cold. The sea water froze in some coastal areas between Empordà and Roussillon. Agriculture, one of the main productive activities of the Catalan counties, was particularly affected by the cold. Much of the crops were damaged, and even now it is remembered as the year the cold killed the olive trees. The winter vegetable gardens lost their harvest, much of the cereals suffered the effects of the cold (depending on the growth stage they were in, and other aspects such as oats being more vulnerable than wheat). The episode was also very intense in Mallorca, where it is still remembered by those who lived through it as the Year of the Snow. A minimum temperature of -13.5 °C was reached, and snow depths of more than 50 cm were recorded, limits not surpassed since then. It affected all the municipalities of the island, and snow was part of the Mallorcan landscape for 17 days, from February 3 to February 20, consolidated in three waves of snowfalls. The agricultural damage was immense, as all the fields remained frozen, and it had significant economic effects since the primary sector was still of great importance at the time, as tourism had not yet consolidated, and the process of "Balearization" had only just begun.

In the Principality, the olive trees that had been pruned during the month of January in a period of very pronounced mild weather suffered greatly, as the sap began to rise as if it were an early spring, and the arrival of low temperatures, with intense and prolonged frosts and strong tramontane winds, caused the splitting of branches and even the cracking of entire trunks. The oil mills in the region worked little that year. As a result of this cold wave, the damaged olive trees were uprooted. Informatively, 62% of the area occupied by olive trees in 16 municipalities of Alt Empordà (Avinyonet de Puigventós, Boadella, Borrassà, Figueres, Garrigàs, Navata, Ordis, Pontós, Sant Miquel de Fluvià, Sant Mori, Santa Llogaia d'Àlguema, Saus-Camallera, Siurana, Taravaus, Vilamalla, and Vilaür) disappeared in the following years.

Article_Name: Fredorada de desembre de 2001 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The cold spell of December 2001 was a cold wave that affected the Iberian Peninsula. The peak intensity of the cold was during Christmas of that year when, in addition, there was snow in many areas (except the coast). This cold spell was not as intense as the cold wave of February 1956 or that of 1985.

Whole_Text.header: Effects of the cold snap of December 2001
Whole_Text.content: The effects of thermal inversion are observed, for example, in Boí (2,540 m altitude) and Lleida (290 m), where the minimum temperature is the same (-14 °C); in La Garrotxa, the frost was more severe in Vall d'En Bas (463 m) due to the accumulation of cold air being surrounded by mountains, compared to Olot, which is practically at the same altitude (421 m); in Osona, Gurb, at the bottom of the Vic Plain (517 m), recorded 11 °C less than Muntanyola (higher at 809 m altitude). Finally, the lowest temperature recorded in December 2001 was in Das at 1,096 m altitude (-22.6 °C), a situation also caused by temperature inversion, as in the high Cerdanya mountains, the minimum temperatures were about 10 degrees higher. Since the cold was accompanied by snowfalls almost at sea level[1] and the snow froze on the roads, there were problems with communications and transport. In agriculture, olive trees in the western lands were particularly affected, as damage to vegetation occurs from -7 °C; in many cases, the aerial part of the olive trees died, but since the roots were not affected, they sprouted again later. Official aid from the Generalitat of Catalonia was provided for the agricultural damages of December 2001.

Article_Name: Fredorada de gener de 1947 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The cold spell of January 1947 began around January 23 with a rapid influx of cold air from the north and east into the Iberian Peninsula. In general, it was notable for heavy snowfalls rather than particularly intense cold or the duration of this cold episode. The temperature recovery was rapid starting from the first half of February. There were snowfalls in places like Girona and Tarragona. In Barcelona, it only snowed in the higher parts of Collserola, with the minimum temperature at the Fabra Observatory on January 26 being -2.4°C. On January 27, the city of Manresa recorded -15°C. In Madrid, there was a snowfall of 20 cm, and even in Seville, it snowed, though weakly. In Palma, snow fell but did not settle on the ground. In Vitoria-Gasteiz, the temperature dropped to -13.2°C. In Reinosa (Cantabria), it reached -16°C. Molina de Aragón recorded -26.7°C on January 31, 1947. In France, this cold wave was not among the most significant of the past hundred years.

Two steam trains were buried in the snow at Font Picant, with only the chimney sticking out. It took two days to rescue the passengers, who in the meantime were able to feed themselves with the provisions carried by two fellow smuggler travelers. In the town of Els Remeis, the snow reached over three meters in height.

Article_Name: 2016년 북반구 폭설 및 한파 - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.header: 2016 Northern Hemisphere heavy snowfall and cold wave
Whole_Text.content: The 2016 Northern Hemisphere snowstorm and cold wave is a snowstorm and cold wave event that occurred across the Northern Hemisphere since January 2016.

The Arctic jet stream acts as a barrier preventing cold air from the Arctic from moving southward. This jet stream undergoes Arctic oscillations, changing in strength, and in January 2016, as the jet stream weakened and moved southward, it brought a cold wave to the Northern Hemisphere.

On January 4, heavy snowfall occurred in the Danube lowland region of Serbia, and a cold wave brought temperatures down to as low as -12°C. On the same day, Poland also experienced a cold wave, with average temperatures dropping from around -4°C to below -18°C, resulting in the deaths of over 40 people. Additionally, 29 people died from suffocation while using heating devices. On January 11, a snowstorm hit western Russia, including Moscow, with over 25 cm of heavy snow, leading to the closure of major highways. On January 17, a blizzard accompanied by strong winds struck southern Romania, closing 16 main roads, the A2 highway, and three ports, including Constanța. Approximately 50 cm of snow accumulated in the Bucharest area, and flights at Henri Coandă International Airport were delayed. The strong snowstorm also caused power outages, leaving 17,000 people in six counties without electricity and heating. As a result, the number of frostbite-related deaths from November to January sharply increased to 79. On the same day, a severe snowstorm with snowfall exceeding 38 cm hit northern and central Bulgaria, cutting off electricity to 1,000 villages and affecting over 10,000 people. The highway connecting Sofia to Montana was also closed. Additionally, heavy snowfall occurred in the Czech Republic, Poland, Croatia, and Serbia. On the same day, heavy snowfall in northwestern Turkey led to the cancellation of 250 flights to and from Istanbul, and schools were closed. In southern Turkey, warnings of heavy rain and flooding were issued. On January 18, heavy snowfall returned to Germany, Poland, and the Czech Republic. Switzerland experienced record-breaking snowfall exceeding 50 cm, while Sofia, Bulgaria, saw over 40 cm of snow, with three days' worth of snow falling in just a few hours. On January 19, heavy snowfall hit Russia and Ukraine. The average temperature across Ukraine dropped to -23°C, with a low of -30°C, resulting in 37 deaths. The highway connecting Kyiv and Lviv was closed. In the Odessa region, two people died due to the sudden cold wave, and all passenger flights to and from the area were canceled.

Article_Name: 2018年1—2月東亞寒潮 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.header: East Asia Cold Wave in January–February 2018
Whole_Text.content: The East Asia cold wave of January-February 2018, also referred to by the mass media as a slow-moving cold wave, refers to the mid-January 2018 dual blocking collaboration (Atlantic-Western Europe blocking and Pacific-North America blocking) extending towards the poles, causing the Arctic Oscillation (AO) phase to turn negative, splitting the polar vortex southward, and accumulating a large amount of cold air in Siberia, resulting in a stronger-than-usual Siberian high. The cold air erupted from late January to early February, during which a blocking high pressure near Alaska prevented the Siberian high pressure from moving eastward smoothly, leading to a prolonged and abnormally cold cold wave in East Asia. Eastern China, southern China, and Taiwan experienced widespread cold, parts of South Korea and Japan saw heavy snowfall, and some areas in eastern China experienced the largest snowfall in 10 years. Even the northern mountains of Xiamen, Fujian, saw snowfall, and many regions recorded the longest-lasting low temperatures in decades.

Under normal circumstances, high and low pressure systems in the Northern Hemisphere move counterclockwise around the Arctic. However, in mid-January 2018, a dual blocking pattern (Atlantic-Western Europe blocking and Pacific-North America blocking) emerged in the mid-to-high latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere, invading the polar region. This transported warm, moist air from the mid-latitudes of the two oceans to the polar region. Under the dominant effect of non-adiabatic heating, the polar region rapidly warmed, the Arctic Oscillation (AO) phase turned negative, the polar vortex weakened and split, and cold air accumulated continuously in Siberia, resulting in an abnormally strong Siberian high-pressure system accompanied by a strong East Asian horizontal trough. Later in the month, the East Asian horizontal trough turned vertical, guiding cold air southward to invade China, triggering a cold wave. 

At the same time, due to the La Niña (anti-El Niño) phenomenon, a high-pressure system formed near Alaska, moving slowly and creating a blocking high-pressure system. This forced the Siberian high-pressure system to shift southward and slow down, causing a large-scale temperature drop in East Asia. The cooling persisted until early February, forming a gradual cold wave. The timing of low temperatures varied across regions. In Hong Kong, temperatures below 10°C were recorded starting January 29, with the lowest temperature of this cold wave recorded on February 1. In Taipei, temperatures below 10°C were not recorded until February 3, with the lowest temperature of this cold wave recorded on February 5. Both Taipei and Hong Kong experienced consecutive days of temperatures below 10°C, which ended on February 7.

Affected by the cold wave, electricity consumption in the northwest and northeast regions reached a record high, hundreds of highways were closed, impacting the Spring Festival travel rush. On January 30, the Central Meteorological Observatory stated: "From January 30 to February 5, due to the frequent southward movement of cold air, temperatures in the central and eastern regions will remain consistently low. In some areas of Huanghuai, Jianghan, Jianghuai, Jiangnan, and South China, temperatures will be 5-6°C lower than usual." Affected by blocking high pressure, abnormally low temperatures appeared in South China and East China, and seawater along the coasts of North China and Northeast China froze. On the evening of January 27, Shaoguan City in Guangdong Province began experiencing icy rain and snow. On the 28th, sea ice in Liaodong Bay reached a thickness of 35 cm, and the ice coverage area in Laizhou Bay exceeded 2,000 square kilometers. On the 29th, a low temperature of -9.1°C was recorded in Xiangyang City, Hubei Province. On the 30th, a low temperature of -5.1°C was recorded in Meihua, Lechang City, Guangdong Province. On February 1, ice walls and ice corals appeared on Jinzi Mountain in Guangdong Province. From 8 a.m. on February 2 to 7 a.m. on February 3, 62 administrative regions in Guizhou Province experienced temperatures below zero, and 49 administrative regions had snowfall. On February 4, a low temperature of -1.5°C was recorded in Junying Village, Xiamen, Fujian Province. Snow also fell in the high mountains of Xiamen and in Fuzhou in the afternoon, with Fuzhou experiencing snow for the first time in 16 years. In Quanzhou's Qingyuan Mountain, snow fell for the first time in 351 years. Several highways in Yunnan Province were closed due to icing. A low temperature of -5.2°C was recorded in Chongming District, Shanghai. A low temperature of -9°C was recorded in Yantai, Shandong Province. On February 5, a low temperature of -7.8°C was recorded in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, which was even lower than the cold wave ten years ago. As of February 6, the cold wave had affected 440,000 people in Yunnan Province, causing a loss of 20 million yuan. In Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province, temperatures below -1°C were recorded for nine consecutive days, the first time since 2000.

Affected by the cold wave, the Hong Kong Observatory issued a cold weather warning on January 28, with a low temperature of -1.8 degrees Celsius recorded at Tai Mo Shan on the 31st. On February 1, the Observatory recorded the lowest temperature of this winter at 6.8 degrees Celsius, with Ta Kwu Ling reaching a low of only 3.2 degrees Celsius. On February 5, the Observatory issued frost warnings for three consecutive days, and the previous day recorded a low temperature of 0.5 degrees Celsius on Lantau Island. On the 6th, under the influence of radiative cooling, Tai Mo Shan recorded a low temperature of 0.3 degrees Celsius, and Ta Kwu Ling recorded 0.9 degrees Celsius. The urban area experienced temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius for nine consecutive days, the first time since 1968, marking a half-century interval. On February 8, the Observatory canceled the cold weather warning, which had lasted for 263 hours and 15 minutes, making it the second-longest cold weather warning on record.

The Central Weather Bureau stated on February 2: "Due to the arrival of a strong cold air mass, this cold wave will freeze the entire Taiwan for five days starting today. It is estimated that with sufficient moisture, humidity, and temperature, there is a possibility of snowfall in mountains above 1,000 meters in altitude." Affected by the cold wave, 49 people died suddenly from the cold within less than a day from February 2 to 3. On February 4, a low temperature of 7.8 degrees Celsius was recorded in Xinwu District, Taoyuan, and 7.9 degrees Celsius in Hsinchu. Snow also fell on Datun Mountain, which is just over 1,000 meters above sea level. Snowfall began on Taiping Mountain on February 3, and accommodations were not provided on February 4 and 5. Matsu experienced its first snowfall in 16 years. The next day, Hsinchu recorded a low temperature of 6.3 degrees Celsius, and Xinwu recorded 6.4 degrees Celsius. From February 2 to the morning of February 5, 120 people had died suddenly, and combined with the 134 sudden deaths from January 29 to the morning of February 1, a total of 254 sudden deaths had occurred across Taiwan as of the morning of February 5. Agricultural losses were estimated at 3.23 million. Although the impact gradually diminished on February 6, radiation cooling caused the lowest temperatures in central and southern Taiwan to be lower than the previous day. Chiayi recorded a low temperature of 6.9 degrees Celsius. Morning temperatures in flat areas returned to above 10 degrees Celsius, but Hsinchu experienced 69 consecutive hours of temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius, and Banqiao in New Taipei experienced 64 consecutive hours of temperatures below 10 degrees Celsius. Additionally, the low temperatures affected the rescue efforts for the Hualien earthquake on February 7. Temperatures gradually rose afterward, but starting on February 10, another wave of dry and cold air caused temperatures to drop again before returning to normal levels. On the morning of February 12, Tamsui in New Taipei recorded a low temperature of 9.1 degrees Celsius. On February 13, the only low temperature below 10 degrees Celsius in flat areas was recorded in Tamsui, which was far from the Central Weather Bureau's earlier estimate of 6 degrees Celsius and the Japan Meteorological Association's estimate of 4 degrees Celsius.

Due to the convergence of warm, moist air from the ocean and cold, dry air from the continent over South Korea, Seoul recorded 16.5 centimeters of snowfall, the highest since 2001. At Jeju International Airport, heavy snow caused hundreds of flight cancellations or delays, leaving many travelers stranded. This cold wave also affected the preparations for the Winter Olympic Games, with temperatures dropping to minus 20 degrees Celsius, leading to over 2,000 volunteers withdrawing from the preparation work.

Due to the impact of a strong low-pressure system and cold air, snowfall occurred in northern Japan and the Pacific coastal areas. On February 3, two men in Yurihonjo City, Akita Prefecture, were buried by snow and lost their lives. On February 4, Kitahiroshima Town in Hiroshima Prefecture recorded 147 cm of snow accumulation. Even Tokushima Prefecture, which rarely experiences snow, saw snowfall. Nationwide transportation was greatly affected. In Hakusan City, Ishikawa Prefecture, on the Sea of Japan side, there was 93 cm of snow accumulation, more than double the usual amount. On February 6, Fukui Prefecture recorded 130 cm of snow, the most in 37 years, and 1,500 vehicles were stranded on the section of National Route 8 between Awara City and Sakai City.

Article_Name: Vague de froid intense au Canada et au Nord des États-Unis — Wikinews

Whole_Text.header: Intense cold wave in Canada and the northern United States
Whole_Text.content:
Published on December 19, 2016  
Records for low temperatures were broken in Canada and the northern United States as the weather remained turbulent. In Quebec, wind chill reached -40 degrees Celsius on Friday, then turned into a snowstorm on Saturday and freezing rain on Sunday. Finally, the temperature dropped back to around -20°C on Monday, while the December average is -6.3°C. "The weather is yo-yoing, and it's simply a transition as winter tries to take hold," said meteorologist Dave Phillips on CBC. An extreme cold alert was also issued in Toronto. "Hypothermia occurs when body temperature falls below 35°C and has serious consequences such as organ failure and death. Frostbite can also occur in cold weather when the skin freezes, and in the most severe cases, amputation is necessary when deeper tissues are affected," said the city in a statement. In the provinces of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba, temperatures range between -21 and -27°C according to Environment Canada.
