Article_Name: Ola de calor en Argentina de 2023, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heat wave in Argentina in 2023 was an extraordinarily late extreme heat phenomenon that occurred from February 28 to March 20 of that year, mainly in the central region of the country, as well as in the northern and coastal areas. It was the longest heat wave experienced in Argentina since the heat wave in 2013, primarily affecting the provinces of Buenos Aires, Santa Fe, Córdoba, and all the northern provinces where multiple cities recorded record temperatures. It was characterized as an unusual heat phenomenon, not only because of its duration but also due to the magnitude of temperatures during the month it occurred, as in March in Argentina, temperatures typically decrease with the onset of autumn. The heat wave is associated with the Atlantic anticyclone, an extremely intense new La Niña phenomenon in the Pacific, and the regional effects of climate change. A heat wave is characterized by a marked and sustained increase in temperatures, especially maximum temperatures, occurring in several cities above what is considered extreme.

According to the National Meteorological Service, the heat wave is due to the presence of high pressures that create an atmospheric blockage interacting with a constant influx of warm air coming from the north through a high-pressure system in the South Atlantic Ocean, which results in persistent and unusually late high temperatures for this time of year.

The National Meteorological Service reports, through its daily updates, information on the development of the heatwave. It covers the center and north of the country, encompassing 18 provinces, with two more added if the north of Patagonia is considered.

During the heatwave, new records of national electricity demand were set, exceeding 28,500 MW. On March 1, a massive blackout occurred, affecting more than 6 million users in the north and center of the country, impacting half of the nation. According to the Secretariat of Energy, a grassland fire affected a power line, prompting the Atucha I plant to suspend its activities preventively. Intense increases and decreases in the number of households without power were also recorded on the following days.

Amid the heatwave, the combination of high temperatures and a historic drought triggered forest fires in areas such as the Costanera Sur Ecological Reserve and the Iberá Wetlands, which affected agriculture in Argentina's weakened economy and caused a considerable increase in the price of various agricultural products such as eggs or vegetables. Soybean and corn crops, the country's main harvests, are suffering the impact of extreme heat. The period of extremely high temperatures and the absence of rain allowed the proliferation of Thysanoptera, tiny insects that invaded the province.

In 2023, a heatwave is occurring in Bengal, with an intense heatwave flowing in Bengal and mild heatwaves affecting parts of Bihar, Odisha, and Tripura-Meghalaya. The heatwave began in early April, marking the highest in nearly half a century in the region's history, with the highest temperature of 42.2 degrees recorded in Chuadanga district of Bangladesh on April 15. Due to the heatwave, health warnings were issued, school and office hours were disrupted, power outages occurred, and there was an unusual disruption in normal daily life.

A May study by World Weather Attribution found that climate change made heatwaves at least 30 times more likely in India and Bangladesh, and climate change increased April temperatures by about 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit).

Bangladesh experiences mild heatwaves in some areas and severe heatwaves in others. With the rise in temperature, the humidity in the air also decreased. On April 16, the capital of Bangladesh, Dhaka, witnessed another severe heatwave after 58 years, recording a temperature of 40.4 degrees Celsius. On the same day, Bangladesh's Environment Minister Md. Shahab Uddin informed the media that a 'temperature-related emergency' might be declared to address the severe heatwave crisis.

In early April, a mild heatwave was observed in West Bengal. On April 13, a temperature of 39.6 degrees was recorded in Kolkata. The India Meteorological Department issued a heatwave warning for West Bengal, and the state government declared the closure of all educational institutions in the state due to the heatwave.

Throughout the month of May, temperatures fluctuated, with storms and rain in some areas and mild to severe heatwaves in others. On May 9, the weather forecast indicated severe heatwaves in five districts of the country and mild heatwaves in several others. On May 8 and 9, a temperature of 41 degrees Celsius was recorded in Chuadanga, while 40.5 degrees Celsius was recorded in Kumarkhali and Netrokona, and 40.3 degrees Celsius in Rajshahi, according to the Meteorological Department. On May 21, a press release from the Bangladesh Meteorological Department stated that mild heatwaves were sweeping over the districts of Rajshahi, Pabna, Jessore, and Chuadanga and might continue. Towards the end of the month, temperatures began to rise, and on May 31, the Meteorological Department forecasted that mild to moderate heatwaves were sweeping across the country and would persist.
A heatwave warning was issued in West Bengal on May 27. The Indian Meteorological Department fears that by the end of May and in June, the temperature may exceed 40 degrees Celsius.

At the beginning of June, the temperature rises, and on June 2, an intense heatwave swept over the districts of Rangpur, Dinajpur, Rajshahi, and Syedpur in Bangladesh, while a mild heatwave began to affect parts of Sylhet, Patuakhali, Bhola, Barisal, Chandpur, Noakhali, and Feni districts, as well as parts of Dhaka, Mymensingh, Khulna, Rangpur, and Rajshahi divisions. During this time, the highest recorded temperature in the country was 41 degrees Celsius.
The Indian Meteorological Department's press release states that mild to severe heatwaves are ongoing in several districts of West Bengal, including Kolkata, and may continue until June 7.

Article_Name: Tonn teasa in Éirinn agus sa Bhreatain, 2023 - Vicipéid

Whole_Text.content: The highest temperature ever recorded in Ireland during the month of June was 28.8C on June 13, 2023, at Oak Park Station in County Carlow.

The average temperature in June 2023 was 16 degrees Celsius. The average temperature had never been so high during the month of June in Ireland since 1940. According to Met Éireann, June 2023 was the hottest June ever in Ireland up to that point. The Weather Office stated at the time that higher temperatures and more thunderstorms are expected due to climate change. During June 2023, the sea off the west coast of Ireland was 5 degrees Celsius warmer than usual, a major concern for scientists. In August 2023, the Killybegs Fishermen's Organisation expressed concern about the impact of climate change on white fish stocks such as cod, and the risk that with a significant change in sea temperature off the coast of Donegal, fish such as cod, haddock, and herring would move to cooler waters further north. It was warm in Ireland during September. The people of the Corca Dhuibhne Gaeltacht were surprised when drops of soot from the Sahara fell on them.
The highest temperature ever recorded in England was during June 2023, exceeding 30C.[11]
The World Meteorological Organization issued a warning in 2023 that the continent of Europe is warming twice as fast as other continents.

Whole_Text.content: The year 1540 is also known as the great sun year. Central and western Europe experienced a Mediterranean climate in 1540. In Basel, it rained only 10 days in 10 months. The summer of 1540 effectively began in February. The sunny, mostly warm weather lasted for nine months. The rivers nearly dried up, causing water mills to stop working, so grain could not be ground and bread could not be baked. Occasionally, "bad weather" brought some relief, but also fatal fires. Rivers dried up, and in Cologne, the Rhine also ran dry. In Paris, people walked across the bed of the Seine without getting their feet wet. Forest and heath fires were a daily occurrence, but village centers and even some cities also caught fire. It was exceptionally dry and hot: between March and August, there was hardly any rain, and especially from April to July, it was extremely warm. In July, not a single drop fell in several places. In many areas, people began planting grapes for wine. But this was not successful, as three bad summers followed this warm one. Even after the summer, the sunny, warm, and dry weather continued. Even in October 1540, the sun and warmth returned, and apart from a few brief rain showers, it remained dry and sunny until the end of the year.

The 2007 heatwave in the United States is an extreme climatic event that affected several regions of the United States between June and August of 2007. Characterized by two distinct heatwaves, it first impacted the western coast of the country before spreading to the Midwest plains later. Temperatures ranging from 40°C (Memphis) to 47°C (Las Vegas) were recorded, causing the deaths of several dozen people across the country.

The 2007 heatwave affected the United States starting at the end of June. An initial heatwave hit the western regions of the country from June 25, with temperatures nearing or exceeding 40°C locally in Montana, Washington State, Arizona, Nevada, and California. In the following days, the phenomenon intensified, and record values were recorded in southern Nevada and western Arizona. On July 5, 43°C was recorded in Reno, breaking the previous record from 1970, while 47°C was recorded in Las Vegas. A heat peak was recorded in Baker, California, where the mercury rose to 51°C. In Las Vegas, as in several other cities in the region, the intensive use of air conditioners caused a series of power surges on the electrical grid, leaving entire neighborhoods without power. In Reno, the Salvation Army opened an emergency shelter for people without air conditioners. A one-year-old child found dead in a car in Orofino, Idaho, was one of the first victims of the heatwave to be reported. The drought and extreme temperatures caused several fires to break out. In Utah, 1150 km² of vegetation were destroyed by flames, forcing authorities to evacuate some homes and close access to highways I-15 and I-70. Three people died as a result of the disaster. After a period of relative respite, a new heatwave hit the country starting July 9, this time reaching the Midwest plains, the South, and part of the East Coast. States like Tennessee and Missouri were particularly affected by the phenomenon, with temperatures nearing 40°C recorded in several localities. On July 11, 37.7°C was recorded in some localities in New Jersey. To limit accidents, the New York City municipality decided to open nearly 300 air-conditioned emergency centers. On August 16, Tennessee authorities announced a toll of nine deaths, while the Missouri Department of Health reported seven victims. In Illinois, eight people died as a result of this heatwave.

This article is a stub about meteorology or climatology. edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The heatwave of July 1983 is a heatwave during which high temperatures affected Italy and the Southeast of France in the last weeks of July 1983. In France, it took place from July 9 to 31 and particularly impacted Marseille, which recorded an excess mortality of 300 deaths in its region alone[1],[2]. It is considered in Italy as one of the most significant heatwaves the country has experienced since World War II[3].

From July 10 to July 23, an anticyclonic blockage persists most of the time, which allows stable, hot, and very dry weather to be maintained over southern and western Europe. This anticyclone helps to transport very hot air over a large part of Europe despite some episodic weaknesses, but this anticyclonic blockage is not the only cause of this heatwave; it is also due to the fact that a depression has settled over the Bay of Biscay.
The El Niño phenomenon of 1982-1983 lasted 16 months. It is one of the six largest El Niño events since 1856[4].

Several temperature records were reached in Italy. The meteorological station of the Ximenes Observatory recorded a temperature of 41.6°C for the Italian city of Florence on July 26, 1983, a record considered historic for the city, surpassing the temperature of 40.2°C recorded on August 1, 1958. Peaks above 40 degrees were observed in several Italian localities, including the cities of Cagliari (43.7°C), Reggio Calabria (44.2°C), Ancona (40.5°C), and Arezzo (40.3°C). On July 31, temperatures of 42.5°C were observed in Saint-Raphaël, 42°C in Paray-le-Monial (Saône-et-Loire), 41°C in Vichy, Clermont-Ferrand, and Saint-Étienne, 39°C in Besançon, Mâcon, Mulhouse, and Saint-Dizier, 38°C in Bourg-Saint-Maurice (850 m altitude), and 37°C in Chamonix (1000 m altitude).

The year 1983, with 92,000 deaths during the July-August period, is one of the years, along with 2003 and its 99,000 deaths, with the highest mortality rate during the July-August period. The excess mortality during June and July 1983, across France as a whole, amounted to a total of 4,700 deaths. The city of Marseille, which experienced maximum temperatures between 35 and 40 degrees, recorded an excess mortality of around 300 deaths during the heatwave, directly or indirectly attributable to it.
Several prevention procedures were implemented following this heatwave[7].

Article_Name: Vague de chaleur de l'été 1947 en Europe — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.header: Heatwave of the summer of 1947 in Europe
Whole_Text.content: The heatwave of the summer of 1947 in Europe is an exceptionally significant climatic event that occurred from June to August 1947. These episodes of intense heat are the most widespread since the beginning of records. Numerous temperature records were recorded.

The summer of 1947 is part of a series of scorching summers that affected Western Europe in the years following World War II (1945, 1947, 1949, 1950, and 1952). During the year 1947, temperatures were consistently above average from April to early October. Europe experienced three notable heatwaves (21 days): from June 26 to 28 (low intensity), from July 22 to August 4 (exceptional intensity), and from August 14 to 20 (moderate intensity)[1]. The spring had been abnormally warm, with unusual temperatures starting in April, as 30°C was reached in many regions of France during the second half of the month, and even exceeded in the south. On May 27, Saharan air invaded France with temperatures exceeding 30°C in the northern half and approaching 35°C in the southern part. After a respite in mid-June, a first heatwave hit Europe during the last decade of June. In France, between June 26 and 28, 35°C was exceeded in much of the country. After a break in mid-July, a new heatwave—comparable to the August 2003 heatwave—occurred from July 22 to August 4. According to Météo-France, it was "the most intense heatwave episode since the post-war period, after the August 2003 heatwave," ... and even since 1873, the date from which Météo-France's chronological data begins. In some places, such as the Paris region, absolute records were observed: on July 28, 1947, 40.4°C was reached. This record would only be broken 72 years later, on July 25, 2019, with 42.6°C [2]. 

In southern France, the peak of the heatwave was reached on August 2 and 3, with 40°C in Lyon and even higher further south. On August 3 and 4, storms brought an end to this heatwave. But a new, more moderate wave occurred between August 14 and 20: 35 degrees were again exceeded throughout France, except along the coasts. A final wave took place during the second decade of September, with maximum temperatures still exceeding 30°C in most weather stations. In 1947, the heat was certainly less concentrated than in 2003, and the humanitarian consequences were less critical for a population less exposed. However, the episodes of intense heat in 1947 were never as widespread since the beginning of records. The Alpine glacier systems then recorded historic losses, which they would not be able to recover from thereafter.

The British autumn heatwave of 2011 was an unusually warm period experienced in the United Kingdom in the autumn of 2011, which arrived at the end of September and continued into October. As a result, many local autumn temperature records were broken across the country. The temperatures were on the same level as in the spring heatwave of 2011.[1]

The unusually warm weather caused a 149 percent increase in visitor numbers at Chester Zoo in Britain on September 28.[2] Along with the heatwave, hiking, the filling of caravan sites, and accommodation bookings also increased in much of the country.[3][4] Businesses in Winchester were also found to be popular during this time.[5] A negative impact for many British companies was a decline in sales, and some clothing retailers suffered the worst losses in two years as sales of autumn and winter clothing dropped.[6]

Article_Name: Calorada de juliol de 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The heatwave of July 1994 was the most significant heatwave of the 1990s and the most important since the heatwave of July 1982. Central Catalonia, mainly Bages and Berguedà, was the area that suffered the most from the catastrophic forest fires, burning nearly 45,000 hectares, and where the highest temperature values in Catalonia were recorded. The heatwave began in the last days of June, reaching its peak between July 3 and 5. It affected all of Catalonia but was especially intense in the Terres de Ponent, Central Catalonia, the pre-coastal area, and the pre-Pyrenean valleys of Pallars Jussà and Alt Urgell. In these areas, thermometers soared above 40°C, a value rarely reached in Catalonia and not every summer. On July 4, 1994, 43.0°C was recorded in Montblanc and Esparreguera, and 42.5°C in Manresa and Piera. Even in elevated areas of the Pyrenees, temperatures reached very high values, such as 25°C on July 1 at the 2,041 m altitude of the Boí-Taüll ski resort. A new, less intense heatwave affected all of Catalonia again in mid-month, with maximum temperatures once again reaching 40°C in the hottest parts of the country, but this time especially affecting the northeastern regions and the Central Coast, where sea breezes had tempered the temperature during the first heatwave of the month. In these areas, the absolute maximum temperature of that month was then reached. During those days in July 1994, a bubble of very hot air of Saharan origin affected much of the Iberian Peninsula and the southwestern area of Europe, with temperatures at 850 hPa reaching 30°C over Andalusia, 25°C in the Ebro Valley, 22°C in the Pyrenees, and 20°C in the Alps between July 3 and 4, 1994. The entry of this very hot air mass was facilitated by a southern wind flow at all levels caused by a significant ridge at 500 hPa centered over the Alboran Sea and extending to Scandinavia. The following maps show the 20CRP (NCAR-NCEP, USA) reanalyses for 07/03/1994 at 18 UTC of the geopotential height and temperature fields at 500 hPa (top image) and 850 hPa (middle image), as well as the sea-level pressure and 2 m temperature fields (bottom image). The two heatwaves of July 1994 resulted in a significant thermal anomaly at 850 hPa over the Iberian Peninsula and much of Europe, as well as a significant positive anomaly in geopotential height at 850 hPa over Scandinavia. Monthly temperature values at 850 hPa exceeded 3.5°C above the climatic average for the 1948-2013 period over the Valencian Community and the Terres de l'Ebre, and exceeded 4°C in northern Germany. The average geopotential height field at 500 hPa also shows a clear dominance of southern wind circulation in Western Europe, thus favoring the entry of warm air from the Sahara into the Iberian Peninsula and Western Europe for much of the month. This configuration is very different from the predominant one during July across Western Europe, with a circulation of predominantly westerly winds. The winter and spring of 1994 had been very dry in much of the country. Accumulated precipitation was clearly below the climatic average, especially in spring (in Berguedà and Bages, it had rained half of what is usual). Therefore, at the beginning of the summer of 1994, the forests of Catalonia were in a state of significant water stress. The extremely high temperatures recorded in the interior of the country as a result of the great heatwave, combined with low humidity due to the moderately intense dry southern wind that blew during those days, facilitated the occurrence of the devastating forest fires in Catalonia in 1994.

Article_Name: Värmeböljan i Australien i november 2009 – Wikipedia

Whole_Text.header: The heatwave in Australia in November 2009
Whole_Text.content: The heatwave in Australia in November 2009 was a period of seasonally extreme high temperatures that affected southeastern Australia in November 2009. It was the second massive heatwave to hit the region during 2009 (see Heatwave in Australia 2009), with the worst-affected states being South Australia, Victoria, and New South Wales. The heatwave at the turn of January-February 2009 was indeed even more intense, but according to the Australian weather service, it was unprecedented in terms of intensity so early in the summer season. In many places, record-high temperatures for November were measured, locally over 45 degrees C. However, it was primarily the duration that made the heatwave unique. Temperatures of around 40 degrees C or more have indeed been recorded many times in November in the affected areas, but the heat has usually lasted only a few days. In this case, many locations experienced such high temperatures for over a week, with daytime temperatures 10-15 degrees above normal. Just like during the heatwave 10 months earlier, the cause of the warm weather was a powerful, stationary high-pressure system over the Tasman Sea, which led to very warm air from central Australia flowing down over the southeastern part of the country. The winter of 2009 had been extremely warm in Australia, and very high temperatures were already recorded in the region at the end of October. However, the heatwave is considered to have started on November 6 and ended only on November 19-20.

As so many times before in connection with extreme weather of various kinds, politicians, environmental activists, and many others have linked the heatwave to the ongoing warming of the Earth (see Global Warming), which is generally considered to be caused by human activities. A spokesperson for the environmental group Climate Emergency Action Network claimed that the current heatwave is a clear example of "climate change weather," i.e., extreme weather events that can be expected as the climate becomes increasingly warmer. However, the weather service emphasized, as usual, that an unusually intense individual heatwave does not prove anything. On the other hand, they argue that it is indisputable that Australia has warmed faster than the global average and that heatwaves have become both more frequent and longer. Additionally, large parts of the continent have been affected by very severe drought during the 21st century.

The March 2012 heatwave in Britain was an exceptionally warm period during which temperatures rose in many places above 20 degrees. The average temperature at this time of year would be 10 degrees. In Aboyne, Scotland, 22.8 degrees was recorded on March 26, which is Scotland's March temperature record.

This heatwave was caused by a high-pressure system anchored over Great Britain, named Harry by FU Berlin.[2][3] This high-pressure area was held in place by the jet stream and associated systems that moved to the northern parts of the country.[4]

As temperatures rose across Great Britain, beaches became crowded, and businesses in seaside resorts reported increased sales. Nevertheless, wildfires broke out in various parts of Great Britain, including a forest fire south of Dumfries that started from a controlled burn.

The heatwave of 2007 refers to the intense heat that struck a wide area of Japan during the summer of 2007. In July, the heat affected the Nansei Islands, in August it centered on the inland areas of Honshu and extended from Hokkaido to Kyushu, and in September it impacted the entire country, particularly the Seto Inland Sea coastal areas and northern Kyushu. Although it was a record-breaking heatwave at the time, three years later in 2010, temperatures significantly surpassed those of this year, setting the highest temperatures in recorded history. As a result, the 2007 heatwave became less prominent and faded from memory. Furthermore, 2011 recorded the fourth-highest summer average temperature, with August of the following year ranking third and September ranking first in high temperatures.

The rainy season in 2007 tended to be delayed across Japan. The start of the rainy season was delayed nationwide, except for southern Kyushu, averaging 8.6 days later than usual, and the end of the rainy season was delayed by 5.4 days compared to the average, except for southern Kyushu and the Nansei Islands. Before the rainy season began, it was predicted that the rainy season would be short and the summer would be hot due to the effects of the La Niña phenomenon. However, in reality, the rainy season was delayed due to factors such as the weak influence of the Pacific high-pressure system. 

As a result of the delayed rainy season, July experienced low temperatures and heavy rainfall, except for southern Kyushu and the Nansei Islands, with average temperatures in Honshu and Hokkaido being 0.8-1.7°C lower than usual. However, after the rainy season ended and August began, the Pacific high-pressure system strengthened, leading to stable sunny weather and a shift from a trend of low temperatures to high temperatures. By mid-August, the number of locations observing extreme heat days with maximum temperatures of 35°C or higher rapidly increased from the Kanto region to Kyushu. On August 15, a temperature of 40.2°C was recorded in Tatebayashi City, Gunma Prefecture, marking the first time that year a temperature of 40°C or higher was observed. The following day, August 16, temperatures of 40.9°C were recorded in Kumagaya City, Saitama Prefecture, and Tajimi City, Gifu Prefecture, breaking the previous record of 40.8°C observed in Yamagata City, Yamagata Prefecture, on July 25, 1933, for the first time in 74 years. After this, temperatures began to drop gradually from the north, but high temperatures persisted until late August. The average monthly temperature for August was 0.6-1.3°C higher than usual across a wide area from Hokkaido to Kyushu, and about 0.3°C higher in the Nansei Islands. The average temperature for the entire summer (June to August) was 0-0.8°C higher than usual nationwide.

From late August to early September, temperatures temporarily dropped due to autumn rains and Typhoon No. 9, but high temperatures continued in areas south of the autumn rain front. From mid-September onward, the autumn rain front weakened, and the Pacific high-pressure system and migratory high-pressure systems broadly covered areas near Japan, while the westerly jet stream meandered significantly northward near Japan. As a result, low rainfall and high temperatures persisted, and some regions experienced record-breaking heat for September. By late September, the heat subsided in areas north of the Hokuriku and Kanto regions due to the southward movement of the autumn rain front, but high temperatures continued in regions further south. The average monthly temperature for September was 0.4-0.8°C higher than usual in the Nansei Islands, 0.9°C higher in Hokkaido, 1.6-2.1°C higher in the Tohoku, Kanto, Chubu, and Kinki regions, and 2.2-2.5°C higher in the Chugoku, Shikoku, and Kyushu regions.

Around mid-August, many people across Japan were hospitalized due to heatstroke. Dozens of deaths were reported, most of whom were elderly individuals staying at home, highlighting the issue of ensuring the health and safety of the elderly during extreme heat.
In this year, many locations that recorded the highest average monthly temperatures have since been surpassed again after 2010 and are no longer ranked first, as shown below.

The factors behind the intense heat in mid-August include the position and strength of the Pacific High, as well as the continuation of stable weather. It is believed that the Pacific High was shifted northeast compared to usual years, and in central Japan, which was near the center of the high-pressure system, a "tall high-pressure system" covered the area from the surface to the upper atmosphere. This was likely due to the La Niña phenomenon and sea surface temperature fluctuations in the Indian Ocean, which activated convective activity near the Philippines. Warm air rose actively near the Philippines, flowed into the vicinity of the Pacific High, descended, and strengthened the Pacific High while warming its interior. Additionally, the Tibetan High was shifted northward. The meandering of the subtropical jet stream (westerlies) caused it to flow northward near Japan, allowing the Pacific High and Tibetan High to extend significantly northward near Japan. The Tibetan High overlapped the Pacific High, broadly and deeply covering the area near Japan. This state persisted for about a week, preventing the heat accumulated during the day from fully dissipating at night, gradually raising the baseline temperature and creating the foundation for record-breaking heat. 

In regions that experienced particularly high temperatures, geographical factors also played a significant role. Cities like Tajimi and Mino are located in basins, while Kumagaya and Tatebayashi are inland areas of plains surrounded by mountains, making them prone to temperature increases due to the Foehn effect. Additionally, areas located in valleys surrounded by high mountains on two sides likely became heat traps due to converging winds. The heat island effect in the Chukyo and Tokyo metropolitan areas, as well as the blocking of convection (such as sea and land breezes or mountain and valley winds) by skyscrapers acting as "walls," are also considered significant factors. 

The active convective activity near the Philippines continued into September, sustaining the strength of the Pacific High. Combined with the northward meandering of the subtropical jet stream, the straightening of the polar jet stream (which rarely descended southward near Japan), and the northward shift of the Tibetan High, the intense heat in Japan persisted into September. 

Regarding the relationship between this heatwave and global warming, changes in atmospheric circulation (airflow) and ocean circulation influenced by global warming, as well as the baseline increase in average temperatures, have been pointed out.

Article_Name: Ola de calor en Argentina en 2013, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heat wave in Argentina in December 2013 was a phenomenon that occurred from December 11, 2013, to January 2, 2014, in the northern and central regions of the country, as well as in the northern part of Patagonia. It was the second longest heat wave experienced in Argentina since records began in 1906, affecting at least 52 cities across the country. For the first time since the creation of the heat alert system, a red-level alert was in effect for several consecutive days both in the city of Buenos Aires and in the city of Rosario in Santa Fe. The cause of this heat wave was the Madden-Julian Oscillation, which caused the South Atlantic anticyclone to settle over the continent, creating an atmospheric blockage that led to high temperatures and scarce rainfall in the central and northern parts of the country, while halting subpolar and subtropical frontal systems, resulting in unusual summer snowfalls in Tierra del Fuego and torrential rains in Brazil.

Starting from December 11, a marked increase in temperatures began to be recorded, especially the maximums, in a vast area of the central and northern Patagonian region, affecting southern Córdoba, southern Santa Fe, southern Entre Ríos, a large part of the province of Buenos Aires, La Pampa, eastern Mendoza, eastern Neuquén, and Río Negro. From the 19th, this anomalous situation began to expand towards northern Argentina and intensified again over the central part, affecting 18 provinces, subsiding around December 30 in the central part and between January 1 and 2 in the far north of the country with the passage of a cold front that caused a change in the air mass. As a result, most localities located between 30°S and 40°S recorded 1 or 2 heatwaves during the period, with durations ranging from 5 to 18 consecutive days, and average minimum temperatures exceeding 4°C and average maximum temperatures exceeding 6°C compared to the normal for the season. The long persistence of this heatwave (22 days) made the event exceptional, breaking several records regarding the highest number of consecutive days with minimum and maximum temperatures above the average in several meteorological stations in the affected area. The National Meteorological Service reported, through its daily updates, information on the development of the heatwave. Meteorological agencies in Uruguay and Paraguay also declared a state of alert due to the heatwave.

It was the first heat wave whose health hazard level was categorized as extreme (red alert). The National Meteorological Service and the Ministry of Health warned the population of the cities and surrounding areas of Buenos Aires and Rosario about the risks to avoid and the basic precautions to follow in the face of intense heat. This occurs in exceptional cases of heat waves, which can affect all healthy people, not just at-risk groups. Up to that point, several deaths had been recorded with heat stroke episodes as direct causes of death. In Santiago del Estero, eleven deaths associated with heat stroke occurred. In Entre Ríos, seven more cases were reported, largely due to cardiorespiratory arrests and decompensations caused by the intense heat, as well as one fatality from heat stroke in the district of Avellaneda, and in the province of Salta, one fatality was reported due to sunstroke. In various locations, several drownings were also recorded (largely due to thermal shock) as people attempted to cool off in some rivers in the provinces of Córdoba (9 cases), Santa Fe (4 cases), Buenos Aires (5 cases), Entre Ríos (4 cases), Mendoza (3 cases), Corrientes (4 cases), San Luis (1 case), Salta (1 case), Santiago del Estero (1 case), and Jujuy (1 case). In the city of Buenos Aires, two people died from carbon monoxide poisoning after turning on a generator to alleviate the intense heat at night. The following day, a similar case occurred, where a 50-year-old man lost his life for the same reason, and several days later, an elderly person was found dead in their apartment in the Villa del Parque neighborhood due to power outages and the intense heat. In the district of Avellaneda, three people died in a fire while trying to light the place with candles since they had no electricity due to power outages. Meanwhile, for the same reason, four people died in a house fire in Quilmes, and one more person in the city of Buenos Aires. In the city of Pergamino, an elderly person also fell victim to a fire caused by an electrical failure in a ventilation device. Also in the city, SAME recorded a peak in emergency calls; most of the emergencies were related to fainting and low blood pressure, typical symptoms of heat stroke, and because pre-existing health conditions worsened, such as the emergence of a dengue outbreak in a region as southern as the province of Entre Ríos, a large province where such disease (dengue in Argentina is almost always a zoonosis carried by people who have previously been in much more northern areas than Argentina). In Rosario, 70 swimmers cooling off in the Paraná River on Christmas Day were attacked by a school of piranhas, carnivorous fish of the genus Serrasalmus —to which piranhas also belong—. These fish were fleeing to cooler areas due to the high water temperatures caused by the heat wave. The following day, another attack by these fish occurred at a beach on the Paraná River in Posadas (Misiones), injuring 15 people.

On December 20, around 200,000 direct residential customers of Edenor and Edesur were left without electricity service. Between December 21 and 27, the number of users without electricity service fluctuated between 50,000 and 70,000. On December 23, the Ministry of Federal Planning reported that the Argentine Interconnection System broke the power demand record when consumption peaked at 23,793 megawatts. Power outages also occurred in cities in the interior of the country, such as Córdoba, Rosario, and San Miguel de Tucumán. On December 23, the Argentine Interconnection System recorded a power demand record for a weekday, with electricity consumption peaking at 23,793 megawatts at 2:20 PM. Additionally, on December 28, it recorded a power demand record for a Saturday, with electricity consumption reaching 21,264 megawatts at 2:10 PM. As a consequence of the relentless heat, there were heavy rains with strong electrical activity in several localities in the central part of the country, and San Miguel de Tucumán experienced high wind activity. On New Year's Eve, the city of Rosario experienced a heat index of 55°C.

On December 23, Buenos Aires legislator Marcelo Ramal presented a bill for an electricity emergency in the City of Buenos Aires. This initial project proposed the creation of a crisis committee composed of: one representative from each legislative bloc, representatives from the consultative councils of the Communes and affected neighborhoods, elected representatives of workers and technicians from energy distributors, and academics from the Faculty of Engineering at UBA. The committee would have authority over the distribution companies and would organize an energy restoration operation. The project included the formation of 60 emergency crews (4 per commune) to repair damaged lines and substations, as well as the provision of 1,500 generators (100 per commune). The costs related to these operations would be financed through a tax on gambling establishments in the City, which are currently exempt. However, only five legislators (in addition to Ramal, Gustavo Vera, Virginia González Gass, Pablo Bergel, and Alejandro Bodart, the latter two with their own projects) signed the request for the Legislature to hold a special session to address this issue. The project was ignored by the remaining legislators, prompting the five signatories to hold a press conference. Chief of Staff Jorge Capitanich pointed to the electricity providers, Edenor and Edesur, as responsible for the outages and urged users to direct their complaints to the companies. He announced an administrative holiday for December 30 starting at 12 p.m. Working groups were created within the framework of the climate emergency, unifying the tasks of security forces (police, army, civil defense, and firefighters) with the availability of 500 patrol cars, 17,000 agents, and 3,200 cameras. Days later, the head of government of the City of Buenos Aires, Mauricio Macri, declared an energy emergency due to the energy collapse affecting his city. Similarly, Capitanich announced the executive branch's intention to nationalize the management of the electricity service if Edenor and Edesur did not resolve the supply issues. When asked about Nicolás Caputo, a shareholder in Edesur and the main beneficiary of public works in Buenos Aires, responsible for the power outages, he avoided responding or referencing the responsibility of energy distribution companies like Edesur, owned by his close friend with whom he shares business interests. As a result of the prolonged power outages, numerous protests occurred due to public discontent in most neighborhoods of the City of Buenos Aires, disrupting traffic on streets, highways, and bridges. One of the most affected roadways by the protests was the Buenos Aires-La Plata Highway, where a total vehicle collapse was recorded. In the city, there were various demonstrations by residents, including street and avenue blockades. By the first days of January 2014, some neighborhoods in the City of Buenos Aires had been without electricity for more than two weeks, leading residents to block the Sarmiento railway line as a form of protest, as well as in the Province of Buenos Aires. Ramal, the author of the law proposing the energy emergency, criticized Macri's measure, considering that "what Macri did is a caricature of an energy emergency, not a real emergency," as "no extraordinary measures were taken to restore the service nor resources allocated to address an emergency." The national and city governments agreed to coordinate assistance tasks for residents who remained without power. Mauricio Macri himself requested a change in the time zone for the City of Buenos Aires, the Argentine coast, and the provinces of Buenos Aires, Santa Fe, and Córdoba. The National Minister of Planning, Julio De Vido, strongly rejected the proposal, explaining that "having two time zones would cause disruptions and costs greater than the benefits, as it would not be logical, for example, to have one time in Córdoba and another in Santiago del Estero." The Minister of Planning then asked "Argentine companies" with shares in Edesur to "take responsibility as Argentines" for the power outages. "I am referring to the Caputo Group, Escasany Group, Miguens Bemberg Group, Guillermo Reca, and Guillermo Vázquez."

Edenor and Edesur companies have been identified as responsible for the outages. It was publicly reported that the companies under-executed investments for which they had resources amounting to 240 million pesos, through the Infrastructure Fund, "as a form of extortion to achieve a tariff increase." The planning minister warned that, due to "negligence and serious non-compliance" in service during the heatwave, distribution companies would have to pay 490 pesos to residential users who were without power for 12 to 24 hours. Edesur was required to compensate users with a total of 221 million pesos, while Edenor had to compensate them with 77 million. After the outages caused by the heatwave, starting in 2014, Edenor initiated an investment plan that allowed for a 32% reduction in outages.

Whole_Text.content: The 2013 heatwave in the United States is an extreme weather event that affected most of the Southwestern United States, specifically California, Nevada, and Arizona, from late June to early July 2013.

The mercury reached 38°C in Utah and 54°C in the Death Valley desert, which is the highest temperature ever recorded on Earth for the month of June, only three degrees lower than the highest temperature ever recorded in Death Valley, 57°C, recorded in July 1913. The mercury still reached 48°C in Phoenix and 47°C in Las Vegas. During the night, the mercury fluctuated between 20 and 35°C, which posed a real danger to the human body, unable to cool down at any time. However, the relative humidity was exceptionally low, often below 10%, making the extreme heat more "bearable." During this heatwave, forecasters recorded 46°C in Phoenix, 42°C in Tucson, and 43°C in Las Vegas by midday on a Saturday, but it was expected that the mercury would rise further in the afternoon. At noon, the thermometer read 45°C in Death Valley, at Furnace Creek. Death Valley is one of the hottest places on the globe.

This extreme heatwave, combined with a very severe drought that is not unusual at this time of year in the southwestern United States, was caused by an Omega block in the atmospheric circulation at high altitude. Thus, there were two depressions located on either side of an anticyclone. On their western equatorial periphery, the high pressures carried very hot and humid air from Mexico in a south to southwest flow, which dried out and warmed further due to the foehn effect as it passed over the Rocky Mountains. As a result, in the plains, there was a completely clear sky, sunny weather, and extremely high temperatures, most exceeding 40°C and approaching 50°C.

It was particularly hot in the western United States, even though most of the states there are accustomed to scorching summers. Authorities spoke of a deadly heatwave. Numerous cases of hospitalizations were reported, including 34 in Las Vegas at an outdoor concert due to sunburns and heatstrokes, while 170 others suffered from nausea and exhaustion. The extreme heat made roads and sidewalks extremely hot. Authorities feared that migrants attempting to cross the border illegally between Mexico and the United States might die in the desert; consequently, reinforcements were deployed to monitor the border on the U.S. side. Seven people were found dead in the Sonoran Desert in Arizona. An elderly person was discovered dead in their home in Las Vegas, as they did not have air conditioning. In Oregon, about forty sheep succumbed to the heat, while more than 200 other animals had to be rescued. The paws of dogs and cats had to be protected from burns caused by the scorching asphalt. Additionally, and particularly in California, the extreme heat hindered airplane takeoffs, leaving them grounded. Numerous fires were reported, including a massive one in California that caused the death of 19 firefighters who were trying to combat the blaze. This extreme heatwave was one of the most intense ever observed in the world: temperatures close to some of the world's heat records were recorded in certain states.

Article_Name: Calorades de l'estiu de 2003 a Catalunya - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: Heatwaves of the summer of 2003 in Catalonia
Whole_Text.content: The heatwaves of the summer of 2003 made it the hottest summer in Catalonia for at least the previous 100 years, with average air temperature anomalies exceeding 4°C compared to the 1961-1990 climatic average. In Western and Central Europe, the summer of 2003 was considered the hottest since the year 1500. The major heatwaves of the summer of 2003 peaked during the first half of August and were caused by the persistence of synoptic situations with advection of hot Saharan air from North Africa (see the reanalyses at 850 hPa below). Additionally, these situations were exacerbated by prior conditions of extreme soil and vegetation dryness due to a prolonged drought in the spring and early summer. As a result of this dryness, almost all of the Sun's radiation was converted into heat, as it could not be absorbed by the soil and vegetation. The predominant zonal circulation pattern (west-east) over Europe shifted slightly, generating a more meridional (south-north) circulation with a higher geopotential height, leading to elevated temperatures and atmospheric stability conditions during the summer of 2003 across Western and Central Europe. Temperatures at 850 hPa that summer were 3°C higher than the 1948-2012 climatic average.

The heatwave affected much of the European continent, but especially Western and Central Europe. Many extreme maximum temperature records and persistence of high temperatures were surpassed. As a result of the heatwaves, more than 30,000 people died across Europe, most of them vulnerable elderly individuals, and nearly 650,000 hectares burned in over 25,000 fires that occurred across the continent. The heat also led to a loss of glacier volume in the Alps on the order of 5-10% (European Climate Assessment and Dataset, ECA&D). The heat affected Western and Central Europe (especially France), with temperatures exceeding 40°C in much of the Iberian Peninsula and France. In the Portuguese region of Alentejo, temperatures reached 47.3°C, while in numerous cities in southern Spain, temperatures exceeded 45°C, with a maximum of 46.2°C in Córdoba. In Catalonia, in Vinebre, in the Ribera d'Ebre, the country's maximum value of 42.2°C was reached on August 13, 2003. At Girona airport, temperatures reached 41.2°C, and at Barcelona airport, 37.3°C.

The entire country was affected by two waves of hot air coming from North Africa: the first between the 11th and the 17th and the second between the 18th and the 25th. The high temperatures, which in some observatories exceeded 40 °C, led to the formation of convective storms that brought particularly heavy and abundant rainfall between the 14th and the 17th and from the 27th to the 29th, mainly affecting the Pyrenees, Pre-Pyrenees, and inland areas. On the 27th, 50.2 mm fell in Organyà (20.8 mm of which fell in 30 minutes) and 69.0 mm at the Sau Reservoir.

It was characterized by high temperatures, above the averages of recent years. The anomaly was not due to exceptionally high extreme temperatures but to the persistence of a synoptic situation that favored the presence of a tongue of warm Saharan air throughout the month. At the beginning of July, there was some instability at altitude, especially between the 3rd and 7th, with the passage of a trough that caused rain and showers in much of Catalonia, particularly intense in parts of Montsià, with 32.2 mm in Mas de Barberans, and in Tarragonès, with 31.0 mm in Torredembarra.

It was one of the warmest of the last 100 years. It was characterized by very high average temperatures, following the trend set by June and July. Like the previous month, the positive anomaly compared to the climatic average was not due to very high extreme temperatures but to the persistence of a synoptic situation that favored a continuous influx of warm Saharan air. On August 17, the synoptic situation was exceptionally altered with the arrival of a front from the Atlantic, which caused intense rains across the country: Òdena 50.6 mm and Botarell 48.4 mm. On the 20th and 21st, a small bubble of cold air at altitude destabilized the atmosphere, producing isolated storms that left 76.4 mm in Olot and 63.2 mm in Pont de Suert.
