Whole_Text.content: At the end of June to mid-September of the year 2015, unusual heatwaves occurred in Europe. With locally over 40°C, the highest temperatures since the beginning of weather records were widely measured. Particularly affected were the Maghreb Mediterranean coast, Southwest, Central, and Southeast Europe with one of the greatest heatwaves of recent decades.
In the border areas, as well as during the respective weather changes, severe storms accompanied the heat.

Around June 23–26, a high-pressure bridge formed from the Azores High to the departing Central Europe High Zoe, from which, under the influence of a low-pressure system over the British Isles (Quintus), the High Annelie developed around June 29, later shifting over the Baltic Sea. Spain was particularly affected by the heatwave in its early stages, where heat records were already set at the end of June 2015 with temperatures reaching up to 43°C. Nationwide heat warnings were in effect from June 25, with at least the second warning level issued from June 28. In Algeria and Morocco, temperatures repeatedly exceeded 40°C, even along the coast. Portugal, however, was comparatively affected only briefly. Other parts of Western Europe also recorded unusually high maximum air temperatures. In France, numerous local record temperatures of just under 40°C were noted, with temperatures along the Channel coast being up to 20°C above the long-term average for this time. At London Heathrow Airport, a temperature of 36.7°C was measured on July 1, 2015, surpassing the previous July record for the UK. In the Netherlands, July 2 saw the hottest July day ever recorded, with 38.2°C in Maastricht, marking the third-highest temperature ever measured in the country. The heat quickly spread to western Central Europe. In Germany, all-time record temperatures were measured at many stations, surpassing the values from the summer of 2003. In Karlsruhe, 40.8°C was recorded on July 5, 2015, by the Institute for Meteorology and Climate Research. However, as the German Weather Service (DWD) had ceased measurements at this location on November 1, 2008, these values are not considered official. The DWD measured 40.3°C in Kitzingen, which at the time was the highest temperature ever recorded in Germany since the start of comprehensive weather records in 1881, narrowly surpassing the previous record of 40.2°C. Switzerland experienced one of the most extreme heat weeks from July 1–7 in 150 years, alongside 2003 and 1947. Unusually high temperatures were also recorded in northern Sweden due to strong southern airflows, with a new high of 32.8°C in Forse, Ångermanland (southern Norrland), on July 2. Elsewhere, temperatures exceeded 30°C in both northern and southern Sweden until July 5. In early July, the center of Annelie shifted over Poland, and the heatwave reached eastern Central Europe with peak values around 35°C in Slovenia, Austria, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, and Poland. However, the all-time record temperatures of the 2013 heatwave were not reached here. Severe thunderstorms developed from the west along the incoming cold front of the next low-pressure system, Siegfried, over the British Isles. In the South Westphalia region, hailstones the size of tennis balls were reported. However, the thunderstorms did not bring significant cooling. Following the front, the European sub-core of the high-pressure complex was named Bigi. From July 7, the heat intensified over eastern Central Europe, Italy, and the Balkans, as a strong cold front from the subsequent North Sea low Thompson, which ended the heatwave, pushed the hot air masses of Western Central Europe ahead of it. Record values were now measured from the Swiss Plateau to the Pannonian Plain. Geneva recorded 39.7°C, the highest value ever measured for the northern side of the Alps. Innsbruck registered a new high of 38.2°C on July 7, while Lugano (25.4°C on July 7) and Vienna (26.9°C on July 8) recorded their warmest nights since measurements began. Seibersdorf recorded the highest early morning temperature ever measured in Austria (30.4°C at 8 a.m.). In Hungary, values exceeding 39°C surpassed local 60-year-old records from the summer of 1957 (39.3°C in Budakalász, Pest). Towards the Black Sea and the Aegean, the heatwave lasted only one to two days with temperatures up to nearly 40°C (Bucharest, July 9), but severe weather warnings were also issued here. The cold front moving over the Alps caused severe storms in central and southern Germany, western and southern Austria, northern Italy, and the Hungarian Plain. In Tyrol (Innsbruck 141 km/h), Carinthia, and also central Hungary, where the greatest heat had recently prevailed (Aszód, PE, 131 km/h), wind gusts reached hurricane strength, leading to windthrow, traffic disruptions, and power outages. Hailstones up to the size of golf balls were reported from Saxony-Anhalt and the Villach–Gailtal area, causing extensive roof damage in some regions. Styria recorded downpours of up to 65 liters in a few minutes. Between Dolo and Mira near Venice, a tornado of category 3/EF4 caused devastation. A reported tornado in Framersheim (Rhineland-Palatinate) might have been a downburst.

After this front, the heat retreated to the Mediterranean region, with the heatwave in Spain entering its third week. On July 6, temperatures exceeded 45 degrees in the lower Guadalquivir region up to the interior of the Valencia province (Córdoba Observatory, Andalusia, 45.2°C), and on July 7 (Zaragoza Airport, Aragon, 44.5°C; Murcia, Murcia, 43°C), numerous locations recorded the highest values since weather records began in the 1920s. In terms of temperature, duration, and extent, it surpassed the heatwaves of 2012 and 1991 by early July and became the second most severe heatwave since 1975, after 2003. With high-pressure system Clara and the low-pressure systems Thompson and Ulrich, normal summer weather returned to Central Europe, bringing a brief slight relief to Spain with cold fronts. Along the Alpine edge, these caused severe thunderstorms in the Salzburg region. From July 11, temperatures in central and southern Spain again widely approached the 40-degree mark. Subsequently, the high-pressure system, named Dietlinde, expanded back towards Central and then Eastern Europe. Temperatures there also quickly rose above 35 degrees. On July 16, the heatwave in Spain eased with the arrival of a cold front (temperatures now up to slightly above 35 degrees), while the Scirocco began in the Maghreb (Tunisia up to 41°C). France recorded a new national peak for this heatwave with over 41 degrees (41.4°C in Brive-la-Gaillarde, Corrèze). In the high mountain regions of the Alps, a record value was also measured (+6.7°C at Capanna Margherita, Piedmont, at 4560m). This time, Italy was more extensively affected, with temperatures repeatedly exceeding 40°C in Emilia, Apulia, Calabria, and record nighttime temperatures (Turin 27.1°C on July 16/17). Slovenia recorded up to 38 degrees during these days. In Hungary, temperatures reached up to 37°C, and the highest heat warning level was in effect in parts of the Balkans, such as Croatia, where 40.0°C was measured in Split-Kaštela, Dalmatia, on July 18, as well as in Bosnia-Herzegovina, Montenegro (38.2°C in Podgorica on July 17), Serbia (up to 38°C), and parts of Romania (up to 39°C). During this time, powerful low-pressure troughs dominated the weather in northern Europe, developing into a series of lows (Waldemar–Xaver–Yakari) with slow paths from the British Isles to the Baltic region, steering disturbance fronts over Central Europe. Severe heat thunderstorms occurred from Spain to the Baltic region, more extensively in Germany, Austria, and Poland. A local gust storm near Strasbourg required the evacuation of a scout meeting with 15,000 attendees. A downpour in the Neuchâtel Jura (La Frétaz, 31mm/10min) reached intensities rarely measured in Switzerland. On July 17, Innsbruck Airport recorded storm gusts of 115 km/h, Altenrhein Airport 109 km/h, Poznań in Poland 101 km/h on July 19, and Prievidza in Slovakia 112 km/h on July 20. Four hail fronts in just five hours devastated the Styrian municipalities of Pusterwald and Pölstal on July 19. A new front from July 21 to 23 settled over the Alps and Carpathians, followed by two unusual Atlantic storm lows for this time of year on July 24/25 and July 26/27, named Zeljko and Andreas. These ended the heat with temperature drops of up to 15 degrees within a few hours in northwestern Europe. They again pushed warm air ahead of them. In the Czech Republic, July 22 was the hottest day of the year, with 39.2°C measured in Husinec u Řeže near Prague. In Slovakia, 38.2°C measured in Dudince in central Slovakia was just 0.1°C below the highest temperature ever recorded (Vysoká nad Uhom, 2007). Austria recorded values of 37.9°C in Langenlebarn and Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, similar to early July. Under high-pressure influence south and east of the Pyrenees and Alps, temperatures remained extreme, especially in Andalusia (up to over 38 degrees) and the Hungarian-Serbian-Romanian lowlands (repeatedly 39.0°C in southern Hungary). The southern side of the Swiss Alps remained under the highest heat warning level until July 24. In southeastern Central Europe, cloud cover during this time made the nights particularly warm, with Tata (Komárom-Esztergom) recording a new all-time record for a tropical night on July 25, with a minimum of 25.2°C at dawn (previously 24.0°C in 1988), while daytime temperatures were widely around 35°C. These cold fronts brought severe storms again from southern France to northern Russia and the Carpathian region. In the Blenio Valley in Ticino, a downpour on July 21 with 70mm within an hour again reached an intensity rarely recorded in Switzerland. After thunderstorms, there was a severe mudslide in the Rauris Valley in Salzburg on July 23, followed by flash floods in the Lavant Valley, Carinthia, on July 24. Storm Zeljko was the most intense summer storm ever recorded in the Netherlands on July 25. On July 26 and 27, severe storms occurred in Russia, with up to 50mm of rain falling northwest of Moscow overnight, and the city itself surpassing a 130-year record for that day with 39.9mm (previously 39.1mm in 1883). Golf ball-sized hailstones were reported this time from places like Horb am Neckar (July 22) and the Bryansk Oblast (July 27). A small tornado was sighted near Püspökladány in Hungary on July 26.

On July 26, the heat largely retreated to the Mediterranean,[128][129] but at the same time merged with the Central Asian heat, which caused high-pressure system Eva, among others, over Russia.[108][9] Now, in addition to southern Spain[12] and the entire Mediterranean coast from Morocco to Syria, Ukraine[130] also reported temperatures well above 35°C, while in Greece (41°C in Larisa, July 29),[131] western Turkey, Serbia, Romania[132], and Bulgaria[133], measurements again exceeded the 40°C mark, as the heat in Eastern Europe retreated to southern Russia.[125]  
At that time, temperatures ranged from about 38°C in the eastern Mediterranean region to nearly 50°C in Mesopotamia and the Arabian Peninsula, with Baghdad recording up to 49°C for several days.[134] In the Maghreb, intense Scirocco winds resumed with 41°C on July 28 in southern Spain and Algiers, and then 42°C on July 30 in Tunis.[135] Around July 31, Central Europe was under the high-pressure influence of high-pressure system Finchen,[136] while a small Mediterranean-Alpine low-pressure system brought some cooling to Spain[12] and severe storms in Tuscany, particularly in Florence.[137] Subsequently, normal summer weather with temperatures around 35°C returned to the Mediterranean region. The high-pressure system stabilized over Eastern Europe. A new, strong, and stationary low-pressure complex over the British Isles to northern Scandinavia, named Bonimir[138][139]-Christian,[140], brought subtropical warm air back to Central Europe with its fronts, this time as a high-pressure ridge primarily eastward around the Alpine region. By August 3, temperatures in the Pannonian Basin, as well as in Poland, eastern Germany, and the Baltic region, rose above 35°C. After a disturbance passed, tropical air flowed west of the Alps from August 6 onward.[141][142] In Vallon-Pont-d’Arc in Ardèche, 40.6°C was recorded on August 6 and 40.9°C the following day.[143]  
On August 7, Kitzingen in Franconia matched Germany's record temperature of 40.3°C from early July.[15][16] On the same day, the Institute for Meteorology and Climate Research in Karlsruhe measured a new high of 41.2°C.[39] In Hungary, Poland, and eastern Austria,[144][145], as well as parts of eastern Germany, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, and northern Serbia, the highest heat warning level persisted for up to 10 consecutive days, with Hungary experiencing it nationwide throughout.  
In the Czech Republic, the Czech Meteorological Institute ČHMÚ recorded 39.3°C in Řež near Prague on August 7[146] and then 39.8°C in Řež and Dobřichovice on August 8,[147] marking the hottest days of the year so far.  
Berlin-Kaniswall on August 7 and Wrocław in Poland[148] on August 8 both recorded new station records of 38.9°C,[149] as did Minsk in Belarus with 35.8°C (124 years of measurements).[150][149] The smaller upper-level low-pressure core Detlef of the departing low-pressure system Christian, which moved southeastward from the Alps over Italy, ended the heat in southwestern Europe but intensified the warm air inflow over the Eastern Alpine region. A new Eastern European high-pressure system, Gwendolin, stabilized.[151][152] Tarifa in Cádiz, Spain, recorded a new high temperature of 35.4°C[153], while Morón de la Frontera (Seville) experienced a nighttime low of 26.6°C on the night of August 9,[153] and Vienna's city center recorded 26.9°C on the night of August 10,[154] both setting new tropical night records. Topoľčany in Slovakia measured 38.2°C on August 10.[155] The low-pressure system Detlef became a Mediterranean low with an unusually southern trajectory of the Va–Vd characteristic[156] and dissipated over Malta. Severe thunderstorms developed locally ahead of the fronts.  
Major landslides occurred on August 5 in San Vito di Cadore near Cortina d’Ampezzo,[157] and in the Gail and Drau valleys in Carinthia.[158]  
In Jósvafő in northeastern Hungary, 50 mm of rain fell in 20 minutes, and hail up to 2.5 cm in diameter was reported in Budapest.[159]  
Severe storms with flooding and mudslides[160] occurred on August 8 in Sarganserland (Weisstannental),[161] Tyrol (Stubaital, Sellraintal),[162] and Salzburg (Mittersill, Kleinarltal, Riedingtal),[163] and on August 10 in Vorarlberg (Gamperdonatal).[164] Severe thunderstorms also occurred on this day in the Stuttgart area, as well as in Saarland, Rhineland-Palatinate, and North Rhine-Westphalia.[165]  
The upper-level trough over Italy caused severe storms with wind and flooding on August 10 and 11 in Italy,[156][166][167] particularly in Campania, as well as in Umbria and Tuscany. A tornado occurred again in Marina di Carrara,[166] a severe hailstorm in Andria,[166] and an enormous 230 mm of rainfall in Rossano Calabro in 5 hours, with 350 mm over the course of the day.[168] Subsequently, the weather pattern shifted: the Azores high extended to Newfoundland, the advancing Atlantic low-pressure system did not move northward beyond Iceland, and unstable low-pressure systems formed over Eastern Europe and the Black Sea region as the high-pressure system moved away, creating a high-pressure bridge over Scandinavia (Hildegard–Isabell) into the Arctic region. A new low-pressure system (Eberhard) formed over the Bay of Biscay and merged with the Icelandic low.[152] These fronts, extending into the Mediterranean region (local low Florian from the Bay of Biscay over the Alps), initially directed warm air with unusual southeastern upper-level flows as far as northern France but then gradually brought more significant cooling to Central Europe. Simultaneously, a northeastern cold air intrusion over northern Russia into Poland brought cooling to Eastern Europe.[169][170] This caused warm air masses to be compressed again in the Pannonian-Carpathian region, with 37.8°C in Budapest-Újpest on August 13 and 26.1°C in Lágymányos, marking the hottest day and warmest night ever recorded in Budapest (previously 37.4°C in 1946 and 25.0°C in 1952, respectively).[171] Similar high temperatures were recorded in adjacent areas of Slovakia[172] and Serbia, while in Moravia, 35 stations (out of a total of 161 nationwide) recorded a day as hot as it had not been in 20 to 50 years, including 36.9°C in Lučina on August 14.[173] Temperatures across Central Europe dropped by up to 20°C within a few days, such as in Montélimar, France, with thunderstorms reducing temperatures from 37°C on August 13 to 20°C on August 14,[174] or in Prague from 35.2°C on August 14 to 14.6°C on August 18.[175]  
In Germany, the front caused severe, sometimes stationary storms with wind, hail, and flooding, including a 5–10-year rainfall event in the Stuttgart metropolitan area.[176]  
In the western Alps, a Föhn storm with speeds up to 100 km/h began on August 13, and on August 14, the pressure difference between the western and eastern halves of Switzerland was 8 hPa.[177]  
The fronts also affected the Adriatic region, with storms in Italy, particularly in Bologna and Rome,[178][179] and in Croatia in Istria and the Kvarner region on August 15.[180]  
In the Greater Poland and Lower Silesia regions, intense thunderstorms occurred on August 15.[178]  
Then, in a relatively narrow band from the northern Balkans to the German North Sea coast, intense rainfall began,[169][181][171] with Budapest recording 80 mm in just one hour and 139 mm in 51 hours on August 17, which is double the average August rainfall,[170] or 90.2 mm on the same day in Hurbanovo, the highest daily total recorded there since measurements began in 1876 and nearly double the monthly average.[181]  
In Germany, up to 150 mm of rain fell in a strip from Saxony to North Rhine-Westphalia between August 16 and 19, leading to flooding during heavier thunderstorms due to the parched soils.[176] A small upper-level low over the upper Adriatic[182] continued to cause intense rain in northern Italy and the western Balkans.

Whole_Text.header: Fourth phase end of August/beginning of September
Whole_Text.content: Over Scandinavia, the stable high-pressure system (Isabell) persisted, with midsummer temperatures reaching Norway, where the summer had previously been largely rainy. Frosta in Nord-Trøndelag (Central Norway) recorded 28.8°C on August 19, temperatures comparable to Rome at that time. Areas such as Pomerania and Western Pomerania were not affected by the cold snap. Then, a southern airflow reestablished itself ahead of the fronts of the powerful Icelandic low-pressure system from previous days, with temperatures exceeding 35°C in Portugal and Spain from August 17, up to 33°C in the Foehn regions of southwestern France, and up to 30°C in southeastern England on August 22. A new Bay of Biscay–North Sea–Scandinavia low-pressure complex (Gerald–Hans–Immanuel) with an associated Mediterranean low brought heavy rainfall to the western and southern Alpine edges, causing floods and landslides in Hérault (Soumont 210 mm/24 h) and on the Côte d’Azur. The situation escalated particularly in Montpellier in southeastern France. In the Alps, Foehn storm fields reached speeds of about 120 km/h at Gütsch or Patscherkofel. Behind these low-pressure systems, a stable bridge developed again from the Azores high to the high-pressure system Isabell, which had since moved to Eastern Europe and was renamed Jessica. This brought another heatwave to Central Europe with a southwestern upper airflow and subtropical air, while a low-pressure trough extended as an air mass boundary from the central North Atlantic over northern Germany to the Black Sea. In southern Italy, temperatures of up to 35°C were recorded from August 24, and in Spain's interior, temperatures reached up to 38°C again from August 25. The heat then extended back to the Baltic region and the Black Sea (High Karma, later Jessica there) and merged once more with the Middle Eastern heat. Temperatures of over 30°C were recorded as far as Latvia, and over 35°C again in several areas of the Balkans, Romania, southern Ukraine, and the Krasnodar–Caucasus region of southern Russia. Only from August 30 did a cooling begin, starting from the Iberian Peninsula, as the disturbance zone controlled by the Scandinavian lows Hans/Immanuel, which had previously been situated in a west-east direction over Central Europe, slowly ended this last heatwave of the meteorological summer. The persistent southwestern airflow shifted the warm air to Eastern Europe. Ahead of the cold front, the hottest September day ever recorded was noted in many places from the Baltic Sea to the Pannonian Plain on September 1, with some locations even setting new all-time highs, such as Görlitz in Saxony with 33.3°C (one degree above the previous record from 1947). With Foehn winds, temperatures in the Austrian Alpine foreland and the Weinviertel exceeded the 35°C mark, with the highest value recorded in Pottschach at the Alpine edge at 36.0°C. In the Czech Republic, Vráž in South Bohemia reported 36.5°C on August 31, and Javorník in Silesia recorded 37.4°C the next day (far exceeding the previous highest September value of 32.2°C on September 6, 2008). Michalovce in the Eastern Slovak Lowland recorded 36.4°C. Dombegyház on the Hungarian-Serbian border also set a national September record with 36.9°C. Temperatures above 35°C and higher warning levels persisted in southeastern Serbia and Macedonia until September 5. The following day, the heatwave reached around Athens for several more days, with temperatures nearing 40°C, ahead of the low-pressure trough advancing southward over the Balkans. A smaller low-pressure complex Jonas/Kalle over the North Sea, Baltic Sea, and then the Baltic region, which had formed from the previous disturbance zone, brought heavy thunderstorms with widespread severe weather, storms, hail, and flooding, particularly along the air mass boundary in the Mediterranean region, for over a week. Temperatures dropped widely by 15°C to 20°C in a short time. On the night of August 31 to September 1, a large storm cell formed over southwestern France, with hurricane-like gusts (152.6 km/h, Le Montat in Lot, the highest wind peak ever recorded there). From northern Europe, only isolated severe local storms were reported, such as in the Aurich district in East Frisia and Saxony. In Emmerich am Rhein, crows were killed by very sudden hail, a rare phenomenon. Severe hailstorms occurred in the Tyrolean Inn Valley on September 3. From September 3 to 4, more than a month's average rainfall fell from a storm cell in southern Spain and the Balearic Islands. These then moved with heavy rain over Provence and northern Italy, with hailstones the size of eggs reported in Naples on September 5. Another larger thunderstorm area (mesoscale convective system) brought torrential rain of up to 100 mm/3 h on September 8 in Calatabiano (Sicily), 90 mm/24 h on Kerkyra (Corfu, Ionian Islands), and then heavier rainfall in Serbia.

The highs Lajana and Maybrit, which had formed from the Azores High near Newfoundland and Greenland in the third week of August and mid-September respectively, slowly moved over the British Isles and Scandinavia into northern Russia during mid and late September, only associated with autumnal warmth. From there, a high-pressure bridge formed between the Mediterranean lows into the North African region, which, starting September 9, again led to temporarily summer-like temperatures from Switzerland to Eastern Europe with strong föhn-like southwesterly flows. From September 14, temperatures gradually rose above 30 degrees in the Alpine foothills, eastern Austria, the Carpathian Basin, and then the Eastern European Plain. The Alpine föhn reached hurricane strength on September 16, with 172 km/h at Gütsch (September 17), 135 km/h at Weissbad AI (Ebenalp) (September 16), 156 km/h at Patscherkofel (Tyrol) (September 16), 119 km/h in the valleys at Brülisau AI (September 16), 136 km/h in Innsbruck-Olympic Village (September 16), and still up to 100 km/h in Vienna (September 18), causing widespread storm damage. In Austria, Gumpoldskirchen recorded a new record of 35.5°C on September 17 for the second half of September, with temperatures above 30 degrees this late in the year being recorded only a few times in the entire measurement history (in Vienna in 1947, 2003, 1961, and 1867). In the central Balkans and later along the lower Danube, the heat reached well over 35 degrees. Szeged measured 36.4°C on September 17, and Körösszakálon recorded 37.2°C on September 18, each setting new national September records. In the southern and eastern Carpathians, temperatures were up to 10°C above the normal weekly average for these days, with some locations recording the highest values of the year. Along the Italian lower Adriatic (Abruzzo, Molise, and Puglia) on September 17, temperatures even exceeded 40 degrees, also marking the highest September temperatures ever recorded there. The warmth also reached the Baltic region and Scandinavia. The heat persisted in the Carpathian Basin until September 19 and then retreated with High Lajana into the Aegean–Black Sea region. Around September 25, it reached the Moscow area and the White Sea region with High Maybrit and large-scale southern flows, persisting until early October in the Russian Black Sea region and Volga area. Ahead of the advancing fronts of an Atlantic low-pressure complex – Leo, Michael, and ex-Henri, a tropical storm from the mid-Atlantic – there were massive rains in the southern slopes of southern France (Épisode méditerranéen) from September 11–13, with 256 mm/24 h in Valleraugue (Gard), 242 mm/6 h in Grospierres (Ardèche), and over 110 km/h winds in Nice. The following front, which pushed the heat out of Southeast Europe, brought storms on September 16 from Portugal across northern Spain, central France (135 km/h in Saint-Dizier, Champagne-Ardenne, and Clamecy, Burgundy), southeastern England, western Germany, to southern Sweden. Another Adriatic low (Patrik) caused heavy rainfall and tornadoes in the Aegean region on September 21/22. This was followed by another stable European high, Netti, which in Central Europe was only associated with autumnal temperatures but again brought temperatures above 30 degrees in Portugal and southern Spain.

A particular feature of this heatwave is the preceding series of large and poorly predictable temperature fluctuations in Europe during the spring.  
As early as the beginning of May, a heatwave in Spain reached temperatures of nearly 45 degrees (44.4°C in Carcaixent, southern Valencia) and claimed lives, while temperatures in Central Europe reached 30 degrees. This heatwave ended with severe storms.  
Subsequently, the Alpine region experienced persistent rain, sub-zero temperatures, and snowfall down to low altitudes due to a strong cold spell. In some areas, this month was the cloudiest May in the last 25 years.  
June initially brought another heat period with up to 35 degrees in Central Europe and again severe thunderstorms. The subsequent "sheep cold" in the second half of June – surprisingly according to medium-term forecasts – led to a polar cold air intrusion with temperatures significantly below 10 degrees (e.g., 0.3°C in Obertauern, 1772 m, on June 24).  
It was the globally warmest May and June recorded since the beginning of worldwide consistent and reliable weather records in the 1880s. At the same time, abnormal heat prevailed at the eastern edge of the European heatwave, in the region from Central Siberia to the Caspian Sea (47.2°C in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan, June 30) to Pakistan (49°C in June) and then in Siberia and northern China (up to 40°C in mid-July) and to the Middle East (52.5°C in Mitribah, Kuwait, July 17; Mahshahr, Iran, 46°C, August 1) and in Northeast Africa (46°C in southern Egypt in mid-August), with severe wildfires in Siberia around Lake Baikal.  
Heatwaves also occurred simultaneously in North America (northwest; repeatedly 45°C, June 28), where one of the most intense wildfire years in recent history occurred after years of drought, in Mexico (up to 40 degrees at the end of August), and in Japan (38.5°C in Jōetsu Takada, July 13).  
Colombia (42.2°C, Urumitia, July 1) and Thailand (41.1°C, Kamalasai, July 1) also reported their hottest July days since records began. In Africa, July was the second hottest (after 2002), and in South America, the fifth hottest in recorded history.  
In contrast, unusual cold was recorded in New Zealand and Australia during their southern winter in mid-July (snowfall in the Blue Mountains not seen in 20 years).  
Overall, both July and August – like the two preceding months – were the hottest ever recorded globally, with August particularly in Europe, Africa, and South America.  
From May onward, there was an extensive blocking situation across the entire Northern Hemisphere, which was particularly pronounced over the Pacific and led to an abnormal jet stream pattern, disrupted westerly drift, and stationary high-pressure systems, causing heatwaves on four continents.  
The North Atlantic and Arctic Oscillation indices fell sharply contrary to forecasts, indicating polar cold air flowing toward Europe due to a weak Azores High; however, this air did not reach the continent due to the blocking but remained over the mid-Atlantic.  
The last such regularly occurring hemispheric blocking situation had led to a major cold wave in North America, winter heat in Siberia, as well as storm surges and floods in Europe during the winter of 2014.  
From the second decade of July, a powerful polar high dominated Europe's weather. As a result, the tropical Hadley cell expanded into mid-latitudes. Simultaneously, the West African monsoon system (Guinea monsoon) intensified, steering tropical air masses over the Sahara into the Mediterranean region. Consequently, the heat center shifted from the western to the central and then eastern Mediterranean.  
At the beginning of August, a strongly blocked omega pattern developed again between Atlantic lows and a cold-air-drop-like low over Siberia, with warm air advancing over the White Sea to the North Pole; for example, 850-hPa temperatures there on August 7 were above 0°C, comparable to Ireland or the West Siberian Plain east of the Urals.  
The Azores High, on the other hand, had shifted to the western Atlantic at about 35° north latitude, corresponding to the latitude of North Carolina–Gibraltar. The jet stream was consequently displaced to northern latitudes of 40–60°, reaching the latitude of Newfoundland–Biscay–northern Scandinavia.  
On August 6, an abnormally strong Sahara dust outburst toward South America was observed.  
The final phase was characterized by blocked North Atlantic highs, with the jet stream remaining extremely far north.  
The overall weather pattern is seen as a symptom of the ongoing El Niño event, active since April, which intensified into the fall and only transitioned into a La Niña event in May 2015.  
The intensity of the heat event is considered to be linked to global warming, according to current research.  
Due to the El Niño influence and the Azores High characteristics, the Atlantic hurricane season was largely absent, being one of the weakest in many years. In contrast, Pacific typhoons were above average in frequency.  
The course of the heatwave could be well predicted in July with the European IFS model of ECMWF (10–14 days in advance), while the American NOAA-NCEP CFS/GFS model showed poor results.  
The medium-term climatology lies outside expectations even in the ensemble, and long-term forecasts from the spring – for example, regarding hurricanes – were repeatedly revised.  
In addition to numerous local daily values across Europe, which were the highest since the beginning of respective records, it was already foreseeable by mid-July that July 2015 would be the hottest July ever recorded in Spain, Austria, Switzerland, and northern Italy, and one of the hottest months overall, including August months.  
August 2015 was the hottest August in eastern Germany, such as in Berlin and Dresden, in 208 years, with 13 to 14 (locally up to 17 in southeastern Brandenburg) hot days, surpassing the old hot day records of August 1944.  
August 2015 thus strongly resembled July 2006, which brought up to 21 hot days in Lusatia.  
The overall high summer (July and August 2015) was in Berlin – albeit narrowly – the warmest since 1834, surpassing the high summer of 1994.  
However, the three-month interval June–August (meteorological summer) was only the third highest measured in Europe since 2012, after 2003 and 2010.  
The low precipitation levels are also abnormal. This can be described as a century event on a large scale.

Heat-related excess mortality was recorded in several countries across Europe. Spain and Switzerland were the most affected, but Italy, France, Belgium, and Greece were also impacted. Direct heat casualties were only sporadically reported, but numerous fatal swimming accidents occurred, particularly in East-Central Europe and the Baltic region. Special emergency plans for health issues caused by prolonged heat were activated in Spain, the Netherlands, and France, among others. The storms and severe weather accompanying the heatwave caused damages amounting to billions of euros (e.g., €150 million on July 8 in Carinthia, one of the region's most severe thunderstorm/hail damage events ever). These events claimed lives in Italy (July 8, August 5, August 10), Hungary (July 8), Austria (July 9, July 21), Poland (July 19), the Netherlands (July 26), the Czech Republic (July 26), and France (August 23, September 16). The heatwave also exacerbated humanitarian issues related to the refugee crisis at the time. It affected North Africa and the crisis region in the Middle East, where droughts and the Syria/ISIS conflict forced millions to flee, with life-threatening conditions due to temperatures exceeding 50°C. Similarly affected were the southern and east-central European countries, which are typical first-asylum states. Their reception centers were completely overcrowded: since spring, over 200,000 refugees arrived in Greece, and around 100,000 in Italy via the Mediterranean. Starting in July, there was uncontrolled migration to Central Europe, particularly along the Balkan route through Greece—aggravated by the economic crisis there—which escalated, with daily transit numbers rising from several hundred in early summer to several thousand by early autumn. Border controls had to be reinstated at numerous borders, even within the EU, sometimes with military support. Hungary erected a border fence with Serbia over the summer. Macedonia declared a state of emergency in late August. Even in Austria and Germany, the main destination for most of these refugees, chaotic conditions prevailed. Across the Mediterranean region and even in temperate Europe, drought increasingly became a problem, especially in areas where annual rainfall was already far below average due to spring heatwaves, such as in Portugal, Spain, almost all of France, central Germany, northern Italy, eastern Austria, Ukraine, and Belarus, as well as in Ireland, which was not affected by the heat. Crop failures across Europe also reached billions of euros. For example, the Austrian Hail Insurance estimated the total agricultural damage from heat at €170 million, with an additional €40 million from storms. An exception was viticulture, where the heat led to widespread expectations of a fully ripe harvest and a significant vintage of reserve wines. However, there were also severe hail losses, particularly affecting Chablis in Burgundy shortly before the harvest. The drought also caused river levels to drop, with the Elbe experiencing a 50-year low, and navigation on the Rhine and Danube increasingly hindered, though less so due to intermittent storms in their catchment areas. The Po River experienced extreme low water levels in July. A unique aspect of the weather event was the overheating of the Mediterranean Sea. By mid-July, surface water temperatures in the Tyrrhenian Sea off southern Italy were already widely at 30°C, and over 28°C in a third of the entire sea area from Gibraltar to the Levant, with peak values in some bays reaching 34°C. (In 2003, temperatures of 32°C were measured off the Balearic Islands in August.) At the end of July, fish die-offs occurred in the Tyrrhenian Sea off Tuscany. Switzerland also experienced dramatic fish die-offs. However, feared severe storms in autumn due to stored energy largely did not materialize. Overheating also became a problem in continental waters, with Lake Constance reaching over 26°C, the highest temperature ever recorded. Widespread forest fires occurred in Europe, including one near the site of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster in early July. Ukrainian and Russian authorities reported no increased radioactivity. In southwestern Germany, there were several forest and grass fires in the first half of July. The situation in the Mediterranean region remained under control by late July, such as in Greece, which had not been abnormally affected by the heat, with numerous bushfires, including one near Athens, as well as in Italy and the eastern Adriatic region in Croatia, Albania, and Macedonia. More severe fires occurred in Portugal and Spain in mid-August. However, widespread forest damage feared due to the general heat and drought did not materialize. Windthrow from Storm Niklas in late March and others during the summer remained the main cause of localized high forest damage, while bark beetle infestations remained at a low level (e.g., in 2003, severe beetle damage occurred after Winter Storm Uschi and summer heat). In Germany, heat damage to road surfaces in early July caused full closures and speed limits on various highways. In Essen, some urban rail vehicles became stuck in softened bitumen. In the Upper Palatinate, severe track distortions and prolonged closures occurred on the Cham–Waldmünchen and Cham–Bad Kötzting railway lines in mid-July. In Austria, track breaks occurred on the Arlberg and Außerfern railways in Tyrol in early July, which were quickly repaired. According to the French grid operator RTE, numerous power outages occurred at the start of the first heatwave due to grid overloads from cooling systems. On June 30, nearly one million French households were without power. Later, there were several extensive power outages across Europe due to storms.

Whole_Text.content: The heatwave of 2013 refers to the intense heat that affected Japan nationwide, particularly in eastern and western Japan, during July and August 2013 (Heisei 25). Notably, on August 12, the highest temperature in Japan's history, 41.0°C, was recorded in Ekawasaki, Shimanto City, Kochi Prefecture.

Due to the strong Pacific high pressure system extending from the southern seas of Japan to western Japan, eastern Japan and areas to the west were often covered by the Pacific high pressure system during the peak summer period, and warm air easily flowed into northern Japan, resulting in high temperatures nationwide. In mid-June, when warm high pressure covered the region, extreme heat days were recorded one after another in western Japan. In early July, when the Pacific high pressure system intensified, temperatures from northern to western Japan were higher than average. Particularly from August 9 to 12, the country experienced four days of the most intense heat, with over 290 locations recording extreme heat days, an unprecedented event even compared to 2018. Additionally, record-breaking heat was notable in Pacific coastal prefectures such as Miyazaki, Kochi, Wakayama, and Chiba. On the other hand, due to the limited impact of the Foehn phenomenon on the Sea of Japan side, there were many cases where the maximum temperatures were below average, such as in Niigata Prefecture and the two San'in prefectures, where maximum temperatures did not exceed 37 degrees Celsius.

In Katsunuma, Koshu City, Yamanashi Prefecture, the daily maximum temperature exceeded 39°C for four consecutive days, recording 39.1°C on the 9th, 39.2°C on the 10th, 39.3°C on the 11th, and 39.1°C on the 12th. In Tatebayashi City, Gunma Prefecture, a daily maximum temperature of 39.5°C was observed on the 11th. Additionally, from around July 22 to 25 and from July 31 to August 3, high temperatures were recorded in Saga Prefecture, Miyazaki Prefecture, Kochi Prefecture, and other areas. From late August to mid-August, temperatures from northern Japan to western Japan were significantly higher than average, with 39.3°C observed in Ekawasaki, Shimanto City, Kochi Prefecture, on the 9th. Regarding the series of record-breaking high temperatures observed in Ekawasaki, Shimanto City, Kochi Prefecture, and other locations, it has been suggested that the "two-story structure" of high pressure, where the Tibetan high pressure extends over the Pacific high pressure, strengthens the downward airflow within the high-pressure system, compressing and heating the air near the surface, thereby raising temperatures. Additionally, the Foehn phenomenon, where dry, hot winds blow over mountains, has also been cited as a contributing factor. From around the 18th to the 23rd, extreme heat returned to Kyushu. On the 20th, a daily maximum temperature of 39.6°C, tying the record for the highest in Kyushu's history, was observed in Ushibuka, Amakusa City, Kumamoto Prefecture. On the 22nd, extreme heat of 38–39°C was recorded in various parts of the Tokai region. Although the heat gradually subsided thereafter, on October 9, a temperature of 35.1°C, the latest-ever recorded midsummer day in October nationwide, was observed in Itoigawa City, Niigata Prefecture. The monthly temperature deviations from the average were +0.9°C in eastern Japan, +0.7°C in western Japan, and +0.9°C in the Nansei Islands in June; +1.3°C in northern Japan, +1.6°C in western Japan, and +0.3°C in the Nansei Islands in July; and +1.3°C in eastern and western Japan and +0.8°C in the Nansei Islands in August. Notably, the deviations of +2.8°C in western Japan in mid-June, +3.4°C in northern Japan in early July, +1.4°C in the Nansei Islands in early August, and +2.7°C in northern Japan, +2.4°C in eastern Japan, and +2.3°C in western Japan in mid-August were all record highs for those respective periods. Furthermore, in western Japan, the average summer temperature was +1.2°C, the highest since statistics began in 1946. This summer, 125 locations (143 including tied records) out of 927 AMeDAS observation points nationwide set new records for daily maximum temperatures.

The previous highest record was 40.9°C in August 2007 in Kumagaya City, Saitama Prefecture, and Tajimi City, Gifu Prefecture. The highest record on the mainland was 30.5°C in August 2010 in Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture, and Okayama City, Okayama Prefecture (the domestic record in Japan is 30.7°C in July 1956 in Ishigaki City, Okinawa Prefecture). The highest domestic record in Japan was 36.2°C in August 1995 in Sakuma Town, Shizuoka Prefecture, and Tajimi City, Gifu Prefecture (at meteorological offices and observatories, it was 36.1°C in August 1995 in Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture). The highest number of days in Japan was 45 days in Hita City, Oita Prefecture, in 1994.

Over Japan, both the lower Pacific high-pressure system and the upper Tibetan high-pressure system were stronger than usual nationwide, with the Pacific high-pressure system extending strongly to western Japan and the Nansei Islands. This resulted in continued clear weather and high temperatures. It is believed that the downward flow of air within the high-pressure system was intensified, compressing and heating near the surface, thereby raising temperatures.  
Additionally, the Kochi Local Meteorological Observatory attributes the extreme heat exceeding 40 degrees Celsius in Ekawasaki, Shimanto City, to the above factors combined with the Foehn phenomenon, where dry, hot winds blow over the mountains.
Meteorological observation values, data, and analysis related to the impact of extreme heat are based on the following website unless otherwise specified.

Temperatures reached a record high in Japan, affecting many areas of the country by July 2018. Many regions experienced temperatures exceeding 35 °C (95 °F), especially in Kumagaya, which recorded a maximum temperature of 41.1 °C (106.0 °F) on July 23, the highest ever in Japan. At least 80 people were killed due to this heatwave, while 22,000 others suffered from heatstroke requiring urgent transportation to hospitals.

Following the floods and landslides that lasted from late June to mid-July 2018, a heatwave spread across mainland Japan, especially in the prefectures that experienced the worst floods and landslides, such as Hiroshima, Okayama, and Ehime. These heatwaves caused over 145 people to suffer from heat strokes, particularly after temperatures reached 35 °C (95.0 °F). On July 15, 200 out of 927 stations in the country recorded maximum temperatures exceeding 35 °C (95.0 °F). On July 23, the temperature rose to about 41.1 °C (106.0 °F) in Kumagaya, 65 kilometers (40 miles) northwest of Tokyo. Many cities recorded temperatures nearing 40 °C (104 °F) on this day, while in Kyoto, temperatures reached 38 °C (100 °F) and persisted for seven consecutive days for the first time since the 19th century. It is worth noting that the Japan Meteorological Agency considered this unprecedented rise in temperatures as a natural disaster and indicated that Japan experienced "unprecedented levels of heat."

At least 80 people nationwide have died due to the heat, while more than 22,000 others suffered heat strokes that required urgent hospitalization. The majority of heat-related deaths were concentrated in 28 out of 47 prefectures. Between July 15 and July 22, 65 people were killed, including 11 on July 21 alone and 13 on July 23. On July 17, the Tokyo Fire Department dispatched 2,900 ambulances to manage the situation. The Ministry of Education issued a warning to schools to take necessary precautions against heatstroke following the death of a six-year-old child who was exposed to the sun outdoors. It is worth noting that less than half of the schools in the country are equipped with air conditioning, and government officials have previously discussed extending school holidays for the safety of children. Additionally, the government covers the cost of installing air conditioners in schools. Kyushu Electric Power Company had also offered a 10% discount on the bills of customers aged 75 and older between August and September to encourage the use of air conditioning.

Whole_Text.content: The heatwave in Australia 2018/2019 refers to a weather anomaly in Australia at the end of 2018 and the beginning of 2019 with unusually high temperatures for the season (summer in the southern hemisphere).

The year 2018 was one of the warmest worldwide since the beginning of weather records. This was evident, for example, through a persistent drought and heat in Europe, wildfires in California, and other weather events in the Northern Hemisphere. The heatwave in Australia thus continued a series of global heatwaves, following unusual weather events already recorded in Australia in 2016. Since January temperatures in Australia are typically higher than December temperatures, it was feared as early as December 2018 that the heatwave in Australia could persist or even intensify. Many Australians associate the heatwave with global warming. January 2019 was the warmest January in Australia since the beginning of weather records; for the first time, a nationwide average temperature of 30 degrees Celsius was exceeded. The previous January record was surpassed by 2 to 3 degrees in some cases. With 36.6 degrees Celsius on January 26 in Wanaaring (North Western, New South Wales), the nighttime heat record for the Southern Hemisphere was broken.

At the end of December, temperatures above the 40-degree Celsius mark were recorded in large parts of the states of New South Wales, Victoria, and South Australia. For the southeast of the country, this was ten to sixteen degrees Celsius above the average values typical for the season. On December 27, a midday temperature of 49.1 degrees Celsius was measured in Marble Bar in northern Western Australia, which is already considered the hottest place in Australia; this was only slightly below the Australian temperature record of 50.7 degrees Celsius from January 1960. Subsequent bushfires and droughts were feared. High ozone levels were also reported. A nationwide fire ban was issued. The heatwave also affected large parts of Australia in January. At the end of January, the city of Adelaide broke its heat record from 1939 with 46.2 degrees. On January 25, the highest temperature ever recorded in a coastal location was measured in Port Augusta at 49.5 degrees. The heatwave was followed by a monsoon with partly extreme rainfall. In some areas, over 1000 mm of rain fell per square meter; northern Queensland was particularly affected. The city of Townsville had to be deliberately flooded to prevent a dam breach; 2000 houses were underwater.

The Australian Open 2019 was among those affected by the heatwave. Additional break times had to be introduced during the tennis tournament. The weather anomaly contributed to a debate about the climate crisis. In particular, in Australia itself, which has a comparatively high per capita greenhouse gas emission, the heatwave triggered extensive discussions in politics. Coal is Australia's second most important export product, and accordingly, the Australian coal industry, which has a strong lobby in politics, received backing from the governments of previous years, while climate change and renewable energies played no significant role in the political debate. In the settlement of Santa Teresa, about 80 kilometers southwest of Alice Springs, around 40 dead brumbies were found in dried-up waterholes. Rangers shot 55 more feral horses suffering from water shortages. In Western Australia, more than 2,500 wild camels were shot. They had broken through fences around private grazing land to access water. Uluru (Ayers Rock) was closed due to the extreme heat, yet a German tourist died of water shortage on New Year's Day. Supermarkets in Australia can no longer sell chilled goods because refrigerators are not functioning due to the heat.

At the end of June 2019, widespread heat prevailed in Europe. Temperatures exceeded 40°C in some places, with a new all-time record air temperature in France (46.0°C) and Andorra. Towards the end of July 2019, a second heatwave occurred. This event brought all-time records with temperatures again exceeding 40°C for Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Belgium, and the United Kingdom. In early August, a heatwave affected mainly Southern Europe. At the end of August 2019, another heatwave occurred. Overall, the meteorological summer (consisting of the months of June, July, and August) of 2019 ended as the hottest summer ever recorded since measurements began in 1940. Due to global warming, this summer temperature record was already broken in 2023.

The causes of this heatwave were the persistent high-pressure system (Vera) over Europe and the slow-moving Atlantic low-pressure system (Nasir). Nasir formed around June 18 near Newfoundland and remained near Spain and England until almost the end of the month before moving eastward over Scandinavia. With a powerful southwesterly upper-level flow, an air mass from the Azores High – initially called Ulla, later referred to as the high-pressure bridge Vera from June 25 – moved into the North Sea region and then southeastward over Central Europe. As a result, hot Saharan air advanced over the Iberian Peninsula and southern France from June 23, reaching the Baltic Sea region by the end of the month. With a low-pressure system, Otto, in the Baltic region, a short-term omega block formed over the flat pressure distribution of several lows in the Mediterranean region. Temperatures reached a peak of 46.0°C on June 28 in Vérargues, Hérault, southern France (and 45.9°C in nearby Gallargues-le-Montueux, Gard), the highest temperature ever recorded in mainland France (previously 44.1°C in Conqueyrac, August 2003). This record was surpassed in 2019 at several measurement sites in the region. France became the seventh European country to record temperatures above 45°C. Andorra also recorded a new national record of 39.4°C in Borda Vidal on the 28th (previously 38.5°C in Andorra La Vella, July 2005). Numerous all-time records were set, including in Spain, France, Switzerland, Germany, Austria, and Croatia. Nighttime minimum temperatures also reached new all-time records at several stations. Another notable feature was the abnormally high temperatures in elevated areas, such as the Pyrenees – where the peak temperatures in southern France were also influenced by Foehn effects – and the Alps. For example, Davos (Graubünden, 1596 m) recorded a new high of 29.8°C on the 26th (previously 29.3°C in 2015), as did the Schmittenhöhe (Salzburg, 1956 m) on the 27th with 25.0°C (previously 24.6°C in 1952). St. Martin in Passeier (South Tyrol, 586 m) reported 39.9°C on the same day. At the beginning of July, the hot air was pushed back into the Mediterranean region, with a few more hot days in the Balkans. In the Eastern Alps, for example, the midsummer weather persisted until July 7. The heatwave ended with some severe thunderstorms, such as in France and Austria, and around July 10 with the advance of cold air into Spain, the upper Adriatic, the eastern edge of the Alps, and Greece. By mid-July, more unstable weather patterns prevailed (storms in Corsica and the Southern Alps). There were widespread wildfires, favored by drought and heat.

The later part of July was characterized by a series of Atlantic low-pressure systems, each with a northeasterly trajectory. With a renewed southwesterly flow, heat returned to Spain around July 18, and a more stable high-pressure system (Yvonne) formed over Central Europe. By July 23, with the arrival of a strong Atlantic low-pressure system, a brief omega-like weather pattern developed. In Spain and France, temperatures of over 40°C were widely recorded as early as July 23. The following days became even hotter.

Several national weather services recorded unprecedented peak air temperatures:
In Germany, the stations in Duisburg-Baerl and Tönisvorst reported 41.2°C on July 25; the day before, 40.5°C had been measured in Geilenkirchen near Aachen (previously 40.3°C in Kitzingen, 2015; see also heat records in Germany) – this old record was surpassed in several locations.
In Belgium, 41.8°C was recorded in Begijnendijk on the same day; the day before, 39.9°C was measured in Kleine-Brogel (previously 38.8°C in Liège-Monsin, July 2015).
In the Netherlands, 40.7°C was recorded in Gilze en Rijen at the same time; the day before, 39.3°C was measured in Eindhoven (previously 38.6°C in Warnsveld, August 1944) – a 75-year-old record that was broken.
In Luxembourg, 39.0°C was also recorded on that day at the Findel-Aéroport station (previously 37.9°C there in August 2003).
On July 25, a national record of 38.7°C was measured in the United Kingdom at the Botanical Garden of the University of Cambridge (previously 38.5°C in Faversham, August 2003).
Numerous individual locations also registered their new all-time records, including Paris, which recorded 42.6°C on July 25, marking the highest value in Europe during this heatwave (Montsouris station, previously 1947). With the strong Atlantic low-pressure system moving northward toward Iceland, the heatwave in Central Europe ended as early as July 26, accompanied by stormy weather and a significant temperature drop of up to 15°C. The subtropical warm air mass was split (low-pressure front Vincent), separated in the Baltic Sea region, and displaced by south winds over northern Scandinavia. There, the air mass merged with the current polar high and was carried westward by the Icelandic low-pressure complex, reaching East Greenland. In the Greenland Sea–Norwegian Sea area, it remained abnormally warm until the early days of August. On July 27, Norway recorded 35.6°C in Laksfors, at over 65°N, equaling the country's nearly 40-year-old all-time record (Nesbyen, June 1970; significantly further south at 60°), and also experienced tropical nights.

In central Sweden, southern Finland, and all of Estonia, temperatures above 30°C were widely recorded, with Helsinki setting a new record of 33.2°C (previously 31.6°C in July 1945). In Greenland, 20.6°C was measured on July 31 in Qaarsut, located on the west coast by Baffin Bay (71°N) – a normal summer temperature there is around 10°C. The Nord station, only 900 km south of the North Pole, recorded 16.0°C. In Central Europe, the weather was dominated by Atlantic cold fronts and a Mediterranean low-pressure system as an offshoot. From July 26, this led to severe storms, particularly in Morocco, Catalonia, central Italy, all of Austria, the western Balkans, as well as the Czech Republic, Slovakia, and Poland. The heat retreated fairly quickly from the Mediterranean region.

The British Isles experienced heavy rainfall around the turn of the month due to the Atlantic low-pressure system.

The third heatwave began with a high-pressure system (Zella), which caused temperatures on the Iberian Peninsula to rise above 40°C as early as August 4, and a low-pressure system (Xaver), which quickly moved across Europe and brought severe storms on August 6 from the Pyrenees through southern France to the southern Alps and the northern side of the Alps. Around August 7, another strong Atlantic low-pressure system (Yap) formed, causing another surge of Saharan air into southern Europe (high-pressure zone Andrea). The center of this heatwave shifted from southern Spain to the region of the Italian Peninsula, the Balkans, and the Aegean. Thessaly recorded temperatures of 40°C from August 8, 2019, Leskovac in Serbia reached 38.1°C on August 12, and Belgrade experienced five consecutive tropical nights. During this time, similar peak temperatures were also measured in Ukraine. The heat slowly retreated to the southeast, with temperatures still exceeding 40°C in Turkey. Wildfires broke out again in the Mediterranean region. In the stormy zone at the edge of the Atlantic low-pressure system, a tornado formed on August 9, causing severe damage in Luxembourg. The front remained storm-prone over Central Europe for several days, with localized heavy rainfall. Southern and Eastern Europe remained under the influence of the Azores high-pressure offshoots (Beatrix), with a strong low-pressure system (Bernd) over England. Temperatures in southern Spain reached over 40°C for another week, and widespread temperatures exceeded 35°C up to the Black Sea. The front from Bernd, with a small Mediterranean low-pressure system as an offshoot, led to severe storms from August 19 to 22, with partly hurricane-like gusts, from eastern Switzerland through parts of southern and central Germany to the Polish-Slovak Tatra Mountains.

This was followed by an Atlantic high-pressure system, Corinna, which had been approaching from the American west coast since mid-August behind low-pressure system Bernd. It merged with the Sahara high-pressure system and extended into the White Sea region, bringing midsummer temperatures back to northern Europe. The focus of this heatwave, in addition to southern Spain, where peak temperatures above 40°C occurred again for several days, was the Serbia–Hungary–Poland area. On August 27, the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI) officially confirmed another heatwave in the Netherlands, and the Royal Meteorological Institute of Belgium (KMI) confirmed the third heatwave of 2019 in Belgium.

Such intense heat so early in the year was a rarity across Europe; some countries and numerous weather stations recorded new daily maximum temperature records for June. In Poland, an 80-year-old record for peak temperature was broken (1935), in Germany a 70-year-old record (1947). In France, almost a quarter (23%) of all Meteo-France stations recorded new all-time records, and almost two-thirds (60%) recorded a June record. The beginning of June was already exceptionally hot; throughout June, there was a prevailing foehn-like south to southwest airflow. June 2019 became the warmest month ever recorded in all of Europe since the beginning of weather records (1 degree warmer than the previous record June of 1999), including in Austria (weather series since 1767), in Poland (previously June 1811), in Germany (weather series since 1881), in the Czech Republic (since 1961), and in Latvia (since 1924); it was the second warmest in Switzerland (after 2003). The minimal nighttime cooling was also remarkable; Vienna (Inner City), for example, experienced thirteen tropical nights not dropping below 20°C during the month (also a new local record for June). July was also abnormally warm but only locally a record month.

A peculiarity of this heatwave was the drift of warm air to the northwest, leading to an intense ice melt event in Greenland. There, even at 3200 m (Station Summit Camp), the zero-degree threshold was exceeded for several days, which had only previously occurred in 2012. (See also Consequences of Global Warming in the Arctic#Mass Loss Greenland) The period of the last days of June was regionally 10–6 degrees above the long-term average, mainly in France, northern Spain, northern Italy, Switzerland, western Austria, southern Germany, and the Czech Republic.

As a heatwave lasting up to 7 days – slightly longer in some places – the event ranks among the 5 to 10 most intense in the longer measurement history in some regions. The second heatwave was comparable and, particularly in France, more intense than the first event, contrary to the national record set in June. The cause of the heatwaves was an excessively oscillating jet stream in the Northern Hemisphere, which then transitioned into chaotic phases. This shift of the polar front led to strong heat exchanges from the tropics to the polar regions.

The northwest and northeast of North America also recorded their hottest July, and extreme heatwaves occurred simultaneously in the USA, the Near and Middle East, and East Asia. In the Arctic belt, numerous wildfires broke out due to the abnormal dryness. The extent of polar ice melt was in the range of record years 2012, 2002, 2007, and 2016 (see Consequences of Global Warming in the Arctic and Consequences of Global Warming in the Antarctic). Globally, June was also the warmest ever recorded, 0.1° above the last record month, June 2016. July 2019 matched the previous record of July 2016 (analysis beginning in the 1980s).

As in 2016, 2019 experienced an El Niño event (but not for the long European heat anomalies of summer 2017 and 2018, which each followed a La Niña event). As with every heatwave in recent years, this one is also attributed to global warming according to current research, an assumption not directly provable for individual events but a correlation (statistical probabilities). According to a 2020 study by the Institute of Physics, the results of climatological attribution research show that the short and simultaneously intense events occurring during the heatwave would have been very unlikely without human-induced climate changes. Not only the temperatures but also the precipitation levels were unusual this summer, either extremely high or low: Summer 2019 was overall rated as "extremely dry." Over the entire calendar year, 2019 was the warmest year in Europe since records began.

In the southwest of Europe, the heat was associated with severe drought, while the situation in Central Europe, after an initially too dry early spring following the summer drought of the previous year, partially eased after a regionally rainy May. In a band from Spain through northern Italy to the Baltic region and another band from northeastern France to Sweden, there was hardly any rain in June, and in July, these areas also experienced abnormally low precipitation. There were numerous large wildfires, for example, in June in Spain (around Almorox in the Madrid metropolitan area, near Toledo, in Catalonia), in southern France (Gard department); in July in Germany (near Lübtheen in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania); in Portugal (Vila de Rei); again in southern France (Argelès-sur-Mer and Trèbes), Italy (on Sardinia), in Croatia (Pag Island); in August in Greece (e.g., on Elafonissos, near Marathon) and Cyprus. On Gran Canaria, off the west coast of Africa, there were also wildfires due to the heatwave; on August 19, 3,400 hectares and on August 20, 6,000 hectares were affected. In some areas outside the Mediterranean region – where drought, especially in Spain, has already become a long-term problem – there was also water scarcity, including in northern and central Germany. The situation was particularly precarious for agriculture in parts of Poland and the Baltic region, where prolonged drought threatened significant crop failures. At the beginning of July, Lithuania declared a national emergency. Severe weather also caused significant damage. Another consequence of the heatwaves is extensive forest damage, the causes of which lie in the droughts of previous years, such as mass infestations of bark beetles and other forest damage patterns. In Germany, the discussion about forest dieback became relevant again.
In the two heatwave summers of 2018 and 2019 alone, an additional 15,600 people died in Germany due to the effects of heat stress.

Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The European heatwave of August 2020 is an exceptional climatic event that occurred in August 2020. These episodes of intense heat are the most widespread since records began. Numerous temperature records were recorded. It occurred one year after the heatwaves of June and July 2019.

If this heatwave was of moderate intensity for the south of France, it was unprecedented in the north of the country where a red alert was issued by Météo France. At the peak of the episode, more than three-quarters of France were under a heatwave alert. Fifty-four French departments were placed at the orange level, from Midi-Pyrénées to the northeast. More impressively, the 15 departments of Haute-Normandie, Hauts-de-France, and Île-de-France were placed on RED alert from Friday, August 7, to Tuesday, August 11. This heatwave was an exceptionally significant climatic event that occurred in August 2020. These episodes of intense heat are the most widespread since records began. Numerous temperature records were broken. An initial heat peak occurred on July 30 and 31, with the heat arriving from the southwest and then moving toward the western and eastern regions. On July 30, temperatures of 41.9°C were recorded in Socoa (a new absolute heat record), 40.6°C in Cazaux (monthly record), and 38.3°C in Royan (monthly record). The next day, temperatures reached 41.3°C in Vichy, 39.4°C in Nevers, and 37.9°C in Boulogne-sur-Mer. The heat then shifted toward the southeast, and temperatures eventually returned to more bearable levels. However, this respite was only temporary as a new, longer heatwave arrived on August 6. Numerous monthly and even absolute heat records were set on August 7 in western France, with 41.9°C in Bellis in the Landes (absolute record), 39.8°C in Cognac, 39.6°C in Nantes, and 33.4°C in Cherbourg (monthly records). Temperatures then dropped in the west, but the heat intensified in the north and east of the country. August 8 and 9 were the hottest days in northern and eastern France. On August 8, the mercury reached 37.1°C in Lille (monthly record). Also noteworthy on the same day were minimum temperatures of 25.2°C in Boulogne-sur-Mer and 22.2°C in Alençon (absolute records). The next day, temperatures reached 39.3°C in Creil and 38.4°C in Rouen (monthly records). The temperature did not drop below 23°C in Lille (monthly record) or 21.4°C in Beauvais (absolute record). On August 10, the heatwave lost some intensity but remained quite strong. It was not until August 13 that the heatwave subsided, with the arrival of numerous storms. On a national scale, this episode was shorter and less intense than that of 2003, but in some departments, it was of an intensity close to or even locally exceeding that of 2003 (for example, in Lille, where the average temperature over seven days exceeded by 1°C the highest average temperature recorded over seven days in 2003). The first half of this August was the second hottest ever recorded (though far behind 2003), and this August was the third hottest ever recorded, with a 2°C surplus compared to the 1981–2010 average, behind 2003 (+4.2°C) and 1997 (+2.1°C). It would later be surpassed by August 2022. The heatwave is estimated to have caused 1,900 deaths.

It lasted 12 days (from August 5 to 16, 2020), which remains a fairly high value for a heatwave, but it is especially its intensity that is remarkable. With 8 days above 30°C, it is the 4th highest value observed, behind the heatwaves of 1976 (17 days), 1911 (14 days), and 2018 (9 days). These 8 days were consecutive (from August 6 to 13 inclusive), however, only one longer series has been observed: in 1976, temperatures exceeded 30°C from June 24 to July 8, i.e., for 15 consecutive days. But this high intensity led to the RED heatwave alert being triggered in Belgium for the first time in history. The record in Uccle was 35.9°C. However, this record had been surpassed on July 31, with 36.5°C, making it the third hottest day ever recorded in Uccle. The main victims of the heatwave's effects: 742 people aged over 85 and 600 others in the 65 to 84 age group.

Temperatures in the United Kingdom reached 34°C or higher for six consecutive days. Five tropical nights (temperature not dropping below 20°C) were recorded in the United Kingdom in August, including four consecutive ones. Additionally, at least 20 stations across the United Kingdom recorded temperatures of 32°C or higher for six consecutive days for the first time since the great heatwave of 1976.

The Netherlands experienced a national heatwave from August 5 to 16, lasting a total of 13 days. For 9 days, temperatures exceeded 30 degrees. For the very first time, the Netherlands experienced eight consecutive days with temperatures above 30. This heatwave caused approximately 400 deaths.

The heatwave in Siberia in 2020 was a several-month-long period of unusually hot days in Siberia during the summer half of 2020. At the cold pole of the (inhabited) Earth (Verkhoyansk), temperatures of up to 38 degrees Celsius were measured. This value was reached on June 20, 2020, and recognized by the WMO in 2021. The record temperature was caused by warm air masses from the southern continental temperate climate zone in the region and a large high-pressure area. Even the winter of 2019/20 and the spring of 2020 were exceptionally mild/warm.

According to Anders Levermann from the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, temperatures in Siberia from January to May 2020 were about 7 degrees Celsius higher than usual. This is a completely new and so far unexplained phenomenon; the jet stream cannot explain it (quote: it "lasts only one to two weeks, not five months"). The heatwave is associated with global warming in the Arctic (see also the consequences of global warming in the Arctic). A group of European scientists from the World Weather Attribution published the results of an investigation of various climate models on the current climate events in Siberia on July 15, 2020. They attribute the heatwave to human influences. The warming of Siberia is such an extreme climate event that even considering climate change, it would only occur every 130 years; without climate change, such an extreme weather event would occur only about every 80,000 years. Humans increase the likelihood of such heatwaves by 600 times through greenhouse gas emissions. As a result of the extreme heat, thawing of the permafrost is being observed. The diesel oil disaster near Norilsk is to be considered a consequence of the heatwave. In 2020, as in 2019 and 2021, there were exceptionally many and large wildfires in Siberia.

Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The European heatwave of July-August 2021 is a period of unusual summer heat of remarkable intensity that particularly affects Southern Europe.
A heat dome, a powerful anticyclone stalled over the same region accompanied by scorching air, settles in the heart of the Mediterranean and causes extreme heat in the countries of Southern Europe.

Between late June and early July, a first heatwave caused temperatures of 44 degrees for 11 days. According to data from the National Observatory of Athens, it was the 5th longest heatwave in Greece in 40 years. In early August, temperatures exceeding 45 degrees were recorded, with a peak temperature of 47.1°C reached in Langadás on August 3.

A heatwave driven by the anticyclone "Lucifer" is causing a significant increase in temperatures. On August 10, extreme temperatures of 47°C in Lentini and 46.7°C in Paterno were recorded by SIAS, the Sicilian agrometeorological service. On August 11, significant values were recorded in Italy. The town of Santa Maria Capua Vetere in Campania reached 42.2°C, followed by 44.5°C in Bova in Calabria, and finally 43.6°C in Ballao in Sardinia. It is in eastern Sicily where the highest values were recorded, with 47.4°C in Paterno and then a peak of 48.8°C recorded by SIAS in Floridia in the province of Syracuse, which would be the highest value recorded in Italy and Europe.

Starting from August 12, the heat dome affects Spain. On August 13, 45.5°C is recorded in Granada in Andalusia, 44.8°C in Aguilar de la Frontera, and 41.7°C at Madrid airport. But it is August 14 that proves to be the hottest day, with heat peaks reached: 46.9°C in Cordoba, matching the record of July 13, 2017, 42.7°C at Madrid Barajas airport (new record), 47.4°C in Montoro, and up to 47.6°C at 4:48 PM at the La Rambla weather station (Cordoba) in Andalusia recorded by AEMET, which would represent the new national record in Spain. On August 15, the heat peak shifts to the Mediterranean. New temperature records occur in the Segura Valley, in the Region of Murcia: 47°C in Murcia-Alcantarilla and 46.2°C in Murcia-Guadalupe. On August 16, it reaches 44.3°C in Tenerife.

The heatwave is also affecting the Balkans, with temperatures reaching 40°C. Albania has had to deal with no fewer than 75 forest fires, which have mobilized 300 firefighters. The authorities have requested help from the European Union, reports the Reuters agency. Numerous fires have also mobilized emergency services in Serbia, Bosnia, Macedonia, and Croatia.

In France, it is in the southeast that the heatwave settles; in mid-August, 40.7°C is recorded in Porto-Vecchio in Corsica, 40.9°C in Varages in the Var, and a temperature peak is reached on August 13 in Trets with 41.2°C in the Bouches-du-Rhône.

Fires are occurring in Greece, burning thousands of hectares on the island of Euboea, causing the evacuation of 3,000 people by sea. Since July 29, there have been 586 fire outbreaks and more than 93,700 hectares devastated by flames. In Sicily and Calabria, large-scale fires are spreading. On the night of August 11 to 12, more than 500 fires were recorded, resulting in the death of 4 people. Spain is also facing flames between Navalacruz and Riofrio. A massive fire with a perimeter of 90 km has devastated 12,000 hectares of vegetation and led to the evacuation of 1,000 residents. In France, in the Var region, 6,300 hectares have burned, leading to the evacuation of 7,000 people. Additionally, the fires have caused the death of 2 people. In Finland, the region bordering the Kalajoki River has experienced the worst forest fires since 1971. In August 2021, Finland reported about 12.5 times more burned forests since the beginning of the year compared to the average established over the period 2008-2020 (488 ha, instead of 39 ha per year). The fires also pose a threat to biodiversity.

According to the latest IPCC state report, July 2021 was the hottest month ever recorded. This confirms the IPCC's predictions of a +1.5°C increase in global temperature around 2030, which will result in the saturation of CO2 absorption by forests, soils, and oceans. The rise in sea levels and the accelerated warming of the Arctic are consequences of this climate escalation.

In 1987, Greece experienced a prolonged heatwave from July 20 to July 31, with at least 1,300 deaths in the Athens area, making it the deadliest heatwave to ever hit the country. It is notable that the number of deaths was more than double that of the second deadliest heatwave, an extremely strong one that struck central Greece in August 1958 and killed 600 people, mainly in Thessaly. The maximum temperature recorded at the National Observatory of Athens, in the center of Athens, was 41.9°C on July 23, and in Nea Filadelfeia, it was 43.6°C on July 27, which was the highest recorded in the Athens area. These temperatures were combined with high minimums, the highest being 30.2°C in central Athens on July 27 and 29.9°C on July 24 in Nea Filadelfeia. The lowest minimum was 25.6°C in central Athens. Additionally, humidity was high (60% in Athens on July 23), and wind speeds were low, contributing to discomfort even during the night. The first deaths—nine in total—were recorded in Athens on July 22, and the number began to rise rapidly each day. On July 23, 12 people died, on July 24 another 95, and on July 25 another 250, causing burial issues. By July 26, the total number of victims had reached 900, with 180 more added on July 27 and another 200 on July 28. It is estimated that 400 elderly people died helplessly. Although the heatwave also affected other cities, such as Thessaloniki and Larissa, it is considered that the discomfort was more intense in Athens due to the presence of photochemical smog, which had worsened due to temperature inversions caused by a high-pressure system that simultaneously moved in from the Sahara.
