Article_Name: Ola de calor en Europa de junio de 2022, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The heatwave in Europe in June 2022 was an unusually early episode of extreme heat that affected Portugal, Spain, France, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. In Spain and France, countries affected by drought, high temperatures favored the outbreak of wildfires.

The heatwave was due to an interaction between high pressures that generate atmospheric stability and Cyclone Álex, the strong insolation of the boreal summer, and a mass of air coming from North Africa, which entered the Iberian Peninsula loaded with suspended dust and caused haze in the central and southern parts of the peninsula.

The special warning for high temperatures was activated by Aemet on June 10, but only for 12 provinces, with yellow alerts in Aragón, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, Extremadura, and Madrid, and orange alerts in Andalusia. In this initial stage, the unusual heat did not affect the Canary Islands, Galicia, the western Cantabrian coast, and parts of the Mediterranean coast of the peninsula. Initially, Aemet forecasted that the heatwave would last until Wednesday, June 15, without ruling out the possibility of it continuing for the rest of the week. On June 11, high temperatures were already recorded in the southwest of the peninsula, with 41°C in Seville. Alerts remained active for Aragón, Castilla y León, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, and Madrid at the yellow level, and orange for Extremadura and Andalusia. However, the meteorological conditions did not meet the official criteria to declare the start of the heatwave. On June 12, thermometers recorded 43.2°C in Almadén (Ciudad Real), the highest value on the official start day of the heatwave. Temperatures above 40°C were also recorded at 47 Aemet network stations. Additionally, the agency issued special notice number 3/2022 with information about the phenomenon, its forecast, and announced the start of the national plan for preventive actions against the effects of excessive temperatures on health, including a level assignment map. In the province of Almería, a 62-year-old man died after collapsing and showing symptoms of dehydration while hiking on the Antenas trail near the Totem of Aguadulce. On June 13, Aemet announced in its official report a possible end date for the heatwave on Thursday, June 16, while noting that "due to the behavior of a DANA (isolated depression at high levels) located in Madeira, whose evolution cannot be precisely determined." On June 14, the heatwave extended to southern Galicia and the interior of the Cantabrian region. Tropical nights also continued, with thermometers not dropping below 20°C in many provinces, particularly in Jaén, where a minimum of 27°C was expected. Furthermore, it was forecasted that the peak of the heatwave would be reached on Friday, June 17, breaking some temperature records in cities like Zaragoza, Lleida, and Córdoba. The only areas in Spain that had so far escaped the heatwave were Asturias, the Canary Islands, and the autonomous cities of Ceuta and Melilla. In its daily report, Aemet forecasted the end of the meteorological episode for Saturday, as the DANA in the Atlantic, which injects hot African air, approached the peninsula, causing instability and a drop in temperatures. In Vega de Valcarce, a 69-year-old German pilgrim possibly died from heatstroke while walking the Villafranca del Bierzo stage of the Camino de Santiago. Rubén del Campo, Aemet spokesperson, stated that it was the "most intense heatwave for mid-June in at least the last 20 years." On June 15, the "Iberian exception" was applied for the first time, whereby the regulated price of electricity is calculated with a cap on gas for its generation. The PVPC (Voluntary Price for Small Consumers) means higher electricity bills due to compensation for thermal power plants and increased use of gas and coal during the heatwave. Once this unusual heatwave subsides, it will be seen if PVPC-referenced bills decrease when all air conditioners are no longer running simultaneously. On June 18, the extraordinary heatwave that affected Spain between June 11-12 and June 18 came to an end, being described as "intense, extensive, and extraordinary," according to the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), which also highlighted that this spring heat episode was one of the earliest in the country since records began. On June 20, Monday until 12 p.m., the Zaragoza City Council extended the orange alert of the Civil Protection Emergency Plan for the heatwave, which had been activated on Tuesday, June 14, due to the high temperatures affecting the city, exceeding 40°C on several days and not dropping below 25°C on some nights. On July 6, the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) published a report detailing the month of June, highlighting the intense heat episode that extended from the first day of the month until June 19, with both maximum and minimum temperatures well above normal, particularly high during the central days of the month, due to an invasion of warm air from North Africa. The heatwave in the Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands between June 11 and 18, 2022, was the earliest occurrence in the series, matching records with the one that occurred on June 11, 1981.

On June 16, Météo-France activated a red alert in 12 departments and an orange alert in another 25 due to a heatwave. The departments under red alert are mainly located in the southwest, along the Atlantic coast, and the south, while the severity is generally lower the further north and east. This is the earliest heatwave on record and the fourth time a red alert for heat has been issued since the protocol was established after the 2003 heatwave. On June 17, the red alert was activated in 14 departments, with the Hautes-Pyrénées and Pyrénées-Atlantiques added to the twelve from the previous day. Additionally, the orange alert was activated in 56 departments.

On June 14, in response to the Met Office's forecast of high temperatures, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issued level 2 health alerts in several regions for the period between midnight on Thursday the 16th and midnight on Saturday the 18th. The affected regions were London, the East Midlands, London and the East, Southeast, and Southwest of England. On June 15, the UKHSA issued level 3 alerts for London, the East, and the Southeast of England, while maintaining level 2 alerts for the East Midlands and the Southwest of England. According to the Met Office forecasts, the heat peak would arrive on Friday, reaching the threshold necessary for a heatwave classification, before temperatures dropped significantly on Saturday the 18th. On June 17, London exceeded 32°C on the hottest day of the year so far. According to Stephen Dixon, a Met Office spokesperson, temperatures above 30 degrees "are not unusual, but it is uncommon to see such high temperatures so early in the year." Dixon added that the temperatures on that same day would be the highest since the summer of 2020.

On Wednesday the 15th, a heat wave alert was activated in the Italian-speaking canton of Ticino. The following day, Thursday, June 16, the French-speaking cantons of Geneva and Vaud issued their own alerts. On the 16th, the Federal Office of Meteorology and Climatology (MeteoSwiss) reported that temperatures between 31 and 33 °C had been recorded in the southern Alps, central Valais, and the Lake Geneva region, but the threshold to be considered a heat wave (average temperature of 25 °C throughout the day) had only been exceeded locally. On Friday, June 17, MeteoSwiss activated orange and yellow heat wave alerts for most of the country. Maximum temperatures between 32 and 37 °C were expected from that same day until the following Tuesday in low-altitude areas of Valais and French-speaking Switzerland, and between Saturday and Tuesday in the Basel region.

In Spain, after the heatwave of 1981, it is the earliest heatwave on record. The episode began on Sunday, June 12, 2022, when temperatures above 40°C were recorded at 47 stations of the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet) network, located in Andalusia, Extremadura, and Castilla-La Mancha. This heatwave follows two other related climatic episodes in Spain in 2022: the widespread drought in the winter of 2021-2022 and the hottest May of the 21st century. The heat caused hundreds of swift chicks to prematurely leave their nests, falling to the ground as they did not know how to fly. The Seville-based NGO Ecourbe, dedicated to biodiversity conservation, reported that up to one hundred chicks were collected from the ground in a single day in Córdoba and Seville. Comisiones Obreras of Extremadura demanded that the reduction of the working day by one hour for construction workers be brought forward, as this reduction is applied from July 15 to mid-August. On June 15, the Madrid City Council activated the red alert protocol for meteorology, given the forecast of a combination of temperatures above 35°C and wind gusts of more than 55 km/h, and consequently closed nine parks in the Spanish capital. The high temperatures, along with the drought, created conditions of extreme risk for forest fires throughout peninsular Spain, except for Galicia, most of the border with Portugal, and isolated points along the coast. A fire in the Sierra de la Culebra (Zamora) forced the evacuation of eight municipalities, while another fire in the province of Toledo led to the evacuation of 3,200 people from the Puy du Fou España theme park. High temperatures in schools caused an increase in dizziness and fainting among children. Families, teachers, and experts called for a plan to adapt schools to future heatwaves, which they will face if no action is taken for the next school year. Air conditioning should be the last resort to lower temperatures in schools, as it accelerates climate change, which in the coming years will cause more frequent and extreme heatwaves. The Community of Madrid manages four public swimming pools in the capital. Until Thursday, June 16, the intention was to keep them closed until the end of June. Swimming in pools alleviates the unpleasant thermal sensation caused by extreme heat, so public complaints led the Sports Councilor, Marta Rivera de La Cruz, to change the opening plan for these public pools. She apologized to the people of Madrid: "It is true that the heatwave should have brought forward that opening." She announced that next year they will open at the beginning of the month, as was historically done until 2019. On Monday, June 20, hospitals in Zaragoza recorded an "unusual peak" in emergencies due to the heatwave. Some patients had to wait more than 60 hours to be admitted due to a lack of beds, with conditions caused in elderly and chronically ill people by the prolonged heatwave of the previous week. This new workload due to the heatwave adds to the burden that hospital emergency staff have been enduring for more than two years.

In the twelve French departments on red alert due to the heatwave, the Ministry of National Education and Youth established several preventive measures. Among them, it allowed primary and secondary school students not to attend classes on Friday, June 17, if their parents so wished. Likewise, several departments have implemented restrictions on outdoor physical activity. The Gers prefecture recommended canceling any outdoor physical or sports activity. The Gironde prefecture urged its residents not to exercise outdoors and banned any public events outdoors or in non-air-conditioned venues. In Tarn, the broadcast of the Top 14 rugby championship semifinal between Castres Olympique and Stade Toulousain on a giant screen was prohibited. Finally, several departments, even without being on red or orange alert, have recommended that drivers reduce their speed on the road.
Northern Italy experienced the worst drought in the last 70 years. The flow levels of the Po and Tiber rivers recorded very low levels for this time of year, with the Po reaching critical levels.

The Royal Ascot equestrian event took the unprecedented step of relaxing its dress code, allowing men to remove their hats and jackets after the royal procession. It also allowed spectators to enter the enclosure with drinks.

During the flood of 1784, dikes in various places in the Dutch river area broke due to ice drift caused by the severe winter of 1783-1784. Particularly in the vicinity of Nijmegen, the river was completely frozen for several weeks. Mid-February, the thaw set in. This resulted in a large amount of meltwater from the Alps and German low mountain ranges, causing the water level of the Waal to rise rapidly. On February 27, 1784, the ice near Nijmegen broke loose. Further downstream near Druten, however, the river was still blocked. Behind this ice dam, chunks of ice and meltwater began to accumulate. In an attempt to prevent a disaster, the local population quickly tried to raise the dikes. However, it was all in vain, and over time, the dikes broke through in no fewer than eleven places. Nijmegen also flooded, and the lower wall tower of the Valkhof (the Lappentoren) collapsed. On March 19, the dikes gave way near the village of Haalderen. The residents were completely taken by surprise, and 15 of them lost their lives. The village was almost entirely destroyed. The castles of Ooij, Lent, and Persingen were lost. 200 years later (in 1984), a memorial was erected in Haalderen in remembrance of the disaster. The pools or wheels created during the disaster are still visible today.

Whole_Text.content:
During the flood of 1776, during the night of November 20 to 21, 1776, a heavy southwesterly storm caused dikes to break in many places in the Netherlands. This was the second time in just over a year, following the flood of 1775. Both were severe storms with an estimated recurrence interval of 254 years. Northwest Overijssel was particularly hard hit. The village of Beulake was destroyed for the second time and subsequently abandoned. The writer Hering describes the following about the village in the book "Bespiegeling over Neerlandsch waternood, tusschen den XXIsten en XXIIsten november, MDCCLXXVI, Amsterdam":

"In Beulake, the situation was particularly dire. This village, due to its proximity to the sea dike and thus exposed to the first assault of the water, and mostly consisting of large peat bogs, was the first and most affected by the sea's fury: the houses and peat barns of the inhabitants were swiftly destroyed by the waves; their peat (the trade of which was the only means of livelihood for the residents) and even large pieces of peatland drifted away."

In Mastenbroek, four people drowned, including a mother and two children in the Koekoekspolder. In Elburg, the waves destroyed eleven homes, with seven people drowning. In many places, the water rose higher than in 1775. Shipworms caused a permanent crisis in the technology and financing of shoreline protection in the Netherlands. The islands in the Zuiderzee were heavily affected, particularly Schokland. In some places, the island disappeared underwater. A three-masted ship stranded near the 'Swartendijk' by Kampen even drifted over the island. On Urk, since 1773, the erosion of the High Cliff north of the lighthouse, the highest part of the boulder clay hill, had increased to the point that new measures had to be taken every year. However, the November storms of 1775 and especially 1776 severely damaged the boulder clay cliff despite the row of poles. A large portion was washed away, "along with two houses on the northwest side [... while] the lighthouse was also stripped of all its foreground."

The island of Wieringen was also heavily affected. Four people and between 2,000 and 3,000 sheep drowned. On Texel, several dikes broke. The village of Oudeschild was abandoned by three-quarters of its inhabitants, who fled to higher places on the island. Five fishermen drowned. Several ships anchored at the Texel Roads were lost. In the following days, many bodies washed ashore. In Harlingen, a 14-year-old girl drowned. Off the coast of Scheveningen, the galleot ship Neptunus was lost. Of the nine crew members, seven were rescued.

Whole_Text.content: During the flood of 1775, on November 14 and 15, 1775, a severe northeasterly storm caused dikes to break in many places in the Netherlands. Northwest Overijssel was particularly hard hit. The village of Beulake was almost completely destroyed. In Mastenbroek, seventeen people drowned, in Kamperveen nine, and in Oosterwolde twenty. The city of Kampen was flooded due to a dike breach nearby. The flooding happened so quickly that the city was already underwater before residents could move their belongings upstairs, transport livestock to higher ground, or bring themselves to safety. In Elburg, 28 people drowned. Dikes also broke in other places, such as on Texel and in the river area. In Amsterdam, Jacob Eduard de Witte saved the city from disaster by opening the Amstel sluice and the locks in the city walls. North of Amsterdam, however, dikes did break, and part of Waterland was flooded. The village of Oosthuizen was affected by flooding after the dike breach at Warder. Around the walls of Amsterdam, only water could be seen. A year later, the Zuiderzee region was hit again by a flood disaster, the flood of 1776. It is likely that the 1775 event involved a northeasterly storm and the 1776 event a southwesterly storm. Both were severe storms with an estimated recurrence interval of 254 years.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of 1808 was a deluge in which large areas of the Dutch province of Zeeland were inundated. The city of Antwerp was also severely affected, resulting in significant material damage. In Zeeland, 102 polders were flooded: 40 in Zeeuws-Vlaanderen, 20 in Zuid-Beveland, 19 in Tholen, 12 in Schouwen-Duiveland, 7 in Noord-Beveland, and 4 in Walcheren. Veere and the coastal city of Vlissingen were heavily impacted; there were 4 and 31 fatalities respectively. The Vlissingsche Courant reported on January 19: Today, within this city, the sorrowful ceremony took place, which perhaps may never happen again, being the solemn burial of the unfortunate victims who perished in the recent flood. A list of 31 victims follows, including many residents of Paardestraat. In Veere, a woman and two children lost their lives in Wijngaardstraat, and a woman drowned in Kapelstraat. In Zierikzee, a man drowned in his home, and in Goedereede, a watchman perished. In the city of Antwerp, a young girl drowned. Altogether, 43 people lost their lives in Zeeland during the flood. After the disaster, King Louis Napoleon visited Zeeland and took decisive measures such as raising dikes. This earned him much credit among the common people. In response to the flood, the Haarlem writer Adriaan Loosjes (1761-1818) wrote the tragedy Ewoud van Lodijke or the downfall of the Zeeland city of Romerswaal, which centers on the Saint Felix Flood of 1530. The proceeds from the work were donated to the victims of the 1808 disaster.

Whole_Text.content: The so-called November Flood of 1981 (also known as the North Friesland Flood of 1981) was a storm surge in the North Sea from November 24 to 25, 1981. Jutland and North Friesland were particularly severely affected. The storm surge produced the highest peak water levels recorded up to that time, with over 4 meters above the normal sea level[1], and caused significant erosion to the edge dunes.[2] At Cuxhaven, the water level rose to 4.75 m above NN.[3]

The Saint Vincent flood was a storm surge on January 22, 1393 or 1394[1] during which parts of the Flemish coastal strip were flooded. The Testerep peninsula, with the then still young city of Ostend, disappeared into the sea; Ostend was subsequently rebuilt further inland.[2] The submerged settlement of Walraversijde was also rebuilt after the storm surge at a safer location.[3] The flood is named after Vincentius of Zaragoza, whose feast day takes place on January 22.

The New Year's Flood of 1855 was a storm surge that led to a flood disaster on the German North Sea coast. On January 1, 1855, unprecedented water levels were reached on the lower course of the Elbe and its tributaries, such as the Ilmenau. On the East Frisian Islands, in the Altes Land, Wilhelmsburg, the Vier- and Marschlande, as well as in the Winsen Elbe Marsh, there were dike breaches, floods, and subsequent severe destruction caused by ice drift. The aftermath extended into March 1855.

On New Year's Day of 1855, the sea level rose due to changing winds, even though low tide was indicated by the tide calendar. After the wind calmed down, it picked up again in the evening with the rising tide. This developed into a storm surge that lasted until the following day. In the subsequent eight weeks, there was persistent frost, which froze the flooded water and parts of the North Sea. At the beginning of March 1855, thawing began on the Elbe, releasing the frozen masses of water. Additionally, on March 19, another storm set the ice masses in motion.

The storm surge first affected the islands in the North Sea. Subsequently, the masses of water moved up the tidal part of the Elbe, reaching Hamburg and beyond.  
Since the water froze into ice masses and could not flow away, the storm surge caused massive damage even months later.

During the flood, the island of Wangerooge was largely submerged. In the island village, only the West Tower, completed in 1602, remained standing. The residents of the northern island beach fled to the southern part of the island on January 1, 1855. Of the 75 residential houses in the village of Wangerooge, 21 were destroyed. Graves were exposed in the cemetery. Seawater pushed up through the groundwater into wells. The protective dune wall in the area of the West Tower was leveled. The North Sea beach was eroded by up to 1 meter. The island was divided into three parts. The main island was reduced to only 175 hectares (for comparison: today it is around 500 hectares). Under the eroded dunes of Old Wangerooge, remains of brick and lime walls, wooden gutters, and refuse heaps from an earlier settlement were uncovered at a depth of 3.5 meters. In the north, hewn sandstone was found, which may have served as house foundations in the medieval original settlement of Oppidum Wangerooch. After the storm, a government commission from Oldenburg assessed the damage. There was no insurance against storm surge damage. The old lighthouse was particularly at risk and was to be rebuilt in the southeast of the island. The bathing facility, which had served as a source of income since 1804, was destroyed and would later be dissolved. With emergency aid of 100 Reichstaler, a new cemetery was established in the eastern dunes. The community buried 27 recovered bodies there. A final decision on relief measures was announced for the end of March. A few days after the flood, winter set in. Wangerooge was surrounded by drift ice for over eight weeks, making traffic with the mainland impossible. Particularly affected were 80 families, including 29 widows, orphans, and elderly people. Relief shipments arrived in the spring. In June 1855, the government commission saw no hope for reconstruction. They urged the islanders to resettle on the mainland. The resettlers received financial support. 82 Wangerooge residents refused to leave the island. In 1865, they founded a new village near the lighthouse completed in 1856.

On Norderney, large parts of the dune zone in the west and northwest were lost, which had previously protected the island from the floods. At that time, only a narrow row of dunes separated the sea from the island village and the bathing facility. To protect the island from future storm surges, a fortification was built in the west starting in 1858. This structure was the first dune defense structure on the German North Sea coast.

Several dikes of the Elbe broke under the pressure of the floods, including in the Vierlande, in Hamburg-Bergedorf, in the Alten Land, and in Hamburg-Moorburg. In Hamburg-Wilhelmsburg, the dikes broke in nine places, causing the low-lying Elbe island to be flooded. Four people died. The Alster locks were flooded, resulting in the streets in the city center and the then suburb of Hamburg-St. Georg being inundated. After the February flood of 1825 had already struck Hamburg, the city now had the dikes renewed and raised to heights between 5.60 and 5.80 meters.

The water level of the Lower Elbe rose to the top edge of the dikes. In Tespe, Rönne, Drennhausen, Krümse, and other places, houses were damaged. The inland marsh was flooded. The dikes broke as far as Fahrenholz, resulting in fatalities. A few days after the flood, the masses of water froze at a very high water level. In the Winsen Marsh, it was possible to travel over the ice to Winsen, which was normally very difficult due to poor road conditions. In the houses on the Elbe dike up to Haue, people had to live in the attics. At the sexton's house in Marschacht or on mounds, the ice reached window height. When the thaw set in, no water could flow off via the Elbe due to solid ice formation. The meltwater, thus dammed up from the upper Elbe, caused the water in the marsh and its houses to rise further. A storm set the masses of ice in motion. In Fahrenholz, buildings were destroyed, and in Tönnhausen, all houses on the dike were damaged. Trees were uprooted by the ice, for example, up to 100 old oaks near Sangenstedt. Uprooted trees piled up around the villages and hindered relief efforts.

At Artlenburg, the Elbe had become free, but icebergs had settled in the river. Because water threatened to flow over the dike in several places, the dike was raised with manure and earth. The water rose to over 6 meters until the dike broke at dike cable 157. Water flowed into the Elbe field for hours. The dike in the Ilmenau marsh broke in several places. Of the places not located on the dike, only a few could be saved. In Echem, a significant rise in water was noticed. In Garlstorf, water stood in the gardens. The elevated Mariental was spared. In Hörstenfeld, the ice began to move. Animals and buildings were damaged, among others, in Laßrönne and Haue. In the Vorgeest villages of Handorf, Rottorf, and Sangenstedt, water flowed through the windows into the houses. The water destroyed the timber and clay framework. The water surface froze into an ice field and swept everything away in the brack. After the dike breaches, people in all houses on the Elbe dike had to live in the attics. When a passage opened between the ice from Oldershausen to Rottorf, the office in Lüneburg sent relief ships. On the country road, ships instead of wagons then traveled, landing near Wittorf. The ships brought food and transported livestock and furniture out on the return trip. In the geest villages of Rottorf, Handorf, and Wittorf, many people migrated with their livestock.

In Artlenburg[6], the dike was breached over a stretch of more than 200 meters. The restoration costs of the main dike amounted to 30 to 40 talers for a few feet. To restore the dikes, Artlenburg employed 100 workers daily. For the emergency dike alone, 500 cubic rods of earth (approximately 3,000 cubic meters) were needed; a large ship could transport about 2.5 cubic rods. Fertile soil was covered by sand, which in some places was over 1 meter high. Approximately 1,000 acres of land (about 2,500,000 square meters), which had been spared from previous dike breaches, were covered with sand. From the cemetery established in Artlenburg in 1851, 40 of the 200 coffins were carried away by the water but were recovered. The deceased were partially kept in the churchyard but were also transferred to Schnakenbek and Marienthal. Victims of the flood were buried in Schnakenbek. The churchyard was restored with drift sand. As long as the corpses could not be buried, their storage was problematic. In Marschacht, they were stored in the tower[8] for weeks. In Handorf, they were initially housed in the St. Mary’s Church and buried in Bardowick at the end of March. By mid-April, burials resumed in Handorf. People gradually returned to their villages, where they initially had to share the highest-lying houses. Due to a persistently high water level, the harvests that year were very poor. By late summer, at least fodder could be harvested. The price of grain rose sharply. Positive consequences of the flood included the founding of the Artlenburg Dike Association, the Ilmenau Lowland Water Association, and the Ilmenau Lowland Melioration Project.

Whole_Text.content: During the flood of 1799, dikes in the river area broke in several places after ice drift, as was the case during the flood of 1784. The villages of Doornik and Haarsteeg were particularly hard hit. After the thaw set in at the end of January, the first ice blockages began causing problems in the Nijmegen area between February 1 and 4, later also downstream. Around February 15, the first dikes broke. In Millingen, 15 houses were destroyed. On February 21, the dike near the village of Doornik broke in two places. During this breach of the Waal, 17 people drowned, and all eighteen houses, including the church, were lost. After this, the village of Doornik was never fully rebuilt. Downstream, problems arose in Rossum, where a mill was destroyed, and in Haarsteeg, where several dozen houses, including the town hall, were completely destroyed by water and ice floes; 12 lives were lost. This event seemed to have come entirely unexpectedly: a massive ice floe reportedly simply pushed over the dike. The church was also destroyed in this event. After this disaster, it was decided to abandon the dangerous protruding corner of the dike, which had been breached twice in four years, and replace it with an inward straight-line dike. 838 · 1014 · 1042 · 1134 · 1163 · 1164 · 1170 · 1196 · 1212 · 1214 · 1219 · 1220 · 1221 · 1248/1249 · 1277 · 1280 · 1282 · 1287 · 1288 (I) · 1288 (II) · 1322 · 1334 · 1362 · 1374 · 1375 · 1377 · 1404 · 1421 · 1424 · 1468 · 1477 · 1509 · 1514 · 1530 · 1532 · 1552 · 1566 · 1570 · 1610 · 1643 · 1651 · 1675 · 1682 · 1686 · 1703 · 1717 · 1726 · 1741 · 1775 · 1776 · 1784 · 1799 · 1808 · 1809 · 1820 · 1825 · 1855 · 1861 (I) · 1861 (II) · 1877 · 1906 · 1916 · 1926 · 1953 · 1962 · 1993 · 1995 · 2006 · 2021

Whole_Text.header: All Saints' Day tidal wave in 1675
Whole_Text.content: The All Saints' Day tidal wave of 1675 mainly affected the Northern Netherlands, causing floods:
André Nuyens wrote a children's book, The Water Wolf, which talks about this flood, mentioning the dike breaches of the Zuiderzee in Hoorn.

The All Saints' Flood of 1510 was a severe storm surge that struck the entire North Sea coast from Flanders to Eiderstedt on November 1, 1510. It followed the so-called St. Magnus Flood, which had already caused severe devastation on September 5/6, 1510, and had previously breached the dikes, which had been damaged and only provisionally repaired after the Second Cosmas and Damian Flood of September 26, 1509. Many dikes were breached again, and vast coastal areas were flooded. The water rose up to 3.80 meters above mean high tide. Only ten weeks later, on January 16, 1511, the Antoni Flood or "Ice Flood," a storm surge accompanied by heavy ice drift, struck East Frisia and Butjadingen, completing the destruction caused by the floods of 1509 and 1510. The Dollart and the Jade Bay reached their greatest extent, there were significant land losses between the Jade and Weser, and a breakthrough occurred between the Jade and Weser.

The Julianenflut (Juliana storm tide) occurred between February 16 and 17, 1164 (on Saint Juliana's Day) and is one of the earliest known storm tides along the North Sea coast. Around 20,000 people and thousands of livestock died during this natural disaster. The hardest-hit areas were East Frisia and Frisia in present-day Germany, as well as the areas around the Zuiderzee in present-day Netherlands. Between the towns of Dauens and Hummens, between present-day Wilhelmshaven and the mouth of the Jade River, a breach in the dikes occurred that could not be repaired. This marked the beginning of the current Jade Bay.

The All Saints' Flood of 2006 was a storm surge on the German North Sea coast on November 1, 2006 (All Saints' Day), which particularly caused damage in East Frisia. The flood is considered one of the most severe on the coast since 1906. No lives were lost. Near Norden, cattle were evacuated just in time from the foreland outside the dike. The cause of the flood was the hurricane low "Britta" from the northwest, which, together with the tidal level, generated a spring tide. The hurricane stormed over the North Sea with up to twelve Beaufort, with the highest wind speed recorded on the island of Spiekeroog (156 km/h). Off Borkum, the highest water level since the storm surge of 1962 was recorded, and in Emden and at the (timely closed) Ems Barrier in Gandersum, even the highest values ever measured: In Emden, the water rose to 3.59 m above the mean high tide (MThw), in Gandersum to 3.90 m above MThw. In Bensersiel, 2.91 meters above MThw were reached, the third-highest water level after the storm surges of 1906 and 1962. Damage was caused in Emden in the sections of the harbor located outside the dike. The building of the ferry company AG Ems was flooded. Near Neuharlingersiel, a landing craft about 30 meters long was lifted out of the harbor basin by the force of the water and ended up nearly 100 meters inland on a parking lot after the flood. In the marina of Norddeich, several boats were destroyed. On the East Frisian Islands, the storm surge caused significant dune erosion. In the Port of Hamburg, the hurricane tore a ship from the quay, which was secured again with tugboats. A coastal motor ship about 100 meters long got into distress off Borkum after the rudder system failed. The Norwegian drilling platform "Bredford Dolphin" was torn loose from its tug at sea. In both cases, no people were harmed.

The Antoniflood, also known as the Ice Flood, was a severe storm surge that destroyed the coast of East Frisia and Oldenburg on January 16, 1511, and was named after St. Anthony's Day (Anthony the Great) on January 17. The flood was associated with heavy ice drift and added to the destruction caused by the storm surges of 1509 and 1510. The flood and the accompanying ice floes caused massive damage to the dikes, particularly in Rüstringen and Butjadingen. Since the dikes could no longer be repaired in many places, it became necessary to abandon several villages and parishes. For example, in the Jade Bight near Sande, this affected the parishes of Oldebrügge, Bordum, Bant, Ahm, Ellens, Seediek, as well as the Johanniter Commandery Havermonniken. Another series of parishes had already been abandoned in the 15th century. The land losses in the Dollart, the Jade Bight, and between the Jade and Weser were significant. Arngast became an island in the Jade Bight. The Dollart and the Jade Bight reached their greatest extent, and a breakthrough occurred between the Jade and Weser. The sinking of the village "Bandt" in the Antoniflood, now a district ("Bant") of Wilhelmshaven, is commemorated by the "Banter Ruine" monument in Wilhelmshaven, erected in 1889, which is modeled after the ruins of the Banter Church.

The Allerkindleinsflut was a devastating storm surge that struck primarily the west coast of Schleswig-Holstein and the Elbe region on December 28, 1248. December 28, 1248, is the Day of the Innocent Children; it gave the storm surge its name. According to other sources, it occurred in 1249.

The storm surge separated the West Frisian Islands from the mainland on the North Sea coast, destroyed parts of the first dike system in the Elbe, devastated large parts of the Haseldorfer Marsh area, and separated the present-day islands of Altenwerder and Finkenwerder from the diked former Elbe island of Gorieswerder. The number of victims in the Elbe region and North Friesland is not precisely known. A parish on the west side of Rømø near Husum was devastated by the storm surge.

The Cäcilien flood was a devastating storm surge in the Lower Elbe region on November 21, 1412. The name of the storm surge is derived from the feast day of Saint Cecilia.

On November 21, 1412, a storm pushed the water of the North Sea into the Elbe estuary, preventing the Elbe water from draining. The accumulating masses of water flooded the land and reached the area around the city of Hamburg in the evening. Prior to this, the water had already destroyed a village at the mouth of the Este River. During the flood, there was less damage along the coast, but the destruction along the Lower Elbe was massive. Later chroniclers reported that 30,600 people were said to have lost their lives in this flood, which is likely a typographical error for 36,000. It is said to have been the most severe flood since the Grote Mandrenke in 1362. The pastor at the Hamburg Pesthof, Peter Hessel (1639–1677), wrote in the 17th century:

The flood changed the structure of the landscape and its settlement. The village of Altenwerder was completely evacuated after being almost completely destroyed. It was rebuilt in a nearby but better-protected location. Finkenwerder was also heavily affected, as were the areas around Billwerder, Ochsenwerder, and Moorwerder. All the villages were rebuilt only after several years. In the Alten Land, the village of Zesterfleth drowned, and the Elbe island of Hahnöfersand was separated from the mainland.

The two Dionysius floods were two severe storm surges in the North Sea that caused significant destruction between Flanders and the Weser on October 9, 1374, and from October 8 to 10, 1375. The storm surges are named after Saint Dionysius of Paris, whose feast day is October 9. In Flanders, about seventeen villages and a monastery were destroyed in 1374 and 1375. In East Frisia, according to excerpts from 16th-century chronicles, there were devastating dike breaches in 1374 and the following years. After the flood, the Leybucht reached its largest extent at about 13,000 hectares, and the village of Westeel had to be abandoned. Subsequently, the flood is said to have reached the town of Norden, where the waves reached the walls of the Dominican monastery. The town then gained access to the North Sea and acquired a harbor. Through the now silted-up bays of Sielmönken and Campen, the water also penetrated deep inland. In the late 14th century, the parishes of Drewert and Walsum, as well as the village of Ham, were destroyed in the Rysumer Nacken area. The historian Ubbo Emmius reported on the effects in the 1590s: "On October 9, 1373 (!), there was a great flood, such as had not been seen in living memory, which extended over the entire Frisian coast and brought great misfortune to the inhabitants. For it covered the notable village of Westeel, located in a fertile area almost 2,000 paces south of Norden and facing east towards the rising sun, with such a quantity of water that all buildings, including the church, were torn down and destroyed, and even part of the ground was swallowed up, with people and animals disappearing."

The first Cosmas and Damian flood on September 27, 1477, was a storm surge that affected the entire North Sea coast of the German Bight and the Dutch-Belgian coast. It is named after the church saints Cosmas and Damian, whose feast day is September 26. In East Frisia, the storm surge destroyed several dikes. It is known from the Rheiderland that several villages had to be abandoned. The destruction caused by the first Cosmas and Damian flood contributed to the formation of the Dollart. The storm surge of 1477 is considered one of the most severe to have struck the Netherlands. The coast of Flanders was particularly affected. In Zeeland, the town of Arnemuiden was devastated, and Hellenburg Castle near Baarland was severely damaged.

The storm surge chain of autumn 1973 refers to a series of storm surges in the autumn of 1973 along the German North Sea coast. Between November 13 and December 14, there was an unprecedented accumulation of severe and very severe storm surges. In Hamburg alone, a total of 28 storm surges were recorded during this period, including two severe and four very severe ones. In particular, the storm surges of November 16 and 19 as well as December 6 caused severe damage in the Weser and Elbe areas. During the storm surge of November 13, 1973, one person lost their life at the Ochtum.

Exactly one year after the hurricane Quimburga, another hurricane event occurred in northern Germany, claiming the lives of at least 25 people. Due to the significantly more northerly shifted path, a very severe storm surge occurred along the entire German North Sea coast, with around 100 sheep falling victim on the North Frisian island of Nordstrand. There was one fatality at the Ochtum. On the Knechtsand in the Outer Weser, the Danish coastal motor ship Balka (299 GRT) ran aground after becoming unmanageable with a heavy list. The crew was rescued by the Helgoland sea rescue cruiser Adolph Bermpohl.

Only six days after the first severe storm surge, a second storm surge occurred along the entire German North Sea coast. During this storm surge, the highest water levels of the storm tide chain were recorded, especially in the East Frisian coastal area and at the Jade. In the lower reaches of the Hunte, Lesum, and Ochtum, which were not yet secured by barriers at the time, severe damage occurred, including to summer dikes, roads, and areas in front of the main dikes. On the islands in the Lower Weser as well as on Krautsand, buildings located on insufficiently high mounds were flooded for the second time within a week. On the East Frisian Islands and on Sylt, dune erosion occurred. The situation at the sea dike in front of Christianskoog in the Meldorfer Bay also became critical.

On December 6, the penultimate storm surge of the late autumn 1973 series occurred, during which the highest water levels of the storm tide chain were reached in the Weser area below Brake as well as in the Lower Elbe. In Hamburg, this storm surge almost reached the peak water level of the 1962 storm surge, even though there was no storm in the city itself, but rather very strong winds. Although there were no dike breaches, there was very severe damage in the flooded harbor area, where numerous businesses were caught off guard by the unexpectedly high surge. The sea dike in front of Christianskoog, which had not been raised after the 1962 storm surge, was again severely damaged and could only be held with massive deployment of emergency forces. At sea, the anchor chain of the lightship Elbe II, which was still stationed in the Elbe estuary at the time, broke due to the storm. The lightship ran aground in the Klotzenloch off Cuxhaven and was later salvaged by tugboats. The crew was rescued by the rescue boat Rickmer Bock, which was on reserve in Cuxhaven. Five nautical miles north of the lightship Elbe I, the Hamburg motor vessel Grete Hauschildt (424 GRT) sank after the hatch covers were smashed in the heavy seas. Despite a dramatic rescue operation involving several helicopters, the ferry ship Prinz Hamlet, and the supertanker Fernhaven, only three of the seven crew members could be saved.

The Second Dionysius Flood was a storm surge in the North Sea, which, according to old chronicles, is said to have caused severe destruction between Flanders and the Weser on October 9, 1377.

Their mention was based on various reports from Flanders and East Frisia, which originally referred to the years 1374 and 1375. Later chronicles shifted the floods to 1376 or 1377, although in Flanders it was claimed that the flood had occurred on November 16 (the Monday after Martinmas). In East Frisian chronicles, a second Dionysius flood of 1377 then appeared, which was believed to have worsened the damage from 1377. The adherence to the year 1377 is presumably a reference to late medieval flood myths, which emphasized that Lamech and his 77 descendants had drowned in the flood as a punishment from God.[1] The coastal researchers Petrus Georg Bartels and Dodo Wildvang strongly adhered to this date, but Carl Woebcken expressed his doubts early on. The Dutch researcher Elisabeth Gottschalk determined from the sources that there is "not a single piece of evidence" for a Dionysius flood in 1377, although some damage to the Flemish dikes in November of that year cannot be ruled out.[2] Additional climate studies have confirmed her findings. In Flanders, around seventeen villages and a monastery were destroyed in 1374 and 1375. The Zuudzee or Braakman bay was formed, which later—like its counterpart at the Ems estuary—was also likely called Dollaert. This number was doubled by the East Frisian chroniclers. In East Frisia, according to excerpts from 16th-century chronicles, there were devastating dike breaches in the Leybucht area in 1374 and the following years, during which the village of Westeel was destroyed. Subsequently, the flood is said to have reached the town of Norden, where the waves reached the walls of the Dominican monastery. The town then had access to the North Sea and gained a harbor. Through the now silted-up bays of Sielmönken and Campen, the water also penetrated deep inland. In the late 14th century, the parishes of Drewert and Walsum as well as the village of Ham were destroyed at the Rysumer Nacken.[3]

The Second Cosmas and Damian Flood on September 25/26, 1509, was a storm surge that affected the entire North Sea coast of the German Bight. It is named after Cosmas and Damian, whose feast day is September 26. In East Frisia and the neighboring Netherlands, the flood caused devastating damage in the Rheiderland and the adjacent Oldambt. The villages of Torum, Wilgum, Fletum, Westerreide, and Osterreide, as well as the Palmar Monastery, had to be abandoned as a result of the natural disaster. The later chancellor of the Lordship of Jever, Remmer von Seediek, reported in his chronicle of the Jeverland: "In the year 1509, on the day of Cosmas and Damian, a great flood occurred in all the Netherlands. It destroyed many dikes in Östringen and Wangerland and especially in Rüstringen. Large whirlpools broke in there, and the dikes broke miserably, so that Junker Edo had enough to do with land and people for two years before the dikes were restored." The Dollart reached its greatest extent, and the Jade Bight also expanded significantly. Near Emden, the Ems broke through a river bend and created a new riverbed, which meant that Emden was no longer a direct seaport, the harbor silted up, and economic decline set in.
